The CO adsorption energy is linearly related to the magnetic moment of the TM on TM-TCSACs Figure S16a. Therefore, the CO adsorption mechanism was further elucidated by analyzing the DOS of the systems. Spin splitting is not observed in the DOS of the ZnO substrate, and the C-px and py orbitals are slightly coupled with Zn-dx 2y 2 and dz 2 in the unoccupied state. It indicates that CO is weakly adsorbed on the ZnO surface. The DOS of Mn-TCSAC shows similarity to the slight coupling of the p-d orbitals Figure S17. In contrast, in Fe-TCSAC, the Fe-d orbitals DOS shifts from the unoccupied to the occupied state, which causes the adsorbed C of CO to undergo spin splitting. Near the Fermi energy level 0.45 eV, the C-px and py orbitals of the spin-down bonding state exhibit enhanced coupling with Fe-dx 2y 2 and dz 2. Moreover, the spin-up C-pz orbitals are strongly coupled with the Fe-d orbitals, enhancing CFe interactions. It benefits CO activation and conversion, promoting the transition from COOH to CO Figure 3h. However, in Co-TCSACs, the strong coupling of the C-pz orbital with the Co-d orbitals provides a strong CO adsorption energy, which is unfavorable for CO desorption Figure S17. The iCOHP of CO is consistent with the findings of the DOS analysis Figure S18. The above results suggest that the couplings of adsorbed molecules-px, py with TM-e orbitals, and adsorbed molecules- pz with TM-t2 orbitals are the

metadata.source: /Users/zemao/ChemQA/data/raw_papers/Liu 等 - 2025 - Spin-state effect of tetrahedron-coordinated single-atom catalysts on CO2 electroreduction.pdf
metadata.title: Liu 等 - 2025 - Spin-state effect of tetrahedron-coordinated single-atom catalysts on CO2 electroreduction.pdf

text: strong CO adsorption energy, which is unfavorable for CO desorption Figure S17. The iCOHP of CO is consistent with the findings of the DOS analysis Figure S18. The above results suggest that the couplings of adsorbed molecules-px, py with TM-e orbitals, and adsorbed molecules- pz with TM-t2 orbitals are the main reasons for improving the catalytic performance of TCSAC. The performance of TCSACs for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction was evaluated by a flow cell Figure S39. Figure 4a shows the total current densities of the TCSACs under different potentials from 0.5 to 1.0 V vs RHE. It demonstrates that Fe-TCSAC exhibits the highest current density at 1.0 V compared with the Mn-TCSAC, and Co- TCSAC. With increasing potential, the Faraday efficiency of CO FECO correspondingly increases, and the FECO of Fe- TCSACs reaches a maximum of 91.6 at a potential of 0.9 V Figure 4b. The Pourbaix diagram of the Fe-TCSAC shows that the structural stability of the Fe-TCSAC is maintained at pH 11 and an applied potential of 0.9 V to RHE Figure S40. The gas products of Fe-TCSAC were evaluated by online gas chromatography GC, as shown in Figure S41. Fe- TCSAC provides excellent selectivity for CO production, which is consistent with the results of the DFT calculations. The FEH2 values of the TCSACs are shown in Figure S42, demonstrating that Fe-TCSAC has the lowest FEH2 value compared with ZnO, Mn-TCSAC, and Co-TCSAC. Moreover, the CO partial current density of the Fe-TCSAC reaches a maximum value of 46.43 mA cm2 at 1.0 V Figure 4c. The electrochemically active surface areas ECSAs of different samples were then investigated by measuring the double-layer capacitance Cdl. Figure S43 presents the CV curves of ZnO, Fe-, Mn-, and Co-TCSAC. Fe-TCSAC exhibits the highest Cdl 0.16 mF cm2, compared to ZnO, Mn-TCSAC, and Co- TCSAC 0.12, 0.124, and 0.12 mF cm2, respectively Figure S44a. The relatively larger Cdl of Fe-TCSAC implies a higher electrochemically accessible surface area. While we acknowl- edge that the electrochemical surface area ECSA measure- ments may not take into account the exact conditions of gas access within the triple-phase boundary region during the CO2RR, its influence on the difference in activity should be negligible because all catalysts have similar morphology and surface chemistry. After normalization by the ECSA, the CO current densities of the four catalysts at different voltages still showed a similar trend, suggesting that the increase in catalyst activity may mainly stem from the enhancement of intrinsic activity Figure S44b. The ECSA normalized current density for the CO of Fe-TCSAC reaches a maximum value of 23.22 mA cm2. The trend of current density after BET normal- ization is consistent with the current density performance under a geometric area Figure S45. In addition, the long-term stability of the Fe-TCSAC at 0.9 V was investigated. The FECO, FEH2, and current density of the Fe-TCSAC remain stable after 30 h of electrolysis Figure 4d, indicating the excellent stability of the Fe-TCSAC. In addition, the CO2RR performance of the Fe-TCSAC is superior

metadata.title: Liu 等 - 2025 - Spin-state effect of tetrahedron-coordinated single-atom catalysts on CO2 electroreduction.pdf

text: Figure S45. In addition, the long-term stability of the Fe-TCSAC at 0.9 V was investigated. The FECO, FEH2, and current density of the Fe-TCSAC remain stable after 30 h of electrolysis Figure 4d, indicating the excellent stability of the Fe-TCSAC. In addition, the CO2RR performance of the Fe-TCSAC is superior to that of other previously reported ZnFe-based catalysts Table S6 and Figure 4e. Compared with conventional ZnO-based catalysts,38 Fe-TCSAC, as an inexpensive catalyst, has a comparable FE. In situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy FTIR measurements were performed to identify the reaction intermediates involved in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO Tables S7 and S8. As displayed in Figure 4g, the Fe- TCSAC displays an absorption band with a vibration frequency of 1393 cm1, which is ascribed to the presence of a key COOH in the electrocatalytic CO2RR process. This absorption band shows an intensity higher than that of ZnO Figure 4f. Thus, in situ FTIR analysis demonstrates that the CO2 absorbed on the surface of the Fe-TCSAC is more favorably converted into surface COOH, facilitating the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO. The HER always acts as a competing reaction to the CO2RR. The Gibbs free energies of the HER of the TCSACs were calculated Figure 4h. The absolute values of the HER reaction energy for Mn-, Fe-, Co-, Cu-TCSACs, and ZnO substrates are 0.96, 0.72, 1.06, 0.82, and 1.25 eV, respectively, which are all higher than those of CO2RR PDS. Thus, the competitive HER reaction is inhibited on TCSACs. In addition, HCOOH is significantly less selective than CO Figure S19. The dynamic stability of the structure was first assessed by using ab initio molecular dynamics AIMD simulations, revealing that the structure remains stable at room temperature for 10 ps Figure 4i. Mn- and Co-TCSACs also exhibit dynamic stability at room temperature Figure S20. To align more closely to the experimental conditions, the performance of the Fe-TCSAC was investigated with implicit solvents under constant-potential conditions. The Fe-TCSAC structure containing the implicit solvent was relaxed to reach equilibrium. Subsequently, the PDS i.e., the conversion of COOH to CO of the reactions in constant charge states was studied under a constant potential. The potential- dependent free energy profiles over the Fe-TCSAC at potentials of U 0, 0.4, 0.6, and 0.8 V were calculated Figure 4j. At a constant charge state U 0 V, the conversion of COOH to CO must overcome a reaction energy of 0.57 eV. However, in a constant-potential state of U 0.4 to 0.8 V, the PDS reaction energy decreases, and the reaction transitions from endothermic to spontaneous exothermic. With increasing voltage, the conversion of COOH to CO becomes more exothermic, facilitating the reaction. Based on these results, it can be inferred that under Journal of the American Chemical Society pubs.acs.orgJACS Article https:doi.org10.1021jacs.4c18550 J. Am. Chem. Soc. The above results suggest an intrinsic source of

text: it can be inferred that under Journal of the American Chemical Society pubs.acs.orgJACS Article https:doi.org10.1021jacs.4c18550 J. Am. Chem. Soc. XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX H constant-potential experimental conditions applying a voltage greater than 0.4 V allows for the spontaneous conversion of COOH to CO. The above results suggest an intrinsic source of robust stability and high CO selectivity on IS Fe-TCSACs. CONCLUSIONS In summary, the spin-state effect of TCSACs on the electroreduction of CO2 has been systematically investigated. The results show that TM single atoms at tetrahedral positions effectively regulate the adsorption and activation of CO2 molecules due to their higher t2 energy levels and more unoccupied orbitals. The TM magnetic moments and UL of the CO2RR exhibit a volcano relationship. The introduction of the spin state in Fe-TCSAC reduces the UL of CO2RR on the ZnO substrate by 0.53 eV. The conversion of COOH to CO and the desorption of CO are the PDS of the CO2RR on ZnO, Mn-, Fe-, and Co-, Ni-, Cu-TCSACs. Thus, CO becomes the key intermediate in the CO2RR over the TM-TCSACs. Spin- state analysis indicates that the IS state Fe atoms induce spin splitting of the C atom orbitals of the adsorbed CO and facilitates optimal coupling between C-px, py, and Fe-dx 2y 2, dz 2; between C-pz and Fe-d. This coupling results in a moderate bonding strength between TCSACs and CO, indicating that the TCSAC strongly activates CO. In addition, the Fe-TCSAC exhibits excellent performance for electro- catalytic CO2RR FECO of 91.6 at 0.9 V vs RHE. Moreover, the FECO and current density of Fe-TCSACs remain stable after 30 h of electrolysis at 0.9 V. The spin state of the Fe-TCSAC from experiments agrees well with the calculation results. This work provides a theoretical basis for studying the spin-state effect of tetrahedron-coordinated single-atom catalysts. Moreover, the research methodology reported herein provides valuable guidance for the rational design and optimization of high-performance electrocatalysts. text: Electrochromic Rutile with Dynamically Tailored Surfaces in Formaldehyde-Mediated Hydroxylamine Electrosynthesis Jiaqi Zhang, Erbo Zhao, Chou-Hung Hsueh, Weng-Chon Max Cheong, Xin Tan, Chuhao Liu, Xiang Liu, Jinxin Wang, Hai Xiao, and Chen Chen Cite This: https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c03124 Read Online ACCESS Metrics More Article Recommendations sı Supporting Information ABSTRACT: Electrocatalytic nitrate reduction is an attractive route for sustainable hydroxylamine synthesis, but its selectivity is limited by over-reduction and competing hydrogen evolution, highlighting the need for in-depth mechanistic understanding to guide catalyst design. Here, we systematically investigate the electrochemical synthesis of hydroxylamine via a formaldehyde-mediated method on titanium oxides. An electrochromic rutile array prepared via a wet-chemical route achieved a Faradaic efficiency FE of 92.6 for formaldehyde oxime and a corresponding yield rate of up to 2085 μmol cm2 h1 under ambient conditions. Mechanistic studies reveal that the electrochromism is a macroscopic manifestation of the protonation of Ob bridging oxygen sites and the formation of Ov oxygen vacancies and Ti3, which act as proton sponges and electron reservoirs. Formaldehyde not only serves as the capturing agent but also helps to stabilize NH2OH through molecular tuning, thereby achieving high selectivity. Through formaldehyde-nitrate electro-reforming, hydrogen, formic acid, and hydroxylamine can be coproduced at 200 mA cm2 under an ultralow cell voltage of 0.78 V. This work links the catalytic performance of hydroxylamine electrosynthesis to the dynamic surface of titanium oxides, offering insights into selectivity control in nitrate electroreduction and providing a green, cost-effective alternative to conventional hydroxylamine synthesis. INTRODUCTION Nitrogen is a vital element for all life forms and plays a crucial role in industrial production and daily life.1,2 However, the industrial processes and artificial nitrogen conversions have elicited a persistent imbalance in the nitrogen cycle Figure 1a, resulting in the accumulation of harmful nitrates and nitrites in environment, thereby leading to a series of ecological crises.35 In recent years, the electroreduction of nitrate NO3 and nitrite NO2 , preferably powered by renewable energy, has emerged as a promising strategy to restore a balanced nitrogen cycle, garnering increasing attention.68 Electrochemical nitrate reduction NO3RR effectively removes nitrate pollutants from wastewater and converts it into valuable chemicals, facilitating the recycling of nitrogen resources9,10 Current research focuses primarily on two strategies Figure 1b: reducing NO3 into dinitrogen N2 for water purification11 and converting NO3 into ammonia NH3 for nitrogen fertilizer production.12 The main by- products in these processes are hydrogen and nitrite NO2 , with barely any other products reported. Hydroxylamine NH2OH is an important nitrogenous feedstock and is extensively used in synthesizing various nitrogen-containing compounds in the chemical, pharmaceut- ical and agrochemical industries.1315 Conventional hydroxyl- amine synthesis encompasses diverse routes Raschig, hydro- genations, often facing challenges like multistep processes, byproduct generation, or reliance on harsh conditions, motivating greener electrochemical approaches.1618 In contrast, the route of reducing nitrate into hydroxylamine NO3 to NH2OH using water as the proton source and powered by renewable energy could not only effectively remove the nitrate pollutants from wastewater but also provide a more sustainable avenue toward green production of hydroxylamine. However, the NO3RR

text: electrochemical approaches.1618 In contrast, the route of reducing nitrate into hydroxylamine NO3 to NH2OH using water as the proton source and powered by renewable energy could not only effectively remove the nitrate pollutants from wastewater but also provide a more sustainable avenue toward green production of hydroxylamine. However, the NO3RR process follows a complex multielectron and multiproton transfer mechanism and NH2OH is usually formed as a reaction intermediate.1921 Its strong adsorption on catalyst surface, the high tendency of HONH2 bond to cleavage, and the instability of NH2OH pose significant challenges for achieving high-selectivity direct production via NO3RR. In this regard, strategies explored include employing various catalyst materials and structures or Received: February 22, 2025 Revised: May 22, 2025 Accepted: May 27, 2025 Article pubs.acs.orgJACS XXXX American Chemical Society A https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c03124 J. Am. Chem. Soc. XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX Downloaded via TSINGHUA UNIV on June 15, 2025 at 12:44:42 UTC. See https:pubs.acs.orgsharingguidelines for options on how to legitimately share published articles. utilizing molecular catalysts to manage intermediate binding and selectivity.22,23 Aldehydeketone mediators represent another approach, typically viewed simply as the capturing agents for the NH2OH intermediate.2426 However, achieving both high selectivity and high production rates remains a significant hurdle for these methods. Inspired by strategies using surface adsorbates to modulate catalytic activity, here we hypothesize that mediators like formaldehyde may play a role more than simply capturing the NH2OH intermediate, but also potentially tuning the reaction pathway via surface interactions. To explore this potential molecular tuning effect27,28 and to develop high-efficiency hydroxylamine synthesis systems, transition metal oxides with rich surface chemistry and tunable structures offer an attractive platform. In particular, titanium dioxide TiO2 has garnered extensive attention by virtue of its stability, cost-effectiveness, and the known role of surface defects like Ov oxygen vacancies in catalysis. Herein, we systematically investigate the formaldehyde- mediated electroreduction of nitrate on various TiO2 phases and facets, focusing on elucidating the interplay between the catalysts dynamic surface associated with its electrochrom- ism and the potential molecular modulating role of form- aldehyde. We developed a high-performance rutile array catalyst via a wet-chemical method, and identified Ti5cOb sites as the active centers facilitating an unconventional nitrate reduction pathway. This rutile array catalyst exhibited a remarkable Faradaic efficiency FE of 92.6 for the formaldehyde oxime product and achieved a yield rate up to 2085 μmol cm2 h1 under ambient conditions. The pronounced electrochromism of this catalyst reflects the dynamic formation of Ov and Ti3, which effectively activate NO3 . Combining in situ characterizations attenuated total reflectance Fourier-transform infrared ATR-FTIR, differ- ential electrochemical mass spectrometry DEMS and solid- state NMR ssNMR with density functional theory DFT calculations, we infer that formaldehyde not only acts as a capturing agent but also modifies the catalyst surface forming Ti5cOCH2Ob species, altering the reaction pathway and promoting hydroxylamine intermediate desorption Figure 1c. Finally, we demonstrate an energy-efficient electro- reforming system that coproduces hydrogen, formic acid, and the hydroxylamine precursor at 1 V cell voltage, highlighting its potential industrial viability through techno-economic analysis and device-scale tests.

Finally, we demonstrate an energy-efficient electro- reforming system that coproduces hydrogen, formic acid, and the hydroxylamine precursor at 1 V cell voltage, highlighting its potential industrial viability through techno-economic analysis and device-scale tests. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION Catalyst Screening and Performance Analysis. The synthesis of hydroxylamine was investigated through a nucleophilic additionelimination reaction mediated by form- aldehyde which helps to capture the intermediates during nitrate reduction. The electrochemical reaction was con- ducted in an H-type cell using 1 M KOH solution containing Figure 1. A series of commercial TiO2 samples Figure S1 with different crystallo- graphic structures including rutile, anatase, and brookite, as well as P25 were tested. After 1 h electrolysis at 0.8 V vs RHE, the 1H NMR spectra for the electrolyte show distinct peaks corresponding to CH2NOH Figure S2. Notably, the commercial brookite sample exhibits the highest catalytic activity, achieving a FE of 36 Figure 2a. To systematically unravel the structureactivity relation- ships for formaldehyde-mediated nitrate reduction over titanium oxides, we investigated the influence of some key properties of the materials used, including surface coordination sites, defect density Ov, and charge transport characteristics. Our findings are summarized in Figure S3. We began by examining the role of surface sites dictated by crystal phases and exposed facets. Using hydrothermal synthesis, we prepared a series of TiO2 samples with well-defined shapes and specific exposed facets29 see details in Supporting Information, including B brookite, Figure S4 210, A anatase, Figure S5 001, A 101, A 111, and R rutile, Figure S6 110, 111, 331. These specific crystal facets were confirmed via X-ray diffraction XRD, Raman spectroscopy and trans- mission electron microscopy TEM Supplementary Notes 1, 2. Activity tests Figure 2a revealed a rather low performance for the anatase phases; in contrast, brookite B 210 showed a good activity FE 36, similar to commercial brookite. Notably, the rutile samples synthesized via wet-chemistry, such as R 110 and the high-index R 331, exhibited significantly higher activities than commercial rutile. A common feature among these active facets B 210, R 110, R 331 is the presence of the Ti5cOb structural motif Supplementary Note 3 and Figure S7, suggesting its potential role as the active center. A common feature among these active facets B 210, R 110, R 331 is the presence of the Ti5cOb structural motif Supplementary Note 3 and Figure S7, suggesting its potential role as the active center. Defects could also play a crucial role in catalytic activity. We synthesized defect-rich rutile clusters R-D, Figure S8 using ammonium lactate induction, which showed an impressive production rate of 1248 μmol cm2 h1, indicating a clear link between Ov density and catalytic activity. These results above suggest that Ov sites are crucial and probably could facilitate Figure 2. In addition to active sites and defects, an optimized electrocatalytic performance also requires efficient charge transport. To address the potential limitation in electrical conductivity for powder catalysts, we directly grew the rutile array on conductive carbon paper rutile arrayCC, Figure S9. This architecture, ensuring excellent catalyst support interface and inheriting the advantages of wet- chemically synthesized rutile predominantly exposing 110 facets with Ti5cOb sites and inherent Ov, displayed exceptional catalytic activity and selectivity. The rutile array displayed an exceptional FE of 92.6 and a production rate of 1521.5 μmol cm2 h1, indicating a superior catalytic selectivity and intrinsic activity. To evaluate the economic potential of this synthesis strategy for hydroxylamine NH2OH production, we conducted a techno-economic analysis TEA based on recently reported models23 Supplementary Note 6. With the electricity price presumed at 3 centskWh, using the rutile array or other high- selectivity and high-activity catalysts proves profitable Figure 2b. Furthermore, we believe that when the current density exceeds 200 mA cm2 with an efficiency greater than 90, the catalyst would meet the industrial demands of electrochemical production. With the catalytic activity further improved and renewable energy prices further decreased, the costs associated with this strategy would be lowered significantly, demonstrat- ing its promising application potential Figure S10. text: of the rutile arrayCC. Gas chromatography was used to analyze the gaseous products H2, NO, N2O, N2, and 1H NMR was used to quantify the yield of formaldehyde oxime CH2NOH Figure S11a, b. A colorimetric method was used to assess the yields of byproducts such as NO2 and NH3 Figures S11, S12. The linear sweep voltammetry LSV curves Figure 2c indicate that the introduction of formaldehyde can suppress the hydrogen evolution reaction HER, as evidenced by a decline in current density, probably because of the competing adsorptions between formaldehyde and H. The current density measured in the nitrate-containing electrolyte was significantly higher than in the 1 M KOH electrolyte, demonstrating the pronounced electrocatalytic activity of the rutile array for nitrate reduction compared with background reactions such as HER under these conditions. The introduction of formaldehyde during the nitrate electro- reduction results in a slight decrease in current density. Over the applied potential range from 0.4 V to 1.0 V, CH2NOH emerges as the main reduction product Figure 2d, with NH3 as the major byproduct in electrolyte and N2O as the major byproduct in gas phase. The total selectivity for CH2NOH is greater than 80 Figure 2e, and the FE trend displays a volcano-like shape, yet with the production rate monotonically increasing. Under the reaction conditions, formaldehyde does not undergo electroreduction to methanol Figure S13, as NO3 would be preferentially reduced over HCHO.30,31 Moreover, the Cannizzaro reaction in alkaline environment within the reaction time frame did not significantly impact the results. Notably, at an applied potential of 0.8 V vs RHE, the FE for CH2NOH reaches 92.6, with an average current density approaching 262 mA cm2. At 1.0 V, the yield rate of CH2NOH over the rutile array is as high as 2085 μmol cm2 h1, standing as one of the highest yield rates reported thus far for NH2OH electrosynthesis Table S1. CH2NOH was not detected in the absence of KNO3 and HCHO, confirming that the carbon and nitrogen sources for CH2NOH do come from HCHO and KNO3 Table S2, respectively. High FEs for CH2NOH can be achieved over a relatively wide range of formaldehyde concentrations Figure S14. Furthermore, the rutile array exhibited an excellent catalytic durability, maintaining a FE of 85 and a yield rate of 1500 μmol cm2 h1 after 20 cycles under the same reaction conditions Figure 2f. The catalyst after electrocatalytic reaction preserved its original structure and morphology Figure S15. A simple acidification and separation process yielded a substantial amount of NH2OHHCl product, with XRD and 1H NMR confirming its purity Figure 2g, S16 Material Synthesis and Characterization. Atomic-scale structures were investigated via aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy HAADF-STEM Figure 3c. Furthermore, the oxygen atoms within the TiO2 lattice were imaged at the atomic level using a phase imaging technique in integrated differential phase contrast STEM iDPCSTEM32 Figure 3d. In the images, oxygen atoms appear dim around bright Ti atoms, and Ov are marked with dashed circles. Additionally, the existence of oxygen bridges between Ti atoms could be observed. Electron paramagnetic resonance EPR spectroscopy Figure 3f also confirms a substantial amount of Ov 33 in both the rutile array and R-D samples g 2.003, as evidenced by the characteristic asymmetric signals from trapped electrons, although signals from Ti3 were not detected Figure S17. XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX E vibration peak e.g., to 442.5 cm1 for rutile array and 440.04 cm1 for R-D, with notable broadening, further implying the presence of Ov due to the symmetry disruption.34 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XPS Figure S18 also confirms the presence of Ov alongside a corresponding lower oxidation state for Ti.35 Based on the evidence above, we infer that the surfaces of RD and the rutile array, as depicted in Figure 3h, are rich in coordination-unsaturated Ti5c, bridging Ob, and Ov. Mechanistic Investigations. It is worth noting that rutile array exhibits a prominent reversible electrochromism Figure 4a, which correlates with its catalytic activity. When the potential reached 0.3 V vs RHE, the catalyst started to turn blue electron and proton injection. The catalyst color in the potential ranges from 0.4 V to 0.9 V changed from light blue to dark blue, and the formaldehyde oxime yield increased rapidly. When the potential reached 1.0 V, numerous bubbles were observed on the catalyst surface Figure S19, indicating the occurrence of HER and the formation of N2O. During a complete cyclic voltametric scan, the catalyst turns blue as the potential goes negative and rapidly bleaches as the potential goes positive along with 0.25 V vs RHE oxidation peak.36 For a more detailed explanation on the reversibility of the entire process, please see Supplementary Note 4 Video S1 and Figures S20, S21. We then employed a variety of character- ization techniques to probe the actual active sites in rutile array Figure S22. For the TiO2 surface, the electrochromism is typically attributed to the light absorption due to free electrons at Ov and the dd transitions of Ti3 in JahnTeller distorted octahedra.37 By comparing the quasi-in situ XPS profiles Figure S23 for the original and colored states preserved and detected under argon atmosphere, it was noted that the binding energy of Ti 2p shifts to lower energy for the colored state. The binding energy decreases by 0.45 eV for the dark- blue sample in sole NO3 reduction and by 0.3 eV for the light-blue sample in NO3 HCHO cooperative reduction, suggesting that the electrochromism is primarily due to the reduction of TiO2 as it accepts electrons, forming Ti3 species.38 We hypothesize that as the potential goes negative, electrons in the catalyst attract protons in the electrolyte onto the surface to form ObH bonds, and simultaneously reduce Ti4 into Ti3. The ObH could further undergo elimination of H2O molecule, yielding Ov. When the material is subjected to a potential more positive than 0.3 V vs RHE or to an oxidizing atmosphere, the Ov would become occupied and the surface- adsorbed hydrogen species would undergo oxidation and desorption Figure S24.39 During the electroreduction of nitrate, the generation

text: of H2O molecule, yielding Ov. When the material is subjected to a potential more positive than 0.3 V vs RHE or to an oxidizing atmosphere, the Ov would become occupied and the surface- adsorbed hydrogen species would undergo oxidation and desorption Figure S24.39 During the electroreduction of nitrate, the generation of colored Ti3 species through electrochromism is facilitated by the formation of Ov and TiObH, along with hydrogen insertion. These surface-active species are closely associated with the nitrate reduction and the electrosynthesis of formaldehyde oxime. To probe the electronic structure and surface states of the catalyst under working conditions, we performed operando X- ray absorption spectroscopy XAS to investigate the ensemble average of the near-surface local Ti coordination environment in the Rutile Array samples Figure 4b, S25. Ti K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure XANES profile shows three pre-edge peaks characteristic of rutile at 4969.4, 4972.0, and 4975.1 eV, corresponding to dipole-allowed transitions in the distorted octahedra of rutile: the first peak stems from the quadrupolar transition of 1s 3d t2g, the second from the dipolar transition of 1s 3d t2g 4p hybridized states, and the third from the pure dipolar transitions of 1s 3d eg 4p hybridized states.40 As the potential gradually shifts cathodically, pre-edge peaks with higher intensities emerge, indicative of a broken symmetry, and a more distorted local structure. This implies that the density of Ov increases further at more cathodic potentials, or that the surface adsorbates disrupt the coordination symmetry of Ti, exacerbating the JahnTeller effect.41,42 Simultaneously, at more negative potentials 0.6 V to 0.8 V, the absorption edge shifts to lower energy, and the white line intensity diminishes, indicating a lowered oxidation state of Ti. Semiquantitative fitting reveals a valence state of 3.72 Figure S26. The Fourier transform extended X-ray absorption fine structure FT-EXAFS spectra shows three primary scattering paths Figure 4c: the major peak at 1.5 Å corresponds to the TiO path, the peak at 2.4 Å to TiTi scattering in the second shell, and the peak at 3.1 Å to TiOTi scattering in the third shell. The intensities of these peaks decrease in the order of 0 V, 0.2 V, and 0.8 V, which agrees well with the decrease in the coordination numbers CNs of O and Ti around the Ti center. The CNs of the TiO2 samples were determined through quantitative fitting of the FT-EXAFS curves Figure S27. When the potential goes from 0 V to 0.8 V, the CNs of TiO in the first shell decreases from 3.28 to 2.83, whereas the CNs of TiTi scattering path decreases from 1.23 to 0.97. This decrease in coordination, reflecting increased oxygen vacancy formation, coincides with the enhancement of cathodic current density and the development of macroscopic electrochromism in the catalyst Table S5. In addition, quasi- in situ XRD reveals a slight decrease in the lattice constant Figure S28, further confirming the increase in Ov during the electroreduction. Therefore, the electrochromism is a macroscopic manifes- tation of low-valence-state, high-reducing-activity Ti3 species accompanied by Ov and

text: of macroscopic electrochromism in the catalyst Table S5. In addition, quasi- in situ XRD reveals a slight decrease in the lattice constant Figure S28, further confirming the increase in Ov during the electroreduction. Therefore, the electrochromism is a macroscopic manifes- tation of low-valence-state, high-reducing-activity Ti3 species accompanied by Ov and hydrogen adsorption Hads at cathodic potentials. These active species play a crucial role in the activation process of nitrate reduction. The introduction of formaldehyde leads to competitive adsorption, which decreases the concentrations of Ov and Hads on the catalytic surface, resulting in a lighter color. Such a change would also lead to the formation of new active adsorbed species which will be discussed in detail below, thereby modulating the catalytic selectivity. Reaction Intermediates. In the process of electro- reduction from nitrate to ammonia, there may be over a dozen of reaction intermediates and surface-adsorbed species, including H, OH, NO2 , HNO3, NO, NOH, HNO, N, NH, NH2, NHOH, NH2O, NH2OH, N2O and NH3. To investigate the reaction pathway for the coreduction from HCHO and NO3 to formaldehyde oxime, DEMS was employed to detect reaction intermediates under different conditions Figure S29.43 The tests were conducted in an alkaline electrolyte containing KNO3 Figure 4d: 1 no DEMS signals were detected at open-circuit potential; 2 at 100 s, a potential of 0.8 V vs RHE was applied, and signals for mz 44, 30, and 17 were clearly identified, indicating the formation of N2O, NO and NH3; 3 at 420 s, formaldehyde was introduced, and the DEMS signal for NH3 rapidly diminished within 100 s, while the NO signal intensified further, and signals for HNO and NH2OH emerged, with the signal for NO2 mz 46 showing a first increasing and then decreasing trend. Yet the signal for N2O did not change. It is possible that there may exist other active sites that are not affected by formaldehyde. Furthermore, we explored the DEMS signals of intermediates Journal of the American Chemical Society pubs.acs.orgJACS Article https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c03124 J. Am. Chem. Soc. XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX F in different electrolytes under various potentials using a pulsed potential sequence Figure S30. Before the potential reached 0.4 V, and the catalyst did not turn blue, no signals were detected. As the potential went from 0.5 V to 0.9 V, the signals for intermediates intensified, indicating the generation of more intermediates. Complementary experiments using 15N- labeled nitrate Figure S31 verified nitrate as the nitrogen source for the detected species. Furthermore, the key intermediate signals observed were consistent with those obtained in the nonlabeled DEMS experiments, validating the data set used for subsequent pathway analysis. Derived from these DEMS results, we propose the plausible reaction pathways for the NO3RR over rutile array Figure S32. Notably, during the nitrate reduction process, only trace amounts of HNO and NH2OH intermediates were detected. In contrast, under coreduction conditions, the signals for HNO and NH2OH were significantly stronger, with CH2NOH mz 45 also directly detected. If HCHO acts merely as a capturing agent for NH2OH intermediates to

text: S32. Notably, during the nitrate reduction process, only trace amounts of HNO and NH2OH intermediates were detected. In contrast, under coreduction conditions, the signals for HNO and NH2OH were significantly stronger, with CH2NOH mz 45 also directly detected. If HCHO acts merely as a capturing agent for NH2OH intermediates to form form- aldehyde oxime, NH2OH would be rapidly consumed,44 and the signal for HNO would not exhibit a significant increase. Therefore, HCHO here may not only function simply as a capturing agent, but most likely also acts as a molecular tuning agent27 influencing the thermodynamic stability of intermedi- ates and the reaction kinetics of nitrate reduction through competitive adsorption with Hads and Ti5c on the rutile surface. This hypothesis is also corroborated by examining the effect of HCHO concentration Figure S14. We observed that the FE for CH2NOH exhibits a saturation at higher concentrations, while the overall yield rate follows a volcano-like trend owing to decreasing current density. Such a nonlinear and saturation kinetics is characteristic of surface-adsorption-mediated pro- cesses, providing strong evidence against the simple solution- phase trapping mechanism and supporting the role of formaldehyde as a surface modulator. Since DEMS detects the intermediates extracted from the near-surface region, its ability to observe specific intermediates depends on their surface kinetics and adsorption strength. Intermediates with very short lifetimes may not reach detectable steady-state concentrations, while strongly adsorbed intermediates may not desorb readily enough to be sampled, hindering their detection. This suggests that the pure nitrate reduction process might proceed at such a rapid pace that HNO, NO2, and NH2OH are not able to accumulate. The characteristics of strong adsorption and easy dissociation for NH2OH on the TiO2 surface hinder the detection via DEMS. In contrast, after the addition of formaldehyde, the surface modulation induced by formaldehyde lowered the nitrate reduction reaction rate, rendering the intermediates more readily detectable and facilitating the desorption of NH2OH. This promotes the carbonnitrogen coupling process from either the electric double layer in solution or the catalyst surface. Kinetics studies via operando electrochemical impedance spectroscopy EIS also suggest disparate mechanisms in different electrolyte Figure S33, Supplementary Note 5. ATRFTIR spectroscopy further validated these mecha- nisms by directly identifying the intermediates. Notably, ATRFTIR spectroscopy detects surface-adsorbed species on the catalyst, rather than the desorbed species as detected using DEMS. In the NO3 reduction reaction Figure 4g, the peaks at 2852 cm1 and 2926 cm1 correspond to the formation of NH2OH,25 whereas the peak at 1457 cm1 is attributed to the bending vibration of NH2 Figure 4e, most likely resulting from NH4 formation. The peak at 3743 cm1 may correspond to νTiOH Figures S34, S35, indicating the generation of surface hydroxylated structures.45 These peaks gradually intensified as the potential went cathodic. In the system with formaldehyde added Figure 4f, a distinct C NO peak was detected at 1698 cm1 in the more negative potential range, arising from the coupling product H2C NOH46 or HCHO. Moreover, the peaks characteristic of hydroxylamine disappeared Figure 4h, indicating efficient coupling of

text: the potential went cathodic. In the system with formaldehyde added Figure 4f, a distinct C NO peak was detected at 1698 cm1 in the more negative potential range, arising from the coupling product H2C NOH46 or HCHO. Moreover, the peaks characteristic of hydroxylamine disappeared Figure 4h, indicating efficient coupling of formaldehyde with NH2OH or rapid desorption of NH2OH. In contrast to the spectrum recorded in sole NO3 reduction, the νTiOH peak is absent here, confirming that the addition of aldehyde indeed lowered the surface hydrogen coverage, which competes for adsorption with protons. An additional peak emerged at 1429 cm1, which can be attributed to bidentate titanium-coordinated formaldehyde Ti2 OCH2O Figure S36.47 This surface-adsorbed species has been confirmed to be one of the key intermediates in the removal of formaldehyde in TiO2 during thermocatalysis, as have been evidenced via in situ scanning tunneling microscopy, infrared spectroscopy.48,49 In addition, we also explored the surface adsorbed species of rutile using quasi-in situ ssNMR Figure 4i. Notably, the rutile array sample synthesized using tertbutyl titanate as the precursor exhibits a significant amount of alkoxy-terminated TiOCH23CH3 structures on its surface, as indicated by the presence of methyl and methylene groups at 1.2 and 3.7 ppm, respectively.40 The potential- dependent Raman spectra show a gradual decrease in the intensity for the CH bond around 27603000 cm1 as the potential went cathodic Figure S37. This suggests that the alkoxy structure could be easily removed during electro- catalysis, carrying away surface bridge oxygen atoms, thereby generating more surface Ov than for commercial rutile catalysts. This is also the reason why the sample synthesized using liquid-phase synthesis method exhibits superior perform- ance compared to commercial rutile. After the reaction, the alkoxy-terminated structure disappears from the rutile surface, and a peak corresponding to the key adsorbed species Ti2 OCH2O emerges at 4.4 ppm.50 By examining the C 1s difference spectrum from quasi-in situ XPS Figures 4j and S38, we noticed that the signals for CHx and CO bonds increase significantly after the reaction, alongside a smaller increase for CON species. This indicates the presence of a bridged OCH2O structure with single-bond characteristics on the surface.51 On the basis of the studies involving electrochemistry, in situ XAS, ATR-FTIR, and DEMS, through cross-validation and analysis Figure S39, we conclude that the electrochemical reduction coupling of NO3 and HCHO occurs on the rutile surface, as illustrated in Figure 4k. Further kinetic insights were obtained from Tafel analysis. The experimental Tafel slope for NO3RR on the rutile array was determined to be 119.7 mVdec without formaldehyde, compared to 123.8 mVdec with HCHO addition Figure S40. These values imply that the first electron transfer step in the overall reaction sequence might be the rate-determining step RDS corresponding to a theoretical slope of 120 mVdec for n 1 electron transfer involved in the RDS. Notably, this kinetic behavior aligns with the concurrent onset of significant nitrate reduction currents and electrochromism indicating OvTi3 formation at potentials around 0.4 V Figures 4a, 2c, points toward a mechanism where

text: RDS corresponding to a theoretical slope of 120 mVdec for n 1 electron transfer involved in the RDS. Notably, this kinetic behavior aligns with the concurrent onset of significant nitrate reduction currents and electrochromism indicating OvTi3 formation at potentials around 0.4 V Figures 4a, 2c, points toward a mechanism where the initial activation of the catalyst surface itself, most likely involving the Journal of the American Chemical Society pubs.acs.orgJACS Article https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c03124 J. Am. Chem. Soc. XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX G generation of OvTi3 active sites, plays a key role in controlling the reaction kinetics. This hypothesis could help explain a key seemingly contradictory observation: our rutile array, while being relatively inert for the hydrogen evolution reaction HER and having a poor intrinsic conductivity, exhibits anomalously rapid kinetics for nitrate reduction once a sufficient cathodic potential is applied. Conventional NO3RR pathways often rely heavily on efficient surface hydrogen H generation via water dissociation, which is expected to be sluggish on the HER-inert TiO2. Furthermore, the initial reduction of the stable NO3 into NO2 is generally considered as the bottleneck in conventional mechanisms. However, the rapid kinetics observed here, coupled with the Tafel slope suggesting Figure 5. Electroreforming system for hydrogen and hydroxylamine coproduction. a Calculated free energy changes for nitrate reduction to NO on rutile 110 surfaces with Ov. b Gibbs free energy diagram for the formation of NH3 and NH2OH on the rutile 110 facet. c Gibbs free energy diagram for the formation of NH3 and NH2OH on the rutile 110 facet with the adsorption of HCHO. d Comparison of various cathode and anode reactions in a formaldehyde-nitrate electro-reforming system. Solid lines represent experimental data with 80 iR correction, and dashed lines indicate theoretical electrode potentials. e Schematic illustration for cathodic NH2OH production anodic formaldehyde oxidation FOR electro-reforming in a two-electrode flow cell electrolyzer. f Comparison of cell voltages for two integrated strategies: using rutile array Cu3Ag7 for FOR coupled with hydroxylamine production, and rutile array IrO2 for nitrate reduction to hydroxylamine combined with the oxygen evolution reaction OER. Journal of the American Chemical Society pubs.acs.orgJACS Article https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c03124 J. Am. Chem. Soc. XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX H an early electron transfer step as RDS, strongly indicates an alternative pathway. We propose this alternative mechanism is mediated by dynamically generated Ov, with surface Ob sites potentially assisting protonation for Ov formation. For the nitrate reduction process after the rate-limiting Ov generation step, the high density of these Ov sites could facilitate the insertion of oxygen from NO3 . This disrupts the high symmetry of the nitrate ion, impairing the relatively inert NO bond and leading to ultrafast nitrate reduction kinetics, and thus the NO3 to NO2 step is no longer the RDS here. In DEMS, NO2 intermediates were not detected, further confirming that the reduction from NO3 to NO occurs with a high efficiency. Additionally, H exists on the Ti surface bonded to Ob, allowing for a high mobility through the hydrogen bonding network, generating a self-sustained hydrogen spillover.52 Furthermore, H may also

text: In DEMS, NO2 intermediates were not detected, further confirming that the reduction from NO3 to NO occurs with a high efficiency. Additionally, H exists on the Ti surface bonded to Ob, allowing for a high mobility through the hydrogen bonding network, generating a self-sustained hydrogen spillover.52 Furthermore, H may also insert into the TiO2 lattice to form HTiO2 with lattice H, enabling reversible hydrogen storage, which collectively facilitates the on-demand supply of hydrogen.40 The vacancies and adsorbed species as electron donors introduce new energy levels, while the surplus 3d orbital electrons of Ti occupy the Ov, enhancing the metallic characteristics of TiO2x and improving the conductivity to promote electron transport. In the presence of formaldehyde, HCHO competes for adsorption with H, thereby influencing the concentrations of Ti3 and Ov. Under electrochemical reduction conditions in aqueous solution, chemically adsorbed HCHO predominantly exists in a stable Ti5cOCH2Ob form. Through spatial effects and electronic modulation, this process constrains the kinetics of nitrate reduction and stabilizes the NH2OH intermediate, enabling efficient electrosynthesis of the coupling product CH2NOH across a wide potential range. Theoretical Investigations via DFT Calculations. To gain a more comprehensive understanding of the mechanism of nitrate electroreduction on the rutile surface and the potential regulating role of formaldehyde in this process, we conducted spin-polarized density functional theory DFT calculations on all possible pathways for the overall reaction. As electron microscopy characterizations and geometric analysis have shown in Figure 3b, the 110 plane is the exposed facet. Thus, the rutile 110 surface with a symmetric structure of Ti5c and Ob was constructed as the active surface. Given the complexity of the nitrate electroreduction mechanism on the TiO2 surface, we calculated the most stable adsorption configurations of all intermediates on the rutile surface as illustrated in Figures S41, S42 and systematically studied the evolution pathways of the active species in NO3RR Tables S6, S7. To validate our hypothesis regarding the RDS derived from Tafel analysis, we calculated the energetics for Ov formation on both an ideal rutile 110 surface and an OBu n-butanol- terminated model surface. The results detailed in Figure S43 revealed that the RDS for Ov generation on the OBu- terminated surface is indeed the initial electron transfer protonation step Step 1 in our proposed scheme, with a barrier of 0.64 eV. This finding strongly supports our interpretation of the experimental Tafel slope 120 mV dec and confirms that active site formation probably governs the overall reaction kinetics in our system. With the understanding that Ov generation is the kinetic bottleneck, we then used DFT to investigate the subsequent reaction pathway initiated by the facile activation of nitrate on these Ov sites. We explored the interaction of NO3 with the Ov-containing surface Figure 5a.53 Compared with bidentate adsorption of NO3 on Ti5c 0.11 eV, the oxygen atom in NO3 could more readily occupy the Ov site for recovery 0.32 eV. In this process, the electrons previously stored at Ti3 could be released synchronously, resulting in an altered local charge density that activates

metadata.title: Zhang 等 - 2025 - Electrochromic rutile with dynamically tailored surfaces in formaldehyde-mediated hydroxylamine electrosynthesis.pdf

text: Figure 5a.53 Compared with bidentate adsorption of NO3 on Ti5c 0.11 eV, the oxygen atom in NO3 could more readily occupy the Ov site for recovery 0.32 eV. In this process, the electrons previously stored at Ti3 could be released synchronously, resulting in an altered local charge density that activates the NO bond in the inserted NO3 , effectively cleaving NO3 to generate NO2 , while the recovered Ov now exists as OH. This step NO3 H NO2 OH is highly exothermic 1.95 eV, different from conventional mechanisms for nitrate electro- reduction where the activation of nitrate to nitrite occurs readily. This finding aligns well with the fact that NO2 intermediates could barely be detected in DEMS. Further, the NO2 adsorbed on Ti5c would rearrange into a bidentate adsorption ONOD configuration, followed by sequential H2O elimination to generate NO. This step has no significant thermodynamic barrier, featuring a gradual decrease in free energy. We then calculated the reaction pathway for reducing NO to NH3Figure 5b. NO would be preferentially reduced into NHO ΔG 0.05 eV rather than to NOH 0.445 eV. The conversion from NOH to N is even less favorable, thus establishing the basis for selective hydroxylamine production. Starting from NHO, NH3 could be produced via three pathways: 1 Protonation at the N end to form NH2OH, which then dissociates and undergoes H2O elimination to generate NH2. 2 Protonation at the N end to form NHOH, which undergoes H2O elimination to give NH, and then further protonated directly to NH2. 3 Protonation at the O end to form ONH2, which can either follow the NH2OH route via pathway 1 or proceed via the Langmuir Hinshelwood mechanism to directly yield ONH3 through a hydrogen atom transfer HAT process. For pathways 1 and 2, both reactions are exothermic and likely to occur, whereas pathway 3 ONH2 ONH3 has a small thermodynamic barrier ΔG 0.13 eV. To sum up, on the rutile 110 surface, nitrate electro- reduction is more likely to follow pathway 1 involving the key intermediate NH2OH. The selectivity between NH2OH and NH3 depends on the balance between the adsorption and dissociation of NH2OH. On pure rutile surfaces, NH2OH is more likely to dissociate 0.59 eV than to desorb 1.61 eV, making it rather difficult to detect NH2OH in DEMS, and therefore NH3 becomes the predominant detectable product. When formaldehyde is introduced, it adsorbs in the form of OCH2, generating the key adsorbate species Ti2OCH2O, which facilitates strong electron transfer at the TiO2 surface. Additionally, its adsorption site overlaps with the protonated Ob sites responsible for the electrochromism, leading to competitive adsorption, which explains the observed fading in electrochromism. The adsorbed HCHO significantly alters the electronic structure of the surface and affects the stability of various intermediates through intermolecular interactions. On the basis of these results, we calculated the energy landscape in the presence of the Ti2OCH2O species Figure 5c. Similar to the clean surface, the surface with formaldehyde is more likely to follow the NHO intermediate pathway, forming NHOH

text: and affects the stability of various intermediates through intermolecular interactions. On the basis of these results, we calculated the energy landscape in the presence of the Ti2OCH2O species Figure 5c. Similar to the clean surface, the surface with formaldehyde is more likely to follow the NHO intermediate pathway, forming NHOH through protonation, which then generates NH2OH. Remark- ably, the aldehyde intermediate stabilizes NH2OH, rendering it less likely to dissociate into NH2 OH, with a dissociation barrier of 1.27 eV. In contrast, NH2OH can more readily desorb to form free NH2OH 0.96 eV. Additionally, if free formaldehyde molecules are introduced on the surface, a direct Journal of the American Chemical Society pubs.acs.orgJACS Article https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c03124 J. Am. Chem. Soc. XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX I coupling reaction NH2OH HCHO CH2NOH H2O occurs, with the Gibbs free energy change for CH2NOH formation being 1.03 eV, indicative of a highly exothermic reaction. This suggests that the key adsorbate species Ti2OCH2O, arising from competitive adsorption of aldehydes, effectively stabilizes the NH2OH intermediate, making it difficult to cleave, while allowing for easier desorption. This promotes the direct coupling with free HCHO, resulting in the formation of CH2NOH and significantly altering the product distribution to achieve a high selectivity for CH2NOH. Electro-reforming System. To achieve higher yields, enhanced energy efficiency, and lower the cost of electro- catalytic hydroxylamine production, we explored an electro- reforming route for hydroxylamine synthesis. Here form- aldehyde, in addition to being the molecular modulator and capturing agent for nitrate reduction as discussed above, also served as an energy carrier. Recently, copper-based materials have been shown to be a promising approach to achieve low- potential oxidation of aldehydes and through Tafel recombi- nation to produce hydrogen and formic acid under alkaline conditions,54 with a theoretical potential of only 0.22 V. Therefore, combining anodic FOR formaldehyde oxidation reaction with cathodic formaldehyde-mediated nitrate reduc- tion for hydroxylamine synthesis presents a thermodynamically more favorable strategy Figures 5d, S44, S45. This not only generates value-added anodic products such as H2 and HCOOH, but also significantly lowers the cell voltage input and maximizes the utilization of formaldehyde. We employed Cu3Ag7CF55 as the catalyst for aldehyde oxidation dehydro- genation and used rutile array as the catalyst for hydroxylamine synthesis Figure 5e. In comparison to the 2.3 V cell voltage required for the system with OER at the anode, our system with FOR at the anode only requires 0.78 V to achieve an industrial current density of 200 mA cm2 Figure 5f, while simultaneously producing hydroxylamine, formic acid, and hydrogen Figure S46. In the flow electrolyzer, the reaction system could operate stably at a current density of 200 mA cm2 for 10 h with almost no degradation in Faradaic efficiency for CH2NOH Figure S45c. Notably, the theoretical potential for nitrate-to-hydroxylamine conversion under alkaline con- ditions is 0.53 V vs RHE. By engineering electrocatalysts with lower overpotentials, the energy-consuming processes of nitrate electroreduction and formaldehyde electro-oxidation can be reconfigured into a formaldehyde-nitrate fuel cell that generates electrical energy, potentially achieving an open- circuit voltage

text: S45c. Notably, the theoretical potential for nitrate-to-hydroxylamine conversion under alkaline con- ditions is 0.53 V vs RHE. By engineering electrocatalysts with lower overpotentials, the energy-consuming processes of nitrate electroreduction and formaldehyde electro-oxidation can be reconfigured into a formaldehyde-nitrate fuel cell that generates electrical energy, potentially achieving an open- circuit voltage OCV as high as 0.75 V Figure 5d. This would significantly improve the economic feasibility of this technological approach Supplementary Notes 6, 7. With its superior energy conversion efficiency, we believe that our formaldehydenitrate coelectrolysis system holds great prom- ise for industrial-scale applications. SUMMARY In conclusion, we unveiled the reaction mechanism of nitrate electroreduction into hydroxylamine mediated by formalde- hyde on various phases and surfaces of TiO2, and identified Ti5cOb as the active center. The self-supported rutile array, predominantly exposing the 110 crystal facet, exhibits a remarkable catalytic activity, achieving a Faradaic efficiency of 92.6 for CH2NOH and a yield of up to 2085 μmol cm2 h1. In addition, we found that the electrochromism of the catalyst is highly related to its catalytic activity. Specifically, this electrochromism manifests the dynamic generation of Ov and Ti3, the true active species that drive nitrate reduction via cycling processes involving Ob sites. Moreover, formaldehyde not only serves as a capturing agent but also as a molecular regulator, thereby enhancing the stability of the NH2OH intermediate and altering the reaction pathway to achieve selective reduction to give the target product. This work opens up a sustainable route to producing NH2OH under mild conditions through green electrochemistry and provides new insights into the selective regulation of nitrate reduction. text: Article https:doi.org10.1038s41467-025-60429-6 Copper-catalyzed Csp3H amination and etheriﬁcation of unactivated hydrocarbons via photoelectrochemical pathway Jiawen Yin1, Chengcheng Shi1, Ao-Men Hu1, Mengqi Luo1, Chao Yang 1, Lin Guo 1 Wujiong Xia 1,2 Csp3H activation and functionalization of unactivated hydrocarbons has provided enormous opportunities for the construction of diverse organic molecules, which facilitates the structural modiﬁcation of pharmaceutical molecules. To achieve this goal, the direct hydrogen atom transfer HAT via radical pathway has become an attractive strategy. Taking the advantage of photoelectrochemistry, we herein describe oxidative Csp3H amination and etheriﬁcation reactions via a photoelectrochemical pathway, which could directly transform easily available hydrocarbons into N-heterocycle and ether products under mild conditions. Applying 9-phenylacridine as a direct hydrogen atom transfer d-HAT reagent under 390 nm LED light irradiation and electrolysis, the scope of our method includes not only simple alkanes, but also a wide range of Csp3H molecules including ethers, thioethers, silanes, and amides. The reaction shows broad scope 135 examples and uncon- ventional regioselectivity, with the occurrence of both Csp3H amination and etheriﬁcation preferentially at the sterically unhindered positions. Further- more, gram-scale experiments and relevant mechanistic investigations are carried out to illustrate the reaction mechanism. Hydrocarbons are fundamental raw materials in physical science. The development of synthetic methodologies for the functionalization of simple and unactivated hydrocarbons has the potential to explore uncharted chemical space and construct complex molecular scaffolds14. Moreover, by directly activating aliphatic CH bonds of hydrocarbons, chemists can bypass commonly used alkyl halides and organometallic reagents, and directly use the feedstock materials for late-stage derivatization of pharmaceutical molecules, natural pro- ducts, agrochemicals and functionalized materials58. However, the strong bond dissociation energies BDE: 96101 kcal.mol-1 of Csp3H bonds in alkanes, combined with their high redox potentials usually above 3.0 V vs. SCE, have hampered the direct use of unactivated alkanes in synthetic transformations9,10. In recent years, photo-induced radical-mediated hydrogen atom transfer HAT strategy has been greatly expanded into this area, as the efﬁcient conversion of visible light into chemical energy allows the direct functionalization of unactivated Csp3H bonds under thermodynamically unfavorable or kinetically inert conditions, overcoming the constraints of redox potentials under mild conditions11,12. Current hydrogen atom transfer methods that directly trap the generated carbon-centered radical intermediates include the use of diverse radical acceptors as well as transition-metal-catalyzed platforms, and a series of carbon-carbon and carbon-heteroatom bond forming reactions have been success- fully achieved Fig. 1a, transition metal copper, iron, manganese, etc.1317. Among these developed protocols, Csp3H amination and etheriﬁcation stand out as unique transformations, as the incorpora- tion and manipulation of N-heterocycle, amine, and ether functional- ities on hydrocarbons would provide a plethora of opportunities for the preparation of simple building blocks and drug intermediates18. Major challenges in current Csp3H amination protocols lie in the Received: 5 December 2024 Accepted: 19 May 2025 Check for updates 1State Key Lab of Urban Water Resource and Environment, Harbin Institute of Technology Shenzhen, Shenzhen, China. 2School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Henan Normal University, Xinxiang, Henan, China. e-mail: guolinhit.edu.cn; xiawjhit.edu.cn Nature Communications 2025 16:5123 1

On the other hand, Csp3H oxygenation reaction for the construction of ether products directly from simple alkanes has been rarely reported41,42. Therefore, explora- tion of catalysts and reagents that allow the selective functionalization of unactivated hydrocarbons under more practical and functional- group-tolerant conditions and with greater generality with respect to N- and O-coupling partners would be of great value. With this in mind, we questioned whether our recent Csp3H functionalization work43, combining HAT with a photoelectrochemical approach, would be suited to the development of a mild and general protocol for Csp3H amination and etheriﬁcation. The use of elec- trons in electrochemistry as a green and economical redox reagent can overcome the high oxidation potential of alkanes in a milder and more practical way4447. Simultaneous anodic oxidation and cathodic reduction reactions enable the transformation of a mild radical med- ium, eliminating the need for proton acceptor or stoichiometric oxi- dantreductant4853. In recent years, a series of photoelectrochemical strategies based on the advantages of photochemistry and electro- chemistry have been reported, which further enrich the chemical conversion approaches5457. The successful application of photoelec- trochemical reactions with reference value provides a practical path- way for the direct Csp3H functionalization of unactivated hydrocarbons58. In this work, we present an efﬁcient copper-catalyzed Csp3H amination and etheriﬁcation protocol mediated by a photoelec- trochemical hydrogen atom transfer process. Using easily available hydrocarbons as substrates, N-heterocycles and aromatic alcohols as coupling partners, this method enables the synthesis of the corre- sponding alkylated N-heterocycles and ethers in a single step Fig. 1b. Key features of this study include: 1 the absence of external oxidant species, the use of inexpensive and readily available copper catalysts, ligands, electrolytes, additives, and solvents, along with mild reaction conditions, straightforward operation, scalability, and efﬁcient performance in batch, highlighting the methods potential for industrial application; 2 a broad substrate scope, which has been expanded not only to diverse Csp3H hydrocarbons including simple alkanes, ethers, thioethers, silanes, amides, and aldehydes, but also to a series of N- and O-coupling partners; 3 most notably, the photoelectrochemical hydrogen atom transfer process is accomplished by the addition of 9-phenylacridine as a direct hydrogen atom transfer d-HAT reagent11,12. While the use of acridine salts as photocatalysts5964, electrophilic nitrogen-centered radicals e.g., quinuclidine, amine, sulfonamide, amide, and azide as d-HAT reagents has been widely reported65,66, HAT reactions involving acridine-based N-centered radicals as cheap and easily available d-HAT reagents have not been explored yet6770. Mechanistically, our reactions are proposed to proceed via photo- excitation of the d-HAT photocatalyst PC to generate PC species, followed by hydrogen

text: amide, and azide as d-HAT reagents has been widely reported65,66, HAT reactions involving acridine-based N-centered radicals as cheap and easily available d-HAT reagents have not been explored yet6770. Mechanistically, our reactions are proposed to proceed via photo- excitation of the d-HAT photocatalyst PC to generate PC species, followed by hydrogen atom transfer with unactivated hydrocarbons, while electrochemical anodic oxidation promotes the transformation of PC-H back into PC species. Detailed mechanistic studies are further conducted to elucidate the reaction mechanism. Results Optimization studies To explore the feasibility of the assembly of Csp3N bond on unac- tivated hydrocarbons, our studies were initiated by optimizing reac- tion conditions for the reaction of 3-bromo-1H-indazole 1 and cyclohexane 2, as shown in Table 1. The photoelectrocatalytic Csp3H amination reaction was conducted in an undivided cell 10 mL oven-dried quartz tube equipped with a graphite rod anode and a platinum plate cathode. Upon electrolysis and 390 nm light irradiation, 9-phenylacridine was utilized as an efﬁcient HAT catalyst under N2 atmosphere. After an extensive evaluation of the reaction conditions, the corresponding aminated product 3 was afforded in 73 yield Table 1, entry 1, employing CuCl2 as catalyst, L1 3,4,7,8- tetramethyl-1,10-phenanthroline as supporting ligand, Cs2CO3 as base, nBu4NBF4 as electrolyte in a mixed solvent of MeCNDCM 2:1, vv under constant-current electrolysis at 3.0 mA for 6 h at room Fig. 1 Prior art in radical-mediated Csp3H functionalization and an overview of this work. a Radical-mediated Csp3H functionalization via hydrogen atom transfer. b Photoelectrochemical copper-catalyzed CH amination and etheriﬁcation this work. Article https:doi.org10.1038s41467-025-60429-6 Nature Communications 2025 16:5123 2 temperature. Notably, the use of other copper salts such as CuOTf2 led to decreased yield entry 2. Supporting ligand plays a crucial role in the reaction, as the use of L1 gave the best yield, whereas substituting L1 with ligand L2 4,7-diphenyl-1,1-phenanthroline or L3 4,4-dimethoxy- 2,2-bipyridine resulted in a substantial decrease in efﬁciency entries 3-4. The experimental results showed that the replacement of nBu4NBF4 with nBu4NPF6 as electrolyte is unfavorable to the reaction entry 5, and only a moderate yield was afforded using BTMG 2-tert- butyl-1,1,3,3-tetramethylguanidine as base entry 6. Moreover, the use of other solvents was explored but provided no improvement over mixed MeCNDCM, and replacing the platinum plate cathode with a graphite rod cathode led to lower reaction efﬁciency entries 78. In addition, the wavelength of the LEDs light source was also explored, but provided no improvement over 390 nm entry 9. The use of Eosin Y or TBADT tetrabutylammonium decatungstate instead of 9-phenylacridine led to no reaction efﬁciency entry 10. Control experiments indicated that electric current, catalysts, base and light irradiation are all essential, as the corresponding reactions performed without them resulted in poor or no reaction entries 11-13. Further investigations revealed that the reaction was performed under air atmosphere with lower yield of the desired product entry 14, indicating that the desired Csp3H amination product can be formed in the presence of oxygen, with loss of reaction efﬁciency. Exploration of Substrate Scope With the optimized reaction conditions in hand, we began to investi- gate the scope of N-heterocycles for this photoelectrochemical Csp3H amination reaction. As illustrated in Fig. 2, the N-alkylation reaction of indazoles with cyclohexane 2 was successfully demon- strated, yielding the corresponding products 312 in moderate to good yields. A range of indazole substrates bearing halide 3-4, 10-12, aldehyde 5, nitrile 6, ester 7, ketone 8 and methyl moieties 9 proceeded well under the standard conditions.It is noteworthy that the photoelectrochemical reaction can be extended to substituted pyrazole 1318, indole 1923, pyrrole 2425, carbazole 2627, triazole 2829, imidazole 30 and phthalazone 31, producing the corre- sponding amine products in moderate yields. Electron-rich N-hetero- cycles, such as 5-methoxyindole and 6-tert-butylindole, were found to be not suitable in our protocol. The substrate scope was then expanded to substituted anilines 32, aminopyridines 3337, aminopyrimidine 38, and triazinamine 39, delivering the corresponding Csp3H amination products in moderate yields. Article https:doi.org10.1038s41467-025-60429-6 Nature Communications 2025 16:5123 4 pyridinamide 49, and benzenesulfonamides 5051 proved to be viable substrates under our reaction conditions, whereas the use of N-benzylbenzamide, 2-phenylacetamide, or 2-2-triﬂuoromethylphe- nylacetamide cannot proceed with hydrocarbon as a reaction coun- terpart. Furthermore, the reaction demonstrated that N-heterocycles such as oxindole 52, isatin 53, phthalimide 54, benzimidazolone 55 and cyclic carbamate 56 were tolerated as well. Moreover, we examined the late-stage modiﬁcation of several bioactive pharmaceu- tical agents to investigate the utility of this photoelectrochemical Csp3H amination method. Theophylline, which is a commonly used alkaloid for angina treatment, was tolerated under the standard con- ditions to give Csp3H aminated product 57 in 36 yield. Furthermore, our photoelectrochemical method facilitated the direct installation of alkyl groups on the N-heterocyclic drug molecules such as irbesartan, baritinib, and olaparib, yielding the desired N-alkylated products 59 to 61 in moderate yields, thereby providing opportunities for the selective modiﬁcation of structurally complicated pharmaceuticals. The oxazo- lidinone ring in muscle-relaxant drugs such as metaxalone underwent successful Csp3H amination with cyclohexane, producing products 62 in moderate yields. Finally, a large-scale experiment of cyclohexane 2 and 3-bromo-1H-indazole 1 on a 6 mmol scale was performed in order to evaluate the practical uses of this method, which could afford 3 in 60 yield 1.00 g, see the SI for more details. Next, we explore the scope of Csp3H bond-containing hydrocarbons with 3-bromo-1H-indazole 1 under the optimal pho- toelectrochemical conditions Fig. 2. In addition to cyclohexane, other cycloalkanes bearing various ring sizes, including cyclopentane 63, cyclooctane 64 and cyclododecane 65, are all found to be viable Csp3H substrates, which were smoothly converted into the corresponding Csp3H aminated products in 45-60 yields. Nota- bly, norbornane readily reacted with 3-bromo-1H-indazole 1a to yield the product 66 in 46 yields with high regioselectivity and stereo- selectivity 95:5 r.r, 95:5 exo:endo. Adamantane bearing a rigid cage structure also exhibited interesting regioselective character- istics, with the secondary Csp3H bond of adamantane pre- ferentially aminated 67, 55:45 regioselectivity of 2:3 C H bonds. These site-selective characteristics are unlike other previously reported Csp3H functionalization reactions, in which the HAT process usually occurred at the 3 Csp3H bond64,71. text: also exhibited interesting regioselective character- istics, with the secondary Csp3H bond of adamantane pre- ferentially aminated 67, 55:45 regioselectivity of 2:3 C H bonds. These site-selective characteristics are unlike other previously reported Csp3H functionalization reactions, in which the HAT process usually occurred at the 3 Csp3H bond64,71. Several acyclic alkanes were further investigated and were found to be well com- patible under the standard reaction conditions, furnishing the desired amine products 6870 in moderate yields. Csp3H amina- tion of n-hexane gave a mixture in a combined yield of 48 68. The reaction favored the methylene groups over the distal methyl group, the site selectivity of which matched our previously reported Csp3H thiolation reaction via a photo-induced Fe-LMCT process72. Interestingly, the reaction of 2,3-dimethylbutane 69 exclusively occurred at the distal methyl position rather than weaker and steri- cally hindered 3 Csp3H bonds, which indicates that steric hin- drance also plays a key role in affecting the regioselectivity of CH amination. Upon using 1,3,5-triisopropylbenzene as a substrate, the Csp3H amination exclusively took place at the terminal isopropyl group 71, while the sterically hindered benzylic 3 CH bond was not observed. The CH amination of 1,3,5-tri-tert-butylbenzene 72 with complete regioselectivity for the methyl groups. Furthermore, our method allowed the Csp3H amination to occur preferentially at the α-methylene of cyclic ethers, with the generation of the desired products 7375 in moderate yields. Similar to these exam- ples, the Csp3H amination reaction of acyclic ethers exclusively occurred at the weak and unhindered α-oxy Csp3H position, delivering the desired aminated products 7679 in acceptable yields and complete site selectivity. Notably, a recent report by Noël and co-workers describes an accelerated photoelectrocatalytic Csp3H amination reaction enabled by continuous-ﬂow synthesis, using compounds containing weak and secondary Csp3H bonds e.g., α-oxy, α-amino, and benzylic positions as viable substrates19. Our method, however, demonstrates the capability to react not only with hydrocarbons containing stronger Csp3H bonds but also with ether compounds containing both primary and secondary α-oxy Csp3H bonds. In addition, phenyl sulﬁde also proved to be an effective substrate, giving the N-alkylated product 80 in 38 yield at the position adjacent to a sulfur atom. Photoelectrochemical Csp3H amination of various silanes was also investigated, with the observation of Csp3H amina- tion products at the distal methyl groups 8182. Notably, the reaction of tetraethylsilane 83 revealed that the steric effect still dominated the site selectivity, preferentially giving the distal methyl aminated product. Finally, amide compounds proved to be viable substrates. The Csp3H amination reaction of dimethylacetamide with 3-bromo-1H-indazole 1 successfully gave 84 in 61 yield with complete site selectivity for the weak and active α-amino position rather than the CH site adjacent to the carbonyl group. Compared to the substrate scope of peroxide-based Csp3H amination reactions32,34, our method demonstrates a sub- stantially broader substrate range, allowing for the successful amination of hydrocarbons with aniline and aminopyridine compounds. Our method is not only applicable to the amination of simple alkanes, but can also be applied to various small organic molecules containing carbon-hydrogen

text: of peroxide-based Csp3H amination reactions32,34, our method demonstrates a sub- stantially broader substrate range, allowing for the successful amination of hydrocarbons with aniline and aminopyridine compounds. Our method is not only applicable to the amination of simple alkanes, but can also be applied to various small organic molecules containing carbon-hydrogen bonds, including alkylated arenes, ethers, thioethers, silanes, and amides. After exploring the substrate scope of Csp3H amination reac- tion, we next hypothesize that the photoelectrocatalytic strategy would provide a universal platform for the Csp3H oxygenation reaction of unactivated hydrocarbons with alcohols, thus converting these readily available substrates into valuable ether products. After a series of condition optimizations see the SI for more details, the use of 9-phenylacridine and CuOTf2 benzene complex as co-catalyst, 4,7- diphenyl-1,1-phenanthroline L2 as supporting ligand, K2CO3 as base, nBu4NPF6 as electrolyte in a mixed solvent of MeCNDCE 1:1, vv upon photoirradiation and electrolysis could signiﬁcantly promote the Csp3H oxygenation reaction and obtain the target aryl ether pro- ducts. Under this optimal condition, we further extend the metho- dology to alcohol substrates to explore the substrate scope, as shown in Fig. 3. Expectedly, a myriad of phenols containing electron-donat- ingneutral 8590, 102103 and electron-withdrawing 91101 substituents were both successfully coupled with cyclohexane to give the corresponding aryl ether products in moderate to good yields. Notably, aryl halides 9193 groups were tolerated well in this C O cross-coupling reaction. Other important functional groups such as triﬂuoromethyl 94, sulfonyl 95, cyano 96, alkynyl 97, ketone 9899, and ester 100 were all compatible under the photoelec- trochemical conditions. A key intermediate in the production and modiﬁcation of lipid-lowering drug fenoﬁbrate can also react 98. Notably, both aryl boronate ester 101 and amide 102103 moieties were also tolerated. This method can be well applied to polycyclic aromatic ring 104. It was notable to see that hydroxy-substituted heterocycles containing benzooxazole 105, isobenzofuranone 106, dihydrobenzofuran 107, and dihydroquinolinone 108, a crucial intermediate in the synthesis of the antipsychotic medication aripi- prazole moieties were also compatible to afford the corresponding aromatic ether products 105108 in moderate yields. Furthermore, the current Csp3O cross-coupling method was applied to the late- stage etheriﬁcation of natural products and molecular drugs. Natural phenolic compounds such as raspberry ketone 109 and estrone 110, as well as pharmaceutically relevant substances such as L-tyr- osine derivatives 111 and ezetimide 112, underwent the photoelec- trochemical reactions with cyclohexane to gain the corresponding aryl ether products in moderate yields. Alkanols and carboxylic acids were also tested under the standard conditions for C O bond construction, but the reactions did not provide any positive results. In addition to C O bond formation, the scope of other nucleophiles for the Article https:doi.org10.1038s41467-025-60429-6 Nature Communications 2025 16:5123 5 construction of Csp3P, Csp3Se and Csp3S bonds was subse- quently explored. The ﬂame retardant intermediates 9,10-dihydro-9- oxa-10-phosphaphenanthrene 10-oxide DOPO and phenylselenol could be reacted well and provided 113 and 114 in moderate yields.
