text: 5 construction of Csp3P, Csp3Se and Csp3S bonds was subse- quently explored. The ﬂame retardant intermediates 9,10-dihydro-9- oxa-10-phosphaphenanthrene 10-oxide DOPO and phenylselenol could be reacted well and provided 113 and 114 in moderate yields. Thiophenols containing either electron-donating 115 or electron- withdrawing 116117 substituents were both coupled to give the corresponding thioethers in acceptable yields. The success of all the above-mentioned substrates, many of which contain sensitive alkyne, carbonyl, halide or heterocyclic groups, underscores the high che- moselectivity and functional group compatibility of our developed method. Next, the scope of C H bond-containing hydrocarbons for Csp3O bond formation was assessed. As shown in Fig. 3, various cycloalkanes were all found to be suitable Csp3H substrates Fig. 3 Substrate scope of Csp3H oxygenation. Reaction conditions: undivided cell, graphite rod anode φ 6 mm, platinum plate cathode 15 10 0.2 mm3, aryl alcohol 0.3 mmol, 1.0 equiv., hydrocarbon 3.0 mmol, 10.0 equiv., 9-phenylacridine 0.03 mmol, 10 mol, CuOTf2C6H6 0.06 mmol, 20 mol, 4,7-diphenyl-1,1-phenanthroline L2 0.06 mmol, 20 mol, K2CO3 0.3 mmol, 1.0 equiv., nBu4NPF6 0.60 mmol, 2.0 equiv., 0.2 M and anhydrous MeCN:DCE 1:1 vv, 3.0 mL, constant current 3 mA, 390 nm LEDs 10 W under N2 atmosphere at room temperature for 10 h 3.7 Fmol1. Yields of isolated products after chroma- tographic puriﬁcation. Regioselectivity r.r. and diastereomeric ratio d.r. were determined by 1H NMR analysis. aThe reaction was performed on a 6.0 mmol scale. Article https:doi.org10.1038s41467-025-60429-6 Nature Communications 2025 16:5123 6 118121, which were smoothly converted into the corresponding alkyl aryl ethers in 41-60 yields. Norbornane, as a viable substrate, could readily react with 4-phenylphenol to give the corresponding product 122 in 36 yield. Our method also showed the successful validation of Csp3H oxygenation of adamantane 123, with the occurrence of HAT process at the tertiary C H bond. Moreover, the Csp3O coupling of n-pentane 124 was found to effectively afford a mixture of ether products in a combined yield of 48, and the reaction favored the methylene groups over the distal methyl group. Similar to Csp3H amination protocol, our method allowed the Csp3H oxy- genation reaction to occur preferentially at the α-oxy position of cyclic and acyclic ethers 125130, indicating that the reaction favors the Csp3H functionalization of weak and sterically unhindered Csp3H bonds. Thioanisole proceeded well under the standard conditions 131. Notably, the Csp3O coupling of tetraethylsilane 132 revealed that the steric effect still dominated the site selectivity, preferentially giving the distal methyl Csp3O coupling product. The reaction of 4- methyl-1-pentene was also feasible 133, with the occurrence of Csp3H oxygenation exclusively at the weak allylic position. 2,3- Dimethyl-2-butene was demonstrated to be compatible with the method, furnishing the desired Csp3O coupling product 134 in 66 yield. It is noteworthy that the Csp3O coupling of aldehyde substrate 135136 delivered the corresponding ester products in moderate yields with complete site-selectivity at the CacylH bond. text: is noteworthy that the Csp3O coupling of aldehyde substrate 135136 delivered the corresponding ester products in moderate yields with complete site-selectivity at the CacylH bond. Further- more, the reaction of dimethylacetamide with 4-phenylphenolatthe α- amino position was also exclusively observed 137. Mechanistic studies In order to get a deeper insight into the reaction mechanism, several mechanistic experiments were then carried out, as shown in Fig. 4. Firstly, the model reactions of Csp3H amination and etheriﬁcation were both strongly suppressed by a radical trapping experiment using 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl TEMPO as the radical scavenger Fig. 4a. The formation of the corresponding adduct 1-cyclohex- yloxy-2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine 139 between TEMPO and cyclo- hexyl radical was observed and isolated see the SI for more details, with no detection of the expected Csp3H amination and etheriﬁca- tion products 3 and 85. Both of these results indicated that a radical pathway and key alkyl radical species might be involved in these two photoelectrochemical transformations. In order to further capture the key radical intermediates, an electron paramagnetic resonance EPR experiment was performed with the addition of a free radical spin trap 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide DMPO, as shown in Fig. 4b. The EPR spectroscopy studies revealed that a carbon-centered radical species were generated from the corresponding alkane substrate via an intermolecular HAT process and rapidly captured by DMPO to form relatively stable free radicals g 2.0074, AN 14.62 G, AH 21.54 G7376. To gain more insights into the hydrogen atom transfer HAT species, several control experiments were conducted in the absence of N-heterocycles or alcohols, as shown in Fig. 4c. Considering nitrogen radicals are prone to undergoing the HAT process65,66, the photoelec- trochemical reaction of 9-phenylacridine with cyclohexane 2 was then conducted in the absence of copper catalyst and supporting ligand, and yielded compound 141 in 16 yield as the major product. Notably, the yield of 141 was increased to 53 without constant cur- rent. This result indicated that the HAT species in this reaction is highly likely to be the nitrogen radical species formed by photoexcitation of 9-phenylacridine for the UV-Vis spectrum, see the SI for more details. The nitrogen radical extracted hydrogen from the alkane substrate to generate a transient alkyl radical 143 and a persistent triarylmethyl trityl radical 142, which would further undergo radical-radical coupling to release the ﬁnal product 141. Similar results were afforded with the utilization of mesitylene 144 or 1,3,5-trimethoxybenzene 146 as the hydrocarbon substrate instead of cyclohexane, and the reactions successfully delivered the corresponding radical addition products 145 and 147 in 50 and 45 yields, respectively. Support for this mechanism was also provided by the formation of isotopically labeled product 141-D in 56 yield upon photo-induced reaction of 9-phenylacridine with deuterated cyclohexane 2-d12. The lower NH deuterium incorporation 12 D obtained in the product 141-D may be due to fast deuterium-proton exchange. Kinetic isotope effect KIE experiments were subsequently performed to explore whether the HAT step was the rate-determining step of the overall reaction process, as shown in Fig. 4d. The photoelectrochemical reaction of 3-bromo-1H-

text: NH deuterium incorporation 12 D obtained in the product 141-D may be due to fast deuterium-proton exchange. Kinetic isotope effect KIE experiments were subsequently performed to explore whether the HAT step was the rate-determining step of the overall reaction process, as shown in Fig. 4d. The photoelectrochemical reaction of 3-bromo-1H- indazole 1 with equal amounts of cyclohexane 2 and deuterated cyclohexane 2-d12 for 3 h under the standard conditions produced a mixture of CH amination products 3 and isotopically labeled 3-d11 in 32 yield. The obtained ratio kHkD 2.1 suggests that the HAT pro- cess is a turnover-limiting step in the overall reaction. A similar ratio kHkD 1.8 was obtained for the KIE of Csp3H etheriﬁcation under optimal reaction conditions, suggesting that the hydrogendeuterium atom extraction step may also be turnover-limiting. Having demonstrated the key intermediates in the reaction pro- cess, we next set out to investigate the origin of the site selectivity produced in the Csp3H functionalization reaction. As shown in Fig. 4e, we utilized 2,3-dimethylbutane DMB, 148 as a standard sub- strate to probe the site selectivity74,77,78. The control reaction showed that the addition of phenyl acrylate 149 to the standard photoelec- trochemical system containing DMB and 3-bromo-1H-indazole 1 successfully afforded Csp3H alkylation product 150 in 37 yield, with the alkylation preferentially occurring at 3 CH bond intrinsic selectivity of 13 is 1:13, which was calculated by the number of available Csp3H bonds. Electrolysis and photoirradiation of the same starting materials in the presence of 9-phenylacridine without copper also afforded the Csp3H alkylated product 150 in 42 yield. The above results conﬁrm the reversible HAT process for the forma- tion of carbon-centered radicals and imply that the use of radical acceptors largely inﬂuences the site selectivity43,72. To further prove the effectiveness of 9-phenylacridine as a d-HAT reagent, a series of radical-mediated Csp3H functionalization reac- tions of hydrocarbons were conducted under photo-induced reaction conditions Fig. 4f. The use of alkynyl sulfone 151 as an efﬁcient radical acceptor could successfully deliver the corresponding Csp3H alkynylation product 152 in 70 yield. Although the use of diphenyl disulﬁde 153 showed less efﬁciency for Csp3H thiolation, the desired Csp3H selenylation reaction could proceed very well to give the alkyl selenide product 114 in 73 yield. Furthermore, a divided-cell experiment was carried out Fig. 4g, with the placement of substrates 1 and 2 along with 9-phenylacridine, CuCl2, L1, Cs2CO3, nBu4NBF4 and solvent in the anode chamber, while nBu4NBF4 and solvent were added into the cathode chamber. As expected, the desired Csp3H amination product 3 was detected in the anode chamber with 40 yield, which suggested that the photoelec- trochemical Csp3H amination occurred mainly around the graphite rod anode. Similarly, the formation of the desired product 85 was observed in the anode chamber under the standard conditions of Csp3H etheriﬁcation, revealing that the photoelectrochemical Csp3H etheriﬁcation also took place mainly around the graphite rod anode rather than around the platinum plate cathode. Based on the above mechanistic studies and relevant literature reports59,79, we proposed a

text: product 85 was observed in the anode chamber under the standard conditions of Csp3H etheriﬁcation, revealing that the photoelectrochemical Csp3H etheriﬁcation also took place mainly around the graphite rod anode rather than around the platinum plate cathode. Based on the above mechanistic studies and relevant literature reports59,79, we proposed a plausible reaction mechanism for the photoelectrochemical Csp3H amination and etheriﬁcation. Taking the Csp3H amination reaction as an example, which is outlined in Fig. 5, we postulated that the reaction is initiated from the excitation of the acridine-based photocatalyst A to generate the excited species B. Then, the excited species B undergoes a hydrogen atom transfer HAT process with unactivated hydrocarbons to release a key carbon- centered radical intermediate D, while generating a persistent triar- ylmethyl trityl radical 1428082. Subsequently, intermediate 142 is Article https:doi.org10.1038s41467-025-60429-6 Nature Communications 2025 16:5123 7 electrochemically oxidized to triarylmethyl cation at the anode sur- face, followed by an elimination process to regenerate the 9-phenylacridine photocatalyst. On the other hand, the released carbon-centered radical D reacts with the copper complex H to gen- erate a CuIII species I, which undergoes reductive elimination to produce the Csp3H amination product J. Furthermore, the Fig. 4 Mechanistic studies. a Capture of alkyl radical by TEMPO, b Electron paramagnetic resonance EPR experiment, c Capture of trityl radical, d Kinetic isotopic effect KIE experiment, e Investigation of the site selectivity, f Photo- induced Csp3H alkynylation, thiolation and selenylation reactions enabled by 9-phenylacridine as d-HAT photocatalyst, g Divided-cell experiment. Article https:doi.org10.1038s41467-025-60429-6 Nature Communications 2025 16:5123 8 reduced catalyst E is electrochemically oxidized to a CuII species F on the anode, and intermediate F reacts with N-heterocycles to form species H and closes both catalytic cycles. Discussion In summary, we have developed a mild and efﬁcient Csp3H func- tionalization method enabled by a photoelectrochemical strategy. Using 9-phenylacridine as a direct hydrogen atom transfer d-HAT reagent under 390 nm LED light irradiation and electrolysis, this syn- thetic approach is capable of preparing various types of aliphatic N-heterocycle and ether compounds from hydrocarbons. Our meth- odology greatly extends the range of available substrates not only for N-heterocycles and phenol derivatives, but also for a wide variety of Csp3H compounds, including unactivated alkanes, ethers, thioe- thers, silanes, and amides. The mild reaction conditions, operational simplicity, remarkably broad substrate scope 135 examples, as well as scalability, demonstrate that the method has potential for industrial application. Importantly, the reaction exhibits unconventional site selectivity, with the occurrence of both Csp3H amination and etheriﬁcation preferentially at the sterically unhindered position. Considering the importance and versatility of N-heterocycle, amine, amide, and ether compounds as important functional molecules in organic synthesis, we believe that the method we have developed has the potential to be a versatile tool for chemists, offering a plethora of opportunities for selective installation of valuable functional groups at the late stage. Further development of other types of photo-induced and electrochemical reactions is still underway in our lab. text: be a versatile tool for chemists, offering a plethora of opportunities for selective installation of valuable functional groups at the late stage. Further development of other types of photo-induced and electrochemical reactions is still underway in our lab. Methods General procedure for photoelectrochemical Csp3H amination In a glove box ﬁlled with nitrogen, a 20 mL oven-dried quartz tube with a stir bar was charged the N-heterocycle substrate 0.3 mmol, 1 equiv., unactivated alkane 3.0 mmol, 10 equiv., 9-phenylacridine 0.03 mmol, 10 mol, CuCl2 0.06 mmol, 20 mol, 3,4,7,8-tetra- methyl-1,10-phenanthroline L1 0.06 mmol, 20 mol, Cs2CO3 0.3 mmol, 1 equiv., nBu4NBF4 0.15 mmol, 0.5 equiv., 0.05 M and anhydrous MeCN:DCM 2:1 vv, 3.0 mL. The tube was equipped with a carbon rod φ 6 mm anode and a platinum plate cathode15 10 0.2 mm3, and the tubes were then sealed and taken out from the glove box. The reaction mixture was irradiated with 390 nm LED lamps 10 W and 3.0 mA electrolysis for 6 h. The distance between electrodes was approximately 0.5 cm, and the length below the liquid surface was 1.0 cm. Upon completion of the reaction, the reaction yield was monitored by TLC or GC-MS. Subsequently, the solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the resulting mix- ture was puriﬁed by column chromatography on silica gel eluted with petroleum etherethyl acetate to afford the desired pure product. General procedure for photoelectrochemical Csp3H etheriﬁcation In a glove box ﬁlled with nitrogen, a 20 mL oven-dried quartz tube with a stir bar was charged the phenol or phenylthiophenol substrate 0.3 mmol, 1 equiv, unactivated alkane 3.0 mmol, 10 equiv, 9-phenylacridine 0.03 mmol, 10 mol, CuOTf2C6H6 0.06 mmol, 20 mol, 4,7-diphenyl-1,1-phenanthroline L2 0.06 mmol, 20 mol, K2CO3 0.6 mmol, 2 equiv., nBu4NPF6 0.6 mmol, 2 equiv., 0.2 M and anhydrous MeCN:DCE 1:1 vv, 3.0 mL. The tube was equipped with a carbon rod φ 6 mm anode and a platinum plate 15 10 0.2 mm3 cathode, and the tubes were then sealed and taken out the glove box. The reaction mixture was irradiated with 390 nm LED lamps 10 W and 3.0 mA electrolysis for 10 h. The dis- tance between electrodes was approximately 0.5 cm, and the length below the liquid surface was 1.0 cm. Upon completion of the reac- tion, the reaction yield was monitored by TLC or GC-MS. Subse- quently, the solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the resulting mixture was puriﬁed by column chromatography on silica gel eluted with petroleum etherethyl acetate to afford the desired pure product. Data availability Materials and methods, optimization studies, experimental proce- dures, mechanistic studies, 1H NMR spectra, 13C NMR spectra and mass spectrometry data generated in this study are provided in the Sup- plementary Information ﬁle. Source data are provided with this paper. Data supporting the ﬁndings of this manuscript are also available from the corresponding author upon request. Source data are provided with this paper. text: Fully Exposed Cu Clusters with Ru Single Atoms Synergy for High- Performance Acetylene Semihydrogenation Chengquan Sui,Wanni Dong,Maolin Wang,Fei Huang, Shengling Xiang, Hui Wang, Jiawei Chen, Chengyu Li, Mi Peng, Ning Wang, Geng Sun, Ding Ma, and Hongyang Liu Cite This: J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2025, 147, 1980819816 Read Online ACCESS Metrics More Article Recommendations sı Supporting Information ABSTRACT: Semihydrogenation of acetylene is an essential process in the ethylene industry for removing acetylene impurities and ensuring the production of polymer-grade ethylene. Atomically dispersed Cu catalysts have attracted significant attention due to their cost-effectiveness and catalytic potential. However, the inherently weak hydrogen dissociation ability of Cu results in low catalytic activity, necessitating elevated reaction temperatures, which limit its practical applicability. To overcome this limitation, we design a Ru single-atom-decorated, fully exposed Cu cluster catalyst Ru1CunSiO2 that exhibits outstanding performance in semihydrogenation of acetylene, achieving 100 acetylene conversion with 98 ethylene selectivity at 170 C. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy HAADF-STEM, X-ray absorption spectroscopy XAS, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XPS confirm the atomic dispersion of Ru and the structural evolution of Cu clusters. H2D2 exchange and temperature-programmed desorption TPD experiments reveal that Ru modification significantly enhances the hydrogen dissociation ability of the catalyst while tuning acetylene adsorption. Density functional theory DFT calculations further demonstrate that the Ru single atoms and Cu nanoclusters create a synergistic catalytic interface that markedly promotes hydrogen activation and lowers the energy barrier of the rate-determining step. This study provides fundamental insights into the rational design of atomically dispersed bimetallic catalysts and offers a new strategy for the efficient and selective acetylene hydrogenation. INTRODUCTION The semihydrogenation of acetylene is a critical catalytic reaction in the ethylene industry, as even trace amounts of acetylene 0.20.5 vol in the feedstock can poison the ZieglerNatta catalyst used in downstream polymerization.1,2 Therefore, the development of highly efficient catalysts for acetylene semihydrogenation is essential to ensure the selective conversion of acetylene to ethylene while minimizing over- hydrogenation to undesired ethane. Palladium Pd is one of the most active metals for this reaction.3 However, supported Pd nanoparticles NPs often result in poor ethylene selectivity. Achieving an optimal balance between the catalytic activity and ethylene selectivity in Pd NPs remains a significant challenge. To address this, various strategies, such as metal alloying,46 interface modification,7 and coordination environ- ment regulation,810 have been explored to improve the ethylene selectivity of Pd NPs. Despite extensive research on optimizing Pd-based catalysts, their high cost and scarcity necessitate the development of alternative, cost-effective catalytic systems. As a result, Cu- based catalysts have emerged as promising alternatives due to their cost-effectiveness and superior ability to suppress overhydrogenation,1116 thereby enhancing olefin selectiv- ity.1720 Atomically dispersed Cu catalysts, in particular, have demonstrated remarkable ethylene selectivity and stability, in stark contrast to the rapid deactivation observed in Cu nanoparticle catalysts.2125 However, suffering from the inherently weak hydrogen dissociation ability of Cu, Cu- based catalysts exhibit low catalytic activity and typically require high reaction temperatures above 200 C, limiting the potential to scale up

metadata.title: Sui 等 - 2025 - Fully exposed Cu clusters with Ru single atoms synergy for high-performance acetylene semihydrogenation.pdf

text: remarkable ethylene selectivity and stability, in stark contrast to the rapid deactivation observed in Cu nanoparticle catalysts.2125 However, suffering from the inherently weak hydrogen dissociation ability of Cu, Cu- based catalysts exhibit low catalytic activity and typically require high reaction temperatures above 200 C, limiting the potential to scale up for industrial application. To overcome this limitation, recent studies have focused on atomically dispersed bimetallic catalysts, such as CuZnNC2,26 Ni1Cu2g-C3N4,27 and Pd1Cu1NDG,28 which leverage the synergistic effect of incorporating a secondary metal to modulate the electronic structure and surface properties. This modification has been shown to enhance the catalytic Received: March 2, 2025 Revised: May 24, 2025 Accepted: May 27, 2025 Published: May 31, 2025 Article pubs.acs.orgJACS 2025 American Chemical Society 19808 https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c03713 J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2025, 147, 1980819816 Downloaded via TSINGHUA UNIV on June 16, 2025 at 12:07:40 UTC. See https:pubs.acs.orgsharingguidelines for options on how to legitimately share published articles. performance. Moreover, the construction of decoupled active sites mitigates competitive adsorption effects, optimizing selectivity and activity in acetylene hydrogenation.29 Inspired by these, in this study, we report a SiO2-supported atomically dispersed bimetallic catalyst including Ru single atoms and fully exposed Cu clusters Ru1CunSiO2. More- over, Ru1CunSiO2 exhibits high catalytic activity while maintaining exceptional ethylene selectivity during complete acetylene conversion. Through a combination of electron microscopy, X-ray absorption spectroscopy, and theoretical modeling, we identify the active site as a Ru single atom coordinated with a Cu3 cluster. Density functional theory DFT calculations reveal that the introduction of trace Ru atoms significantly enhances the hydrogen dissociation ability of the Ru1Cu3 cluster compared to Cu3 alone. Hydrogen molecules preferentially dissociate on Ru single atoms and then react with acetylene adsorbed on Cu clusters. Furthermore, the energy barrier for the rate-determining step CHCH2 C2H4 is substantially lowered on the Ru1Cu3 cluster, facilitating ethylene generation. These findings highlight the crucial role of RuCu synergy in optimizing catalytic performance, providing valuable insights for the design of novel, highly efficient, and ultrastable atomically dispersed metal catalysts. The Ru1CunSiO2 catalyst was synthesized via a strong electrostatic adsorption method, followed by H2 reduction at 300 C see the Methods section in Supporting Information for details. The Cu cluster regions are noted with dashed yellow quadrangles. Ru atoms observed within the marked region are indicated with dashed white circles. Figure 2. a Ru K-edge XANES profiles and b Ru K-edge EXAFS spectra of Ru1SiO2, Ru1CunSiO2, Ru foil, and RuO2. c Cu K-edge XANES profiles and d Cu K-edge EXAFS spectra of Cu1SiO2, Ru1CunSiO2, Cu foil, Cu2O, and CuO. Soc. 2025, 147, 1980819816 19809 corresponding monometal catalysts Cu1SiO2 and Ru1SiO2 with identical metal loadings were prepared using the same method. The metal loadings of the catalysts were determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry ICP-AES Table S1. Transmission electron microscopy TEM image of the nanosilica support reveals an average diameter of 15 nm Figure S1. Comprehensive character- ization of the Ru1CunSiO2 catalyst was performed to understand its structure. X-ray diffraction XRD analysis Figure S2 of catalysts exclusively displays characteristic SiO2 diffraction peaks, with no detectable peaks corresponding to metallic Ru or Cu, indicating the absence of crystalline Ru or Cu nanoparticles in Ru1CunSiO2. The structure of Ru1Cun SiO2 was investigated by High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy HAADF-STEM Figures 1 and S3. HAADF-STEM image Figure 1a reveals uniform dispersion of small clusters on the SiO2 support, with a magnified view confirming their amorphous structure inset. The HAADF-STEM images and the intensity profiles in Figure S3 further support a single-atom-layer configuration of the fully exposed clusters. The corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray EDX elemental mapping results show that Ru species are highly dispersed on the surface of SiO2, while Cu species are in the form of subnano-Cu clusters Figure 1b. Moreover, we marked the Cu cluster area at the same position on Ru mapping in Figure 1b. Notably, there are Ru atoms distributed close to the Cu cluster within the area as marked in the figure the dashed white circles. Thus, the EDX results corroborate the coexistence of atomically dispersed Ru atoms and fully exposed Cu clusters on the catalyst surface. To investigate the coordination and electronic structures of the catalysts, X-ray absorption spectroscopy XAS Figure 2 and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XPS measurements were performed. The Ru K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure XANES spectra of Ru1SiO2 and Ru1CunSiO2 indicate that the Ru atoms are in an oxidized state Figure 2a. Additionally, fitting results of extended X-ray absorption fine structure EXAFS Figure S4 and Table S2 support the atomic dispersion of the Ru species through the absence of a RuRu path and similar RuO paths in both Ru1SiO2 and Ru1CunSiO2. The Cu K-edge XANES spectra Figure 2c show that both Ru1CunSiO2 and Cu1SiO2 have absorption Figure 3. Journal of the American Chemical Society pubs.acs.orgJACS Article https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c03713 J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2025, 147, 1980819816 19810 edges between those of Cu foil and CuO, with Ru1CunSiO2 exhibiting a more reduced Cu valence state. Notably, Ru1Cun SiO2 reveals a CuCu path with an average coordination number C.N. of 3.2 0.8, whereas no CuCu coordination is observed in Cu1SiO2 Figure S5 and Table S3. These findings indicate the formation of Cu clusters in Ru1CunSiO2, in contrast to the Cu single atoms in Cu1SiO2. The above results demonstrate the existence of Ru single atoms and fully exposed Cu clusters in the Ru1CunSiO2 catalysts. Despite both catalysts being treated under the same reduction conditions, the Cu species in Ru1CunSiO2 were reduced more deeply than those in Cu1SiO2. The structural evolution to Cu clusters in Ru1CunSiO2 suggests that the introduction of Ru single atoms promotes the reduction of Cu species to clusters in Ru1CunSiO2 without requiring high reduction temperatures. Therefore, the CunSiO2 catalyst reduced to 500 C, with metallic Cu clusters as the active sites, was synthesized for comparison. Notably, this high- temperature-reduced monometal sample provides an impor- tant reference for highlighting the unique structural regulatory role of Ru in this bimetallic system. XAS measurements confirm the Cu cluster structure in CunSiO2 Figure S6. The EXAFS curve fitting data at the Cu K-edge Table S4 shows a CuCu coordination number of 3.6 1.0, which is similar to that in Ru1CunSiO2 C.N. 3.2 0.8. This indicates that the introduction of Ru reduces the reduction temperature required for Cu species to form clusters while avoiding possible metal aggregation under high-temperature reduction condi- tions, which emphasizes the critical role of Ru atoms in regulating the Cu structure in the Ru1CunSiO2 catalyst. XPS measurements were conducted after in situ reduction Figure S7. The Cu 2p XPS peak observed at 932.3 eV in Ru1CunSiO2 can be attributed to Cu0 or Cu species, suggesting the formation of metallic Cu clusters during the reduction process. The first-derivative XANES spectra further reveal the distinct Cu valence states between the Ru1CunSiO2 and CunSiO2 catalysts Figure S8. The Cu species in Ru1CunSiO2 exhibit a Cuδ 0 δ 1 state close to the Cu valence state. In contrast, the high-temperature reduction process employed for CunSiO2 leads to the formation of large Cu clusters, wherein the Cu species in CunSiO2 display a lower valence state than that in Ru1CunSiO2, due to the contribution of increased Cu0 species. These results reveal that Ru1CunSiO2 preserves a higher proportion of Cu species compared to CunSiO2. Therefore, we propose that Ru1CunSiO2 possesses a unique dual-site structure consisting of Ru single atoms and fully exposed Cu clusters, whereas fully exposed Cu clusters are

text: Ru1CunSiO2, due to the contribution of increased Cu0 species. These results reveal that Ru1CunSiO2 preserves a higher proportion of Cu species compared to CunSiO2. Therefore, we propose that Ru1CunSiO2 possesses a unique dual-site structure consisting of Ru single atoms and fully exposed Cu clusters, whereas fully exposed Cu clusters are expected to optimize the reactant adsorption due to their abundant sites,30 with Ru single atoms showing potential to optimize hydrogen activation.31,32 Catalytic Performance. To elucidate the role of Ru single atoms and Cu clusters in Ru1CunSiO2, we evaluated the catalytic performance of Ru1CunSiO2, CunSiO2, Cu1SiO2, and Ru1SiO2 for acetylene hydrogenation. The reactions were carried out using a gas mixture of C2H2H2C2H4 1:10:20. Figure 3a presents the acetylene conversion and ethylene selectivity as functions of reaction temperature for different catalysts. The Ru1CunSiO2 catalyst achieved complete acetylene conversion at 170 C with an ethylene selectivity of 97.6, outperforming other catalysts. In contrast, the conversion of CunSiO2 reached only 74 at 200 C, while Cu1SiO2 exhibited a conversion of a mere 13 under the same conditions. These results confirm that Cu clusters exhibit significantly higher catalytic activity than Cu single atoms, consistent with the well-estimated size effect reported in the literature.22 Notably, the Ru1CunSiO2 catalyst not only lowered the temperature required for full conversion compared to its monometallic counterparts but also maintained a high ethylene selectivity even at full conversion. The slight decline in selectivity at high temperatures is attributed to the formation of C4 byproducts 1,3-butadiene and isobutylene, with no ethane production detected Figure S9. These results show that the Ru1CunSiO2 catalyst has an excellent ability to inhibit overhydrogenation. The substantial enhancement in catalytic activity observed for Ru1CunSiO2 compared to CunSiO2 highlights the critical role of Ru atoms in promoting hydrogenation activity. In contrast, Ru1SiO2 displayed negligible activity within the studied temperature range, indicating that Ru single atoms alone are not capable of catalyzing acetylene hydrogenation. Furthermore, a physical mixture of the two monometallic catalysts exhibited poor catalytic performance compared with Ru1CunSiO2, reinforcing that the observed enhancement arises from a genuine synergistic effect rather than a simple combination of the two supported metal catalysts. At 170 C, the specific activity of Ru1CunSiO2 was determined to be 34.02 molC d2H d2molCu 1h1, approximately 5.3 times higher than that of CunSiO2 Figure 3b. The kinetic analysis further confirmed the superior intrinsic activity of Ru1CunSiO2, revealing an apparent activation energy Ea of 42.23 kJmol, significantly lower than that of CunSiO2 60.72 kJmol Figure 3c. These results comprehensively confirm that Ru single atoms and Cu clusters synergistically enhanced the acetylene hydrogenation performance of Ru1CunSiO2. As a result, the Ru1CunSiO2 catalyst achieves full conversion at markedly lower temperatures and imparts outstanding ethylene selectivity for acetylene semihydrogenation. Additionally, Ru1CunSiO2 maintained excellent catalytic performance under high gas hourly space velocity GHSV conditions, achieving complete conversion below 200 C while sustaining ethylene selectivity above 90 Figure S10. Catalyst stability is a crucial factor in the long-term viability of acetylene semihydrogenation. To evaluate the durability of Ru1CunSiO2, continuous reaction tests were

metadata.title: Sui 等 - 2025 - Fully exposed Cu clusters with Ru single atoms synergy for high-performance acetylene semihydrogenation.pdf

text: Ru1CunSiO2 maintained excellent catalytic performance under high gas hourly space velocity GHSV conditions, achieving complete conversion below 200 C while sustaining ethylene selectivity above 90 Figure S10. Catalyst stability is a crucial factor in the long-term viability of acetylene semihydrogenation. To evaluate the durability of Ru1CunSiO2, continuous reaction tests were conducted under the conditions of complete conversion T 170 C and high acetylene conversion about 90, T 165 C, respectively. As shown in Figure 3d, the Ru1CunSiO2 catalyst showed exceptional stability at high conversion, maintaining its activity without noticeable deactivation for over 20 h. Moreover, a durability test under full conversion conditions confirmed that the ethylene selectivity remained stable for over 55 h, indicating a high structural stability of the catalyst Figure S11. The exceptional stability of the Ru1CunSiO2 catalyst can be attributed to the following factors. The decreased reaction temperature for complete acetylene conversion suppresses the formation of C4 byproducts, while maintaining high ethylene selectivity at high acetylene conversion, thus reducing the risk of inactivation due to the accumulation of C4 byproducts. To further benchmark the catalytic performance of Ru1Cun SiO2, we compared its catalytic performance with that of state- of-the-art catalysts reported in the literature Table S5. The specific activity, measured as the volume of acetylene converted per minute per gram of active metal, was determined Journal of the American Chemical Society pubs.acs.orgJACS Article https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c03713 J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2025, 147, 1980819816 19811 to be 400 mLC d2H d2gCu 1min1. Notably, Ru1CunSiO2 not only achieves complete conversion but also maintains high ethylene selectivity, surpassing that of most literature-reported catalysts Figure 3e. These comparative results show the exceptional catalytic efficiency and promising potential of Ru1CunSiO2 for acetylene semihydrogenation. Additionally, a series of RuxCu0.5SiO2 catalysts with different Ru loadings x ranges from 0.02 to 0.5 wt were prepared by simply adjusting the amount of Ru precursor. The catalytic performance of these RuxCu0.5SiO2 catalysts with different RuCu ratios for the semihydrogenation of acetylene is shown in Figure S12. It is found that when the Ru loading is reduced to 0.02 wt , the Ru0.02Cu0.5SiO2 catalyst achieves complete acetylene conversion at 170 C with an ethylene selectivity of 93.6. The results reveal that the promotion of hydrogenation catalytic performance can still be obtained by introducing only small amounts of Ru single atoms. However, when the Ru loading increased to 0.5 wt , a decrease in catalytic activity was observed. This is possibly due to the formation of Ru clusters in Ru0.5Cu0.5SiO2 with an increase in Ru loading, leading to a decrease in the number of Ru single atom and Cu cluster active sites. Collectively, these findings demonstrate the key role of the synergistic interplay between Ru1Cun dual sites in Ru1CunSiO2 in greatly enhancing the catalytic performance. Reaction Mechanism Study. To elucidate the remarkable enhancement in catalytic performance observed for the Ru1CunSiO2 catalyst, we conducted a comprehensive investigation, integrating experimental characterization and theoretical analysis. Given the critical role of hydrogen dissociation in hydrogenation reactions, H2D2 exchange experiments were performed to evaluate the H2

metadata.source: /Users/zemao/ChemQA/data/raw_papers/Sui 等 - 2025 - Fully exposed Cu clusters with Ru single atoms synergy for high-performance acetylene semihydrogenation.pdf
metadata.title: Sui 等 - 2025 - Fully exposed Cu clusters with Ru single atoms synergy for high-performance acetylene semihydrogenation.pdf

text: enhancing the catalytic performance. Reaction Mechanism Study. To elucidate the remarkable enhancement in catalytic performance observed for the Ru1CunSiO2 catalyst, we conducted a comprehensive investigation, integrating experimental characterization and theoretical analysis. Given the critical role of hydrogen dissociation in hydrogenation reactions, H2D2 exchange experiments were performed to evaluate the H2 activation ability of the catalysts Figure S13. The temperature at which HD formation is detected serves as an indicator of the H2 activation. For Ru1CunSiO2, the HD signal initiates at 47 C, closely resembling the behavior of Ru1SiO2 45 C, suggesting that Ru single atoms in Ru1CunSiO2 serve as the primary active sites for H2 dissociation. In contrast, CunSiO2 exhibits a significantly higher HD formation temperature of 83 C, indicating a weaker hydrogen activation capability of Cu clusters compared to Ru single atoms. These findings strongly suggest that Ru atoms in the Ru1CunSiO2 catalyst play a pivotal role in H2 activation, thereby facilitating the hydro- genation process. To further investigate the acetylene adsorption behavior, we performed temperature-programmed desorption TPD experiments Figure S14. The C2H2-TPD profiles of both Ru1CunSiO2 and CunSiO2 catalysts exhibit a desorption peak at 135 C, likely due to the C2H2 desorption on the isolated Cu atoms. Moreover, Ru1CunSiO2 displays a distinct desorption peak at 214 C, corresponding to moderate acetylene adsorption on fully exposed Cu clusters. However, CunSiO2 exhibits a high-temperature peak at 243 C, associated with strong acetylene adsorption on larger Cu clusters or particles. Excessive acetylene adsorption is known to promote the undesired acetylene coupling reaction, thereby diminishing ethylene selectivity. These results confirm that fully exposed Cu clusters serve as the primary acetylene adsorption sites in Ru1CunSiO2, striking a balance between sufficient acetylene activation and suppression of undesired side reactions. To assess the intrinsic reactivity of Ru1CunSiO2 and Cun SiO2 in acetylene hydrogenation, we conducted temperature- programmed surface reaction TPSR analyses using ethylene signals as a probe for CC bond activation Figure S15. The TPSR profile for CunSiO2 exhibits an ethylene formation peak at 215 C, with the reaction onset occurring at 88 C. The relatively high temperature required for hydrogenation activation suggests a limited H2 activation ability of Cun SiO2 after acetylene adsorption. In contrast, Ru1CunSiO2 exhibits a distinct peak at 162 C, with the reaction onset occurring at a significantly lower temperature of 45 C. This lower hydrogenation temperature indicates that Ru1CunSiO2 exhibits enhanced catalytic activity, attributed to the efficient H2 dissociation on Ru single atoms, which facilitates the hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene. These findings demonstrate that the cooperative interaction between Ru single atoms and Cu clusters in Ru1CunSiO2 significantly enhances the efficiency of acetylene hydrogenation with acetylene and hydrogen adsorbed on distinct metal sites, enabling ethylene formation at lower temperatures compared to monometallic Cu catalysts. To gain deeper mechanistic insights into the acetylene hydrogenation process on the Ru1CunSiO2 catalyst, we conducted density functional theory DFT calculations using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package VASP.33,34 The PerdewBurkeErnzerhof PBE functional within the generalized gradient approximation GGA was employed for electronic structure calculations,35 in

metadata.source: /Users/zemao/ChemQA/data/raw_papers/Sui 等 - 2025 - Fully exposed Cu clusters with Ru single atoms synergy for high-performance acetylene semihydrogenation.pdf
metadata.title: Sui 等 - 2025 - Fully exposed Cu clusters with Ru single atoms synergy for high-performance acetylene semihydrogenation.pdf

text: to monometallic Cu catalysts. To gain deeper mechanistic insights into the acetylene hydrogenation process on the Ru1CunSiO2 catalyst, we conducted density functional theory DFT calculations using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package VASP.33,34 The PerdewBurkeErnzerhof PBE functional within the generalized gradient approximation GGA was employed for electronic structure calculations,35 in addition, DFT-D3 was exploited to account for the vdW interactions.36 Given the partial hydroxylation of the silica support under the experimental conditions, a hydroxylated-SiO2 model is constructed to represent the SiO2 surface Figure S16. Based on the average CuCu coordination numbers derived from EXAFS analysis, we selected Cu3 and RuCu3 as model catalysts, respectively denoted as Cu3hydroxylated-SiO2 Figure S17 and RuCu3hydroxylated-SiO2 Figure S18. During catalyst preparation and under in situ H2 conditions, Cu3 and RuCu3 may undergo hydrogenation and dehydrox- ylation. To account for these effects, we systematically modified the structures by adding or removing either hydrogen or water molecules, generating catalyst models with varying stoichiometries. Finally, the most stable configurations of Cu3 and RuCu3 catalysts were determined using ab initio thermodynamics Figures S17 and S18. The results show that under the reaction conditions, the most stable RuCu3 cluster always bears two adsorbed hydrogen atoms; therefore, it will be notated as 2HRuCu3hydroxylated-SiO2 in the following text. The most stable structure of Cu3 is labeled as Cu3hydroxylated-SiO2. The two selected catalyst structures are putative global minima under the reaction conditions 170 C and 0.1 bar of H2, with the optimized structure shown in Figure S19. The distinct electronic structure of Cu clusters in Cu3 and RuCu3 catalysts is confirmed by Bader charge analysis Figure S20. The Bader charge analysis reveals a positively charged Cuδ state in the RuCu3 cluster. Moreover, there is a charge transfer to Cu of about 0.1e per Cu atom, resulting in an increased electron density on Cu in 2HRuCu3hydroxylated- SiO2. Meanwhile, the local density of states LDOS analysis Figure S21 indicates lower d-band energies in the 2HRuCu3hydroxylated-SiO2 catalyst, leading to weakened C2H4 adsorption. C2H2 shows a π adsorption configuration on both Cu3 and RuCu3 surfaces Figure S22. We further analyzed the reaction pathways and energy barriers for acetylene hydrogenation on Cu3hydroxylated- Journal of the American Chemical Society pubs.acs.orgJACS Article https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c03713 J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2025, 147, 1980819816 19812 SiO2 and 2HRuCu3hydroxylated-SiO2 catalysts Figure 4. On the Cu3 catalyst, the initial H2 dissociation step exhibits a free energy barrier of 1.31 eV TSH1, black, indicating the difficulty of H2 activation. The free energy barriers for the C H bond formation steps are determined as 1.16 eV TS1, the first CH bond formation, black and 1.21 eV TS2, the second CH bond formation, black, leading to ethylene generation from the C2H3 intermediate. In contrast, on the 2HRuCu3hydroxylated-SiO2 catalyst, the first CH bond formation preferentially involves the hydrogen atoms that are preadsorbed at CuCu hollow sites on the RuCu3 cluster surface. This step exhibits a free energy barrier of 0.73 eV TS1, red, which is 0.43 eV lower than that of the Cu3 catalyst, corroborating the critical role of Ru-modification

metadata.source: /Users/zemao/ChemQA/data/raw_papers/Sui 等 - 2025 - Fully exposed Cu clusters with Ru single atoms synergy for high-performance acetylene semihydrogenation.pdf
metadata.title: Sui 等 - 2025 - Fully exposed Cu clusters with Ru single atoms synergy for high-performance acetylene semihydrogenation.pdf

text: first CH bond formation preferentially involves the hydrogen atoms that are preadsorbed at CuCu hollow sites on the RuCu3 cluster surface. This step exhibits a free energy barrier of 0.73 eV TS1, red, which is 0.43 eV lower than that of the Cu3 catalyst, corroborating the critical role of Ru-modification in enhancing the hydrogenation activity of acetylene. Notably, the second CH bond formation follows the EleyRideal E-R mechanism37 in which the HH dissociation and CH bond formation occur simultaneously. This step exhibits a free energy barrier of 1.74 eV TSH1-TS2, red. According to the energetic span model,38 the TS1 red and TS1 black render the TOF determining transition state TDTS because they represent the highest points on the free energy profiles, and C2H4 g and C2H4 are the TOF determining intermediates TDI considering they have the lowest free energies, for RuCu3 and Cu3, respectively. Finally, the energetic span ΔGs that governs the reactivity could be formulated as38 G G G G TDTS TDI s r in which GTDTS is the free energy of TDTS, GTDI is the free energy of TDI, and ΔrG is the reaction Gibbs energy, considering that the TDI comes after TDTS. Finally, it is clear that the free energy span from RuCu3 0.77 eV is much smaller than that of Cu3 1.43 eV. This matches well with previous experimental results, showing the superior activity of the RuCu3 catalyst. In Figure 4, we only showed the pathways toward ethylene, and the subsequent hydrogenation toward ethane is also demonstrated in Figures S23 and S24, with the raw energies of key structures for each pathway shown in Tables S6S8, respectively. The free energy barrier for further hydrogenation of the C2H4 intermediate on the 2HRuCu3 catalyst is 1.99 eV, which is slightly higher than that on the Cu3 catalyst TS3, 1.88 eV, and the ethylene desorption is more feasible on 2HRuCu3. Nevertheless, the energy barriers required for further hydrogenation on both catalysts are higher than those required for the desorption of C2H4 to the gas phase from the catalyst surface Figure 4, ensuring the timely desorption of ethylene. Consequently, it can be concluded that the 2HRuCu3hydroxylated-SiO2 catalyst exhibits both high ethylene selectivity and high reactivity. These computational findings are in excellent agreement with the experimental results, reinforcing a more efficient ethylene formation pathway in the 2HRuCu3hydroxylated-SiO2 catalyst. Theoretical calculations reveal that the exceptional perform- ance of the Ru1CunSiO2 catalyst originates from the synergistic interplay between Ru single atoms and fully exposed Cu clusters. Ru atoms serve as highly efficient H2 adsorptiondissociation sites, significantly lowering the activa- tion barriers and ensuring a steady supply of active hydrogen species for acetylene hydrogenation. Meanwhile, Cu clusters facilitate moderate acetylene adsorption, preventing excessive accumulation, which could lead to catalyst deactivation and undesired side reactions. The hydrogen species generated on the Ru sites migrate to Cu clusters, where they participate in the hydrogenation reaction, effectively reducing the energy barrier for ethylene formation. This cooperative mechanism not only enhances catalytic activity but also maintains high ethylene

text: which could lead to catalyst deactivation and undesired side reactions. The hydrogen species generated on the Ru sites migrate to Cu clusters, where they participate in the hydrogenation reaction, effectively reducing the energy barrier for ethylene formation. This cooperative mechanism not only enhances catalytic activity but also maintains high ethylene selectivity, highlighting the crucial role of RuCu synergy in optimizing the reaction pathway. CONCLUSIONS This study highlights the exceptional performance of Ru1Cun SiO2 for acetylene semihydrogenation driven by the synergistic effect of Ru single atoms and fully exposed Cu clusters. Ru single atoms enhance H2 activation, significantly boosting the catalytic activity and lowering the full-conversion temperature to 170 C while maintaining 98 ethylene selectivity. Meanwhile, Cu clusters optimize acetylene adsorption, preventing the strong binding of C2H2 and promoting selective hydrogenation. These findings underscore the power of atomic-scale catalyst design, demonstrating that integrating Figure 4. text: Phosphorus-Mediated Oxygen Vacancy Engineering in Cu2O for Highly Selective CO2 Electroreduction to Multicarbon Products Xiaoqing Mao,Zhongyuan Guo,Saiwu Yang, Yongjun Shen, Li Wei, Congcong Li, Hongliang Jiang, Hao Li, Huihui Li, and Chunzhong Li Cite This: https:doi.org10.1021acsnano.5c04602 Read Online ACCESS Metrics More Article Recommendations sı Supporting Information ABSTRACT: Copper Cu-based electrocatalysts are acknowledged as pivotal catalysts for the electroreduction of CO2 into multicarbon C2 products; however, achieving high C2 selectivity at industrial-level current densities remains a significant challenge. Herein, we propose a phosphorus P-doping mediation strategy to introduce an oxygen vacancy into the Cu2O lattice, resulting in a C2 Faradaic efficiency of 87.0 at a partial current density of 347.8 mAcm2. Mechanistic studies unveil that P dopants dynamically regulate the formation of high-density oxygen vacancies in Cu2O lattices through the formation and subsequent detachment of the PO bond, predominantly in the form of phosphite within an aqueous electrolyte environment. In situ Raman spectroscopy coupled with density functional theory calculations further reveals that the OV-rich structure optimizes the surface coverage of active CO intermediates. This microenvironment not only accelerates the energetically favorable CC coupling pathway but also suppresses competitive protonation reactions, thereby breaking the intrinsic activity-selectivity trade-off. Our work provides atomic-level insights into defect dynamics manipulation for designing high-rate CO2 conversion systems. KEYWORDS: oxygen vacancy, P-doping mediation, CO2 reduction reaction, CO intermediate, multicarbon products INTRODUCTION The excessive use of fossil fuels at the expense of increasing global carbon emissions has caused irreversible climatic changes. The electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction CO2RR, which converts CO2 into high-value-added and easily storable chemical energy, is an environmentally friendly approach with the potential to alleviate the energy crisis.1 Cu- based electrocatalysts have garnered significant attention due to the optimal CO binding energy on the Cu surface, facilitating CC coupling to C2 products. Up until now, a substantial number of researches have made considerable developments of Cu-based electrocatalysts through various strategies, including doping,24 ligand modification,57 do- main-limited space construction,8,9 and defects engineer- ing.1012 However, the sluggish kinetics and high CC coupling energy barrier of the CO2RR process, which involves multiple proton-coupled electron transfer, require high over- potential, leading to low selectivity C2 products. The creation of oxygen vacancies OVs is an effective strategy for the above issues, boosting the CO2RR performance by concurrently modifying the electronic structure and surface reactivity.13 The OVs, serving as fingerprint of the electronic structure of the catalysts, can effectively promote the transfer of electrons to the adsorbed CO2, thus lowering the energy barrier for CO2 electroreduction by enhancing CO2 activation and the adsorption of key intermediates.14,15 Second, it has been demonstrated that the presence of OVs enhances the charge transfer efficiency at the catalytic reaction interface by decreasing the charge transfer resistance, thus increasing the electrocatalytic reaction rate.15,16 Furthermore, it has been demonstrated that OVs can effectively suppress competitive HER activity by modulating the adsorption energy and electronic configuration of CO2RR intermediaries.17 Thus, it is of significant importance to develop Cu-based catalysts enriched with OVs. Nevertheless, the concentration and distribution of OVs exhibit

metadata.source: /Users/zemao/ChemQA/data/raw_papers/Mao 等 - 2025 - Phosphorus-mediated oxygen vacancy engineering in Cu2 O for highly selective CO2 electroreduction to multicarbon products.pdf
metadata.title: Mao 等 - 2025 - Phosphorus-mediated oxygen vacancy engineering in Cu2 O for highly selective CO2 electroreduction to multicarbon products.pdf

text: increasing the electrocatalytic reaction rate.15,16 Furthermore, it has been demonstrated that OVs can effectively suppress competitive HER activity by modulating the adsorption energy and electronic configuration of CO2RR intermediaries.17 Thus, it is of significant importance to develop Cu-based catalysts enriched with OVs. Nevertheless, the concentration and distribution of OVs exhibit high sensitivity to the synthesis conditions such as temperature,18 pressure,19 and gas composition.20 This sensitivity makes it challenging to achieve precise and reproducible control of OVs.21 In addition, despite Received: March 17, 2025 Revised: May 24, 2025 Accepted: May 27, 2025 Article www.acsnano.org XXXX American Chemical Society A https:doi.org10.1021acsnano.5c04602 ACS Nano XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX Downloaded via TSINGHUA UNIV on June 15, 2025 at 12:43:38 UTC. See https:pubs.acs.orgsharingguidelines for options on how to legitimately share published articles. the overall CO2RR being a reductive process, the presence of CO2 and potential intermediate products can generate a relatively oxidizing microenvironment. Oxygen in CO2 or other oxygen-containing species may fill the OVs, reducing their concentration and affecting the catalytic activity.22 When the partial pressure of CO2 is high, the probability of oxygen filling the vacancies increases. Therefore, these factors pose critical challenges for precise synthesis of Cu-based catalyst enriched OVs, as well as maintaining long-term stability in a desired state for optimal catalytic performance. Herein, we proposed a P-doping mediation strategy to precisely control the formation of OVs, combining the one- step liquid-phase method to obtain a surface P-doped Cu2O as-prepared PCu2O at room temperature and the in situ electrochemical pre-reduction process to achieve the successful construction of OVs OVsCu2O. The P-dopant is the key factor for the rapid formation of substantial OVs in the Cu2O lattice, primarily through the formation and subsequent detachment of PO bonds. The ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy UPS demonstrates that the OVs function as charge carriers, thereby facilitating electron transfer during the CO2RR. In situ Raman analysis indicates that the presence of OVs enhances the adsorption of CO intermediates, thus promoting the selectivity for C2 products. As a result, the OVsCu2O electrocatalysts achieved a C2 Faradaic efficiency FE of 87.0 at partial current density of 347.8 mAcm2, along with stable performance exceeding 30 h in a membrane electrode assembly MEA electrolyzer. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION Synthesis and Characterization. The OVsCu2O catalysts were synthesized through a two-step process involving P-doping follow by an in situ electrochemical reduction process Figures 1a and S1. Due to the significant electronegativity difference between P 2.19 and O 3.44, the electron cloud of P with electron-donating ability tends to shift toward O.23 This leads to a strong binding tendency between P and O, thereby facilitating the formation of PO bonds. The second- step of the in situ electrochemical reduction process plays a crucial role in accelerating the detachment of PO bonds, leading to the departure of O atoms from the Cu2O lattice and thus forming OVs to obtain OVsCu2O.24,25 The PO bonds desorb as P-containing species from the catalyst surface into the electrolyte such as phosphate, phosphite, or hypophos- phite in an aqueous electrolyte. TEM images reveal

text: detachment of PO bonds, leading to the departure of O atoms from the Cu2O lattice and thus forming OVs to obtain OVsCu2O.24,25 The PO bonds desorb as P-containing species from the catalyst surface into the electrolyte such as phosphate, phosphite, or hypophos- phite in an aqueous electrolyte. TEM images reveal that both the as-prepared PCu2O Figures 1b and S2a,b and reference Cu2O Figure S3a,b nanoparticles exhibit a comparable size distribution in the range of 1020 nm. High-resolution TEM HRTEM of as- prepared PCu2O reveals two characteristic lattice fingers with spacings of 0.210 and 0.247 nm Figure 1d, corresponding to the 200 and 111 planes of Cu2O, respectively. As further evidence, selected area electron diffraction reveals the characteristic electron diffraction patterns corresponding to Cu2O planes Cu2O111, Cu2O200, Cu2O220, Cu2O- 311, and Cu2O400 Figure S4a. EDS coupled with elemental mapping images confirms the homogeneous Figure 1. Schematic diagram of the synthesis principle of OVCu2O and validation of synthesized PCu2O. a Schematic of a two-step approach to doping and inducing OVs construction. b Transmission electron microscopy TEM image, c energy dispersive spectroscopy EDS mapping image, and d lattice fringes of as-prepared PCu2O. e X-ray diffraction XRD patterns and f magnified XRD patterns of as-prepared PCu2O and reference Cu2O. g Cu LMM spectra of as-prepared PCu2O and reference Cu2O. ACS Nano www.acsnano.org Article https:doi.org10.1021acsnano.5c04602 ACS Nano XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX B distribution of Cu, P, and O elements Figure 1c. These findings, corroborated by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy ICP-OES data, validate the successful P-doping with a Cu: P ratio of 6:1. The XRD patterns exhibit the distinctive diffraction peaks of as-prepared PCu2O and reference Cu2O Figure 1e, which index well to the Cu2O phase JCPDS 05-0667. Notably, compared with the reference Cu2O, the diffraction peaks of as-prepared P Cu2O exhibit a slight shift toward a lower angle Figure 1f, which is possibly caused by the introduction of P.26,27 Additionally, the Cu LMM spectra confirm the presence of Cu in both as-prepared PCu2O and reference Cu2O Figure 1g. These characterization results collectively indicate the successful synthesis of both PCu2O and reference Cu2O. In the second step, the as-prepared PCu2O and reference Cu2O undergo an in situ electrochemical reduction process pre-reduction process to obtain Cu2O enrich OVs OVs Cu2O and pre-reduced reference Cu2O. Scanning electron microscopy SEM and TEM images reveal that both the OVsCu2O Figures S2c,d and S5a and pre-reduced reference Cu2O Figure S3c,d nanoparticles exhibit increased particle sizes and display similar morphologies. The EDS elemental maps of the OVsCu2O clearly demonstrate the depletion of P during the pre-reduction process Figure S5b, which aligns with our anticipated catalyst design objectives and exhibits a compositional profile similar to that of the pre- reduced reference Cu2O. Moreover, the quasi-in situ XRD spectra revealed that, after the pre-reduction process, a fraction of Cu2O in both OVsCu2O and the pre-reduced reference Cu2O transformed into Cu Figure S6. This observation is consistent with the measured lattice spacings of 0.18 and 0.208 nm, corresponding to the Cu100 and Cu111 planes,

text: Moreover, the quasi-in situ XRD spectra revealed that, after the pre-reduction process, a fraction of Cu2O in both OVsCu2O and the pre-reduced reference Cu2O transformed into Cu Figure S6. This observation is consistent with the measured lattice spacings of 0.18 and 0.208 nm, corresponding to the Cu100 and Cu111 planes, respectively Figures S4b and S5c. These observations exclude the morphology and composition as factors influencing the CO2RR performance. Mechanistic Insights into the Formation of OVs. To further investigate the relationship between PO bonds formation, PO bonds detachment, and the rapid, extensive OVs formation, a series of comprehensive characterization analyses were conducted. According to X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XPS characterization analysis, the peak located at 133.18 eV in the P 2p spectra is ascribed to the PO bonds Figure 2. Mechanism of OVs formation and simulation of P-induced OVs construction based on comprehensive experimental results. XPS spectra of PCu2O and reference Cu2O: a P 2p and b O 1s. c In situ EPR spectra of PCu2O catalyst during the pre-reduction process at a constant current of 5.0 mA. d ΔEOVs,formation of pristine Cu2O200 and PCu2O with different ratios of PCu. EPR spectra of e P Cu2O and f the reference Cu2O. g Pristine Cu2O200 and its corresponding P-doped models, where the surface-two layers of all models were only allowed to relax during optimization. ACS Nano www.acsnano.org Article https:doi.org10.1021acsnano.5c04602 ACS Nano XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX C Figure 2a.28,29 The absence of a P 2p peak of the OVs Cu2O provides further evidence that P has been completely detached from the catalysts during pre-reduction process, which is consistent with the ICP-OES results. Correspond- ingly, a significant number of OVs were simultaneously formed on the surface of OVsCu2O following the pre-reduction process, as evidenced by the analysis of the O 1s spectrum. The three peaks detected at 530.15, 531.38, and 532.85 eV of the OVsCu2O are attributed to lattice oxygen Olatt, OVs, and adsorbed oxygen Oads,3032 respectively Figure 2b. A comparison between the as-prepared PCu2O and OVs Cu2O samples indicates that the OVsCu2O catalysts possess the highest concentration of OVs Table S1. To provide direct evidence of the construction of OVs during the pre- reduction process, in situ electron paramagnetic resonance EPR characterization was performed at a constant current of 5.0 mA. The result demonstrated that the persistence of OVs during the pre-reduction process and the concentration increased with the extension of the reduction time, which preliminarily confirmed the mechanism of OVs formation Figure 2c. Furthermore, quasi-in situ EPR was performed for the PCu2O and the reference Cu2O catalysts. Compared to the as-prepared PCu2O and reference Cu2O catalysts Figure 2f, both the OVsCu2O and the OVsCu2O after CO2RR exhibit a more pronounced signal peak at g 2.003 Figure 2e. Moreover, the catalysts after the CO2RR were characterized by XPS, and the O 1s spectra are displayed in Figure S7. Compared with the pre-reduced reference Cu2O catalyst, the OVsCu2O sample after CO2RR retained distinct characteristic peaks associated with OVs, demonstrating that the high-concentration OVs remained stable throughout

text: 2.003 Figure 2e. Moreover, the catalysts after the CO2RR were characterized by XPS, and the O 1s spectra are displayed in Figure S7. Compared with the pre-reduced reference Cu2O catalyst, the OVsCu2O sample after CO2RR retained distinct characteristic peaks associated with OVs, demonstrating that the high-concentration OVs remained stable throughout the entire catalytic process. The corresponding OVs concentration values for both the OVsCu2O catalysts and the pre-reduced reference Cu2O samples after CO2RR, as calculated from the peak areas, are summarized in Table S1. This observation further substantiates the pivotal role of P-doping in mediating OVs formation and its capability to sustain the stability of OVs during the CO2RR process.3335 Furthermore, the peak of the Olatt of as-prepared PCu2O exhibits a distinct positive shift, indicating that P doping results Figure 3. CO2RR performance of OVsCu2O and pre-reduced reference Cu2O in flow cell and long-term stability of OVsCu2O. a LSV curves of OVsCu2O and pre-reduced reference Cu2O electrocatalysts. CO2RR product distribution of b OVsCu2O and c pre-reduced reference Cu2O on electrodes at different current densities. A comparison of d FEC2, e C2 current density, and f FEC2FEC1 and for two samples at different current densities. g Stability of OVsCu2O electrocatalyst electrolyzed at 3.85 V for 30 h. ACS Nano www.acsnano.org Article https:doi.org10.1021acsnano.5c04602 ACS Nano XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX D in a reduction in the electron density of the electrode surface. This is attributed to the electronegativity of P 2.19, which is larger than that of Cu 1.90, thus resulting the charge transfer between Cu atoms and P atoms.26 The phenomenon of electron transfer can also be verified from the Cu 2p spectra. The peaks located at 932.99 and 952.78 eV are attributed to Cu 2p32 and Cu 2p12 of Cu or Cu0, respectively Figure S8. With the introduction of P, the binding energies of Cu 2p32 and 2p12 have a significant positive shift, which further identifies the effect of electron transfer on the surface of the electrocatalysts.36 In contrast, the peak position of Cu 2p32 and 2p12 of the OVsCu2O has a clear negative shift, which may be due to the transfer of hole electrons on the OVs, thus leading Cu atoms in an electron-rich state.18,37,38 Due to the unavoidable partial oxidation of the samples during the delivery process, shoulder peaks of Cu2 are observed at 934.70 and 955.08 eV.12 The P-containing species in the electrolyte were subsequently characterized using ion chroma- tography IC. The results indicate that the majority of the detached P exists in the electrolyte primarily as phosphite Figures S9S11 and Table S2, which is consistent with the presence of PO bonds observed in the P 2p spectrum of the as-prepared PCu2O. All characterization results unambigu- ously confirm that the introduction of P and the construction of OVs can effectively engineer the charge redistribution, thereby facilitating CO2 activation. To gain further insights into the mechanism by which P dopants mediate the formation of OVs, we conducted density functional theory DFT calculations. According to the experimental characterizations, Cu2O200 was selected to

text: introduction of P and the construction of OVs can effectively engineer the charge redistribution, thereby facilitating CO2 activation. To gain further insights into the mechanism by which P dopants mediate the formation of OVs, we conducted density functional theory DFT calculations. According to the experimental characterizations, Cu2O200 was selected to study the effects of P dopant on the OVs formation. The pristine Cu2O200 and its corresponding P-doped models are shown Figure 2g. The OVs formation energy ΔEOVs,formation was employed to describe the tendency of OVs formation caused by P dopants, which was defined by ΔEOVs,formation EOVs EO EnPCu d2O200, where EOVs and EnPCu d2O200 represented the electronic energy of the P-doped models with and without OVs, respectively. EO was calculated from EH d2O and EH d2 EH d2O EH d2. The more negative the ΔEOVs,formation, the more likely to form OVs over Cu2O. Figure 2d demonstrates that the ΔEOVs,formation exhibits a tendency to decrease with an increase in the PCu ratio of the surface phase, suggesting that P dopants can contribute to the generation of OVs. When the ratio of PCu approaches to 0.6, the ΔEOVs,formation is demonstrably lower than that of pristine Cu2O, indicating that higher P dopant level is more likely to form OVs compared to pristine Cu2O. Moreover, the ratio of PCu in the surface phase of PCu2O, as determined by XPS Table S3, falls within the higher PCu ratio interval 0.5 to 0.7. Theoretical calculations further indicate that a higher concentration of P dopants can change the surface configuration of PCu2O, especially the oxygen coordination environments, for example, PO and CuO bonds, which would contribute to the formation of OVs during pre- reduction process Figure S12. Consequently, experimental characterizations in conjunction with DFT calculations indicate that the P-doped Cu2O catalyst facilitated the expeditious and extensive formation of OVs during the pre- reduction process. Electrocatalytic Performance in Flow Cell and MEA. The CO2RR activity of OVsCu2O and pre-reduced reference Cu2O catalysts was evaluated in a flow cell with 1.0 M KHCO3 electrolyte. Figure 3a shows the linear sweeping voltammetry LSV curve of OVsCu2O and pre-reduced reference Cu2O in CO2 and N2 atmospheres. Notably, under a CO2 atmosphere, the total current density of OVsCu2O was significantly higher than that of pre-reduced reference Cu2O at applied potentials lower than 1.2 V vs AgAgCl, indicating the enhanced CO2RR activity attributed to the presence of OVs. Given that the majority of the detached P primarily exists in the electrolyte as phosphite, to eliminate the potential interference of phosphite on the CO2RR performance, the electrolyte is completely drained following the pre-reduction step and subsequently replaced with fresh electrolyte for the subsequent CO2RR tests. As expected, no significant difference in the CO2RR performance was observed Table S4, which further corroborates that the activity enhancement of OVs Cu2O is attributable to the OVs. As illustrated in Figure 3b,c, OVsCu2O demonstrates a significantly higher selectivity for C2 products, including C2H4, C2H5OH, CH3COOH, and C3H7OH, compared to the pre-reduced reference Cu2O. To be specific, the FEC2

metadata.source: /Users/zemao/ChemQA/data/raw_papers/Mao 等 - 2025 - Phosphorus-mediated oxygen vacancy engineering in Cu2 O for highly selective CO2 electroreduction to multicarbon products.pdf
metadata.title: Mao 等 - 2025 - Phosphorus-mediated oxygen vacancy engineering in Cu2 O for highly selective CO2 electroreduction to multicarbon products.pdf

text: was observed Table S4, which further corroborates that the activity enhancement of OVs Cu2O is attributable to the OVs. As illustrated in Figure 3b,c, OVsCu2O demonstrates a significantly higher selectivity for C2 products, including C2H4, C2H5OH, CH3COOH, and C3H7OH, compared to the pre-reduced reference Cu2O. To be specific, the FEC2 of OVsCu2O electrode exceeds 80.0 in a broad current density range of 350 450 mAcm2 and reaches a topmost FEC d2 of 87.0 at a partial current density of 347.8 mAcm2, with 46.1 for FEC d2H d4 and 31.5 for FEC d2H d5OH. In comparison, the pre-reduced reference Cu2O exhibits lower selectivity, with the maximum FE for C2 products reaching only 63.1, whereas the FE for CO remains consistently above 20. Furthermore, the FEC2 Figure 3d and C2 partial current density Figure 3e of OVsCu2O are significantly higher than those of the pre-reduced reference Cu2O across the entire potential range. Especially, at a current density of 450 mA cm2, the value of FEC d2C d1 reaches 12.0, which is over- whelmingly superior to pre-reduced reference Cu2O Figure 3f. Moreover, a comparison has been made between OVs Cu2O and the currently available catalysts Table S5. The results demonstrate that OVsCu2O displays both excellent C2 product selectivity and partial current density in near- neutral electrolytes. Furthermore, to verify the modulation mechanism of P-doping-induced OVs construction on CO2RR performance, a series of PCu2O catalysts with different P doping concentrations were obtained by adjusting the addition of P source during the synthesis process. The feeding versus corresponding ICP-verified CuP ratios in the freshly prepared PCu2O catalysts revealed that the P-doping concentration increased progressively with a higher P precursor dosage until reaching saturation as the feeding molar ratio reached 1.5:1 Table S6. Subsequently, the EPR characterization of the series of OVs-rich Cu catalysts obtained by the pre-reduction treatment of PCu2O samples was conducted. The results revealed that the OVs concentration gradually increased with growing P-doping concentration Figure S13. Notably, the CO2RR product analysis of the OVs-enriched Cu catalysts indicated that the FEC2 exhibited an upward trend with increasing P-doping concentrations, while the competing C1 and H2 byproducts decreased inversely Figure S14. These findings substantiate that P-doping modulates the OVs concentration, providing further insights into the mechanism of P-doping-mediated OVs formation. Long-term electro- chemical stability is a critical parameter that significantly influences the performance of CO2RR. The OVsCu2O catalysts unveil a desirable stability in the MEA electrolyzer ACS Nano www.acsnano.org Article https:doi.org10.1021acsnano.5c04602 ACS Nano XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX E Figure 3g. Demonstrating a marked stability exceeding 30 h at 3.85 V in 0.1 M KHCO3 with negligible decay in current density and FEC d2H d4. During prolonged CO2RR stability assessments at high current densities, continuous electron transfer and proton coupling processes on the catalyst surface result in a reduction of the OVs concentration. This CO2RR- induced process leads to a reconfiguration of the local charge distribution surrounding the OVs, thereby causing a time- dependent decay in the concentration of OVs. As illustrated in Figure S15, the presence

metadata.title: Mao 等 - 2025 - Phosphorus-mediated oxygen vacancy engineering in Cu2 O for highly selective CO2 electroreduction to multicarbon products.pdf

text: and proton coupling processes on the catalyst surface result in a reduction of the OVs concentration. This CO2RR- induced process leads to a reconfiguration of the local charge distribution surrounding the OVs, thereby causing a time- dependent decay in the concentration of OVs. As illustrated in Figure S15, the presence of OVs in OVsCu2O remains evident after a 30 h CO2RR stability test, implying the stability of the OVs in Cu2O catalysts. Mechanistic Study. We conducted a series of character- izations to further elucidate the mechanism of OVs in enhancing the CO2RR activity. The electrochemically active surface area ECSA usually affects CO2RR activity, which was measured by double-layer capacitance Cdl on the basis of cyclic voltammograms for the OVsCu2O and pre-reduced reference Cu2O Figure S16. It is evident that the ECSA values of the two electrocatalysts are relatively similar Figure S17, indicating that ECSA is not a primary factor influencing the difference in the CO2RR performance. Usually, the interfacial properties of the electrode and electrolyte also affect the CO2RR process. Therefore, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy was performed on the electrocatalysts at open circuit potential OCP, and Nyquist plots were obtained for both OVsCu2O and pre-reduced reference Cu2O electrocatalysts. The OVsCu2O exhibits a lower charge transfer resistance Rct, which facilitates enhanced interfacial charge transfer kinetics during the CO2RR process Figure S18. To explore the origin of the fast kinetics and excellent CO2RR activity of OVsCu2O, UPS measurement was carried out to evaluate its electron-donating ability. The work function, which is obtained from the UPS spectra according to the equation: Eφ hα Ecutoff EFermi,39 of the OVsCu2O 3.68 eV is significantly smaller than that of the pre-reduced reference Cu2O 4.34 eV Figure 4a, suggesting that the OVs decrease the energy barrier of electrons from the electrocatalyst surface to the reactants and intermediates during the CO2RR process.40 Furthermore, the valence band of the catalyst can be obtained without bias, as shown in Figure 4b, and the valence band position of OVsCu2O is 1.87 eV, which is closer to the Fermi energy level than that of the pre-reduced reference Cu2O 2.08 eV. According to previous studies, as the center of the d-band of the material gets closer to the Fermi energy Figure 4. Strong electron-donating ability and CO adsorption of OVsCu2O. ACS Nano www.acsnano.org Article https:doi.org10.1021acsnano.5c04602 ACS Nano XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX F level, the absorption of the intermediates on the electrocatalyst surface could be intensified.18,41 The in situ Raman spectroscopy was employed to provide further insights into the adsorption behavior of the CO intermediate over the electrocatalysts during the CO2RR Figures 4c and S19. At OCP, both OVsCu2O and pre- reduced reference Cu2O catalysts

text: absorption of the intermediates on the electrocatalyst surface could be intensified.18,41 The in situ Raman spectroscopy was employed to provide further insights into the adsorption behavior of the CO intermediate over the electrocatalysts during the CO2RR Figures 4c and S19. At OCP, both OVsCu2O and pre- reduced reference Cu2O catalysts exhibit two main Raman peaks at 524 and 625 cm1, which correspond to the signature peaks of Cu2O.4244 As the potential increased to 0.7 V vs AgAgCl, a distinct CuCO bond stretching vibration peak was observed at approximately 365 cm1, which demonstrate the appearance of CO intermediates on OVsCu2O electrode during CO2RR.4547 In comparison, the pre-reduced reference Cu2O exhibited a notably lower peak intensity of CuCO species within the same energy range, indicating an enhanced capacity for CO generation on the OVsCu2O electrode. Meanwhile, the characteristic CuCO peaks of the pre-reduced reference Cu2O only emerged when the voltage was increased to 1.3 V vs AgAgCl, which is more negative than the onset potential for CO adsorption on OVsCu2O. Furthermore, these peaks disappeared at 1.7 V vs AgAgCl, a potential that is more positive compared to the disappearance potential of CO adsorption on OVsCu2O 1.8 V vs Ag AgCl. The adsorption of CO on the OVsCu2O over a wide potential range from 0.7 V to 1.7 V vs AgAgCl further suggests that OVs facilitate the adsorption of CO intermediate to promote CC coupling and improve the selectivity of C2 products.48,49 In addition, electrochemical CO stripping voltammetry was employed to evaluate and compare the CO desorption performance of OVsCu2O and pre-reduced reference Cu2O. A pronounced CO stripping profile with a prominent peak at approximately 0.12 V vs Ag AgCl was observed for OVsCu2O Figure S20, while the corresponding peak for pre-reduced reference Cu2O appeared at around 0.03 V vs AgAgCl. The positive shift indicates a stronger CO adsorption on the OVsCu2O electrode, which is consistent with the conclusion of the in situ Raman experiments.50,51 CC coupling is usually considered as the rate-determining step in the conversion of CO2 to C2 products. Extensive research has shown that this process can be more effectively initiated by enhancing the adsorption of the key intermediate CO. To further substantiate the impact of OVs on the adsorption of CO, we conducted DFT calculations. First, the calculated binding energies of CO on Cu2O200 and Cu2O2004OV four OV sites over the surface are 0.94 eV and 1.61 eV Figure 4d, respectively, suggesting that the presence of OVs intensifies the adsorption of CO on the OVsCu2O electrode, which is in agreement with the above-mentioned in situ Raman and CO stripping results. Furthermore, the results of the Bader charge analysis indicate that the OVs enhance the charge transferred from Cu to CO adsorbed on Cu2O2004OV in comparison with Cu2O200, thus strengthening the adsorption of CO, which is conducive to subsequent CC coupling. Then, DFT calculations were performed to analyze the Gibbs free energy ΔG evolution of the CO2RR process. Based on the experimental results, it is known that almost all of
