The oxidation products were characterized both qualitatively and quantitatively using the complementary analytic techniques 1H NMR spectra Fig. S12 online and HPLC Figs. S13S16 and Table S1 online across different electrocatalysts. Pt1Bi1 DONS demonstrates superior selectivity of 92.2 for the C3 products at a potential of 0.87 V vs. RHE, suggesting that the optimal Pt:Bi ratio in Pt1Bi1 DONS promotes the preservation of the carbon skeleton during GOR Fig. 3e. By contrast, Pt1Bi3 DONS and cPt NC exhibit signiﬁcantly lower selectivities of 91.8 and 76.8 for the C3 prod- ucts, respectively, yielding a more diverse array of oxidation prod- ucts, such as the C1 product FA and C2 products OA and HAc. The enhanced C3 selectivity is attributed to the optimal electronic structure resulting from the interaction between Pt and Bi2O3 in Pt1Bi1 DONS. Given the notable inﬂuence of applied potential on GOR, we conducted characterization of the oxidation products gen- erated by Pt1Bi1 DONS at varied potentials Fig. 3f. At lower poten- tials, the C3 products predominate, indicating preferential oxidation of primary alcohol groups without CC bond cleavage 43. As the potential increases, the selectivity for C3 products grad- ually decreases from 96.6 to 92.2, indicating the onset of CC bond cleavage. The observed decline in C3 selectivity with increas- ing potential can be explained by the enhanced CC bond scission, which occurs as the electrocatalyst surface adopts a higher oxida- tion state 44. The timed current test amperometry i-t curves, AC Fig. S17 online indicates that the Pt1Bi1 DONS exhibit good stabil- ity, which is better than cPt NC. The postreaction characterization data of SEM Fig. S18 online, TEM Fig. S19 online, and XPS Fig. S20 online conﬁrm that the Pt1Bi1 DONS retain their original morphological features and chemical states, demonstrating excel- lent structural and chemical stability under electrochemical condi- tions during the GOR. 5 3.3. The role of Bi2O3 in Pt1Bi1 DONS of GOR To elucidate the role of Bi2O3 in Pt1Bi1 DONS, we compared the activity and selectivity of Pt1Bi1 DONS, PtBi nanosheets PtBi NS, Bi2O3 nanosheets Bi2O3 NS Figs. S21 and S22 online, and Bi nanosheets Bi NS during GOR. The characterization data of PtBi NS Figs. S23S25 online conﬁrms the formation of hexagonal nanosheet structures with a Pt:Bi atomic ratio of 1:1, as corrobo- rated by EDS analysis and XRD patterns matching the PtBi inter- metallic nanosheets JCPDS No. 97-061-6981. The CV result Fig. 4a shows the signiﬁcantly higher peak mass activity of Pt1Bi1 DONS 3.98 A mgPt 1 than PtBi NS 1.93 A mgPt 1, with an earlier onset potential indicative of superior efﬁciency in initiating the GOR. From the LSV curves Fig. 4b, Pt1Bi1 DONS distinctly outper- form all other catalysts, underscoring the synergistic effect between Pt and Bi2O3, which is absent in both PtBi NS and Bi2O3 NS. text: 1.93 A mgPt 1, with an earlier onset potential indicative of superior efﬁciency in initiating the GOR. From the LSV curves Fig. 4b, Pt1Bi1 DONS distinctly outper- form all other catalysts, underscoring the synergistic effect between Pt and Bi2O3, which is absent in both PtBi NS and Bi2O3 NS. Furthermore, Pt1Bi1 DONS exhibit a lower resistance during GOR than PtBi NS Fig. 4c, reﬂecting enhanced charge transfer kinetics facilitated by the unique Pt-Bi2O3 interface. The product distribution from GOR catalyzed by PtBi NS Fig. 4d was also determined using HPLC Figs. S26 and S27 and Table S2 online, revealing distinct differences in selectivity. For Pt1Bi1 DONS, GLA was the predominant product. By contrast, PtBi NS generated a broader range of products, including C1 to C3, with a considerable contribution of DHA, a C3 product notably absent in Pt1Bi1 DONS catalytic reaction. These comparisons highlight the critical role of the Bi2O3 in Pt1Bi1 DONS, which not only ﬁne-tunes the electronic structure of Pt to facilitate C3-selective production but also enhances the speciﬁed production of GLA. H.-Y. Yang et al. Science Bulletin xxx xxxx xxx Fig. 4. GOR performances of Pt1Bi1 DONS, PtBi NS, and Bi2O3 NS in an alkaline electrolyte, DFT results of different adsorption conﬁgurations, and Pt1Bi1 DONS performance of catalytic polyols. a CV curves of Pt1Bi1 DONS and PtBi NS in N2-purged 1 mol L1 KOH 0.5 mol L1 glycerol. b LSV curves of Pt1Bi1 DONS, PtBi NS, cPt NC, and Bi2O3 NS in N2-purged 1 mol L1 KOH 0.5 mol L1 glycerol. c Nyquist plots of Pt1Bi1 DONS and PtBi NS. d C3 product selectivity of PtBi NS at 0.87 V vs. RHE. e Binding energy of glycerol OH species and the GLA production rates for Pt1Bi1 DONS, PtBi NS, and cPt NC. f LSV curves of Pt1Bi1 DONS in N2-purged 1 mol L1 KOH with glycerol, mannitol, ethylene glycol, n-propanol, methanol, and ethanol. To further verify the function of Bi2O3, the CV measurement was conducted on Bi2O3 NS Fig. S28 online. The results exhibit a char- acteristic oxidation peak at 0.56 V vs. RHE in N2-saturated 1 mol L1 KOH solution during the CV scan blue curve. However, on intro- ducing 0.5 mol L1 glycerol, both the oxidation peak and reduction peaks were completely suppressed green curve, indicating that the OHads species from glycerol preferentially adsorb on the Bi2O3 surface, subsequently blocking the Bi2O3 adsorption sites. Supported by the LSV data Fig. 4b showing negligible current for Bi2O3 NS in the presence of glycerol, it is evident that Bi2O3 NS lack intrinsic GOR capability. Thus, the primary role of Bi2O3 NS is to provide adsorption sites for glycerol, thereby enhancing oxidation through synergistic interactions with Pt. The volcano plot Fig. 4e derived from density functional theory DFT calcula- tions Fig. S29 online illustrates the correlation between the bind- ing energy of glycerol OH species and the GLA production rate for various catalytic surfaces, including Pt1Bi1 DONS, PtBi NS, and Pt. Two distinct adsorption conﬁgurations are considered namely

text: volcano plot Fig. 4e derived from density functional theory DFT calcula- tions Fig. S29 online illustrates the correlation between the bind- ing energy of glycerol OH species and the GLA production rate for various catalytic surfaces, including Pt1Bi1 DONS, PtBi NS, and Pt. Two distinct adsorption conﬁgurations are considered namely the lying-down conﬁguration 2OH and the standing conﬁgura- tion 1OH. Pt1Bi1 DONS with the lying conﬁguration Pt1Bi1- 2OH reside at the volcanos peak, signifying the highest catalytic activity and optimal binding energy. This conﬁguration facilitates the formation of GLA due to the simultaneous interaction of two hydroxyl groups with the catalyst surface. Conversely, the standing conﬁguration calculated for Pt1Bi1 DONS and PtBi NS displays a lower activity as it binds too weakly or too strongly. Interestingly, glycerol demonstrates a strong preference for the lying conﬁgura- tion on Pt1Bi1 DONS, whereas the standing conﬁguration is favored on PtBi NS. The preferential adsorption conﬁguration on Pt1Bi1 DONS enhances the selective production of GLA, emphasizing the critical role of Bi2O3 in modulating the Pt binding environment and steering glycerol oxidation toward GLA rather than DHA. 6 Considering the function of Bi2O3 for tuning the adsorption of OHads, we extend the testing of Pt1Bi1 DONS against other multicar- bon alcohols, namely ethylene glycol EG, mannitol, n-propanol, methanol, and ethanol. LSV curves Fig. 4f compare the perfor- mances of Pt1Bi1 DONS in the oxidation of polyols and monoalco- hols. Notably, Pt1Bi1 DONS exhibit considerably higher currents and more negative onset potentials for polyols EG and mannitol than monoalcohols n-propanol, methanol, and ethanol. The CV tests Fig. S30 online further demonstrate the consistent role of Bi2O3 NS across all tested polyols, with oxidation and reduction peaks completely suppressed due to the strong adsorption of poly- ols on Bi2O3 NS, whereas these peaks remain observable with monoalcohols. This adsorption behavior of the Bi2O3 NS confers versatility upon the Pt1Bi1 DONS by providing effective sites for diverse polyols, which stabilize reaction intermediates and enhance catalytic activity. Such adaptability underscores the cru- cial Pt and Bi2O3 synergy, extending the notable electrocatalytic performance of the catalyst from glycerol oxidation to a wider spectrum of polyols. H.-Y. Yang et al. Science Bulletin xxx xxxx xxx 3.4. The reaction mechanism of GOR To further elucidate the enhanced catalytic activity over Pt1Bi1 DONS, operando EIS was employed to study the GOR process, pro- viding insights into the electrode and electrolyte interface proper- ties. The Bode plots for Pt1Bi1 DONS Fig. 5a reveal a narrow single peak across the frequency spectrum, indicative of a more uniform and accelerated charge transfer process, which suggests enhanced kinetics for surface OHads adsorption and subsequent interaction with glycerol molecules 45. Compared to Pt1Bi3 DONS and cPt NC, Pt1Bi1 DONS exhibit lower phase angles, which in EIS typically denotes less resistive behavior 22. In this context, it implies faster reaction kinetics and facilitated charge transfer, corroborating the earlier EIS observations Fig. 3d. By contrast, cPt NC Fig. 5b dis- play a bimodal response with distinct low and high-frequency peaks,

text: DONS exhibit lower phase angles, which in EIS typically denotes less resistive behavior 22. In this context, it implies faster reaction kinetics and facilitated charge transfer, corroborating the earlier EIS observations Fig. 3d. By contrast, cPt NC Fig. 5b dis- play a bimodal response with distinct low and high-frequency peaks, while Pt1Bi1 DONS demonstrate a simpliﬁed impedance pro- ﬁle 46. The 1:1 ratio of Pt:Bi optimizes the surface for OHads adsorption and its reaction with glycerol, potentially streamlining the reaction mechanism. While Pt1Bi3 DONS Fig. S31 online also show enhancements compared to cPt NC, the comparatively lower phase angles and the broader peak of Pt1Bi1 DONS indicate that the 1:1 ratio achieves an optimal balance for OHads adsorption and utilization in the GOR. Moreover, Pt1Bi3 DONS exhibit a more pronounced peak in the midfrequency range, suggesting increased capacitive behavior 47. The pronounced peak can be attributed to higher Bi content, leading to stronger adsorption of reaction intermediates or a more developed electrical double layer. However, the higher phase angles observed in Pt1Bi3 DONS relative to Pt1Bi1 DONS imply slower charge transfer kinetics, indicating that while increasing Bi content enhances OHads adsorption, it may simulta- neously inhibit the subsequent reaction steps through stronger intermediate binding. By contrast, the Bode plots of PtBi NS Fig. S32 online display an even broader peak than that of Pt1Bi1 DONS, suggesting multiple overlapping kinetic processes. The broader peak indicates less efﬁcient charge transfer dynamics and increased intermediate accumulation on the catalyst surface, likely arising from the PtBi NS lack of Bi2O3, which is optimized for efﬁcient OHads modulation in Pt1Bi1 DONS. Fig. 5. In situ characterizations and illustration of the mechanism and reaction process. Bode plots of a Pt1Bi1 DONS and b cPt NC in 1 mol L1 KOH 0.5 mol L1 glycerol. c Bode plots of Pt1Bi1 DONS in 1 mol L1 KOH 1.5 mol L1 npropanol. d Electrochemical in situ Raman spectral evolution of Pt1Bi1 DONS at different potentials in 1 mol L1 KOH 0.5 mol L1 glycerol. e Electrochemical in situ FTIR spectra of Pt1Bi1 DONS at different potentials in 1 mol L1 KOH 0.1 mol L1 glycerol. f Scheme of the GOR reaction pathway. 7 The arrangement of functional groups within small organic molecules markedly inﬂuences their reaction mechanisms. In the context of alkaline GOR, where coadsorption of hydroxide ions and glycerol occurs, the behavior of n-propanol, which maintains the same concentration of hydroxyl groups, was also studied on Pt1Bi1 DONS Fig. 5c. During GOR, the response of Pt1Bi1 DONS exhibits narrower peaks that shifted toward higher frequencies, indicating a relatively uniform process with a fast charge transfer rate. By contrast, the oxidation of n-propanol results in broader peaks, more prominently centered around lower frequencies, sug- gesting a more complex process with signiﬁcant resistance at the molecular adsorption site. Glycerol, with three hydroxyl groups, contains multiple adsorption sites, leading to a stable adsorption conﬁguration. Conversely, n-propanol displays varied adsorption conﬁgurations, resulting in the formation of adsorbed reactants and intermediates with diverse

text: centered around lower frequencies, sug- gesting a more complex process with signiﬁcant resistance at the molecular adsorption site. Glycerol, with three hydroxyl groups, contains multiple adsorption sites, leading to a stable adsorption conﬁguration. Conversely, n-propanol displays varied adsorption conﬁgurations, resulting in the formation of adsorbed reactants and intermediates with diverse binding strengths. The presence of Bi2O3 facilitates a stable conformation for polyols such as glyc- erol, wherein multiple hydroxyl groups are adsorbed on Pt1Bi1 DONS. This not only simpliﬁes the reaction pathway but also enhances hydroxyl activation of the polyols, reducing reliance on hydroxyl ions in solution, which elucidates why polyols generally outperform monoalcohols in the LSV curves Fig. 4f. H.-Y. Yang et al. Science Bulletin xxx xxxx xxx To investigate the GOR kinetics at Pt1Bi1 DONS, electrochemical in situ Raman spectroscopy was applied Fig. 5d, revealing the characteristic vibrational modes of glycerol and its oxidation inter- mediates. The spectral analysis shows intensive peaks in the 800 1000 cm1 region, which are attributed to the sCH2 vibrations of the glycerol 48. The distinct bands around 1050 and 1109 cm1 are assigned to the ʋsCOH modes associated with the terminal and intermediate carbon atoms of glycerol, respectively 49. Nota- bly, the vibrational peaks at 10881130 cm1 diminish with increasing potential, indicating the consumption of the OH groups on intermediate carbon atoms. By contrast, the intensity of the peaks at 10201080 cm1 remains relatively constant, suggesting that the OH groups on the terminal carbon atoms are not signiﬁ- cantly consumed. The peaks below 400 cm1, attributed to OHads adsorbed on Bi, suggest a favorable environment for OHads adsorp- tion, with their intensities slightly decreasing as the potential increases. This behavior implies that the OH groups adsorbed dur- ing polyol oxidation likely originate from the structure of glycerol rather than external sources. In addition, the CC vibrational mode at 518 cm1 exhibits minor changes, indicating variations in the adsorption geometries of glycerol and its intermediates. Notably, the PtC stretching peak at 438 cm1 remains relatively constant across the potential range, indicating the preservation of CC bonds 50. The stability is likely due to the electron-rich Pt envi- ronment enhanced by Bi2O3, which effectively reduces CC bond cleavage and thus improves the C3 selectivity of Pt1Bi1 DONS. A slight increase in the CO peak intensity 2110 cm1 is observed at higher potentials 51, consistent with the minor decrease in C3 product selectivity at elevated potentials Fig. 3f. The reaction intermediates were monitored using in situ Fourier-transform infrared in-situ FTIR spectroscopy Fig. 5e. The spectral analysis reveals characteristic peaks at 1317 and 1400 cm1, attributed to the symmetric carboxylate group stretch- ing modes, alongside a peak at 1580 cm1, which is assigned to the asymmetric carboxylate stretching 52. Additionally, a distinct vibrational feature at 1745 cm1 is attributed to the CO stretching of carboxylic acids or aldehydes 5355. As the applied potential increases, the intensities of these peaks increase, signifying the for- mation of GLA as the predominant product over the tested poten- tial range.

text: carboxylate stretching 52. Additionally, a distinct vibrational feature at 1745 cm1 is attributed to the CO stretching of carboxylic acids or aldehydes 5355. As the applied potential increases, the intensities of these peaks increase, signifying the for- mation of GLA as the predominant product over the tested poten- tial range. By contrast, the peaks at 1032 and 1145 cm1 are associated with the CO stretching vibrations 25. Notably, the persistence of CO peaks at elevated potential indicates partial oxi- dation of glycerol 56, suggesting a high likelihood of preserving the C3 structure. The electron-rich nature of Pt in Pt1Bi1 facilitates controlled partial oxidation, preventing extensive CC bond cleav- age and promoting selective production. Therefore, the reaction pathway for glycerol oxidation on Pt1Bi1 DONS, as shown in Fig. 5f, is a stepwise oxidation process culmi- nating in the formation of tartronic acid. First, glycerol undergoes successive oxidation steps, each involving the loss of two electrons and protons coupled with the addition of hydroxyl ions. This pro- gression leads to the formation of glyceraldehyde, which subse- quently oxidizes to GLA, thereby maintaining the original C3 carbon skeleton. It is noteworthy that the selectivity for C3 prod- ucts can be attributed to the unique electronic properties of Pt1Bi1 DONS, where the electron-rich Pt facilitates controlled oxidation. Meanwhile, the presence of Bi2O3 for the adsorption of the OH groups in polyols, which changes the adsorption conﬁguration, results in the selective production of GLA. 8 4. Conclusion Herein, Pt1Bi1 DONS were developed to achieve a highly selec- tive yield of C3 value-added products during GOR. Pt1Bi1 DONS demonstrate notable performance, delivering a current of 0.82 A mg1 at 0.67 V vs. RHE and achieving an impressive GLA selectivity of 88.3 and an overall C3 selectivity of 96.6 across a broad potential range. Uniquely, Pt1Bi1 DONS facilitate a pathway exclusively converting glycerol to GLA, as opposed to Pt1Bi3 DONS and cPt NC, where additional pathways are active. Both experimen- tal and theoretical analyses reveal that the electron-rich nature of Pt diminishes its propensity to cleave CC bonds, thus curtailing the formation of C2C1 products. In addition, the adsorption conﬁg- uration of glycerol is critical in determining the product proﬁle, suggesting that the adsorption conﬁguration optimized by Bi2O3 NS can further modulate reaction pathways and thus favor GLA production. This study introduces high-performance Pt1Bi1 DONS for converting glycerol into C3 products and elucidates the mecha- nisms behind their enhanced activity, proposing that the inﬂuence of Bi2O3 on the polyol adsorption conﬁguration can be pivotal in directing reaction pathways. text: Hydrophobic Cation-Immobilized Covalent Organic Frameworks Enable Selective and Stable Electrosynthesis of Ethylene from CO2 Zhengyi Qian, Youxing Liu, Zheng Lin, Na Ye, Yingjun Tan, Fei Liu, Yu Gu, Qizheng Huang, Hongyu Guo, Mingchuan Luo, and Shaojun Guo Cite This: https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c05120 Read Online ACCESS Metrics More Article Recommendations sı Supporting Information ABSTRACT: The electrochemical reduction of CO2 CO2RR offers a promising strategy for the synthesis of multicarbon fuels and chemicals. However, the highly dynamic gaselectrolyte catalyst interface, where ions and reactant molecules exchange in a disorderly manner, restricts the electrocatalytic selectivity and stability. Herein, we immobilize quaternary ammonium cations onto covalent organic frameworks COFs to tailor the interface environment for boosting the electrosynthesis of ethylene. We find that the hydrophobic and microporous structures of the COFs enable fast CO2 transport and rational H2O distribution, while the migration of cations is elegantly tailored through the Donnan effect. As a result, the COF-based electrode delivers a Faradaic efficiency of 46.8 and a high partial current density of 374.2 mA cm2 for ethylene. A developed COF-based practical zero-gap membrane electrode assembly electrolyzer is further demonstrated with stable ethylene production over 89.6 h. In situ spectra and density functional theoretical calculations unveil that the cationic COFs further enhance the local electric field strength, resulting in stronger CO adsorption and a boosted CO dimerization rate. Our study provides a new avenue to enhance multicarbon production via tuning the cathode local mass and charge transfer. INTRODUCTION Electroreduction of CO2 CO2RR to multicarbon products has been regarded as a promising method for CO2 resource utilization. Copper has been proven to be the most active catalyst for multicarbon production; however, it encounters undesirable selectivity and stability.1,2 Many strategies, such as adjusting the electronic structures, morphologies, or defects of copper catalysts, have been widely studied.36 And yet CO2RR takes place at the gaselectrolytecatalyst triple-phase interface, where CO2, H2O and ions usually exchange in a disorderly manner, limiting catalytic efficiency.79 Specifically, gas and water management critically influence the adsorption and diffusion of reactants and related intermediates.10,11 Notably, the overaccumulation of aqueous cations within the cathodes has been proven to lead to salt precipitation, block active sites, and lower energy and carbon efficiencies.7,12,13 Therefore, engineering the local microenvironment to reduce the dynamic degree of the interface is urgently needed. Organic modifiers, including amines,14,15 thiols,16 N- heterocyclic carbenes,17,18 bipyridyl molecules,19,20 and fluo- rocarbons,21 have demonstrated efficacy in tailoring the interface microenvironment to enhance CO2RR selectivity and activity. However, up to now, current mechanistic studies predominantly focus on intermediate adsorption energetics on electrode surfaces in molecular-enhanced CO2RR. Fundamen- tal studies of the triple-phase interface structure, the transport behaviors of chemical species CO2, H2O and ions near the catalysts, and the charge transfer kinetics remain lacking, requiring deeper experimental and theoretical elucidation. Herein, we immobilized quaternary ammonium cations onto hydrophobic covalent organic frameworks COFs to tailor the interface microenvironment for achieving the selective and stable electrosynthesis of ethylene from CO2 Scheme 1. Our results suggest that the COF modification significantly enhances ethylene production at industrial-scale

Herein, we immobilized quaternary ammonium cations onto hydrophobic covalent organic frameworks COFs to tailor the interface microenvironment for achieving the selective and stable electrosynthesis of ethylene from CO2 Scheme 1. Our results suggest that the COF modification significantly enhances ethylene production at industrial-scale current density. The hydrophobic cationic COFs efficiently modulate the transport of CO2 and H2O, affording the cathode abundant triple-phase interfaces. And K diffusion is effectively regulated via the Donnan effect. In situ spectra and density functional theoretical DFT calculations suggest that the interfacial electric field is significantly enhanced after cationic COF modification, facilitating CO adsorption and CO dimerization rate. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION Synthesis and Characterization of Hydrophobic COFs. The hydrophobic COFs were prepared using a solvothermal method as described in our previous work.22 Fluorine-modified monomers were deliberately selected to increase their hydrophobicity. The experimental and simulated XRD patterns reveal that the fluorinated COFs exhibit typical AA rather than AB molecular stacking structures Figures 1a,S1 and S2. Quaternary ammonium cation-modified COFs denoted as Me-COF were further prepared using the impregnation method Figure S3. On the one hand, the strong electron-withdrawing nature of fluorine atoms Figure S4 facilitates the robust adsorption of quaternary ammonium cations, as evidenced by the binding energy shift of F 1s following functionalization with quaternary ammonium cations Figure S5. On the other hand, the nanocavity size of the COFs, approximately 3 nm, allows for the precise confinement of NCH34Br salts, as demonstrated by the N 1s XPS spectra Scheme 1. Schematic Illustrations of Local Environment Tailoring for CO2RR Figure 1. a Experimental and simulated XRD patterns of the as synthesized COF. b N 1s XPS spectra of Me-COF. c The CO2 adsorption capacity of the COF and Me-COF. d Comparison of the adsorbed-K concentration on Cu, CuCOF and CuMe-COF electrodes. Journal of the American Chemical Society pubs.acs.orgJACS Article https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c05120 J. Am. Chem. Soc. XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX B of COF, Me-COF and NCH34Br samples Figures 1b and S6. And the crystal structure of the COF remains intact after loading with quaternary ammonium cations Figure S7. To further probe the chemical bonding properties, Fourier transform infrared FT-IR spectroscopy was performed Figure S8. The characteristic peak at 1625 cm1 corresponds to the C N stretching vibration, confirming the formation of imine bonds in the fluorinated COFs, which can also be verified by the solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance spectra Figure S9. Additionally, the bands at 949 cm1, 1356 cm1 and 1492 cm1 are attributed to the characteristic -NCH34

text: 1625 cm1 corresponds to the C N stretching vibration, confirming the formation of imine bonds in the fluorinated COFs, which can also be verified by the solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance spectra Figure S9. Additionally, the bands at 949 cm1, 1356 cm1 and 1492 cm1 are attributed to the characteristic -NCH34 peaks, further corroborating the successful immobilization of quaternary ammonium cations. To investigate the effect of the chemical environment during the CO2 reduction reaction CO2RR induced by cationic COFs, we further evaluated the CO2 adsorption capacity and hydrophobicity. As shown in Figure 1c, Me-COF demonstrates a significantly higher CO2 adsorption capacity than bare COF, primarily due to the strong affinity of quaternary ammonium cations for CO2 molecules,23 which would be beneficial for CO2 mass transport. Additionally, the nanocavities of the COFs also contribute to CO2 enrichment. We further conducted dynamic CO2 bubble transport experiments to gain quantitative validation for the enhanced CO2 mass transport24 Figure S10. Clearly, the CO2 bubble quickly disappeared after touching the CuMe-COF electrode, while residual bubbles persisted for several seconds on both Cu COF and bare Cu electrodes. These observations establish a CO2 transport efficiency gradient of cationic COFs pristine COFs Cu. Compared to the copper electrode, the CuCOF and Cu Me-COF electrodes exhibit improved hydrophobicity Figures S11 and S12, which helps prevent cathode flooding during the CO2RR. Notably, the bare COF is slightly more hydrophobic than the quaternary ammonium-functionalized COF, likely due to the inherent hydrophilicity of quaternary ammonium cations. K adsorption tests on catalysts were further conducted to investigate the ion transport properties Figures S13 and 1d. The results reveal that the local adsorbed K concentration on the CuMe-COF is much lower than those on the CuMOF and Cu electrodes. The incorporated quaternary ammonium cations could effectively repel K diffusion via the Donnan effect, potentially alleviating carbonate precipitation. Overall, the hydrophobic cationic COFs provide a tailored CO2, H2O and K transport pathway, efficiently modulating the microenvironment for the CO2RR. Electrochemical Performance Measurements. We evaluated the CO2 reduction reaction CO2RR performance of COF-modified nanocopper electrodes Figure S14 under alkaline conditions 1 M KOH. First, we studied the effects of the alkyl chain length of quaternary ammonium salts on the CO2RR performance Figure S15. Obviously, the FE of C2H4 decreases with an increased alkyl chain length, which may be due to the increased hydrophobicity. However, the accom- modation of H2O will simultaneously be suppressed. The best performance appears to result from an optimal gaselectrolyte distribution. Subsequently, the mass ratio of copper to cationic COFs was systematically optimized Figure S16. Data in Figure S17 reveal that the CuMe-COF electrode exhibits a lower overpotential compared to CuCOF and Cu electrodes, indicating higher CO2RR kinetics. As further shown in Figure 2a, the Faradaic efficiency FE of ethylene on the CuMe-COF and CuCOF electrodes significantly increases across the full current density range 200800 mA cm2, with the maximum partial current density for C2H4 reaching 374.2 mA cm2 Figure 2b. All of the other gaseous and liquid Figure 2. a FE of

text: 2a, the Faradaic efficiency FE of ethylene on the CuMe-COF and CuCOF electrodes significantly increases across the full current density range 200800 mA cm2, with the maximum partial current density for C2H4 reaching 374.2 mA cm2 Figure 2b. All of the other gaseous and liquid Figure 2. a FE of ethylene on Cu, CuCOF and CuMe-COF electrodes. b The partial current density of C2H4 on Cu, CuCOF and CuMe- COF electrodes. c FE of ethylene on Cu and CuMe-COF electrodes with diluted CO2 feed 40 vol CO2 d The products distribution of CuMe-COF electrode in MEA electrolyzer. e The stability of CuMe-COF based MEA electrolyzer at 200 mA cm2. Journal of the American Chemical Society pubs.acs.orgJACS Article https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c05120 J. Am. Chem. Soc. XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX C products are shown in Figure S18. Notably, the CuMe-COF electrode also exhibits remarkable ethylene production with diluted CO2 feed 40 vol , using Ar for dilution Figure 2c, highlighting the enhanced mass transfer of CO2 within cationic COF-modified cathodes. High selectivity of C2 products could still be achieved on the CuMe-COF electrode under lower CO2 flow rates Figure S19. The CO2RR performances in acidic electrolyte pH 2 were further investigated Figure S20. Although the CO2 electro- catalytic efficiencies are slightly decreased compared to those under alkaline environments, the FE of C2 products on the Me-COF-based electrode is still higher, which is due to the positive charge and hydrophobic nature of the cationic COFs. Besides, the COFs were also found to exhibit a promoting effect for CO electroreduction Figure S21, highlighting the universal application of COFs in reaction environment tailoring. To isolate the potential contribution of COFs to activity, the CO2RR performances of bare COF and Me-COF were further assessed in a 1 M KOH electrolyte Figure S22. The hydrogen evolution reaction was found to dominate, confirming that the COFs act primarily as promoter additives for microenvironment tailoring. Additionally, the electro- chemical surface area ECSA of the samples shows no significant change according to the electric double-layer capacitance Cdl measurements Figure S23, supporting the intrinsic promoting role of the hydrophobic cationic COFs. We further investigated the CO2RR performance in practical alkaline zero-gap MEA devices Figure S24. It is important to note that the chemical microenvironment at the cathode differs between flow cells and MEA electrolyzers.25 For instance, the transport of ions, water, and CO2 may vary significantly, thereby affecting product selectivity. During CO2 electrolysis, dry CO2 was fed to the cathode without humidification to alleviate possible flooding, while a 10 mM KHCO3 solution was used as the anolyte to prevent salt precipitation within the cathode. As shown in Figure 2d, the FE of C2H4 reaches 46.6 at 500 mA cm2 with a cell voltage of 3.61 V, and the selectivity for CO decreases with an increasing current density. The partial current density for ethylene reaches 253.7 mA cm2 at an operating voltage of 3.68 V, representing one of the best performance metrics observed in MEA electrolyzers. The stability of the MEA device was further evaluated

text: 3.61 V, and the selectivity for CO decreases with an increasing current density. The partial current density for ethylene reaches 253.7 mA cm2 at an operating voltage of 3.68 V, representing one of the best performance metrics observed in MEA electrolyzers. The stability of the MEA device was further evaluated at an industrial current density. Interestingly, the C2H4 FE gradually increases during electrolysis, reaching a maximum value of 40.0. This behavior is primarily attributed to the micro- environment change during the CO2 electrolysis. For H2O molecules and K would gradually transport to the cathode due Figure 3. In situ SEIRAS spectra of a Cu and b CuMe-COF. The change of peak position of CO adsorption band with the applied potential: c Cu and d CuMe-COF, and the slopes of the fitted curves show the Stark tuning rates. e Schematic illustrations of enhanced interfacial local electric field induced by Me-COF. f Peak area ratio of the absorbed CO to H2O. Journal of the American Chemical Society pubs.acs.orgJACS Article https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c05120 J. Am. Chem. Soc. XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX D to electromigration, increasing cathode wettability and concentrations of K near the catalyst, which further effectively facilitates CO dimerization for promoting ethylene forma- tion.26,27 Notably, the electrolyzer demonstrated sustained ethylene production over 89.6 h of continuous operation at 200 mA cm2. The final failure of the MEA electrolyzer was found to be largely attributed to the decrease in cathode hydrophobicity Figure S25 and salt precipitation within the cathode and flow fields Figure S26, consistent with previous reports.28,29 In Situ Spectra Studies and Theoretical Calculations. Seeking to elucidate the promoting role of quaternary ammonium functionalized COF, in situ attenuated total reflection surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy ATR-SEIRAS was performed to monitor the surface species. As shown in Figure 3a,b, several characteristic vibration bands appear in the 18003500 cm1 region during the CO2RR. The vibration band at around 20502060 cm1 can be assigned to the linearly bonded COL species, while no distinct bridge- adsorbed COB is observed. This absence is likely due to the distinct crystal and defective structure of the copper catalyst. Although many researchers have reported that the existence of bridge-adsorbed COB is beneficial for multicarbon forma- tion,20,30,31 this was not observed in our study, indicating that the CC coupling process may proceed via a nontraditional pathway, warranting further investigation. Compared to the pure copper electrode, the vibration band of COL on CuMe- COF electrode shifts to a lower wavenumber, revealing that CuMe-COF exhibits higher affinity toward CO intermediate and thus is more favorable for CO dimerization, which agrees well with the in situ Raman spectra Figure S27. In addition to the increased CO adsorption strength, the CuMe-COF electrode also exhibits a higher Stark tuning rate 14.5 cm1V compared to that of the Cu electrode 11.5 cm1V, as shown in Figure 3c,d. The Stark tuning rate is considered as a key indicator of the local electric field strength.32 This finding implies that the quaternary ammo- nium-functionalized COF creates a stronger local electric field across the electric

metadata.title: Qian 等 - 2025 - Hydrophobic cation-immobilized covalent organic frameworks enable selective and stable electrosynthesis of ethylene from CO2.pdf

text: 14.5 cm1V compared to that of the Cu electrode 11.5 cm1V, as shown in Figure 3c,d. The Stark tuning rate is considered as a key indicator of the local electric field strength.32 This finding implies that the quaternary ammo- nium-functionalized COF creates a stronger local electric field across the electric double layer Figure 3e. A local electric field near the electric double layer can boost CC coupling rate by interacting with COL or other adsorbates with certain dipole moment and polarizability.33,34 It is known that quaternary ammonium cations, confined within the COF cavities, have a larger ionic radius compared to alkali metal cations. As a result, they possess less tightly bound hydration shells, giving rise to a larger charge density and a subsequently much stronger interfacial electric field.35 Additionally, a broad band observed in the range of 3010 3500 cm1 is assigned to the stretching vibration of interfacial water νH2O. Obviously, the intensity of νH2O on the CuMe-COF electrode is significantly lower than that on the Cu electrode, suggesting a relatively lower water content and, consequently, suppressed water flooding at the catalytic interface. To quantify this observation, we calculated the peak area ratio of νCOL to νH2O across different applied potentials. The νCOLνH2O area ratio for the CuMe- COF electrode is noticeably higher than that for the Cu electrode Figure 3f, indicating that Me-COF modification leads to higher CO coverage relative to water at the electrocatalytic interface, which efficiently promotes CC coupling toward C2 products. To further clarify the adsorption behavior of interfacial water, we performed Gaussian fitting on the infrared band of Figure 4. a The optimized structures of Cu 100Me-COF, CO adsorption, and COCO coupling on Cu 100Me-COF surface. b CO adsorption energy and c free energy change of CC coupling process on electrodes. Journal of the American Chemical Society pubs.acs.orgJACS Article https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c05120 J. Am. Chem. Soc. XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX E the OH stretching of interfacial water Figure S28. These peaks were resolved into three different parts: the 4- coordinated hydrogen-bonded water 4-HBH2O, the 2- coordinated hydrogen-bonded water 2-HBH2O, and the K ion-hydrated water KH2O. The results demonstrate that the percentage of the KH2O peak was higher on the Cu electrode than on the CuMe-COF electrode, indicating a decrease in hydrogen bonds, increased H coverage, and correspondingly stronger activity for water dissociation.36 The results fully reflect the hydrophobic nature of the cationic COFs. To determine the actual state of the catalytic sites, XRD patterns and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy HRTEM characterizations were performed. The XRD results reveal that Cu2O component was almost completely reduced to metallic copper after CO2RR Figure S29, while Cu 100 and 111 facets are clearly observed in the HRTEM images Figure S30. To further investigate the exposed surface facet ratio, we examined the electrochemical adsorption of OHon the catalysts i.e., Cu OHCuOHad e in terms of their facet-dependent OHadsorption behavior Figure S31. The cyclic voltammetry curve shows an OHadsorption peak at 0.34 V versus the reversible hydrogen electrode RHE, corresponding to OHadsorption on the

metadata.source: /Users/zemao/ChemQA/data/raw_papers/Qian 等 - 2025 - Hydrophobic cation-immobilized covalent organic frameworks enable selective and stable electrosynthesis of ethylene from CO2.pdf
metadata.title: Qian 等 - 2025 - Hydrophobic cation-immobilized covalent organic frameworks enable selective and stable electrosynthesis of ethylene from CO2.pdf

text: investigate the exposed surface facet ratio, we examined the electrochemical adsorption of OHon the catalysts i.e., Cu OHCuOHad e in terms of their facet-dependent OHadsorption behavior Figure S31. The cyclic voltammetry curve shows an OHadsorption peak at 0.34 V versus the reversible hydrogen electrode RHE, corresponding to OHadsorption on the Cu 100 surface. No obvious peaks attributed to Cu 110 and 111 adsorption were observed. At this point, the Cu 100 facet is confirmed to be the major exposed structure during CO2 electrolysis. Density functional theoretical DFT calculations were conducted to investigate the role of cationic COFs in the CO2RR mechanism. Based on the characterizations of the cathode after CO2RR, the Cu 100 facet was first selected as the model structure Figure S32. Some of the quaternary ammonium-functionalized COF units were placed on the Cu 100 surface to form a heterojunction structure Figure 4a. The CO adsorption energies on Cu 100 and Cu 100Me- COF were calculated to be 1.12 eV and 1.33 eV, respectively, indicating stronger CO adsorption on the Cu 100Me-COF electrode, which is consistent with the experimental ATR-SEIRAS results Figures 4b and S33. Additionally, the free energy change for the rate-determining CC coupling process on the Cu 100Me-COF 0.75 eV was significantly lower than that on the Cu 100 surface 0.82 eV, further suggesting the promoting role of quaternary ammonium-functionalized COFs Figure 4c. In addition to studying the Cu 100 surface, we also computationally explored the Cu 111 surface, the more thermodynamically unfavorable surface for C2 production Figures S34S36, showing that the cationic COFs could still exhibit significant promoting effects. Together, these findings suggest that the COFs offer a promising strategy for tailoring the micro- environment for the CO2RR. CONCLUSIONS In summary, hydrophobic cationic COFs are shown to effectively manipulate the microenvironment with lower dynamic degree, enabling efficient CO2 electrocatalysis toward multicarbon products. The modification with hydrophobic cationic COFs leads to an impressive selectivity for C2H4 46.8 FE with a prominent partial current density of 374.2 mA cm2. The microporous and hydrophobic nature of the cationic COFs efficiently modulates CO2 and interfacial H2O transport. Meanwhile, the immobilized quaternary ammonium cations effectively regulate K migration via the Donnan effect and enhance the interfacial local electric field strength, increasing CO adsorption and promoting CC coupling. In a practical MEA electrolyzer, the CuMe-COF electrode could maintain 89.6 h of operation at 200 mA cm2 with no obvious decline in ethylene selectivity. Our study underscores the significance of microenvironment tailoring in CO2 electrolysis and provides valuable insights into the underlying functional mechanism of organic modifiers. text: Effects of NiOH2 Structures on the Electrochemical Conversion of KA Oil Yanwei Li, Jie Chen, and Yi Shen Cite This: ACS Catal. 2025, 15, 1059110600 Read Online ACCESS Metrics More Article Recommendations sı Supporting Information ABSTRACT: Efficient conversion of KA oil cyclohexanol cyclohexanone mixture to adipic acid AA holds great significance. Herein, a series of NiOH2 samples with well-defined morphologies i.e., nanorod and nanosheet and crystal structures i.e., α and β phases were synthesized and evaluated for electrochemical conversion of KA oil. The catalytic performance of the samples was evaluated by cyclic voltammetry CV, linear sweep voltammetry LSV, and chronoamperometric tests. The products of KA oil oxidation were analyzed using high-performance liquid chromatography HPLC. Among the samples, the α- NiOH2 nanorod exhibited the best electrochemical activity, with a maximum current density of 17.6 mA mg1 at 1.57 V. Such superior activity is related to the large surface area and formation of active NiOOH at lower potentials. HPLC results indicate that the β-NiOH2 nanosheet exhibited the highest adipic acid selectivity of 26 at 1.63 V. Notably, the α-NiOH2 nanosheet shows both poor activity and product selectivity. Open-circuit potential OCP and double-layer capacitance Cdl measurements demonstrated that the adsorption capacity of KA oil over the samples follows the sequence of β-NiOH2 nanosheet α-NiOH2 nanorod α-NiOH2 nanosheet. Operando Raman and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy EIS results suggest that the oxidation of KA oil by the α-NiOH2 nanorod mainly follows the indirect oxidation mechanism, while the oxidation of KA oil by the α-NiOH2 nanosheet follows the direct oxidation mechanism. For the β-NiOH2 nanosheet, both direct and indirect oxidations of KA oil take place. KEYWORDS: nickel-based electrocatalysts, biomass conversion, KA oil conversion, adipic acid electrosynthesis, operando Raman 1. INTRODUCTION KA oil, composed of cyclohexanone K and cyclohexanol A, serves as a crucial platform chemical for the chemical industry. Adipic acid AA, obtained by oxidizing KA oil, is a major industrial chemical with an estimated annual value of ca. 6.3 billion worldwide.1,2 The substantial demand for AA can be attributed to its diverse applications in the chemical, pharmaceutical, cosmetic, and food processing industries.37 With technological advancements, the application scope of AA is expected to expand.8,9 In current industrial processes, the conversion of KA oil into AA is conducted by concentrated nitric acid using copperammonium metavanadate as the catalyst.4,10 However, this process exhibits a low yield of AA in a single production.11 Furthermore, this process involves the use of excess nitric acid, which leads to the generation of greenhouse gas N2O, causing ozone depletion, acid rain, and global warming.12 Obviously, developing a green and efficient method for AA synthesis is an urgent priority. The electro- chemical conversion of organic substrates into high-value- added compounds is regarded as a promising synthetic approach.1316 In a typical electrosynthesis process, electrons act as intrinsic clean reagents, utilizing water as the source of hydrogen or oxygen. This approach eliminates the necessity for additional chemical oxidants, avoiding the use of toxic reagents.1719 Owing to the merits of environmental friend- liness, to date, electrochemical approaches

text: promising synthetic approach.1316 In a typical electrosynthesis process, electrons act as intrinsic clean reagents, utilizing water as the source of hydrogen or oxygen. This approach eliminates the necessity for additional chemical oxidants, avoiding the use of toxic reagents.1719 Owing to the merits of environmental friend- liness, to date, electrochemical approaches have been studied for the synthesis of chemicals.2025 Electrocatalytic oxidation offers a green and efficient strategy for converting KA oil to AA.2628 High-performance electro- catalysts are essential for the application of electrochemical processes. Nickel-based catalysts are widely recognized as promising electrode materials due to exceptional catalytic properties, high natural abundance, and remarkable stabil- ity.2932 The earliest work on electro-oxidation of A to AA was reported by Lyalin and Petrosyan in 2004,33 where a nickel oxyhydroxide NiOOH catalyst achieved an AA yield of 11 via a two-step oxidation process when A was used as the Received: October 6, 2024 Revised: April 21, 2025 Accepted: May 21, 2025 Research Article pubs.acs.orgacscatalysis XXXX American Chemical Society 10591 https:doi.org10.1021acscatal.4c06137 ACS Catal. 2025, 15, 1059110600 Downloaded via TSINGHUA UNIV on June 15, 2025 at 07:46:55 UTC. See https:pubs.acs.orgsharingguidelines for options on how to legitimately share published articles. substrate, while the yield of AA was increased to 52 when K was used exclusively as the substrate. Since then, advancements have been achieved in the development of nickel-based catalysts for improving the catalytic performance, in terms of product selectivity and KA conversion. For example, Gong et al. demonstrated that introducing Cu2 into NiOH2 can effectively promote Cα-Cβ cleavage of A.20 Duans research group found that modifying NiOH2 with sodium dodecyl sulfonate SDS and vanadium V significantly improved catalytic performance because SDS facilitates K enrichment on the catalyst surface and V can accelerate catalyst reconstruction and strengthen K adsorption.26,34 Our group has recently reported a manganese-doped NiOH2 catalyst, which possessed good activity and product selectivity because manganese can modify the adsorption of the substrates.35 Jia et al. studied the mechanism of KA oil oxidation over the NiOH2 catalyst and found that Ni3 is responsible for A hydrogenation to K, while oxygen vacancy is crucial for the subsequent oxidation of K to AA.29 Though efforts have been devoted to this research topic, there are few studies on the dependence of KA oil oxidation on the morphology and crystal phase of NiOH2. In this study, we synthesized nickel hydroxides with controlled morphologies i.e., nanorod and nanosheet and crystal phases α and β phases for the electrochemical conversion of KA oil. The electrochemical measurements indicated that the α-NiOH2 nanorod α-NiOH2NR has the best electrochemical activity, yielding a maximum current density of 17.6 mA mg1 at 1.57 V. Additionally, operando electrochemical Raman spectra revealed that α-NiOH2NR exhibited a lower potential of 1.43 V for the formation active NiOOH. High- performance liquid chromatography HPLC results indicate that the β-NiOH2 nanosheet β-NiOH2NS exhibits the highest AA selectivity of 26 at 1.63 V. Notably, the α- NiOH2 nanosheet α-NiOH2NS shows poor electro- chemical activity and product selectivity. To gain mechanistic insights, open-circuit potential OCP and

text: V for the formation active NiOOH. High- performance liquid chromatography HPLC results indicate that the β-NiOH2 nanosheet β-NiOH2NS exhibits the highest AA selectivity of 26 at 1.63 V. Notably, the α- NiOH2 nanosheet α-NiOH2NS shows poor electro- chemical activity and product selectivity. To gain mechanistic insights, open-circuit potential OCP and double-layer capacitance Cdl measurements have been conducted. This work affords new insights on the dependence of KA oil oxidation on the structure of nickel hydroxides. 2. EXPERIMENTAL SECTION 2.1. Methods. The samples were synthesized via a hydrothermal process.36 Typically, for the preparation of α- NiOH2NR, 10 mmol of NiSO46H2O, 10 mmol of NaOH, Figure 1. Structural characterization of the samples. a, d, g FESEM, b, e, h TEM, and c, f, i HRTEM of α-NiOH2NR, α-NiOH2NS, and β-NiOH2NS, j XRD patterns, k Raman spectra, and l N2 adsorptiondesorption isotherms of the samples. ACS Catalysis pubs.acs.orgacscatalysis Research Article https:doi.org10.1021acscatal.4c06137 ACS Catal. 2025, 15, 1059110600 10592 and 40 mL of DI water were mixed and stirred for 1 h, followed by hydrothermal treatment 120 C, 24 h in a PTFE-lined autoclave. For the preparation of β-NiOH2NS, the procedures are the same, except that 20 mmol of NaOH was used. For the preparation of α-NiOH2NS, 0.3490 g of NiNO326H2O, 0.3604 g of urea, 0.0889 g of NH4F, and 30 mL of DI water were prepared for the hydrothermal process. After centrifugation, the obtained products were washed with ethanol and DI water and then dried for further use. 2.2. Structure Characterization. Field emission scanning electron microscopy FESEM and transmission electron microscopy TEM, FEI Tecnai F30 were employed to observe the sample morphology. X-ray diffraction XRD, PANalytical Xpert powder diffractometer was used to analyze the crystalline structure of the samples. Raman spectra of the samples were recorded from a Raman Microscope Thermo Scientific DXR3 with a 532 nm excitation laser wavelength. BrunauerEmmettTeller BET analysis was performed to quantify the specific surface areas of the samples. 2.3. Electrochemical Characterization. Electrochemical characterization was performed on a CHI 760E workstation Shanghai Chenhua Co., Ltd. connected to a three-electrode setup. In alkaline electrolytes, an HgHgO electrode, a blank carbon paper, and a glassy carbon electrode were used as the reference, counter, and working electrodes, respectively. The working electrode was prepared by uniformly loading with 16 μg of catalysts via a typical drop-casting process.37 Potentials were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode RHE using E V vs. RHE E V vs. HgHgO 0.0592 V pH 0.098 V. 2.4. Analysis of Products. The analysis of the products of electro-oxidation of KA oil by the as-prepared samples was conducted by HPLC as reported by our research group.38 Briefly, the reaction was performed in an H-type cell separated by a Nafion-117 membrane. An HgHgO electrode, a blank carbon paper, and the catalyst-coated carbon paper 2 2 cm2 were used as the reference, counter, and working electrodes, respectively. The electrolyte volume was 30 mL. The substrates were quantified by HPLC Agilent 1260 Infinity Series equipped with a reverse-phase C18 column and refractive index detector

text: HgHgO electrode, a blank carbon paper, and the catalyst-coated carbon paper 2 2 cm2 were used as the reference, counter, and working electrodes, respectively. The electrolyte volume was 30 mL. The substrates were quantified by HPLC Agilent 1260 Infinity Series equipped with a reverse-phase C18 column and refractive index detector RID, kept at a constant column temperature of 35 C. The mobile phase consists of acetonitrile and DI water 6:4, vv. For product analysis from KA oil electro-oxidation, separation was achieved using an Aminex HPX-87H Bio-Rad column with 5 mM sulfuric acid aqueous solutions as the mobile phase. The column temperature was maintained at 65 C during the operation. KA oil conversion and product selectivity were determined through the following eqs 1 and 2, respectively KA oil conversion mol of KA oil consumed mol of inital KA oil 100 1 product selectivity mol of specific product formed mol of KA oil consumed 100 2 3. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION 3.1. Structural Characterization. The morphologies of the as-synthesized samples are characterized, as shown in Figure 1. In general, pH is critical for the phase stability of NiOH2 and a specific surfactant can alter the reaction interface and adjust the crystal growth direction. Consequently, control synthesis can be achieved by adjusting the pH and surfactant of the reaction system.36 Figure 1a,b illustrates the representative FESEM and TEM overview images of α- NiOH2NR, which exhibit a typical rod-like structure with an approximate diameter of 13 nm Figure S1a. The HRTEM image in Figure 1c reveals well-defined lattice fringes in α- NiOH2NR with a measured spacing of 0.218 nm in region 1. Correlating this observation with the standard card ICDD No. 00-022-0444 from the XRD database presented in Table S1, it can be determined that this lattice spacing corresponds to the 103 planes of α-NiOH2. As shown in Figure 1d,e, α-NiOH2NS exhibits a sheet-like morphology with an average lateral size of ca. 110 nm Figure S1b. HRTEM analysis Figure 1f further confirms the crystalline structure, where the measured lattice spacing of 0.219 nm in region 2 corresponds to the 103 planes of α-NiOH2. In contrast, β-NiOH2NS Figure 1g,h consists of smaller nanosheets ca. 58 nm, Figure S1c, and its HRTEM image Figure 1i reveals a distinct lattice spacing of 0.265 nm in region 3. Combined with the standard card ICDD No. 00- 001-1047 Table S2 of the XRD database, it can be inferred that this lattice spacing is ascribed to the 100 planes of β- NiOH2. These results indicate the successful synthesis of NiOH2 with well-defined morphologies. The XRD results of the as-synthesized samples are presented in Figure 1j. The diffraction peaks of β-NiOH2NS are well aligned with the standard card ICDD No. 00-001-1047, confirming the formation of the β-NiOH2 crystalline phase. Specifically, the diffraction peaks at ca. 19, 33.2, and 38.6 correspond to the 001, 100, and 101 crystal planes of β- NiOH2, respectively. text: the formation of the β-NiOH2 crystalline phase. Specifically, the diffraction peaks at ca. 19, 33.2, and 38.6 correspond to the 001, 100, and 101 crystal planes of β- NiOH2, respectively. The diffraction peaks of the α- NiOH2-NS sample can be indexed to the standard card ICDD No. 00-022-0444, demonstrating that the sample is primarily composed of α-NiOH2. Specifically, the peaks at ca. 11.6, 23, 33.7, 34.5, 38.9, and 59.9 correspond to the 001, 002, 110, 111, 103, and 300 crystal planes of α-NiOH2, respectively. However, a meticulous analysis indicates that several characteristic peaks in the XRD pattern do not align with the standard card, potentially due to the presence of a minor quantity of β-NiOH2. The synthesis of high-purity α-NiOH2 poses significant challenges.39 Like- wise, the XRD pattern of α-NiOH2-NR displays distinct peak shifts and broadening, which may be ascribed to the presence of β-NiOH2 impurities, variable hydration, and crystal defects.4042 Raman spectra were further employed to investigate the structural features of the samples, as illustrated in Figure 1k. The Raman results reveal significant differences in the characteristic peaks among the samples. According to group theory, β-NiOH2 exhibits four fundamental vibrational modes 2A1g 2Eg, which are typically observed in the spectral regions of 310318, 445453, and 3581 cm1.43 A meticulous analysis of the spectrum of β-NiOH2NS reveals characteristic peaks at 310 and 446 cm1, which are assigned to the EgR and A1gT vibrational modes of β-NiOH2, respectively.44 Additionally, the peak observed at 880 cm1 ACS Catalysis pubs.acs.orgacscatalysis Research Article https:doi.org10.1021acscatal.4c06137 ACS Catal. 2025, 15, 1059110600 10593 corresponds to the lattice vibration of β-NiOH2.39 In contrast, α-NiOH2 usually shows structural irregularities,45 resulting in some differences in the observed peaks. Upon thorough analysis of the spectrum of α-NiOH2NS, a characteristic peak at 470 cm1 is ascribed to the lattice vibration of α-NiOH2, whereas the peak at 1044 cm1 is attributed to the intercalation of NO3 ions between the layers. Additionally, the characteristic peak observed at ca. 1400 cm1 may be due to the splitting of the OH bending mode within the lattice OH caused by the structural disorder.46 The peak at ca. 490 cm1 in the α-NiOH2NR spectrum also arises from the α-NiOH2 lattice vibrations. Notably, the peaks observed at 451, 607, 986, and 1105 cm1 can be attributed to the intercalation of SO4 2in the sample. The N2 adsorption desorption isotherms of the samples were recorded to determine their specific surface areas, as illustrated in Figure 1l. Among the synthesized samples, α-NiOH2NR exhibits the largest BET surface area of 91.1 m2 g1, exceeding those of β-NiOH2NS 55.6 m2 g1 and α-NiOH2NS 6.6 m2 g1. 3.2. Electrochemical Performance. Since K and A share an identical reaction pathway and pure KA is rarely employed in industrial processes,20 we prepared KA oil by mixing equimolar quantities of K and A 1:1 to simulate industrial feedstock conditions. The electrochemical properties of the resulting samples were investigated by using cyclic voltamme- try CV and linear sweep voltammetry LSV. As shown in Figure 2a, the CV curve

text: employed in industrial processes,20 we prepared KA oil by mixing equimolar quantities of K and A 1:1 to simulate industrial feedstock conditions. The electrochemical properties of the resulting samples were investigated by using cyclic voltamme- try CV and linear sweep voltammetry LSV. As shown in Figure 2a, the CV curve of α-NiOH2NR in 1 M KOH solutions reveals an oxidation peak at a potential of 1.42 V, corresponding to the oxidation of Ni2.26,29,47 As the scanning potential continues to increase, a rise in the current density is observed, signifying the onset of the oxygen evolution reaction OER. Similar characteristics are noted from the LSV curve see Figure 2e. Notably, following the addition of 0.1 M KA oil, a higher oxidation peak emerges at a potential of 1.56 V, which is attributed to the oxidation of the KA oil. Specifically, the peak current density for KA oil oxidation in the CV curve of α-NiOH2NR reaches 34.2 mA mg1. Correspondingly, a larger oxidation peak is observed in the LSV results at the same potential, as shown in Figure 2e. The occurrence of the OER subsequently initiates after the oxidation of KA oil, indicating that the oxidation of KA oil has a competitive advantage over the OER. The CV curve of α-NiOH2NS see Figure 2b, similar to that of α-NiOH2NR, exhibits an oxidation peak for Ni2 at 1.41 V in 1 M KOH solutions. After the addition of 0.1 M KA oil, a higher oxidation peak emerges at ca. 1.53 V, which is associated with the oxidation of KA oil. Compared to α-NiOH2NR, α-NiOH2NS demonstrates a lower current density for KA oil oxidation. Specifically, the CV curve indicates a current density of only 2.3 mA mg1 for KA oil oxidation. As depicted in Figure 2c, the CV curve of β- NiOH2NS in 1 M KOH solutions exhibits an oxidation peak at 1.46 V, indicative of the oxidation of Ni2. Upon the introduction of 0.1 M KA oil, the CV curve demonstrates the presence of a shoulder peak located at ca. 1.52 V, which is attributed to the oxidation of the KA oil. Compared to α- NiOH2NS, β-NiOH2NS demonstrates an increased current density for KA oil oxidation. Specifically, the peak current density for KA oil oxidation in the CV curve of the β- NiOH2NS sample is 4.5 mA mg1. Previous studies have confirmed the irreversible phase transition from α-NiOH2 to β-NiOH2 in alkaline solutions, especially under electrochemical conditions.48,49 To evaluate the stability of α-NiOH2NS under the operational conditions, TEM characterization of the catalyst after 4 h electrolysis at 1.63 V was performed. Additionally, after 4 h electrolysis, CV tests of 100 cycles see Figure S2b were performed, which exhibited negligible peak potential shifts, further proving the structural stability of α-NiOH2NS in 1 M KOH 0.1 M KA oil solutions. Figure 2d compares the LSV curves of the three samples in 1 M KOH with and without 0.1 M KA oil solutions. In the absence of KA oil, all three samples show similar OER characteristics, with an onset potential of ca. 1.51 V following a weak peak associated with the oxidation of Ni2 ca. 1.39 V. Notably, α-NiOH2NS has a low current density due to its small BET surface area Figure 1l. Upon KA oil addition, the current densities of the samples increase, and the onset potential of KA oil oxidation is much lower than that of the OER, indicating that KA oil oxidation is more favorable than the OER. The α-NiOH2NR catalysts exhibited a peak current density of 17.6 mA mg1, substantially outperforming both β-NiOH2NS 5.05 mA mg1 and α-NiOH2NS 1.71 mA mg1. The introduction of KA oil significantly accelerated the reaction kinetics of α-NiOH2NR, manifested by shifting the polarization curve toward lower voltages by 156 mV at a current density of 5 mA mg1. The energy efficiency of KA oxidation by α-NiOH2NS and β-NiOH2NS is also superior relative to that of the OER see Figure 2e. Meanwhile, the Tafel slopes of the samples were determined Figure 2f. Specifically, the Tafel slope values for OER and KA oil oxidation of α-NiOH2NS are 85.9 and 53.7 mV dec1, respectively, which are lower than those of α-NiOH2 NR 87.7 and 57.8 mV dec1 and β-NiOH2NS 98.4 and 107.9 mV dec1. 3.3. Analysis of Products. To determine the products of KA oil electro-oxidation, an electrolysis process was conducted in an H-type cell. The concentration of the products and substrates was analyzed by HPLC. First, cyclohexanol A, cyclohexanone K, and several possible carboxylic acids, including adipic acid AA, glutaric acid GA, and succinic acid SA, were identified by HPLC, and a variety of standard curves were established to accurately determine their concentrations see Figures S3, S4a, and S5a. It should be pointed out that AA, GA, and SA are the most desirable products from the oxidation of KA oil. However, some other byproducts could be possibly present in the electrolytes but not analyzed in this work. In addition, to verify the degradation of KA oil in 1 M KOH solutions without electrolysis, 50 mM KA oil was placed under the same

In addition, to verify the degradation of KA oil in 1 M KOH solutions without electrolysis, 50 mM KA oil was placed under the same reaction conditions without performing electrolysis at various times. As shown in Figure S6, the conversion rates of KA oil after 2, 4, and 20 h were 0.9, 1.6, and 5.3, respectively. This extremely low degradation rate is considered to be negligible. Furthermore, no degradation products were detected at the 4 h time point, confirming that the observed degradation had no significant impact on the experimental results. The conversion of KA oil and resulting products obtained from the samples are shown in Figures 3ac and S4bd. In the process of KA oil oxidation, the electrolysis potential is one of the important factors that influences product distribution. Understanding the effects of electrolysis potential on product distribution is desirable for rational control of the target product. Thus, the product distribution of KA oil oxidation by the three catalysts at different applied potentials was investigated. α-NiOH2NR yields AA selectivities of 7.4, 11.0, and 14.1 at applied potentials of 1.43, 1.53, and 1.63 V, respectively. The α-NiOH2NS yields AA selectivities of 5.8, 10.3, and 16.3 at 1.43, 1.53, and 1.63 V, respectively. No GA was detected at 1.43 V, while GA selectivities of 7.6 and 23.7 were obtained at 1.53 and 1.63 V, respectively. At 1.63 V, α- NiOH2NS yields a SA selectivity of 6.2. The β-NiOH2 NS yields AA selectivities of 6.3, 22.9, and 26.0 at 1.43, 1.53, and 1.63 V, respectively. Similarly, no detection of GA was observed at 1.43 V, while GA selectivities of 6.6 and 9.1 were obtained at 1.53 and 1.63 V, respectively. Additionally, SA was observed only at 1.63 V, with a selectivity value of 4.2. The results presented above suggest that the selectivity for AA, GA, and SA of the three catalysts increases with an increasing applied potential. At 1.63 V, the ranking of AA selectivity among the three catalysts follows the sequence of β-NiOH2 NS α-NiOH2NR α-NiOH2NS. Consequently, β- NiOH2NS exhibits the most optimal AA selectivity of 26.0 at 1.63 V for 4 h electrolysis. This could be related to the adsorption of the substrates and intermediates. As illustrated

Briefly, as the applied potential increases, the KA oil conversion of the samples also rises. However, a close inspection could reveal that the KA oil conversion of α- NiOH2NS at 1.53 V does not exhibit a significant increase compared to 1.43 V, while there is a notable increase in product selectivity, potentially attributed to the fact that α- NiOH2NS produced more byproducts at 1.43 V. Notably, β-NiOH2NS exhibits the highest conversion of 30.9 at 1.63 V for 4 h electrolysis, which may be due to the fact that the main exposed crystal plane in β-NiOH2NS is 100, while that in α-NiOH2NR and α-NiOH2NS is 103 as shown in Figure 1c,f,i. To further explore the effects of substrate concentration on the product distribution of KA oil oxidation, chronoamperometric tests were conducted for 4 h in the electrolytes with varying KA oil concentrations at 1.63 V. The products of KA oil oxidation and KA oil conversion obtained from the β-NiOH2NS are illustrated in Figures 3e, S4e, and S5e. AA selectivity of the sample increases from 16.6 to 26.0 as the substrate concentration gradually increases from 10 to 50 mM and decreases with a further increase in substrate concentration to 100 mM, leading to a maximum value of 50 mM. Using 50 mM KA oil as the substrate, the selectivity for side products such as GA and SA is quite limited. With the increase of substrate concentration, the conversion rate of KA oil shows little variation, indicating that within the range of 25100 mM, the conversion of KA oil by β- NiOH2NS is not dependent on substrate concentration. These findings suggest that a substrate concentration of 50 mM is optimal for the selective oxidation of KA oil into AA on the electrode surface, which could be related to the adsorption of the substrates on the electrode

text: of KA oil by β- NiOH2NS is not dependent on substrate concentration. These findings suggest that a substrate concentration of 50 mM is optimal for the selective oxidation of KA oil into AA on the electrode surface, which could be related to the adsorption of the substrates on the electrode surface and subsequent oxidation kinetics.29 In addition, β-NiOH2NS was used to perform constant potential electrolysis of KA oil at 1.63 V for 10 h. The product distribution and KA oil conversion at 1, 2, 4, 6, 8, and 10 h are illustrated in Figures 3f, S4f, and S5f. Throughout the electrolysis, AA is the primary product of KA oil oxidation, and the selectivities of AA, GA, and SA increase with electrolysis time. Specifically, the selectivity of AA is increased from 9.1 to 27.0. The conversion of KA oil also increases with time, reaching 57.5 after 10 h of electrolysis. Within the initial 2 h of electrolysis, the selectivity of AA exhibits a rapid increase, reaching 17.7. However, during the subsequent period of 210 h, AA selectivity slowly increases. Instead, the selectivity of the byproducts, including GA and SA, has demonstrated a steady increase during this period. Notably, the maximum selectivity for GA reaches 15.0. 3.4. Mechanistic Studies on KA Oil Electro-Oxidation. To gain insights into the mechanism of KA oil oxidation, the adsorption behavior of KA oil over the catalysts was first studied by measuring the OCP, which reflects the variation of absorbates within the Helmholtz layer.51 In 1 M KOH solutions, the primary adsorbed species are typically water molecules and K and OHions. As shown in Figure 4a, β- NiOH2NS exhibits the highest OCP before the addition of KA oil, likely resulting from its smallest electrochemical active surface area ECSA and, therefore, the least adsorption of these species. However, upon the introduction of KA oil, the adsorbed species expanded to include water molecules and K, OH, and KA oil molecules in solution. Consequently, the observed difference in the OCP can be attributed to the adsorption of KA oil molecules. Specifically, after KA oil was injected, a more noticeable decrease in OCP of the β- NiOH2NS electrode Δ 395 mV was detected compared with those of α-NiOH2NR Δ 270 mV and α-NiOH2 NS Δ 112 mV, revealing that the absorption capacity of KA oil over the three samples follows the order of β-NiOH2 NS α-NiOH2NR α-NiOH2NS. In addition, Raman spectra were used to investigate the adsorption properties of the samples see Figure S7a. For clarity, the Raman spectra of KA oil, K, and A solutions and carbon paper were also recorded see Figure S7b. The band assignments were made by referencing established experimental and theoretical studies.52,53 In 1 M KOH solutions, no other peaks are noted, except those of carbon supports. In contrast, additional peaks at 2863, 2907, and 2951 cm1 are noted in 1 M KOH 0.1 M KA oil solutions, which were attributed to the vibration of CH groups from the carbon rings, indicative of the adsorption of

text: solutions, no other peaks are noted, except those of carbon supports. In contrast, additional peaks at 2863, 2907, and 2951 cm1 are noted in 1 M KOH 0.1 M KA oil solutions, which were attributed to the vibration of CH groups from the carbon rings, indicative of the adsorption of KA oil onto the samples.35 In the vicinity of OCP, the variation of the adsorbates within the Helmholtz layer could substantially influence the Cdl of the electrode.51,53 Thus, measuring the Cdl values provides insights into the KA oil oxidation mechanism of the synthesized catalysts. Within the non-Faradaic region, the CV curves were recorded at varying scan rates, as shown in Figures S8 and S9. The current at the anodic sweep ia and cathodic sweep ic were recorded, and their difference Δi was determined by Δi ia ic2. The slope of the linear fitting of Δi against the scan rate corresponded to the value of Cdl see Figure 4b,c. The Cdl values of α-NiOH2NR, α-NiOH2NS, and β- NiOH2NS in 1 M KOH 0.1 M KA oil solutions are 3.11, 3.45, and 2.84 μF, respectively. The ECSA was derived by dividing the Cdl by the specific capacitance Cs 40 μF cm2.54,55 The ECSA values of the samples were determined to be 0.078, 0.086, and 0.071 cm2, respectively, which primarily arise from crystallographic phase effects and morphological differences.50 Specifically, the α-NiOH2NS samples exhibit a loosely stacked layered structure compared to that of β- NiOH2NS, and the NiOH2 nanosheets typically possess a higher density of exposed edge sites and structural defects compared to nanorods, contributing to the enhanced ECSA despite their larger lateral size. To verify the potential influence of surface modification induced by urea on the ECSA of α- NiOH2NS, the Cdl values of α-NiOH2NS in 1 M KOH 0.1 M KA oil 0.05 M urea solutions were also determined. The resulting value was compared with that obtained in 1 M KOH 0.1 M KA oil solutions, as shown in Figure S10. Specifically, the Cdl of α-NiOH2NS exhibits a slight increase from 3.45 to 3.56 μF upon adding urea, suggesting that urea had little effect on the ECSA of α-NiOH2NS. Notably, the catalytic activity of the samples does not correlate well with their Cdl values, suggesting that the catalytic oxidation activity of the samples toward KA oil is determined by factors beyond the ECSA. To reveal the intrinsic activity, the ECSA- normalized current density was plotted against potential, as shown in Figure S11a. Figure S11b comparatively shows the intrinsic activity of the three samples for KA oil oxidation and the OER. Interestingly, the ECSA-normalized current density of the three samples follows the order of α-NiOH2NR β- NiOH2NS α-NiOH2NS, which is consistent with that of mass-normalized current density see Figure 2d,e. However, the BET surface area-normalized current density of the three samples follows the sequence of α-NiOH2NS α- NiOH2NR β-NiOH2NS see Figure S12, which is due to the fact that α-NiOH2NS with a loosely stacked layered structure exhibits the smallest BET surface area and

text: of mass-normalized current density see Figure 2d,e. However, the BET surface area-normalized current density of the three samples follows the sequence of α-NiOH2NS α- NiOH2NR β-NiOH2NS see Figure S12, which is due to the fact that α-NiOH2NS with a loosely stacked layered structure exhibits the smallest BET surface area and the largest ECSA among the three samples. This behavior aligns with previous reports where catalysts with moderate BET surface areas but optimized nanostructures, e.g., Fe-LNO and HCSNi,56,57 exhibit exceptional ECSA. The Cdl values of the catalysts in 1 M KOH solutions were also determined. The resulting values were compared with ACS Catalysis pubs.acs.orgacscatalysis Research Article https:doi.org10.1021acscatal.4c06137 ACS Catal. 2025, 15, 1059110600 10597 those obtained in 1 M KOH 0.1 M KA oil solutions, as shown in Figure 4b. Specifically, the Cdl of β-NiOH2NS exhibits an increase from 2.59 to 2.84 μF upon adding KA oil, suggesting that β-NiOH2NS shows superior adsorption for KA oil. The difference between the two Cdl values ΔCdl follows the sequence of β-NiOH2NS 0.25 μF α- NiOH2NR 0.17 μF α-NiOH2NS 0.02 μF, indicating the variations in the adsorption capacity of KA oil over the three catalysts, which is consistent with the findings from the OCP tests. Moreover, capacitive measurements were applied to explore the adsorption of KA oil over the catalysts. The adsorption of KA oil onto the catalyst surface would modify the structures of the electric double layer, which in turn leads to variations in the interfacial capacitance.24 As illustrated in Figure S13, both β-NiOH2NS and α-NiOH2NR exhibit notable reductions in capacitance upon the addition of KA oil. In contrast, the capacitance of α-NiOH2NS shows the smallest change, demonstrating that among the three samples, α-NiOH2NS displays the lowest adsorption capacity for KA oil. To reveal the active sites of the as-synthesized samples for the electro-oxidation of KA oil, operando electrochemical Raman spectroscopy was employed Figure 4di. In 1 M KOH solutions, the Raman spectrum of α-NiOH2NR recorded at 1.63 V displays two weak peaks centered at ca. 487.5 and 562.7 cm1, which are attributed to Ni3-O bending and stretching vibrations, respectively,29,5860 as evidenced in Figure 4d. In 1 M KOH 0.1 M KA oil electrolyte, the formation of NiOOH occurs at 1.43 V, as confirmed by the appearance of two characteristic peaks at ca. 479.8 and 556.4 cm1 see Figure 4g. α-NiOH2NR exhibits a lower potential for the formation of NiOOH in the presence of KA oil, suggesting that KA oil significantly facilitates the reconstruction of α-NiOH2NR. Notably, vigorous bubble generation was observed at the potentials exceeding 1.63 V, blocking the objective lens and consequently resulting in the disappearance of Raman peaks.34 The Raman spectra of α- NiOH2NS were collected at varying potentials as shown in Figure 4e,h. The absence of Raman signals related to Ni3-O bending and stretching vibrations indicates that Ni2 oxidation in α-NiOH2NS is difficult, aligning with the LSV data. As shown in Figure 4f, β-NiOH2NS requires a lower applied potential 1.53 V to form NiOOH in 1 M KOH solutions compared

text: in Figure 4e,h. The absence of Raman signals related to Ni3-O bending and stretching vibrations indicates that Ni2 oxidation in α-NiOH2NS is difficult, aligning with the LSV data. As shown in Figure 4f, β-NiOH2NS requires a lower applied potential 1.53 V to form NiOOH in 1 M KOH solutions compared with α-NiOH2NR. In contrast, in the presence of KA oil, NiOOH formation occurred at a higher potential 1.63 V, likely due to the excellent adsorption of β-NiOH2NS for KA oil.26,47,61 To further investigate the KA oil electro-oxidation kinetics and interfacial behaviors, operando electrochemical impedance spectroscopy EIS measurements were conducted.27 Figure S14 shows the Bode plots recorded in 1 M KOH 0.1 M KA oil solutions. The high-frequency response 101105 Hz is typically associated with the processes taking place in the inner electrode,62 including the electro-oxidation of the catalyst surface. The low-frequency region 102101 Hz reflects the nonhomogeneous charge distribution, such as the appearance of surface-adsorbed species at the interface.27 The Bode plots of the samples exhibit a characteristic peak at ca. 1 Hz, emerging at 1.23 V, showing a negative phase shift with increasing applied potential. On the basis of LSV results, this peak is ascribed to the adsorption of OH.35 Subsequently, characteristic peaks appear in the direction of higher phase angles, which is related to the oxidation of the KA oil. Specifically, the potentials of KA oxidation of α-NiOH2NR 1.53 V, α-NiOH2NS 1.49 V, and β-NiOH2NS 1.47 V are shown in Figure S15, corresponding to their respective KA oil oxidation peaks at 1.56, 1.53, and 1.52 V in the CV curves see Figure 2ac. According to the report of Bender et al., there are two pathways, namely, direct oxidation and indirect oxidation mechanisms for KA oxidation by NiOH2.61 The detailed mechanism of KA oxidation is closely related to the valence state of the nickel species. To address this issue, the potentials of NiOOH formation determined from operando electro- chemical Raman spectra see Figure 4gi are compared with those of KA oil oxidation derived from operando EIS see Figure S14, and CV results see Figure 2ac, as shown in Figure S15. The oxidation of KA oil by α-NiOH2NR occurred after the formation of NiOOH species, indicating an indirect oxidation pathway. No Raman signals related to the formation of active NiOOH intermediates were detected from α-NiOH2NS in 1 M KOH 0.1 M KA oil solutions, indicating that the oxidation of KA oil by α-NiOH2NS could follow a direct oxidation pathway. In contrast, the oxidation of KA oil by the β-NiOH2NS sample preceded the formation of NiOOH, suggesting that the oxidation process could possibly involve both direct and indirect oxidation mechanisms. 4. CONCLUSIONS In conclusion, three NiOH2 samples, including α-NiOH2 NR, β-NiOH2NS, and α-NiOH2NS, with well-defined morphology and crystal structures were evaluated for electro- chemical conversion of KA oil. α-NiOH2NR had the best electrochemical activity, with a maximum current density of 17.6 mA mg1 at 1.57 V, which was significantly higher than those of β-NiOH2NS and α-NiOH2NS.
