For further confirmation, we quantified the instances of NO3 as hydrogen-bonds acceptors Figure 3E, and the analysis indicated that more hydrogen bonds of H2ON2 were associated with NO3 as the potential decreased Figure S25. The strengthened connectivity of the hydrogen-bond networks facilitates proton transfer to the interface,27,28 which is essential for the conversion of NO2 to ammonia via proton-coupled electron transfer steps. Figure 3F encapsulates the atomic bilayer EDL structure at the 1:11 Au111LiNO3 interface, illustrating both the NO3 activation process and hydrogen bond enrichment. In this scenario, the nitrite yield rate and the population of H2ON2 are proposed to mirror the ammonia yield rate. Moreover, the H2ON2 population serves not only as a direct indicator of the EDL structure but also as a predictive descriptor of the NO3RR activity. Concentration-Dependent EDL Evolution. Notably, the H2ON2 population and yield rates of the products exhibited a volcanic-like dependence on concentration with a maximum of 1:11 LiNO3 Figures 4A and S15. The interplay between NO3 and interfacial hydrogen-bond networks, alongside the reduction behavior, underscores a distinct structurefunction relationship within the EDL. Variations in the H2ON2 population with bias potential were analyzed in both diluted and superconcentrated solutions, as illustrated in Figure 4B,C, respectively. In diluted electrolytes, the limited availability of LiNO3 in the bulk solution restricts the presence of both Li and NO3 at the interface. This scarcity results in a more inclined configuration to interact with H2O at relatively positive potentials Figure S31, thereby impeding the activation of NO3 . Concurrently, although unbound NO3 can enhance the hydrogen-bond network of interfacial water, the Li ions dominate the hydrogen-bond networks due to their propensity to aggregate near the interface inset in Figure 4B. Consequently, this results in a decreasing trend in H2ON2 at less negative potentials. In contrast, at a highly negative potential, the electric field draws an abundance of Li and NO3 to the interface, facilitating the formation of a distinct NO3 bilayer. This leads to an increase in the H2ON2 population, thus boosting the NO3RR efficiency. In more concentrated electrolyte solutions, a less negative potential is required to organize the NO3 bilayer and more H2ON2 is formed correspondently, correlating with enhanced efficiency in NO3RR. However, at excessively high concentrations, a

text: NO3 bilayer. This leads to an increase in the H2ON2 population, thus boosting the NO3RR efficiency. In more concentrated electrolyte solutions, a less negative potential is required to organize the NO3 bilayer and more H2ON2 is formed correspondently, correlating with enhanced efficiency in NO3RR. However, at excessively high concentrations, a significant decrease in the number of water molecules was observed alongside a considerable enrichment of Li ions at the interface. This leads to the phenomenon that nearly all of the oxygen atoms of interfacial NO3 are coordinated with Li, rendering them incapable of forming hydrogen bonds with water molecules the insets are shown in Figures 4C and S32. The weak interaction between the NO3 and water molecules results in less connected hydrogen-bond networks within the EDL. In the context of superconcentrated LiNO3, which exhibits a polymer-like structure Figure S4,19 the formation of stable LiH2O2n chain maintains a constant population of H2ON2 population, with minimal variation with changes in potential. The reduction of NO3 is thus impeded in superconcentrated Au111LiNO3 on account of structural obstacles and a scarcity of available H2O. A schematic of the concentration-dependent interfacial solvation structure on Au111LiNO3 is shown in Figure 4D. The crystallographic orientation and electronic structure of the electrode significantly impact the interfacial waterion networks. We further monitored the NO3RR efficiency by tuning the waterion network through varying the crystallo- graphic orientations of Au single-crystal surfaces Figures S10, S11. The product Figures 5A and S16 yield rates follow the order Au111 Au110 Au100, sharing a similar trend with the corresponding H2ON2 population. The more positive point of zero charge PZC indicates a higher surface charge density on the Au111 surface, thereby facilitating the organization of the interfacial bilayer structure.29 The surface structure thus directly impacts the formation of an efficient EDL, highlighting the critical role of crystallographic orientation in the design of electrocatalytic interfaces. Building on these findings, we designed a heterostructure by spontaneously adsorbing Sn onto the Au111 surface to further enhance the nitrate reduction activity. The Au111-Sn demonstrated superior NH3 and NO2 yield rate Figures 5A, S2B, S16 and S17, alongside the highest proportion of H2ON2 Figure S12, which could be attributed to the suppression of the competing HER by Sn.30 The hetero- structure design of Au111-Sn underscores the importance of combining different materials to leverage synergistic effects, where Sn acts to optimize the interfacial waterion networks and further enhances the catalytic performance shown in Figure 5B. The activation energy for dissociation of NO3 with Li-coordinated oxygen on Au111-Sn was calculated by AIMD Figure S33. The activation energy decreases to 0.96 eV on Au111-Sn, revealing Sn-induced electron redistrib- ution facilitates nitrate adsorption and activation. These findings indicate that the EDL structures share similarities at these electrodes, and the variance in the electrocatalytic performance is primarily derived from the efficiency in orchestrating the bilayer structure, as evidenced by H2ON2 populations. CONCLUSIONS Utilizing AuhklLiNO3 interfaces as a model system, we established a comprehensive framework that deciphers the intricate relationship among interfacial waterion networks, electrolyte concentration, and nitrate reduction kinetics. At operational potentials, we observed the formation of a hierarchical structure consisting of well-organized cation anion planes and highly connected hydrogen-bond networks. Figure 5. XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX F The structured cationanion planes act as a catalyst, driving the attraction and activation of anions through electrostatic forces, while the interconnected hydrogen-bond networks facilitate continuous anion reduction. The efficiency of these interfacial waterion networks is crucial for constructing the bilayer structure, revealing a volcanic-like relationship between anion reduction efficiency and electrolyte concentration. This insight highlights the intricate interactions between ions and solvents at the interface, which significantly enhance the reduction dynamics of anions. Our findings underscore the critical role of the interfacial waterion microstructure in optimizing electrocatalytic kinetics, offering valuable guidance for the design and engineering of more efficient and sustainable energy systems. Ed. 2025, e202509377 Link to VoR: https:doi.org10.1002anie.202509377 RESEARCH ARTICLE 1 Tailoring Coordination Microenvironment of Nickel Molecular Complexes for Electrooxidation of Organic Nucleophiles Chengdong Yang a, Yun Gao b, Yueqing Wang a, Wenwen Cai a, Jizhen Ma a, and Jintao Zhang a a Dr. C.D. Zhang Key Laboratory for Colloid and Interface Chemistry, Ministry of Education School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan 250100, China E-mail: jtzhangsdu.edu.cn J.T. Zhang b Y. Gao Engineering Research Center of Advanced Rare Earth Materials, Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China Supporting information for this article is given via a link at the end of the document. Abstract: Electrochemical oxidation of organic nucleophiles to value- added chemicals using nickel-based catalysts is promising yet hindered by the dynamic evolution of nickel coordination structures during catalysis. Herein, we engineered atomically exposed nickel molecular catalysts anchored on functional carbon black through tailored aromatic ligands coordination. This unique spatial coordination structure efficiently promotes the reconstruction of high- valence NiIII-OOH sites, which boost electrooxidation of 18 organic substrates with peak current density exceeding 800 mA cm-2. Especially, the optimal electrocatalyst achieves record mass activities of 4.38 and 4.26 A mgNi-1 for methanol and ethylene glycol oxidation, respectively. In-situ characterization and theoretical analyses elucidate that the atomically exposed NiIII-OOH centers would directly adsorb organic substrates, thereby enhancing C-CC-H bonds cleavage efficiency. Meanwhile, the proton abstraction from C-H bond would enable reversible redox cycling between NiII-OH and NiIII-OOH, sustaining catalytic activity. This study advances the understanding of organic oxidation mechanisms and showcases the great potential of molecular complexes in electrocatalysis. Introduction Replacing the sluggish oxygen evolution reaction OER by electrooxidation of organic substrates have demonstrated with low energy consumption for hydrogen H2 productions at cathode and value-added chemicals and fuel generations at anode1. In particular, this technology with mild operation conditions shows significant promise in various fields, such as biomass update2, raw materials processing3, waster plastic cycle4, and wastewater pollution treatments5 Figure 1a. Recently, nickel- based catalysts are particularly advantageous for catalyzing organic electrooxidation6, exhibiting much lower onset potential than OER7. The in-situ generation of nickel oxide hydroxide NiOOH species with highly electrophilic lattice oxygen

Recently, nickel- based catalysts are particularly advantageous for catalyzing organic electrooxidation6, exhibiting much lower onset potential than OER7. The in-situ generation of nickel oxide hydroxide NiOOH species with highly electrophilic lattice oxygen atoms endows their efficiently electrochemical activity8,9. However, the immovable lattice oxygen species in bulk NiOOH would shield the directly adsorption of reactants on Ni sites10 Figure 1b, thus leading to low accessibility of nickel sites and limited diffusion rates of reactant. These drawbacks account for slow organics oxidation reaction kinetics, limiting current density to below 500 mA cm-211. Furthermore, for electrooxidation of polyhydric alcohols, the sluggish cleavage of CC bonds leads to unsatisfied reaction activities and product selectivity12. Although the oxygen vacancy-mediated strategies have been proposed13, the limited availability of oxygen vacancies depress the catalytic efficiency, and the mechanisms behind CC bonds cleavage are still not fully understood. Therefore, it is still challenging to properly adjust the structure and surface properties of Ni-based catalysts to fully expose metal sites for advancing organics oxidation processes. In metalloprotein enzymes, organic ligands coordinating with metallic sites have demonstrated the ability to fine-tune catalytic environments, significantly impacting enzyme catalytic efficiency14. The artificial organic-metal hybrids, such as metal- organic frameworks MOFs and coordination polymers featured with the flexible coordination environments15, have also exhibited unexpected catalytic activities and selectivity in various fields16, providing great potential to overcome the innate limitation of traditional catalysts. However, the organic electrooxidation is mainly proceeded on the near-surface regions of a catalyst, thereby the bulk organic-metal hybrids with poor conductivity and complicated structural reconstructions would disturb the essential understanding of structure-activity relationships17. Additionally, the low accessibility of inner catalytic sites limit catalytic efficiency, and the occupied metal orbitals fail to directly activate the CC bonds18. Therefore, at the atomic scale, creating molecularly dispersed organic-metal hybrid catalysts with coordinatively unsaturated states is essential for uncovering the reaction mechanisms of organic oxidation process. Herein, we developed a series of nickel-based isostructural molecular complexes through coordinating nickel ions with aromatic carboxylate ligands on conductive carbon substrates. The π-π stacking interactions between aromatic ligands and the carbon support efficiently stabilize the highly accessible nickel sites. Especially, the geometric diversity of ligands provides high flexibility in regulating the coordination environments and electron structures of nickel sites supported, which is key for the dynamic generation of highly accessible NiIII-OOH sites via sequential OH- nucleophilic attack and dehydrogenation. These hypervalent NiIII- OOH sites with electrophilic oxygen enable superior electrocatalytic oxidation of 18 organic molecules with high- current density over 800 mA cm-2. In particular, methanol and ethylene glycol EG oxidation achieved high mass activities of 4.38 and 4.26 A mgNi-1 at 1.45 V, respectively. In situ characteristics and theoretical analysis confirm that the atomically exposed nickel sites would benefit CH and CC bond cleavage via unoccupied nickel d orbitals Figure 1c, aided by OH- nucleophilic attack. Simultaneously, the electrophilic oxygen species in NiIII-OOH facilitate proton abstraction from CH

This work would provide a foundational understanding of electrocatalytic oxidation mechanisms and highlight the potential of molecular complexes for advanced catalytic applications. Results and Discussion A series of isostructural Ni-based molecular complexes were synthesized by assembling of Ni2 ions with various aromatic organic linkers on oxidzied Ketjenblack OKB Figure 2a, referred to as Ni-PTAOKB, Ni-BPDAOKB, and Ni-PTDAOKB, respectively. Importantly, the different geometry configurations and molecular structures of these aromatic ligands allow rational manipulation of the π-π stacking interactions between the molecular complexes and OKB supports19. The oxygen functional groups on carbon support would also facilitate the anchoring of nickel-ligand coordination sites through strong π-π stacking interactions. Transmission electron microscopy TEM images reveal that the OKB supports are coralloid nanostructure with an average branch size of 3040 nm Figure S1. The absence of MOFs sheets in these Ni-based molecular complexes suggests that the nickel sites are molecurlarly dispersed on the carbon supports Figure 2b and Figure S2-S3. For comparison, the direct assembling Ni2 ion with aromatic ligands in the absence of OKB support leads to the formation of nickelbased MOFs layers Ni-MOL with 2D nanosheets structure Figure S4. Xray diffraction patterns of these Ni-based molecular complexes only display the characteristic diffraction peaks of carbon substrate Figure S5-S6, confirming the molecular dispersion of nickel sites. Furthermore, high-resolution high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM HAADF-STEM of Ni-BPDAOKB exhibits isolated bright dots marked by yellow circles on carbon support, unveiling the atomic dispersion of nickel centers Figure 2c and Figure S7. STEM elemental mapping and line scanning results demonstrate the uniform distribution of Ni elements on carbon supports Figure S8-S9. Then, Fourier transform infrared FTIR spectra show noticeable redshifts of the vCO peak to 1600 cm-1 and the vC-O peak to 1385 cm-1 in these molecular complexes, compared with the organic ligands, attributed to the coordination between nickel ion and carboxylic acid group Figure S10. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XPS analysis revealed that the Ni loading in Ni-BPDAOKB was approximately 6.72 wt Table

Additionally, the X-ray absorption near- edge structure XANES spectra at the Ni K-edge exhibit a slightly higher absorption position than that of NiO, suggesting an average valence state higher than Ni2 Figure 2e. Fourier transforms FT and wavelet-transforms WT analyses of the extended X-ray absorption fine structure EXAFS spectra at the Ni K-edge exhibit a primary peak at 1.97 Å and a weaker peak at 2.45 Å Figure S13-16. These peaks correspond to Ni-O bonds in first coordination shell and Ni-O-C bonds in second coordination shell, respectively Figure 2f and Table S2. Notably, the Ni-O-C bonds, with coordination numbers around 1.9, indicates that the unsaturated Ni sites are coordinated with two BPDA ligands. Notably, the Ni-O-C bonds, with coordination numbers around 1.9, indicates that the unsaturated Ni sites are coordinated with two BPDA ligands. The presence of long-range Ni-CO bonds confirms the interactions between Ni sites and OKB supports, which would stabilize the structure of molecular complexes. Besides, no Ni-Ni or Ni-O-Ni bond in EXAFS spectrum can be detected, confirming the atomical dispersion of nickel sites in Ni- BPDAOKB. Electrocatalytic performance Cyclic voltammetry CV curves were conducted to investigate the NiII to NiIII oxidation Figure 3a. The Ni-BPDAOKB exhibit a pronounced quasi-reversible redox peak at 1.26 V compared to Ni-PTDAOKB at 1.27 V and Ni-PTAOKB at 1.30 V, indicating an easier redox process for NiIINiIII in Ni-BPDAOKB21. This can be contributed to fast electron transferring between molecular complexes and OKB substrate through the strong π-π stacking interactions20c. Then, the electrocatalytic oxidation activities of 18 organic substrates, including primary alcohols, aldehydes, amines, and compounds with multiple reactive groups were evaluated using linear sweep voltammetry LSV curves in 1.0 M KOH Figure 3b. The Ni-BPDAOKB shows low onset potential and rapidly-growing current density for various organic substrates, demonstrating the exceptional electrocatalytic activities Figure S17-25. Methanol oxidation reaction MOR is employed to evaluate CH bond cleavage kinetics in 1.0 M KOH Figure S26-S27. The Ni-based molecular complexes show faster reaction kinetics than that of corresponding bulk Ni-MOL, indicating the superior catalytic performance due to the highly accessible nickel sites Figure S28. Besides, the Ni-BPDAOKB only requires 1.47 V to reach a current density of 400 mA cm-2, significantly lower than those of Ni-PTDAOKB 1.52 V and Ni-PTAOKB 1.55 V Figure 3c. The ratios of overpotential η to current density logj for Ni-BPDAOKB is lowest 200 mV dec-1, indicating the fastest reaction kinetics Figure 3d and Figure S2922. The outstanding catalytic performance of Ni-BPDAOKB can be attributed to rapid electron transfer between the molecular complexes and carbon substrates. Ion chromatography IC and 1H nuclear magnetic resonance NMR spectroscopy analyses revealed the high Faradaic efficiencies FE of formate production, exceeding 94 under various applied potentials Figure S30-S31. Besides, the potential-dependent Nyquist and Bode plots obtained from in situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy confirmed the fast electron transfer Figure S32. The long-term durability test performed at 1.4 V and 1.5 V without iR compensation demonstrate the stability of Ni-organic coordination structures during electrooxidation Figure S33. Ethylene glycol oxidation reaction EGOR studies showed similar catalytic behaviors as MOR, with Ni-BPDAOKB exhibiting high catalytic efficiency for CC bond cleavage Figure 3e. The Ni-BPDAOKB achieve an ultra-high current density of 800 mA cm-2 at 1.59 V, outperforming previously reported EGOR catalysts with current density below 500 mA cm-2 Figure S34 and Table S3. In contrast, the Ni-BPDA-MOL shows much slower EGOR catalytic kinetic than that of MOR. This slower rate is attributed to the sluggish CC bond breaking on saturated Ni-BPDA-MOL with fewer accessible nickel sites. However, the Ni-BPDAOKB shows an ultra-high EGOR mass activity of 4.26 A mgNi-1 at 1.45 V, which is 13 times higher than that of Ni-BPDA-MOL Figure 3f. IC and 1H NMR spectra confirmed the high FE of formate production across a wide range of potentials Figure 3g and Figure S35-S36, resulting from the effective cleavage of CC bonds. This structural advantage highlights the significance of atomically dispersed nickel sites in enhancing catalytic activity for organic oxidations. The dynamical structural evolution and reaction pathways on Ni-BPDAOKB were further elucidated using in situ Raman measurements in different electrolytes Figure S37-S38. Under OER conditions, new Raman bands appear at 471 and 552 cm-1 with a potential of 1.30 V Figure 4a, assigning to the bending and stretching vibrations of Ni3-O structures in γ-NiIII-OOH24, respectively. These characteristic bands of NiIII-O remained stable after reactions Figure S39, indicating that the NiIII-OOH structure once formed, is irreversible during OER. In comparison, during MOR, the bending and stretching vibration peaks show a blue shift to 476 and 560 cm-1, respectively, suggesting the weakened NiIII-O bond in NiIII-OOH Figure 4b. Interestingly, upon removal of the voltage input, the NiIII-OOH species gradually disappeared after 60 s, thus demonstrating the transient nature of these active sites Figure 4c and Figure S40. The transient NiIII- OOH with highly electrophilic oxygen species, facilitates proton abstraction from α-CH bonds, thereby achieving a reversible redox process between NiII-OH and NiIII-OOH and the regeneration of coordination structures in Ni-BPDAOKB. In situ Raman spectra also reveal that the NiIII-OOH formation is driven by the dehydrogenation of OH adsorbed on highly oxidative nickel atoms Figure 4d. To further explore the dynamic reconstruction of NiIII-OOH, CV curves were conducted with varying organic substrate concentrations. At high substrate concentrations, the

text: structures in Ni-BPDAOKB. In situ Raman spectra also reveal that the NiIII-OOH formation is driven by the dehydrogenation of OH adsorbed on highly oxidative nickel atoms Figure 4d. To further explore the dynamic reconstruction of NiIII-OOH, CV curves were conducted with varying organic substrate concentrations. At high substrate concentrations, the CV curves of MOR and EGOR exhibit high current density during the negative scan, thus indicating a hysteresis effect Figure 4e and Figure S41. The hysteresis can be interpreted by the insufficient NiIII-OOH active sites during the initial positive scan, demonstrating that the favorable adsorption of organic substrates would compete with the formation of active NiIII-OOH. This standpoint can also be confirmed by the delayed MOR onset potential and the weakening of NiII NiIII redox peaks at higher methanol concentrations Figure S42-S43. Furthermore, the pristine Ni-BPDAOKB presents increasing current density over time, demonstrating a self-activation process wherein Ni sites undergo gradual structural reconstruction to form NiIII-OOH species Figure S44. Compared with Ni-BPDAOKB, the Ni- BPDAOKB-OOH obtained by direct activation in 1.0 M KOH, exhibits a lower MOR onset potential but suboptimal catalytic performance at high-current densities Figure S45, likely due to disrupted coordination structures. The above findings demonstrate that the NiIII-OOH species, featuring highly electrophilic oxygen atoms and atomically exposed nickel sites, play a pivotal role in driving the oxidation of organic substrates. Meanwhile, intensive proton transfer from activated CH bonds ensure structural stability by reduction of the active centers. Then in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy XAS analysis under MOR conditions has been conducted. As shown in Figure 5a, b, the Ni K-edge gradually shifts to higher energy as the applied potential increases from open circuit potential OCP to 1.5 V, indicating an increase in the oxidation state of Ni species. This high valence state is attributed to the dynamic structure evolution of Ni-ligand coordination structure in alkaline conditions. The spent Ni-BPDAOKB catalyst after MOR shows a lower Ni valence state compared to that after OER, thus indicating the presence of a reversible NiIII-OOH center during MOR. Figure 4. The Ni- BPDAOKB after MOR only exhibits a Ni-O bond at 2.07 Å, similar with that in pristine Ni-BPDAOKB, indicating a reversible redox cycle between NiIII-OOH and center NiII-OH. Conversely, the Ni- BPDAOKB after OER shows a prominent Ni-O bond at 2.05 Å and a weak Ni-O-Ni bond at 3.17 Å Tables S4-S8, suggesting the formation of irreversible NiIII-OOH centers under these conditions. For Ni 2p XPS spectra, the Ni-BPDAOKB exhibits a slight increase in the valence states of Ni after MOR Figure 5d, which is consistent with XAS analysis. Furthermore, the HAADF- STEM image of Ni-BPDAOKB after prolonged MOR show isolated bright dots marked by yellow circle Figure 5e, demonstrating the stable nickel-ligand coordination structures. Mechanism investigation To further understand the pathways of organic oxidation on electrophilic transient NiIII-OOH sites, the attenuated total reflection surface-enhanced infrared adsorption spectroscopy ATR-SEIRAS was conducted Figure S49. Before MOR, the vC-OH peak at 1228 cm-1 Figure 6a and Figure S50 indicates the favorable adsorption of methanol on coordinatively unsaturated nickel sites. This is primarily due to the feasible electron donation from the σ-orbital of -OH group into the vacant d orbital of Ni2 centers. As the potential increases above 1.35 V, this peak weakens, suggesting the consumption of methanol adsorbed. Besides, the emergence of a new v-COO peak at 1580 cm-1 confirms the formation of CHOO-. Density functional theory calculations further elucidate the reaction pathways, using a model with nickel sites coordinated to two ligands Figure S51-S52. The Ni-BPDAOKB exhibits the highest π-π stacking energy between Ni-molecular complexes and carbon substrate Figure 6b, which would facilitate electron transfer. The π-π stacking interactions are influenced by both the length of aromatic nucleus and the geometry of organic ligands. The BPDA ligand, with longer benzene ring, leads to stronger π-π stacking interactions in Ni-BPDAOKB compared to Ni-PTAOKB. In contrast, the Ni-PTDAOKB

text: carbon substrate Figure 6b, which would facilitate electron transfer. The π-π stacking interactions are influenced by both the length of aromatic nucleus and the geometry of organic ligands. The BPDA ligand, with longer benzene ring, leads to stronger π-π stacking interactions in Ni-BPDAOKB compared to Ni-PTAOKB. In contrast, the Ni-PTDAOKB with longest benzene ring exhibits lower π-π stacking due to the reduced overlap of π-electron clouds caused by the off-plane conformations of PTDA ligands Figure S53. This is further supported by Mulliken atomic charge analysis, which shows the highest valence state of Ni sites in Ni- BPDAOKB Figure S54-S55. An exponent relationship is observed between NiII-OH dehydrogenation energy and π-π stacking energy for Ni-based molecular complexes Figure 6c and Figure S56. This result unveils that the strong π-π stacking interactions would promote the dehydrogenation of NiII-OH structure, thus facilitating the reconstruction of hypervalent NiIII- OOH. The reaction pathways for electrocatalytic MOR were investigated, starting with methanol adsorbed on NiII-OH sites, followed by a stepwise dehydrogenation process. Optimized adsorption configurations and corresponding Gibbs energy diagrams reveal that the spontaneous dehydrogenation of OH bonds in methanol can be driven by the highly oxidative NiIII-OOH species Figure 6d and Figure S57. Proton abstraction from CH bonds can be significantly facilitated by the electrophilic oxygen atoms in NiIII-OOH compared to NiII-OH Figure 6e and Figure S58. Importantly, this proton abstraction process not only benefits the activation and dehydrogenation of CH bonds, but also aids in the reduction of NiIII-OOH to NiII-OH. See the Terms and Conditions https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comterms-and-conditions on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License RESEARCH ARTICLE 8 6g, likely due to the weaker activation effects of the Ni d-orbital on C-C bonds25. Additionally, the Pourbaix diagrams, derived from pH-dependent catalytic activity tests, exhibit that the slope of Ni-BPDAOKB is consistently around 122 mV pH-1 Figure 6h and Figure S61. Thus, the high slope demonstrates that the EG oxidation can be significantly influenced by the OH- nucleophilic attack26. Overall, the organic electrooxidation processes on Ni- based molecular complexes are illustrated in Figure 6i. The hypervalent NiIII-OOH species, acting as proton acceptors, facilitate the dehydrogenation of CH bonds through rapid proton abstraction, which helps regenerate the Ni-organic coordination centers. The direct adsorption of organic substrates on atomically exposed nickel sites would promote CC bond cleavage via the activation of Ni d orbital. Additionally, the OH- nucleophilic attack can also assist in CC bonds cleavage and formate formation. Conclusion A series of molecular complexes were developed by coordinating aromatic organic ligands with nickel on oxygen-functional ketjenblack. This configuration is optimized to modulate the Ni- organic coordination structure for dynamic generation of NiIII-OOH. Typically, the Ni-BPDAOKB electrocatalyst demonstrated the ability to electrooxidize 18 different substrate molecules. Especially, the methanol and EG oxidation achieved high mass activity of 4.38 and 4.26 A mgNi-1 at 1.45 V, respectively. In situ characterizations and theoretical analysis revealed that the atomically exposed NiIII-OOH sites with unoccupied d orbital enable direct adsorption of organic reactants, thus achieving feasible CH and CC bonds cleavage. The proton abstraction from CH bonds to NiIII-OOH can induce the reversible redox transition between NiII-OH and NiIII-OOH, thereby stabilizing the coordination structures. This study provides essential insights into the mechanisms of organic nucleophile oxidation on innovative molecular complexes sites. The authors also acknowledge the assistance of the Analytical Center for Structural Constituent and Physical Property of Core Facilities Sharing Platform Shandong University, and the 1W1B station in the BSRF for help with XAS characterizations. text: RESEARCH ARTICLE www.advmat.de Tuning Surface Coordination Environment of Ni3N by Fluorine Modiﬁcation for Eﬃcient Methanol Electrooxidation Assisted Hydrogen Evolution Hongye Qin, Jinhong Li, Guangliang Lin, Kangnan Yuan, Haocheng Yang, Yukun Ye, Ting Jin, Fangyi Cheng, and Lifang Jiao Replacing the kinetically sluggish oxygen evolution reaction with the thermodynamically favorable methanol oxidation reaction MOR represents a promising strategy for energy-eﬃcient hydrogen production. However, optimizing electrocatalytic performance in the coupled hydrogen evolution reaction HER and MOR requires precise regulation of the electrochemical coordination environment and a fundamental understanding of activity origins, posing a signiﬁcant challenge. Here, a scalable strategy is developed that harnesses the high electronegativity of ﬂuorine F to tailor the coordination environment of Ni3N, enhancing HER kinetics. Concurrently, adsorbed F ions induce rapid and extensive self-reconstruction of the Ni3N surface during MOR by dynamically modulating interfacial ion concentrations OHand Ni species. This reconstruction enhances catalytic activity and enables the selective oxidation of methanol to formate via a sequential pathway, involving primary O-H bond activation followed by subsequent C-H bond cleavage at Ni active sites. Consequently, F10-Ni3N demonstrates exceptional bifunctional performance, delivering 2.02 V and remarkable stability 600 h for MOR-coupled hydrogen production in a membrane electrode assembly-based ﬂow electrolyzer at an industrially relevant current density of 200 mA cm2. This work establishes a dual-regulation paradigm for electrocatalysts, oﬀering mechanistic insights into surface reconstruction and a rational design framework for next-generation energy conversion systems. 1. Introduction As concerns grow over the depletion of fossil fuels and the as- sociated environmental impact of their use, increasing attention H. Qin, J. Li, G. Lin, K. Yuan, H. Yang, Y. Ye, T. Jin, F. Cheng, L. Jiao Frontiers Science Center for New Organic Matter Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry Ministry of Education State Key Laboratory of Advanced Chemical Power Sources Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Science and Engineering Tianjin College of Chemistry Nankai University Tianjin 300071, China E-mail: jiaolfnankai.edu.cn The ORCID identiﬁcation numbers for the authors of this article can be found under https:doi.org10.1002adma.202507573 DOI: 10.1002adma.202507573 has been drawn to the exploration of al- ternative and greener carbon sources.1 Hydrogen, with its non-toxic, high-energy density, and environmentally friendly prop- erties, is emerging as one of the most promising candidates to replace conven- tional fossil fuels soon.2 Electrocatalytic water splitting for hydrogen production is one promising method that can trans- form intermittent energy from renewable sources, such as solar and wind, into sta- ble chemical energy.3 However, the slug- gish kinetics and high overpotential of the OER hinder the eﬃciency of H2 produc- tion in water splitting and severely ham- per the large-scale application of electro- chemical water splitting.4 Thus, replac- ing anodic OER with small-molecule oxida- tion reactions, which have favorable ther- modynamic potential, is gradually becom- ing a promising research ﬁeld.5 A promis- ing strategy is integrating the methanol oxidation reaction MOR with the hydro- gen evolution reaction HER, which pro- duces both valuable chemicals and hydro- gen with high energy density and low toxicity.6 To expedite the progress of this

metadata.title: Qin 等 - 2025 - Tuning surface coordination environment of Ni3 N by fluorine modification for efficient methanol electrooxidation assisted hydrogen evolution.pdf

text: modynamic potential, is gradually becom- ing a promising research ﬁeld.5 A promis- ing strategy is integrating the methanol oxidation reaction MOR with the hydro- gen evolution reaction HER, which pro- duces both valuable chemicals and hydro- gen with high energy density and low toxicity.6 To expedite the progress of this emerging ﬁeld, it is crucial to focus on designing eﬃcient bifunctional electrocatalysts that can facilitate both HER and MOR. Non-noble metal nickel Ni-based materials, such as nitrides like Ni3N, show great potential for industrial applications in HER and MOR due to their high catalytic activity, unique electronic structures, and enhanced surface morphologies.7 In addition, as HER catalysts, even partial active sites on the low-index facets of Ni3N show Pt-like hydrogen adsorption Gibbs free energy ΔGH theoretically.8 However, the weak Ni-N interaction and the interstitial occupation of N typically result in elevated unoc- cupied orbital energy, particularly for Ni atoms distant from N atoms, which consequently leads to a weak capability for water activation. Furthermore, the hollow sites far from N atoms with stronger ΔGH constrain the HER dynamics severely.5f,9 Con- currently, Ni3N catalysts have been widely studied for electrocat- alytic biomass oxidation owing to their excellent capacity to ac- tivate C-H or O-H bonds.10 Additionally, as for non-noble Ni- based catalysts, in situ-generated oxyhydroxides during MOR Adv. Mater. 2025, 2507573 2025 Wiley-VCH GmbH 2507573 1 of 14 www.advancedsciencenews.com www.advmat.de are usually regarded as real active sites for pre-catalysts.11 How- ever, most nickel-based MOR pre-catalysts exhibit sluggish sur- face self-reconstruction processes and low electrical conductiv- ity, which signiﬁcantly reduce the MOR rate, increase energy consumption, and severely hinder their practical applications.12 Therefore, the reasonable design of the surface structure of Ni- based catalysts to accelerate the formation of favorable NiOHO sites under low voltage remains a critical challenge in MOR. Meanwhile, a deeper understanding of precatalysts reconstruc- tion essentials and methanols dissociation mechanism on MOR- activated surfaces, particularly at the atomic level, is imperative. Based on the abovementioned concerns, a rational bipolar de- sign of the catalyst is beneﬁcial to achieve high-performance bi- functional materials for both MOR and HER applications. Typ- ically, the performance of catalysts is largely determined by the chemical structure of outer or sublayer atoms surrounding the surface active sites that directly interact with reactant species.13 Therefore, rationally tuning the surface micro-structure of Ni3N to achieve eﬃcient bi-functional HER and MOR is critical. Pre- cise surface functionalization of catalysts is a crucial strategy for modulating their chemical and structural properties, enhancing catalytic performances, and accelerating their self-reconstruction process. The ﬂuorine F element, with the strongest electroneg- ativity 3.98, is expected to serve as an ideal surface modiﬁer for Ni3N due to its strong ability to attract electrons.14 Recent stud- ies suggest that ﬂuoride ions form strong metal-ﬂuorine bonds by coordinating with the surface metal of catalysts, owing to their unique structural characteristics. This bonding enhances ionic interactions, thereby modulating the electronic structure of the active sites.15 Furthermore, ﬂuoride incorporation has been shown to improve catalyst conductivity, which

text: Recent stud- ies suggest that ﬂuoride ions form strong metal-ﬂuorine bonds by coordinating with the surface metal of catalysts, owing to their unique structural characteristics. This bonding enhances ionic interactions, thereby modulating the electronic structure of the active sites.15 Furthermore, ﬂuoride incorporation has been shown to improve catalyst conductivity, which facilitates in situ dynamic surface reconstruction. As a result, the pre-catalyst un- dergoes a favorable transformation into the active high-valent nickel oxide phase under electrooxidation conditions.14a Herein, we report the controllable synthesis of surface Fion modiﬁed Ni3N nanosheets composed of nanoparticles on metal- lic Ni using a hydrothermal method and sequential nitriding treatment. Under alkaline conditions, these modiﬁed nanosheets exhibit higher electrocatalytic activity for HER and high selec- tivity for MOR. Multifaceted characterization and analysis reveal that the F anions occupy surface inactive sites on the Ni3N sur- face, forming strong ion bonds, and act as activity centers or pro- moters to enhance water dissociation and proton transfer col- lectively. Additionally, the ﬂuoride incorporation increases sur- face ion concentration OH, and Ni2, promoting in situ rapid dynamic surface self-reconstruction and converting the original F10-Ni3N into a loosely and amorphous metal oxide under MOR conditions. Moreover, combined with the in-situ attenuated to- tal reﬂectance Fourier-transform infrared ATR-FTIR spectrum and the density functional theory DFT calculations, reveals that methanol molecular dehydrogenation involves primary O- H bond activation and secondary C-H bond activation steps at Ni surface sites. The calculated thermodynamic energy barrier for the MOR reveals that the CHO coupling with OH- is a potential determination step. Lastly, a bipolar design system demonstrates F10-Ni3N exhibits outstanding performance 2.02 V and remark- able stability up to 600 h in MOR-coupled hydrogen production within a membrane electrode assembly-based ﬂow electrolyzer at an industrially relevant current density of 200 mA cm2. 2. Results and Discussion 2.1. Material Synthesis and Characterization The Ni3N and F-modiﬁed Ni3N catalysts grown on Ni foam were prepared by the hydrothermal method and subsequent nitrid- ing treatment as schemed in Figure 1a. Three distinct samples with varying F concentrations were synthesized: pristine Ni3N denoted as Ni3N, F-modiﬁed Ni3N with 10 mmol F precursor F10-Ni3N, and F-modiﬁed Ni3N with 15 mmol F precursor F15- Ni3N. Their stoichiometric proportions were conﬁrmed using energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy EDX, as shown in Table S1, Supporting Information. The bulk chemical structures were further conﬁrmed by X-ray diﬀraction XRD patterns as shown in Figure 1b. The three prominent peaks located at 44.5, 70.3, and 78.1 correspond to the 111, 300, and 113 planes of Ni3N, respectively.7c The chemical bonding state of Ni3N, F10- Ni3N, and F15-Ni3N were examined through Raman spectroscopy Figure S1, Supporting Information. The peaks observed at 204 and 536 cm1 in the spectrum could be attributed to Raman- active vibration modes of Ni3N.10a Compared to Ni3N, the Ra- man characteristic peak of F10-Ni3N and F15-Ni3N compared with Ni3N exhibits a red shift from 536 to 523 cm1, indicating that introducing F ions alters the chemical environment of the Ni3N surface. SEM images show that pure

text: attributed to Raman- active vibration modes of Ni3N.10a Compared to Ni3N, the Ra- man characteristic peak of F10-Ni3N and F15-Ni3N compared with Ni3N exhibits a red shift from 536 to 523 cm1, indicating that introducing F ions alters the chemical environment of the Ni3N surface. SEM images show that pure Ni3N adopts a morphology resembling seaweed-like clusters Figure 1c. After modiﬁcation with F ions, vertical nanosheets composed of irregular nanopar- ticles were widely distributed on the entire Ni foam Figure 1d. Transmission electron microscopy TEM images demonstrate that Ni3N, F10-Ni3N, and F15-Ni3N are exclusively composed of nanoparticles Figure 1e,f; Figure S3, Supporting Information. The particle size distributions conform to a narrow Gaussian pro- ﬁle, with over 85 of the particles falling within the size ranges of 75150 nm for Ni3N, 75250 nm for F10-Ni3N, and F15-Ni3N, respectively. Notably, the broader size distribution observed in the F-doped variants, particularly F10-Ni3N and F15-Ni3N, sug- gests that the incorporation of F ions signiﬁcantly inﬂuences the growth kinetics of Ni3N, thereby promoting controlled particle coarsening and facilitating the development of larger nanopar- ticles. Moreover, the corresponding element mapping by EDX undoubtedly conﬁrms the homogeneous distribution of Ni, N, and F elements in the ﬂuorinated product, indicating that F is uniformly presented on the Ni3N surface Figure 1g, Figure S4. Additionally, the high-resolution TEM HRTEM images of Ni3N Figure 1h, F10-Ni3N Figure 1ij and F15-Ni3N Figure 1k in- dicate that the lattice spacing of the plane is 0.214, 0.203 nm, which agrees well with the spacing of the 002, and 111 planes of Ni3N.7c To investigate the surface valence states and local micro- environment of catalysts, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XPS measurements were further carried out. The Ni 2p core level spectrum exhibits two pairs of spin-orbit peaks with binding en- ergies at 852.7, 855.9 eV, as well as two shake-up satellite peaks Figure 2a.16 As seen in the XPS spectrum of Ni 2p, there is a positive shift of 0.1 and 0.2 eV for the Ni 2p peak in the F10-Ni3N and F15-Ni3N compared to that in Ni3N. This demon- strates the electron density delocalization around Ni atoms in the F-modiﬁed Ni3N, due to the stronger electronegativity of F com- pared to N. The surface F atomic fraction F atoms F atoms plus N atoms measured by XPS for the F10-Ni3N catalysts is 19.08, which is higher than their bulk contents 11.16, as measured by the energy-dispersive X-ray analysis Table S2, Supporting In- formation. These phenomena collectively indicate that the F ions are more prone to bond at the surface of Ni3N than in the bulk. The X-ray absorption near edge structure XANES results inset in Figure 2e conﬁrm that F10-Ni3N exhibits a slightly higher ox- idation state compared to Ni3N, corroborating the ﬁndings from the XPS analysis. Notably, the pre-edge intensity of the white line, which corresponds to the electronic transitions18 is observed to be marginally elevated in F10-Ni3N compared to pristine Ni3N. This subtle yet signiﬁcant enhancement points to a profound al- teration in the electronic structure of the Ni3N species. Such a modiﬁcation is likely attributable to the pronounced interactions between ﬂuorine and Ni3N, which may induce a redistribution of electronic states and modulate the local coordination environ- ment of the nickel centers. In addition to the comparison of surface F content before and after Ar sputtering, supplementary DFT calculations further cor- roborate the ﬁnding that F ions are prone to occupy the surface sites of Ni3N rather than substituting N sites. The position for F integration in Ni3N was investigated by calculating the forma- tion of energy Eform of substitution or adsorption Figure 2f. Adv. Surface diﬀerential charge density maps reveal that F-modiﬁed Ni3N surfaces exhibit a more pronounced electron-deﬁcient state Figure 2g,h, as more electrons from surface Ni atoms are trans- ferred to F atoms. This electronic redistribution is expected to modulate the subsequent electrocatalytic performance. In addi- tion, the natural bonding of F-Ni bonds has been unraveled by the ELF.19 A high value of ELF 0.8 is a signature of the strong covalent character of Ni-F bonding Figure 2i. For a deeper in- sight into the inﬂuence of electronic interactions at the hetero- junction interface, the partial density of states for the F ion was examined Figure 2j. text: 5.6 eV and very low intensities from -4.0 eV to the Fermi energy indicate that all the F 2p orbitals are almost entirely uti- lized in forming strong bonds with the metal atoms at the hollow site, leading to electron localization at the F ions Figure 2j.20 Based on these results, F ions are successfully coordinated with the surface Ni atoms of Ni3N, forming strong covalent bonds. This interaction enhances catalytic activity by acting as eﬀective promoters, a topic that will be discussed in the following sections. 2.2. Electrocatalytic Performance Toward the HER The alkaline HER catalytic performances of F-modiﬁed Ni3N nanosheet catalysts with diﬀerent F contents are evaluated in a standard three-electrode conﬁguration system. Figure 3a shows the linear sweep voltammetry LSV curves of F-modiﬁed cata- lysts with diﬀerent F contents without iR-correction. The over- potential of F10-Ni3N 78 mV to obtain 10 mA cm2 presents the best electrocatalytic performance among the studied sam- ples, verifying that suitable F content modiﬁcation acts as a key role in optimizing the HER catalytic performance. More- over, the Tafel plot reveals the reaction kinetics and the rate- controlling step in the HER process. In Figure 3b the Tafel slope of F10-Ni3N is only 117 mV dec1, smaller than that of F15-Ni3N 136 mV dec1 and pristine Ni3N 162 mV dec1. This sug- gests that the catalytic reaction happened through the combined Volmer-Tafel mechanisms21 and the catalytic reaction kinetics are greatly improved after F ions modiﬁcation. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy EIS is also conducted to investigate the eﬀects of F ions modiﬁcation on the interfacial charge transfer kinetics during the HER process. F10-Ni3N exhibits the small- est charge transfer resistance among all the studied electrocat- alysts Figure 3c; Table S3, Supporting Information, implying the fastest charge transfer rate at the interface of electrode and electrolyte. The electrochemical double-layer capacitance Cdl is a key parameter to reﬂect the electrochemically active surface area ECSA and intrinsic catalytic activity of catalysts Figure S6, Supporting Information. As shown in Figure 3d, the Cdl of F10-Ni3N 42.9 mF cm2 signiﬁcantly outperforms that of Ni3N 31.7 mF cm2 and F15-Ni3N 32.8 mF cm2. This indicates that ﬂuorine modiﬁcation optimizes the density of active sites, thereby promoting the HER. Additionally, ECSA-normalized LSV curves have been performed Figure S7, Supporting Informa- tion, which show that F10-Ni3N maintains the best HER catalytic performance. Therefore, the improvement of HER catalytic eﬃ- ciency performance is not entirely caused by the increase in spe- ciﬁc surface area. The electrochemical stability of the electrocata- lysts is evaluated via the amperometric i-t curve test. In Figure 3e, F10-Ni3N is found to have superior catalytic stability at a ﬁxed po- tential of 80 mV vs. RHE over 40 h. Based on the above re- sults, the increased active sites and accelerated water dissociation dynamics of Ni3N caused by F ions modiﬁcation synergistically contribute to its higher HER activity. F10-Ni3N demonstrates su- perior performance compared to nickel-based catalysts, as shown in Table S4 Supporting Information. To gain a deeper comprehension

text: Based on the above re- sults, the increased active sites and accelerated water dissociation dynamics of Ni3N caused by F ions modiﬁcation synergistically contribute to its higher HER activity. F10-Ni3N demonstrates su- perior performance compared to nickel-based catalysts, as shown in Table S4 Supporting Information. To gain a deeper comprehension of ﬂuorines role, it is es- sential to unravel various factors that could impact HER in the current system. In the case of F ion modiﬁed Ni3N, the elec- tronic state of the Ni site should be altered by the strong elec- tronic interactions between Ni3N and F ions, which was fur- ther studied by DFT calculations. Ni3N 001-terminated sur- face with the relatively lower surface energy was chosen based on the computed surface phase diagrams as a function of ele- mental chemical potentials in previous work.7c,9 Since the cat- alysts performance is determined by the chemical environment of surface F ions that directly engage with reactant species, the optimal ﬂuorine adsorption energy ΔEF structure was cho- sen as the simulation structure Figures S8S10, Supporting Information. The ΔGH of F ion modiﬁed Ni3N and pristine Ni3N were sys- tematically studied. The ΔGH is increased from 0.62 eV at hol- low sites of Ni3N to 0.45 eV at F-top sites of F10-Ni3N Figure 3f, indicating the kinetics for the subsequent H2 generation are boosted consequently. Moreover, the occupation of F ions at sur- face sites not only adjusts the electronic structure of hollow sites but also initiates the lifting of ΔGH at hollow sites distant from the F ions, which positively inﬂuences proton desorption at active sites. Since the hollow sites far away from N atoms with stronger ΔGH 0.62 eV restrict the HER dynamics severely due to the accumulation of electrons Figure S11, Supporting Information, it is necessary to unveil the eﬀects of ﬂuorine on the electronic structures of F10-Ni3N. To elucidate the underlying mechanism of the high catalytic activity of F10-Ni3N, we performed the partial density of state DOS and surface electron density diﬀerence plot. The d-band center 𝜖d of Ni3N and F-modiﬁed Ni3N relative to the Fermi level Ef was calculated to be 0.03 and 0.11 eV Figure 3g, which demonstrates the 𝜖d is far away from the Fermi level af- ter F modulation. This suggests the antibonding energy states are decreased, and the interaction between the adsorbate and the surface is weakened.22 Considering the hydrogen adsorption on the hollow sites of the Ni3N surface is too strong to boost the HER, the incorporation of F modulates the electronic structure by attenuating electron accumulation in the dx2-y2 and dxy orbitals of Ni atoms, thereby optimizing the electron distribution across the surface Figure S12, Supporting Information. This electronic modulation facilitates enhanced HER kinetics. Note that the HER in alkaline media requires an additional ﬁrst step of water ad- sorption; the adsorption energy of a water molecule ΔEH2O on the Ni3N and F10-Ni3N surfaces was further calculated. F10-Ni3N displays a slightly higher water adsorption energy 0.60 eV compared with pristine

Electrocatalytic Performance Toward the MOR To elucidate the essential role F ions in MOR process, an ad- ditional electrocatalytic performance of precatalysts was per- formed. Figure 4a demonstrates that, at various current densities, F10-Ni3N exhibits the greatest reduction potential in MOR when compared to F15-Ni3N, Ni3N, and NiOH2. Speciﬁcally, F10-Ni3N requires a po- tential of 1.43 V to drive a current density of 100 mA cm2 when catalyzing MOR in 1.0 M KOH with 1.0 M methanol, neg- atively shifting by 240 mV compared to that of OER Figure S15, Supporting Information. Meanwhile, the Tafel slopes of F10-Ni3N and F15-Ni3N are remarkably low, measuring 36.2 and 31.9 mV dec1, respectively. These values are substantially lower than those of pristine Ni3N 54.2 mV dec1 and NiOH2 81.3 mV dec1, underscoring a signiﬁcant enhancement in reaction kinetics for the MOR. This pronounced reduction in Tafel slope highlights the pivotal role of F ion incorporation in modulating the electronic structure of active sites, thereby fa- cilitating accelerated charge transfer and improved catalytic ef- ﬁciency. It is obvious from Figure 3c that F10-Ni3N manifests Cdl with a much higher value of 16.6 mF cm2 than those of F15-Ni3N 12.5 mF cm2, Ni3N 10.9 mF cm2, and NiOH2 1.9 mF cm2, providing substantial evidence for the proposition that F incorporation introduces more active sites for the MOR. The anodic product was identiﬁed as exclusively formate via 1H NMR and ion chromatography, underscoring the high selectiv- ity of the F10-Ni3N for MOR Figures S16 and S17, Supporting Information. It was observed that Ni3N has faster surface reconstruction kinetics compared to NiOH2 in methanol electrolyte, as evidenced by the signiﬁcantly reduced high-frequency phase angle. Concurrently, F10-Ni3N exhibited a markedly lower phase angle compared to catalyst Ni3N at the high frequency region, with surface F ions further accelerating the sur- face reconstruction dynamics. The low frequency 101100 Hz region of the bode plot is generally considered to nonhomogeneous charge distribution,25 namely the formation of intermediate species on the electrode surface. An apparent peak in Figure 4d,e is found in the low- frequency region at the potential of 1.35 V for Ni3N and F10-Ni3N in the methanol electrolyte, which consistently shows a lower on- set potential compared with that in the KOH electrolyte 1.5 V, Figure S18a,b, Supporting Information. The peak frequency sig- niﬁcantly shifts toward a higher frequency region 10 Hz when the voltage increases to 1.35 V and the phase angle decreases with the presence of F modiﬁcation at the surface Figure 4e. This phenomenon indicates F ion modiﬁcation accelerates the kinet- ics of the electrochemical oxidation of methanol molecules. Re- markably, interfacial charge transfer kinetics of F10-Ni3N at 1.40 V demonstrate that the F10-Ni3N possesses the lower electrooxi- dation resistance Ro, 0.28 Ω and electron-transfer resistance Rct,1.96 Ω in the MOR process than that of the control sample Figure S19, Table S5, Supporting Information. Figure S20 Sup- porting Information demonstrates that F10-Ni3N exhibits excel- lent stability over a prolonged 110-h MOR test. The post-MOR morphology remains largely intact, albeit with increased surface roughness, as shown in Figure S21 Supporting Information. These observations suggest that the F modiﬁcation accelerates the dissociation kinetics of MOR and boosts the electrooxida- tion of the intermediates to formate. Noteworthily, the F10-Ni3N demonstrates a superior MOR electrochemical activity compared to state-of-the-art nickel-based catalysts Table S6, Supporting Information. Additionally, to investigate the practical application potential of F10-Ni3N catalyst, we incorporated the KOH-containing elec- trolyte into a two-electrode undivided cell for MOR and water electrolysis Figure 4f. Linear sweep voltammetry LSV curves showed that as-synthesized F10-Ni3N in 1.0 M KOH with 1.0 M methanol electrolyte reached 20 mA cm2 only needs 1.50 V cell voltage, which is far less than that of water electrolysis system 1.68 V and could be maintained at 1.66 V cell volt- age working for 168 h Figure S22, Supporting Information. Lastly, we also evaluated the potential of F10-Ni3N as a bifunc- tional industrial electrocatalyst for hydrogen production cou-

text: cell voltage, which is far less than that of water electrolysis system 1.68 V and could be maintained at 1.66 V cell volt- age working for 168 h Figure S22, Supporting Information. Lastly, we also evaluated the potential of F10-Ni3N as a bifunc- tional industrial electrocatalyst for hydrogen production cou- pled with MOR within a membrane electrode assembly MEA- based ﬂow electrolyzer. Steady-state polarization measurements were conducted at stepped current densities ranging from 50 to 500 mA cm2, with the corresponding cell voltages recorded Figure 4g. Remarkably, F10-Ni3N achieved a cell voltage of 2.02 V at 200 mA cm2 during the MOR, representing a 12.6 re- duction compared to the conventional OER 2.31 V. Notably, the catalyst demonstrated excellent stability at constant current density 200 mA cm2, retaining high activity after 600 h of MEA testing under MOR conditions Figure 4h. This robust performance highlights its long-term durability. Notably, when benchmarked against other nickel-based non-precious metal cat- alysts, F10-Ni3N exhibited outstanding electrochemical activity and durability, underscoring its potential as a highly eﬃcient and robust electrocatalyst for energy conversion applications Table S7, Supporting Information. Taken together, this strategy en- ables the co-production of H2 gas and value-added formate at a quasi-industrial scale in both membrane and membraneless elec- trolyzer systems. Additionally, repeated voltage onoﬀtests, facil- itated by electrolyte replacement, demonstrate that the F10-Ni3N- based electrochemical methanol-to-hydrogen coupling system is capable of eﬃciently storing and converting intermittent energy. These ﬁndings further support the conclusion that F10-Ni3N is a highly eﬃcient bifunctional catalyst for industrial applications. 2.4. Active Phase and Surface Reconstruction Dynamics of Catalysts in MOR For a more comprehensive understanding of the catalysts sur- face reconstruction process and identiﬁcation of the actual ac- tive components, detailed structural, chemical, and valence in- formation was obtained using a combination of methods, in- cluding amperometric i-t curve analysis, postmortem HRTEM, in situ Raman spectroscopy, and ex situ XPS measurements. First, the surface dynamic reconstruction process of catalysts has been systematically investigated. The inconsistent durabil- ity performances of NiOH2, Ni3N, and F10-Ni3N at a constant potential indicate that the precatalysts surfaces undergo a fast dynamic change under alkaline methanol oxidation conditions Figure S23, Supporting Information. Speciﬁcally, at 1.40 V, The F10-Ni3N requires a shorter time 0.5 h to achieve surface re- construction than that of Ni3N 6 h and NiOH2 larger than 10 h. Additionally, a reliable electrochemical steady state of F10- Ni3N was achieved with the aid of F ions leaching Figure S23c, Supporting Information. This phenomenon will be elaborated in the subsequent section. After 0.5 h of reconstruction, compared with Ni3N 12.2 mA cm2, Figure S24, Supporting Information, the elevated current density diﬀerence jafter 0.5 h activation- jinitial observed in F10-Ni3N 24.4 mA cm2, signiﬁes that F expedites the surface restructuring process of the catalyst. Fluorine 1s spectrum for the F10- Ni3N catalyst at 1.351.40 V displayed a couple of peaks located at 684.5 and 688.7 eV that could be assigned to F-Ni and F-covalent, respectively Figure S29, Supporting Information. The emerg- ing F-covalent bonds could be attributed to the F ions coordinated with the surface-active phase.30 Nevertheless, when the poten- tial reached 1.40 V and higher, the F signal vanished, which is consistent with previous results that the surface reconstruction process is accompanied by F ions leaching Figure S29, Support- ing Information. The ratio of Ni3 valance state in Ni3N in MOR increased faster with applied potential 1.45 V along with the decreased percentage of Ni, demonstrating the surface Ni3N re- constructed to NiOOH deeply Figure 5c, Figure S30, Supporting Information. Moreover, the negative shifted Ni3 binding energy 1.40 V could be subjected to the F leaching, causing the local- ized electrons near the Ni atoms. To probe the atomic coordination environment of the recon- structed catalysts active phase, in situ XANES at the Ni-K edge and post-edge XAS at the O-K edge were performed Figure S31, Supporting Information. The data show a progressive Ni-K ab- sorption edge shift toward higher energies with increasing ap- plied potential, signifying an elevated oxidation state of Ni Figure 5d. Notably, the absorption edge of F10-Ni3N shows a signiﬁ- cantly greater positive shift compared to Ni3N under identical potentials Figure 5e, suggesting that F10-Ni3N is more prone to deprotonation and subsequent reconstruction into high valence Ni oxide species. text: Figure 5e, suggesting that F10-Ni3N is more prone to deprotonation and subsequent reconstruction into high valence Ni oxide species. Considering the time-resolution scale of 1 h in in situ XAFS characterizations, surface F ions are prone to loss under a potential of 1.60 V. Consequently, the partial doping of F ions within the bulk phase likely facilitates surface reconstruc- tion through accelerating electronic conductivity. Moreover, in O- K XAS spectra Figure 5f, the ﬁrst feature a corresponds to the pre-peak, attributed to transitions from O 1s electrons to an- tibonding O 2p states hybridized with Ni 3d orbitals, primarily localized at Ni sites. At higher energies, two prominent features b and c are observed, which can be attributed to medium- and long-range structural contributions. Compared to the active phase of Ni3N, the F10-Ni3N catalyst ex- hibits a reduced O-Metal intensity, indicative of increased struc- tural disorder at extended distances.31 Moreover, variations in the relative intensities of features b and c reﬂect a diminished local coordination environment around O atoms. This suggests that ﬂuorine incorporation promotes the reconstruction of the active phase into a short-range-ordered, loosely packed structure with enhanced local disorder.32 These ﬁndings highlight the role of F in tailoring the active phases structural and electronic properties. Considering the surface reconstruction of NiOH2, Ni3N, and F10-Ni3N into high-valence NiOOH, a conclusion previously val- idated for NiOH2 in our prior study, the key distinction lies in the core-phase composition within the reconstructed core-shell structures. Notably, the three materials display distinct electrical conductivities, with Ni3N and F10-Ni3N exhibiting metallic be- havior, whereas NiOH2 manifests characteristic semiconduct- ing properties. Speciﬁcally, F10-Ni3N is distinguished by a higher density of electronic states near the Ef compared to Ni3N, indica- tive of enhanced charge carrier availability Figure S32, Support- ing Information. Furthermore, in the context of the MOR, the electrochemical oxidation resistance follows the trend F10-Ni3N Ni3N NiOH2. This observation allows us to infer a corre- sponding hierarchy in conductivity, which aligns as F10-Ni3N Ni3N NiOH2, underscoring the pivotal role of electronic struc- ture in dictating electrocatalytic performance. Based on this anal- ysis, the F10-Ni3N core structure serves as an eﬃcient electron- transfer bridge between the matrix and the active center Figure 5g, thereby exhibiting superior surface reconstruction capability compared to Ni3N and NiOH2. 2.5. F Ion Accelerating Surface Reconstruction and Methanol Dissociation Mechanism Based on the preceeding in situ Raman and in situ EIS analyses, it has been conclusively demonstrated that the dynamic recon- struction process entails the oxidation of Ni metal sites. Concur- rently, the elevation of Ni valence states is invariably coupled with the deprotonation of the active phase.29,33 To further elucidate the mechanism of ion dissolution and adsorption, we evaluated the dissolution behavior of Ni ions from various catalysts under a constant potential of 1.4 V. Results from inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy unequivocally conﬁrmed the occurrence of Ni dissolution during the electrocatalytic pro- cess. Notably, the F10-Ni3N catalyst exhibited a signiﬁcantly lower Ni dissolution rate compared to pristine Ni3N, underscoring

text: behavior of Ni ions from various catalysts under a constant potential of 1.4 V. Results from inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy unequivocally conﬁrmed the occurrence of Ni dissolution during the electrocatalytic pro- cess. Notably, the F10-Ni3N catalyst exhibited a signiﬁcantly lower Ni dissolution rate compared to pristine Ni3N, underscoring the role of ﬂuorine in suppressing the leaching of Ni ions into the electrolyte Figure S33, Supporting Information. In summary, the dynamic reconstruction process is characterized by a mul- tifaceted interplay of metal site oxidation, dissolution, and re- adsorption of metal ions, and hydroxyl deprotonation. Then, a key question remains: how do the surface F ions signiﬁcantly boost the reconstruction dynamic of F10-Ni3N? Here, the eﬀect of F ions on the thermodynamics of divalent nickel species, 𝛽- NiOOH, and 𝛾-NiOOH growth process was further revealed by DFT calculation. The adsorption process of OH- on the Ni3N surface is likely to be a key event for the next surface reconstruction reactions. First, a signiﬁcant oxidation peak area in the potential range of 0.81.05 V versus RHE in the CV curves can be observed, suggest- ing the OHis prone to adsorb at the F10-Ni3N surface than that of Ni3N Figure S34, Supporting Information. Besides, F10-Ni3N also shows much more strong OHadsorption energy 0.60, 0.16, and 0.49 eV than that of pure Ni3N 0.31, 0.35, and 0.42 eV at catalysis surface Figure 6a; Figure S35, Support- ing Information, which also is consistent with the Zata potential Adv. text: KOH with methanol environment, representing more OHin the inner Helmholtz layer Figure S36, Supporting Information.24 Moreover, the mechanism of F leaching in the process of self-reconstruction was also revealed by DFT calculations. Speciﬁcally, F ions transi- tion from hollow sites to bridge sites during self-reconstruction, inducing a shift of the bonding orbitals to higher energy lev- els. It is noteworthy that the strong electronic interaction be- tween F ions and the of surface-coordinated Ni atoms of Ni3N will be weakened due to the upshifts of F ions energy level, con- sequently leading to the concurrent leaching of ﬂuoride ions dur- ing the dynamic reconstruction process Figure S37, Supporting Information. Moreover, the ability to adsorb Ni ions and OH near the electrochemical interface is strengthened in the F incor- porated 𝛽𝛾-NiOOH. The introduction of ﬂuorine plays a dual role in the reconstruction process. F ions not only act as an OH promoter to boost the adsorption of OH1.68 vs 1.79 eV, Figure S38a, Supporting Information adjacent to the edge sites of 𝛽- NiOOH but also accelerate Ni ions adsorption 0.82 vs 1.87 eV, Figure S38b, Supporting Information. This consistent trend of F modiﬁcation is also evident in the 𝛾-NiOOH phase Figure 6b; Figure S39, Supporting Information, making it energetically fa- vorable to establish a NiOOHNiO2 structure at the surface when compared to the OH-modiﬁed 𝛾-NiOOH. Making it energet- ically favorable to form NiOOHNiO2 structure at the surface compared to that of OH modiﬁed 𝛾-NiOOH. It is important to note that the reconstruction process is typically accompanied by the deprotonation of surface-adsorbed hydroxide ions, leading ul- timately to the formation of the active phase. Therefore, we also investigated the inﬂuence of F ions on this process. DFT results indicate that F ions thermodynamically promote the deprotona- tion steps in both 𝛽-NiOOH 2.85 vs 2.96 eV and 𝛾-NiOOH 1.98 vs 2.22 eV, thus accelerating the generation of the active phase Figures S40 and S41, Supporting Information. Combined with the above experimental and theoretical results, a schematic diagram of the F accelerates surface reconstruction mechanism is given Figure 6c. In an alkaline electrolyte, the surface F ions promote the electrocatalyst to adsorb OHto form OH, making the surface appear divalent. For this oxidation pro- cess, two possible oxidation pathways are proposed here schemed as Figure 6d: 1 the applied potential drives Ni atoms to lose elec- trons and adsorb OHleading to the formation of Ni2𝛿NOHads, 2 the dissolved Ni2 near the catalyst surface will combine with OHto form NiOH2. These two possible pathways lead to the formation of Ni2 compounds. As working potential increases, strong OH- adsorption brings about a phase transition to Ni oxyhydroxide. In this process, F ions act as an OH-and Ni ions promoter, which boosts the adsorption of OHand Ni ions ad- jacent to the edge sites of 𝛽-NiOOH. Here, the residual Ni2 re- constructs into amorphous Ni3N𝛽-NiOOH heterojunctions with high-valence states. Moreover, with a higher degree of polariza- tion charging, the formed metastable nickel hydroxide evolves into the 𝛾-NiOOH

text: Ni ions promoter, which boosts the adsorption of OHand Ni ions ad- jacent to the edge sites of 𝛽-NiOOH. Here, the residual Ni2 re- constructs into amorphous Ni3N𝛽-NiOOH heterojunctions with high-valence states. Moreover, with a higher degree of polariza- tion charging, the formed metastable nickel hydroxide evolves into the 𝛾-NiOOH phase with a lattice expansion owing to K and water molecules inserting. In this process, F ions simultane- ously facilitate the adsorption of both OHions and nickel ions, thereby accelerating surface reconstruction. Meanwhile, the pres- ence of F ions in the bulk phase facilitates electron transfer from the catalyst to the electrode, thereby accelerating the surface re- construction of Ni3N. In summary, the synergistic modulation of electrons and ions by F ions both at the surface and in the bulk phase collectively promotes the catalysts surface reconstruc- tion. Moreover, DFT calculations elucidate that the previously ob- served lower dissolution rate of Ni2 ions into the electrolyte for the F10-Ni3N phase, relative to pristine Ni3N, originates from the presence of F ions, which markedly enhances the adsorption of Ni2 ions on distinct catalytically active surface sites, thereby mit- igating their dissolution. To elucidate the reaction pathway and discern the interme- diates formed during the reaction, in situ ATR-FTIR measure- ments were carried out. Upon an increase in bias potential to 1.40 V, distinct spectral features emerged, signifying critical de- velopments at the reaction initiation Figure 6e. These newly observed bands are ascribed to speciﬁc vibrational modes: the vasCOO vibration mode at 1581 cm1, the 𝛿CH vibration mode at 1381 cm1, and the 𝜈sCOO vibration mode characteristic of formate at 1353 cm1.34 Signiﬁcantly, any discernible in- frared signals were absent within the 17502200 cm1 range, thus establishing that formate formation transpires without fur- ther deprotonation to produce CO species Figure S42, Support- ing Information.6a Consequently, the proposed mechanism for the dissociation of methanol into formate proceeds through a four-step process, consistent with both the in situ ATR-FTIR re- sults and prior research:5e methanol adsorption, dehydrogena- tion, formation of CHO intermediate, and coupling with OH to generate formate. DFT calculations with the explicit solvent model K and water in the NiO2 layer are also further performed to better understand the dehydrogenation activation pathway of methanol at the sur- face of 𝛾-NiOOH. We compare both pathways with either C-H or O-H activation in the ﬁrst step of the reaction. The O-H ac- tivation of methanol, as well as the subsequent C-H activation of methoxy to formyl, takes place over the top of a single metal atom, as shown in Figure 6f. Methanol molecular dehydrogena- tion at Ni surface sites involves the primary activation of the O-H bond, followed by the activation of the C-H bond. The subsequent coupling of CHO with OHrequires overcoming a thermody- namic energy barrier of 2.40 eV. Thus, the observed thermody- namic energy barrier for the MOR reveals that the CHO cou- pling with OHis a potential determination step. Moreover, the C-H activation, identiﬁed as the primary elementary step, was

text: bond. The subsequent coupling of CHO with OHrequires overcoming a thermody- namic energy barrier of 2.40 eV. Thus, the observed thermody- namic energy barrier for the MOR reveals that the CHO cou- pling with OHis a potential determination step. Moreover, the C-H activation, identiﬁed as the primary elementary step, was in- vestigated on the surface Ni4 site originally Ni3. This process yields CH2O and H, with H adsorbing onto lattice oxygen, sig- niﬁcantly lowering the thermodynamic energy barrierdownhill by 2.51 eV compared with primary CH3O-H dissociation, which demonstrates that lattice oxygen participates in and accelerates the C-H activation thermodynamics Figure 6f. However, it re- quires a much larger barrier of 1.72 eV to catalyze the subse- quent lattice O-H bond breaking. This indicates that thermody- namically C-H cleavage as primary activation step is energetically unfavorable. 3. Conclusion In summary, we successfully developed aﬀordable F ions modi- ﬁed Ni3N electrocatalysts through a facile hydrothermal and nitri- dation approach. The surface of nickel nitride modiﬁed by F ions exhibits excellent performance for both H2 evolution and MOR. Adv. Mater. 2025, 2507573 2025 Wiley-VCH GmbH 2507573 12 of 14 15214095, 0, Downloaded from https:advanced.onlinelibrary.wiley.comdoi10.1002adma.202507573 by Tsinghua University Library, Wiley Online Library on 16062025. See the Terms and Conditions https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comterms-and-conditions on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License www.advancedsciencenews.com www.advmat.de Remarkably, we propose a mechanism of atomic occupancy, that is, through the adsorption of anions on the strong hydrogen atom adsorption site and forming a strong coordination adsorption re- lationship with the surface cation, which reduces ΔGH and pro- motes the production of hydrogen consequently. Moreover, the thermodynamics of the conversion of methanol into formate on the reconstructed surface of F10-Ni3N materials was revealed that methanol dehydrogenation carries out primary O-H bond activa- tion and the secondary CH bond activation steps at surface Ni sites. By studying the eﬀect of adsorbed F ions on the oxidation of methanol on Ni3N, we deduce that the adsorbed F ions enhance the surface self-reconstruction process by altering the binding en- ergy between the surface active phases and solutes OH, Ni2. Lastly, the intriguing modiﬁcations of the catalysts surface by ionic interactions, as induced by F ions adsorption, may hold fundamental and mechanistic implications for the broader ﬁeld of electrocatalysis. The electrocatalytic systems examined in this article might serve as the inaugural example of such innovative catalytic enhancement. text: Communication How to cite: Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2025, e202507724 doi.org10.1002anie.202507724 Nitrate Reduction Acidic Nitrate Electroreduction with Ultrahigh Energy Efﬁciency Rong Zhang, Xintao Ma, Shaoce Zhang, Huilin Cui, Chuan Li, Yanbo Wang, Qing Li, Chao Peng, Ying Guo, and Chunyi Zhi Abstract: Ammonia NH3 is an important feedstock for industry, an ideal energy carrier, and a perspective storage media for hydrogen. Recently, electrochemical nitrate NO3 reduction under acidic conditions has received considerable attention but it suffers from limited efﬁciency especially under low NO3concentration. Here, we report an in situ formed positively charged polyethyleneimine-modiﬁed Cu under acidic conditions as a catalyst-electrolyte interface CEI for electrochemical NO3reduction to NH3. Such CEI can effectively accumulate NO3anions via static interactions and accelerate NO hydrogenation to NOH by weakening NO intermediate adsorption on Cu site, thereby facilitating NO3-to-NH3 conversion. Such CEI delivers an increased NH3 Faradaic efﬁciency FE of 83.5 and an impressive half- cell energy efﬁciency EE of 37.1 in 10 mM NO3solution pH 1. The NH3 FE and EE can further increase to 90.2 and 44.1 in 0.5 M NO3, respectively. The high EE of CEI surpasses previously reported catalyst performances for NO3reduction. Finally, we demonstrate the feasibility of a novel NO3-furfural battery, showcasing a self-power electrocatalytic system capable of simultaneously treating NO3pollutants, generating value-added NH3 and upgrading biomass. This work offers valuable insights into the construction of a CEI to enhance the efﬁciency of NH3 synthesis. Ammonia NH3, the pivotal feedstock for producing arti- ﬁcial fertilizers and a carbon-free energy carrier, is essential in contemporary society.1,2 Currently, the global demand for NH3 exceeds 150 million tons per year, predominantly met through the energy-intensive Haber-Bosch process, which operates under harsh conditions of high pressure 200350 atm and temperature 400C600 C, consuming approximately 12 of global energy and contributing to 1.4 of global carbon emissions.3,4 In light of escalating environmental concerns, extensive research is underway to investigate alternative and environmentally sustainable pathways for NH3 production.5,6 Recent endeavours have focused on the electrochemical reduction of N2 to NH3, drawing inspiration from the natural microbial dinitrogen N2 ﬁxation process.6,7 However, the inherent challenges associated with the robust NN bond 941 kJ mol1 and the poor solubility of N2 in water limit the NH3 yield rate to less than 10 mmol gcat1 h1, with partial current densities falling below 1 mA cm2. These limitations impede the widespread use of this approach. Alternatively, nitrate NO3 shows a much lower dissociation energy of 204 kJ mol1 for the NO bond, rendering it an attractive nitrogen source for NH3 electrosynthesis.8 Also, NO3is commonly found in industrial wastewater and polluted groundwater, contributing to eutrophication and ecosystem disruption.9 Thus, the selective NO3reduction reaction NO3RR provides an attractive approach for NH3 synthesis to address energy and environmental crises simultaneously. Despite signiﬁcant progress in catalyst development with consistently improving efﬁciencies in neutral or alkaline electrolytes, the electrochemical NO3RR under acid condi- tions remains relatively rare.10 Nevertheless, acidic NO3- containing wastewater is prevalent in many industrial pro- cesses such as mining, metallurgy and petrochemicals.11,12 Hence,

text: address energy and environmental crises simultaneously. Despite signiﬁcant progress in catalyst development with consistently improving efﬁciencies in neutral or alkaline electrolytes, the electrochemical NO3RR under acid condi- tions remains relatively rare.10 Nevertheless, acidic NO3- containing wastewater is prevalent in many industrial pro- cesses such as mining, metallurgy and petrochemicals.11,12 Hence, achieving NO3RR under acidic conditions is highly desirable, fulﬁlling the demands of these industrial pro- cesses and avoiding the additional cost and energy con- sumption linked with existing treatment methods.
