Charge density diﬀerence of NO intermediate on the h CEI 111 and i Cu 111 surfaces. high-performance electrocatalysts typically operate in highly concentrated NO3 electrolytes 0.1 M, necessitating additional and costly measures to concentrate NO3solu- tions. In reality, many nitrate sources, such as textile industrial wastewater, exhibit low NO3concentrations.13 Consequently, achieving electrochemical low-concentration NO3RR is particularly challenging, given the substantial decrease in Faradaic efﬁciency FE when NO3concentra- tions fall below 10 mM.14 This decrease primarily stems from the planar symmetrical resonant structure of NO3, which results in low binding afﬁnity and nucleophilicity, coupled with the complicated eight-electron, nine-proton transfer process required for NO3-to-NH3 conversion and kineti- cally competitive hydrogen evolution reaction HER.15,16 Furthermore, the negative electric ﬁeld generated by the negatively charged cathode intrinsically hinders the accumu- lation of NO3anions to the interface, where the electrostatic repulsion between the negatively charged cathode and NO3 anions impedes NO3diffusion,17 leading to low NO3 concentration near the electrode surface Figure 1a. While

metadata.source: /Users/zemao/ChemQA/data/raw_papers/Zhang 等 - 2025 - Acidic nitrate electroreduction with ultrahigh energy efficiency.pdf
metadata.title: Zhang 等 - 2025 - Acidic nitrate electroreduction with ultrahigh energy efficiency.pdf

text: evolution reaction HER.15,16 Furthermore, the negative electric ﬁeld generated by the negatively charged cathode intrinsically hinders the accumu- lation of NO3anions to the interface, where the electrostatic repulsion between the negatively charged cathode and NO3 anions impedes NO3diffusion,17 leading to low NO3 concentration near the electrode surface Figure 1a. While several strategies, including nanomicro-conﬁnement and con- struction of internal electric ﬁelds,18,19 have demonstrated success in promoting low-concentration NO3RR, signiﬁcant challenges persist in enhancing the selectivity of NO3RR towards NH3. A potential strategy to address these challenges involves immobilizing cations on the surface of electrocata- lysts to manipulate the inner Helmholtz layer. This approach can reduce the negative charge on the catalyst at the potential required for reducing the anionic reactant, resulting in NO3 accumulation near the surface of the cathode, as illustrated in Figure 1b. This strategy holds promise for enhancing the efﬁciency of NH3 synthesis during NO3RR. In this study, we develop a catalyst-electrolyte interface CEI comprising Cu catalyst modiﬁed with an in situ formed positively charged polyethyleneimine PEI under acidic conditions for electrochemical NO3-to-NH3 conversion, demonstrating high efﬁciency. Theoretical analysis indicates that the in situ formed positively charged CEI effectively attracts NO3anions through static interactions near the catalyst surface and weakens interactions between the Cu and NO intermediates, thereby facilitating NO3reduction towards NH3 synthesis. The resulting CEI shows energy- efﬁcient performance for acidic NO3-to-NH3 conversion, achieving the best half-cell energy efﬁciency EE of 37.1 and FE of 83.5 for NH3 formation in 10 mM NO3 pH 1. Even higher EE 44.1 and FE 90.2 can Angew. Chem. Int. See the Terms and Conditions https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comterms-and-conditions on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License Communication be further achieved in 0.5 M NO3pH 1. The CEI also demonstrates practical potential as an advanced cathode material for a NO3-furfural battery, enabling simultaneous NO3degradation into NH3, biomass upgrading and energy output. We chose Cu catalyst modiﬁed with the PEI layer as demonstration considering that Cu has been extensively explored as an electrocatalyst for NO3RR and many amino groups in PEI molecular chains can be in situ positively charged under acidic conditions owing to the high pKa of PEI.20,21 Density functional theory DFT calculations elucidate the spontaneous protonation of abundant amino groups in PEI, which serve as active positive-charged sites attracting NO3anions via static interactions. As shown in Figure 1c, the protonation of different amino groups on PEI, namely NH3, NH2 and NH, is thermodynamically favourable. The NH3 group exhibits the highest propensity for protonation with a formation energy of 0.64 eV, followed closely by NH2 with a reaction energy of 0.61 eV, and NH with a formation energy of 0.36 eV. Consequently, all three types of amino groups can thermodynamically undergo protonation, altering the charge distribution behavior of the inner Helmholtz plane at the CEI. Molecular dynamics MD simulations were

text: eV, followed closely by NH2 with a reaction energy of 0.61 eV, and NH with a formation energy of 0.36 eV. Consequently, all three types of amino groups can thermodynamically undergo protonation, altering the charge distribution behavior of the inner Helmholtz plane at the CEI. Molecular dynamics MD simulations were also systematically carried out Figure 1d, e. It shows that the densities of NO3anions are uniformly distributed from the electrolyte to the Cu 111 surface, indicating a weak attraction of the Cu 111 surface towards NO3anions Figure 1f. Interestingly, we observed a signif- icant increase in the relative density of NO3anions at the positively charged CEI relative to the bulk electrolyte. This clearly demonstrates the positively charged CEI facilitates the accumulation of NO3. MD simulations also reveal substantial densities of protons occurring at the CEI interface, which were absent in the pure Cu system. These observations demonstrate that the in-situ formed positive-charged CEI can effectively manipulate the negative charge distribution of the inner Helmholtz plane and increase the concentration of NO3via static interactions, thereby conducive to the superior NO3-to-NH3 conversion. Furthermore, the PEI layer itself is electron-insulating, mitigating the adverse effects of the negative electric ﬁeld of the pure Cu cathode on the diffusion barrier of NO3from the electrolyte to the Cu 111 surface, resulting in increased NO3densities at the interface. To understand the NO3RR mechanisms after introducing the PEI chains, the corresponding Gibbs free energy proﬁles of CEI and Cu were calculated based on the pathway NO3 NO3 NO2 NO NOH NHOH NH NH2 NH3 NH3 g, which is the most probable for Cu 111 in previous literature.22 As shown in Figure 1g, it is clear that the introduction of PEI could effectively change the adsorption free energy of different N-containing intermediates. The rate-limiting step of the NO3reduction reaction was identiﬁed as the hydrogenation of NO to NOH. This step incurs a signiﬁcantly higher energy cost on the Cu 111 surface, with a reaction energy of 1.82 eV, compared to as low as 0.80 eV on CEI. This discrepancy may stem from the strong binding of NO at the hollow site on the Cu 111 surface, as indicated by the signiﬁcant charge transfer between NO and the Cu site Figure 1h. This lowers the energy level of the NO state. In contrast, the NO intermediate adsorbs on the Cu site and interacts with the -NH2 group on the PEI. Considerable s-p orbital interactions occur between -NH2 and the oxygen atom of NO, reducing the charge interactions between NO and Cu and weakening NO binding to the Cu surface Figure 1i. Consequently, the energy level of the NO state is elevated. As a result, less energy is required for NO hydrogenation on the CEI, imparting greater activity to the CEI than the pure Cu. All these observations demonstrate that the CEI can effectively enrich the NO3densities at the interface under acidic conditions and further weaken the strong adsorption of NO of Cu catalyst, thereby fascinating the overall NO3 conversion to

text: hydrogenation on the CEI, imparting greater activity to the CEI than the pure Cu. All these observations demonstrate that the CEI can effectively enrich the NO3densities at the interface under acidic conditions and further weaken the strong adsorption of NO of Cu catalyst, thereby fascinating the overall NO3 conversion to NH3. As proof of concept, Cu and CEI nanostructures were ﬁrst synthesized through a facile electrodeposition method refer to the Methods in Supporting Information for details. Both the X-ray diffraction XRD patterns of Cu and CEI exhibit identical peaks characteristic of face-centred cubic Cu Figure S1. Furthermore, when electrodeposited onto Ti foil, both Cu catalysts displayed diffraction peaks corresponding to Cu JCPDS No. 031018 along with those of the Ti sheet JCPDS No. 441294 Figure S1b, afﬁrming the successful deposition of Cu. No diffraction peaks for PEI can be observed due to its amorphous structure Figure S1c. From the scanning electron microscopy SEM of Cu and CEI, it is clear that the addition of PEI leads to the formation of smaller and more uniform nanoparticles Figure S2. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy HRTEM images of the Cu and CEI nanoparticles disclosed crystalline planes with a lattice spacing of 0.208 nm, attributed to the 111 facets of the metallic Cu phase Figure S3. Nevertheless, a mottled contrast is evident in the images of CEI, suggesting the possible presence of defects. To ascertain the incorporation of PEI, scanning transmission electron microscopy with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy STEM-EDS was carried out. As depicted in Figure 2a,b, Cu and N are uniformly distributed on CEI Figure 2a, while no N signal is detected for Cu Figure 2b. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XPS spectra were utilized to probe the chemical states of Cu and CEI. The peaks at 399.0, 400.0 and 400.9 eV in N1s spectra of CEI can be assigned to NH2, NH and NH2NH3 groups of PEI Figure 2c, respectively.23,24 The peak observed at 933.2 eV in Figure 2d closely aligns with the binding energies of the Cu0 element of CEI.25 Meanwhile, the peak at 935.4 eV is attributed to the Cu2 element, indicative of surface oxidation of Cu likely due to exposure to ambient air.26 After etching the CEI surface for 5 nm, the Cu2 signal signiﬁcantly decreases Figure S4. Compared to Cu, the peak for Cu0 in CEI shifts to a higher binding energy, suggesting an interaction between Cu and PEI. This shift implies electron transfer from Cu to the adjacent PEI, rendering the Cu centers more electron-deﬁcient and enhancing the adsorption of NO3. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy FTIR of CEI was conducted to conﬁrm PEIs presence further. Additionally, the NHx peak undergoes a discernible shift to the lower frequency region post-immersion in the acidic solution due to the hydrogen bonds among protonated PEI moieties.33 This phenomenon is substantiated by the Zeta potential values Figure 2f, revealing a positively charged PEI layer on the surface of Cu nanoparticles. Notably, bare Cu exhibits Zeta potentials close to 0 at both pH 1 and pH 7, whereas PEI-containing nanoparticles manifest positive charges at the same pH values. This observation suggests the introduction of a positive charge to the catalyst through the protonation of amine functional groups in the acidic medium. Such a charge modiﬁcation mitigates the repulsion between the catalyst and NO3during the NO3RR. Moreover, treating CEI in a 0.05 M H2SO4 solution and subsequently immersing it in a 1 mM KOH solution results in a decrease in the pH value of the NaOH solution Figure 2g. This phenomenon underscores the neutralization of the positively charged CEI in alkaline media, thereby afﬁrming the in situ formation of the positively charged CEI under acidic conditions. The cumulative evidence points toward the in situ generation of CEI featuring a positively charged layer. This distinctive attribute facilitates the accumulation of NO3and may play an important role in promoting proton transfer and reaction kinetics during the NO3RR, thus enhancing the performance

The electrochemical performance of Cu and CEI was then examined under ambient conditions within a standard three- electrode conﬁguration. Figure 3a presents the linear sweep voltammetry LSV curves of electrochemical NO3RR in an electrolyte with and without 10 mM NO3pH 1. Cu and CEI show poor HER activity with ultralow current density until the negative polarization reaches 0.2 V. Upon introducing 10 mM NO3, the onset potential shifted positively to 0.2 V for Cu, while CEI displays a higher current density than Cu, implying enhanced NO3RR activity facilitated by PEI. To validate the LSV results, FE and yield rate of major products at various potentials were quantiﬁed, employing standard curves for NH3, N2H4, NO3and NO2in Figures S5 and S6. Notably, N2H4 was not detected at any potential for both Cu and CEI Figure S7, and only a small amount of NO2 FE 5 was observed for Cu and CEI at the potentials before 0 V Figure S8. Figure 3b illustrates that both Cu and CEI exhibited a similar trend in FE of NH3 at different potentials, peaking initially with an increase in potential and subsequently decreasing at higher overpotentials. Speciﬁcally, CEI achieves the higher FE maximum of NH3 83.5 at a more positive potential 0 V compared to the Cu electrode 64.9 at 0.1 V, underscoring the superior catalytic activity of CEI over bare Cu. The yield rates of NH3 presented in Figure S9 further substantiate the signiﬁcantly enhanced activity and selectivity of CEI compared to Cu. Figure 3c depicts the concentration changes of NO3and NH3 in the electrolytes. CEI nearly converted 10 mM NO3to NH3 within 200 min at 0.2 V. Moreover, the electrochemical Angew. Chem. Int. NO3RR performance of Cu and CEI was tested at a higher NO3concentration of 0.5 M. Figure 3d shows the LSV curves of Cu and CEI in 0.5 M NO3pH 1. CEI exhibits a more positive onset potential 0.3 V and higher current density than Cu, demonstrating its superior NO3RR catalytic activity in terms of NH3 selectivity and yield rate of NH3 at each applied potential Figures 3e and S10, S11. The maximum NH3 FE 90.2 for CEI is found at 0.1 V, higher than 72.3 for bare Cu at 0 V. The positive potentials and high NH3 FE of CEI make the half-cell EE of NH3 up to 44.1 at 0.2 V Figure 3f. Remarkably, this half-cell NH3 EE for CEI 37.1 and 44.1 at 10 mM and 0.5 M NO3, respectively surpasses those reported for other recent electrocatalysts at both high and low NO3concentrations Figure 3g and Table S1. All these electrochemical observations demonstrate that CEI shows enhanced electrochemical NO3-to-NH3 conversion performance across a wide range of NO3concentrations. The electrochemically active surface area ECSA was also estimated based on double-layer capacitance Cdl.3436 As shown in Figure S12ac, CEI shows a larger Cdl of 14.3 mF cm2, higher than that for Cu 12.4 mF cm2, indicative of a greater exposed active surface area for NO3RR. The intrinsic activity of Cu and CEI was further assessed by normalizing the ECSA. As shown in Figure S12d, CEI still exhibits higher activity than Cu, highlighting the distinguished intrinsic activity of CEI for NO3RR. To investigate the effect of Cu2 on electrochemical NO3RR, the CEI surface was ﬁrst etched for 2 nm to enable the peak area ratio of Cu2Cu close to that for the Cu sample Figure S13. Then, the NO3RR activity of after-etching CEI catalyst was tested at 0.1, 0, and 0.1 V. As shown in Figure S14, the NH3 yield and FE of CEI before and after etching are almost the same, suggesting that Cu2 shows little impact on the NO3RR under acidic conditions. To estimate the electrochemical durability of CEI, we per- formed long-term electrolysis at 0 V versus RHE. Figure 3h shows the chronoamperometric curve, revealing only a slight decrease in current density at a constant potential. Continu- ous electrolysis for 16 h demonstrates a nearly linear increase in NH3 concentration in the electrolyte with minimal changes in NH3 FE, indicative of the high electrochemical stability of CEI. After electrolysis, the nanoparticle morphology of CEI can be well preserved, and the 111-faceted lattice fringes of copper are observed Figure S15a,b. As shown in Figure S17a, only about 46.5 Cu in the CEI is dissolved into the solution after 1-h electrolysis at different potentials due to the inevitable corrosion and dissolution of catalyst materials under acidic conditions.12 With prolonged electrolysis time for 24 h at 0.1 V, about 0.76 Cu in the CEI is dissolved in electrolyte Figure S17b, suggesting the exhibited metal dissolvation at a reduction potential and high stability of CEI under acidic conditions. It is worth noting that the protonation of PEI to form the CEI is reversible. CEI after washing with water and drying in a vacuum oven shows an N-H signal. After re- immersion in acid, the -NH2 signal appears, indicating the reversible protonation of PEI to form the CEI Figure S18a. The regenerated CEI also shows good stability, maintaining a high NH3 FE and yields for six cycles Figure S18b. To further understand the NO3RR kinetics on both Cu and CEI, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy EIS was conducted at the open-circuit potentials under various tem- peratures Figure 4a, followed by an in-depth distribution of relaxation times DRT analysis, which offers a nuanced understanding of the primary electrochemical processes.37,38 Figure 4b reveals a predominant peak spanning from 102 to 1 s, corresponding to the charge transfer resistance Rct on the cathodes.39 At 298 K, CEI shows a lower resistance for the charge transfer than Cu, signifying accelerated kinetics for NO3RR on CEI. Subsequent ﬁtting of the Rct peaks according to the classic Arrhenius law facilitates the determination of activation energies for each interfacial charge transfer process ERct, as illustrated in Figure 4c. Relative to Cu ERct 35.4 kJ mol1, the CEI displays a reduced charge transfer energy barrier of 27.6 kJ mol1. This reduction is attributed to the introduction of PEI on the Cu surface, a modiﬁcation that fosters the direct hydrogenation of NO3to NH3 under acidic conditions. In situ FTIR spectroscopic measurement provides insight into the molecular-level mechanism of NO3RR and the detection of adsorbed reaction intermediates. Potential- dependent transmittance spectra of Cu and CEI are presented in Figure 4dg. Both Cu and CEI catalysts show similar peaks at 1230, 1384, 1640, 3077 and 3650 cm1 assigned to the formation of NO2, NO3, NOH2O, NH2 and NH, respectively,12,4042 indicative of these two catalysts follow the similar NO3RR pathway under acidic conditions. text: LSV scan cycles each cycle involving a scan from 0.3 to 0.5 V vs. RHE using CEI in 0.5 M NO3pH 1. As depicted in Figure 4h, NO2, NO, NOH, NH2 and NH3 are detected via online DEMS. Notably, the NH3 signal exhibits the highest intensity among the ﬁve species, indicating it is the main product during NO3RR. The low intensity of NO2 suggests the high selectivity of CEI for NO3RR towards NH3, aligning with the low NO2FE of CEI. The high intensity for NO implies its signiﬁcance as an intermediate in the process, which agrees with the DFT calculation and in situ FTIR spectra. Finally, to ascertain the nitrogen source of the detected NH3, a 1H nuclear magnetic resonance NMR test was employed to identify the NH3 generation of CEI with 0.5 M 15NO3or 14NO3.4346 The typical 1H NMR spectra of the electrolyte collected after electrolysis at 0 V show two peaks corresponding to 15NH4 after electrolysis with 15NO3and three peaks related to 14NH4 after electrolysis with 14NO3Figure 4i, conﬁrming that the generated NH3 indeed originates from the NO3RR. Further, considering that metal ions may interfere with the results of the indophenol blue method, 1H NMR spectroscopy was also employed to assess the ammonia concentration. The NH3 concentration was quantiﬁed using a calibration curve based on standard 14NH4Cl and maleic acid as an internal standard Figure S19a,b. The measured FE 80.9 and NH3 yield rate 4.83 mg cm2 h1 closely matched the UV-Vis results FE: 82.4; yield: 5.01 mg cm2 h1 at 0.1 V Figure S19c, further verifying the methods reliability. Different from conventional electrolyzer systems entail- ing anodic oxygen evolution reaction OER coupled with cathodic NO3RR, ZnNOxbatteries have emerged as an enticing platform for the simultaneous production of high value-added NH3 and electricity owing to the high theoretical capacity and low redox potential of Zn metal.47,48 However, they confront challenges such as dendrite formation and corrosion. Moreover, the dissolved Zn ions in the electrolyte necessitate additional electricity for recovery. To address these concerns, we proposed a novel electrocatalytic conﬁguration wherein the low overpotential of NO3RR is coupled with the anodic organic oxidation reactions that are thermodynamically favourable and economical. This innovation renders the sustainable production of value- added chemicals. Particularly attractive are catalytic systems utilizing biomass-derived platform chemicals e.g., glucose, furfural and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural as oxidative substrates, owing to the renewable nature of these organic feedstocks.49 Furthermore, generating value-added organic byproducts instead of oxygen maximizes the return on energy investment. Taking furfural electrooxidation as an illustrative example, Cu electrode was prepared as an efﬁcient catalyst to convert furfural to furoic acid at a low potential. The characterizations of the Cu electrode are provided in Figure S20. Figure 5a and b illustrate the assembled electrocatalytic system utilizing low-potential furfural oxidation as the anode reaction and the NO3RR as the cathode reaction. Prior to the battery test, we collected LSV curves, showing that the onset potential for furfural oxidation is about 0.1 V versus RHE in 1 M KOH and 0.2

Prior to the battery test, we collected LSV curves, showing that the onset potential for furfural oxidation is about 0.1 V versus RHE in 1 M KOH and 0.2 M furfural Figure 5c, signiﬁcantly lower than that observed in the absence of furfural. The discharging polarization curve also showcases the highest power density of 15.5 mW cm2 Figure 5e. High-performance liquid chromatography HPLC was used for product analysis of furfural oxidation based on the built standard curves Figure S21. Furoic acid was the primary liquid product for furfural oxidation using a Cu anode in the furfural-NO3 battery, with yields of 0.48, 0.91 and 1.14 mmol h1 cm2 at discharge current densities of 20, 40 and 60 mA cm2, respectively Figure S22a. Meanwhile, furfuryl alcohol was also detected originating from the non-Faradaic Cannizzaro disproportionation reaction under strong basic conditions. The corrected FE for furoic acid reached approximately 100 at 20, 40 and 60 mA cm2 Figure S22b. All these results collectively underscore the feasibility of self-powered elec- trocatalytic systems, addressing multiple objectives, including value-added NH3 synthesis from NO3, biomass upgrading, and electricity output. In summary, we demonstrate that the protonation of amino groups on PEI is thermodynamically favourable and the in situ formed positively charged CEI can alter the charge distribution behaviour of the inner Helmholtz plane, increasing the concentration of NO3near the surface of the electrocatalyst. DFT calculations further evidence the CEI also raises the energy of the key reaction intermediate NO to reduce the energy barrier of the rate-determining step of NO3RR. Further, the distribution of relaxation times analysis reveals more rapid NO3RR kinetics over the developed CEI structure. As proof of concept, the prepared CEI delivers increased NH3 FE of 83.5 in 10 mM pH 1 and a further 90.2 when NO3increases to 0.5 M NO3. In addition, CEI exhibits the half-cell EE of 44.1 and 37.1 in 10 mM and 0.5 M NO3pH 1, respectively, exceeding reported values of NO3RR catalysts. Taking advantage of the high reduction potential of acidic NO3to NH3 conversion, the assembled acid-alkaline NO3- furfural battery represents a novel transformative system for simultaneously treating NO3pollutants, yielding value- added NH3, upgrading biomass and electricity output. Our results will inspire the use of CEI as an efﬁcient strategy for the further development of NO3RR electrocatalysts, and it may also be effective for other electrocatalytic reactions. text: Angewandte International Edition A Journal of the Gesellschaft Deutscher Chemiker www.angewandte.org Chemie Accepted Article Title: Electrochemical Enantioselective Oxidation of Indoles via Chiral Phosphoric Acid Catalysis in Cooperation with H3PO4 in Aqueous Media Authors: Xuefeng Tan, Zhijie Zhou, Minhua Shao, and Jianwei Sun This manuscript has been accepted after peer review and appears as an Accepted Article online prior to editing, proofing, and formal publication of the final Version of Record VoR. The VoR will be published online in Early View as soon as possible and may be different to this Accepted Article as a result of editing. Readers should obtain the VoR from the journal website shown below when it is published to ensure accuracy of information. The authors are responsible for the content of this Accepted Article. To be cited as: Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2025, e202510078 Link to VoR: https:doi.org10.1002anie.202510078 RESEARCH ARTICLE 1 Electrochemical Enantioselective Oxidation of Indoles via Chiral Phosphoric Acid Catalysis in Cooperation with H3PO4 in Aqueous Media Xuefeng Tan,a,b Zhijie Zhou,a Minhua Shaoc and Jianwei Suna a Dr. X. Tan, Z. Zhou, Prof. J. Sun Department of Chemistry and the Hong Kong Branch of Chinese National Engineering Research Centre for Tissue Restoration Reconstruction, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Clear Water Bay, Kowloon, Hong Kong SAR 999077, China E-mail: sunjwust.hk; xuefetancityu.edu.hk b Dr. X. Tan Department of Chemistry, City University of Hong Kong, Kowloon Tong, Tat Chee Avenue 83, Kowloon, Hong Kong SAR, 999077, China c Prof. M. Shao Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Clear Water Bay, Kowloon, Hong Kong SAR 999077, China Abstract: Disclosed here is the first catalytic enantioselective electrochemical oxidative rearrangement of indoles for the efficient synthesis of highly enantioenriched spirooxindoles. The in-situ generated HBr from substrate oxidation, known to be detrimental to the reaction itself, was perfectly consumed by cathode reduction. Challenges of this process include the difficulty in maintaining the synergy between substrate oxidation and cathode reduction as well as the general incompatibility of a hydrogen bonding catalytic system with the aqueous acidic media. A monophasic system was initially developed, but with little substrate generality. Further analysis of the mechanism and careful optimization allowed the development of a much more general and robust biphasic system that exhibited multiple advantages over chemical oxidation, including broader scope, less waste, milder conditions, and better enantioselectivity. It is also the first demonstration of chiral phosphoric acid catalysis in cooperation with H3PO4 in acidic aqueous media. Introduction Since the pioneering studies by Akiyama and Terada in 2004,1 chiral phosphoric acids CPA have evolved as a family of broadly powerful catalysts for diverse organic reactions.2 They have been employed as effective chiral ligands, hydrogen-bond donors, and sources of chiral counter anions. Their extraordinary ability in achieving outstanding asymmetric induction by weak interactions, such as hydrogen bonding, constitutes the key to success. While the design of sophisticated structures of CPAs contributed significantly to their performance, the choice of suitable reaction media often makes a big difference.

text: and sources of chiral counter anions. Their extraordinary ability in achieving outstanding asymmetric induction by weak interactions, such as hydrogen bonding, constitutes the key to success. While the design of sophisticated structures of CPAs contributed significantly to their performance, the choice of suitable reaction media often makes a big difference. CPA-based hydrogen- bonding catalysis is typically implemented in non-polar aprotic solvents to minimize their competing and often detrimental influence. Moreover, other hydrogen-bond donors, such as stronger Brønsted acids, are typically incompatible with CPA catalysis. As a result, it is a formidable challenge to implement CPA-based hydrogen-bonding catalysis in polar protic solvents in the presence of a strong inorganic acid. In the meanwhile, asymmetric electrosynthesis has gained tremendous developments in the past few years.3-7 The conventional use of stoichiometric oxidants and reductants can be potentially replaced by electricity as a greener and more sustainable alternative. However, current success has been mainly in transition metal catalysis domain, which rely on relatively more robust interaction between chiral catalyst and substrate Scheme 1a.3,4 In contrast, asymmetric induction by weak interactions with a chiral organocatalyst in an electrochemical system has met with limited success, partly due to the challenges associated with those unavoidable polar species present in the media, such as electrolytes, that may interfere with the weak but Scheme 1. The synergistic cooperation with inorganic phosphoric acid H3PO4 to achieve high efficiency and enantiocontrol was also demonstrated for the first time. Oxidative rearrangement of indoles to spirooxindoles was chosen as a model reaction for our study, as it represents an important process that converts readily available substrates to highly valuable complex biologically active molecules.8-10 Although great process has been achieved in the development and application of this process in the past few decades, there still remains very limited success in developing a catalytic enantioselective variant Scheme 1b. Moreover, previous asymmetric protocols uniformly required the use of stoichiometric chemical oxidants.9,10 In this context, the advantages of electrosynthesis further inspired us to develop a greener and more sustainable approach by

text: in the past few decades, there still remains very limited success in developing a catalytic enantioselective variant Scheme 1b. Moreover, previous asymmetric protocols uniformly required the use of stoichiometric chemical oxidants.9,10 In this context, the advantages of electrosynthesis further inspired us to develop a greener and more sustainable approach by electrochemical oxidation. Results and Discussion It has been well-known that electrochemical oxidation of Br can be employed to replace chemical oxidants, such as Br2.3,7,11,12 To prove the feasibility of green oxidation approach, we first examined this enantioselective process with stoichiometric Br2 as oxidant and mixed THFH2O as solvent to mimic the electrochemical condition Scheme 2. With A1 structure shown in Table 1 as the catalyst, the reaction of 1a successfully generated the desired product 2a in quantitative yield, but with essentially no enantioselectivity, no matter with Br2 or its analogue nBu4NBr3 entries 12. We also tried slow addition of oxidant, but with no significant improvement entry 3. Next, a control experiment in the absence of A1 showed similar results, suggesting a strong background reaction that might explain the low enantiocontrol entry 4. From the proposed mechanism of this process,10 it is clear that two equivalents of HBr can be generated from this system, which may outcompete CPA to facilitate this process and cause low enantiocontrol. We were also curious about the absence of such dramatic influence of HI generated from the use of NIS in the chemical oxidation protocol.10 Indeed, control experiment indicated that NIS could oxidize HI into I2, thus avoiding the influence of the generated HI see the SI for details. Nevertheless, despite the discouraging chemical oxidation results, we reasoned that an electrochemical oxidation system may fix the problem caused by the generated acid HBr, as the anodic oxidation is accompanied by cathodic reduction, which converts H to H2 and thus neutralizes the reaction system Scheme 2, blue box. To test this hypothesis, we did preliminary study using electricity as oxidant. Gratifyingly, the enantioselectivity was significantly enhanced 73 ee, entry 5. A control reaction by the addition of two equivalents of HBr to this system led to almost complete loss of enantiocontrol entry 6, thus consistent with the above analysis on the influence of HBr in the chemical oxidation. Overall, the preliminary study clearly highlighted the advantage of electrochemical system for this process by synergizing the two half reactions in electrodes. The above preliminary outcome using A1 as catalyst, nBu4NBr as both electrolyte and mediator, and THFH2O as solvent was used as a starting point for further optimization Table 1, entry 1. Variation of the anode material to graphite felt GF, glassy carbon GC or carbon rod CR resulted in decreased yield and ee entries 2. However, almost same results were observed with nickel as cathode entry 3. Other CPAs were also examined. Replacing the spirocyclic backbone to BINOL-based counterpart B1 led to significant decrease in enantioselectivity entry 4. However, changing the side arm to anthracene A2 improved the enantioselectivity to 92, suggesting the reaction was sensitive to

text: same results were observed with nickel as cathode entry 3. Other CPAs were also examined. Replacing the spirocyclic backbone to BINOL-based counterpart B1 led to significant decrease in enantioselectivity entry 4. However, changing the side arm to anthracene A2 improved the enantioselectivity to 92, suggesting the reaction was sensitive to the catalyst steric environment entry 5. After additional screening, catalyst A4 was identified as the best catalyst entry 7. Solvents also showed influence on this reaction. Ethyl acetate resulted in a slight decrease in enantioselectivity, but acetonitrile led to a substantial drop to 11 ee entries 910. However, acetone gave comparable results with THF entry 11, and more importantly, it led to higher conductivity, so it was employed for further study. Finally, decreasing the loadings of catalyst and water provided the optimal outcome entry 12. 10.1002anie.202510078 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. With the optimized protocol, we started to explore the reaction scope. However, to our surprise, this protocol was not general at all. For example, variation of the electronic properties on the indole ring had a drastic influence on reactivity. Substrates 1h and 1k showed completely no reactivity under the above conditions Scheme 3. We reasoned that this might be due to unbalanced synergy between substrate oxidation and cathodic reduction. In the ideal situation, the indole oxidation should not be slower than cathodic reduction krxn kred, thus the whole system is slightly acidic and the generated HBr is reduced in cathode. However, if this balance is broken e.g., krxn kred, there is insufficient HBr generated for cathodic reduction. Consequently, to maintain electron balance, water would be reduced instead, which generates hydroxide OH and turns the system into alkaline. The generated hydroxide

metadata.source: /Users/zemao/ChemQA/data/raw_papers/Tan 等 - 2025 - Electrochemical enantioselective oxidation of indoles via chiral phosphoric acid catalysis in cooperation with H3PO4 in aqueous media.pdf
metadata.title: Tan 等 - 2025 - Electrochemical enantioselective oxidation of indoles via chiral phosphoric acid catalysis in cooperation with H3PO4 in aqueous media.pdf

text: slightly acidic and the generated HBr is reduced in cathode. However, if this balance is broken e.g., krxn kred, there is insufficient HBr generated for cathodic reduction. Consequently, to maintain electron balance, water would be reduced instead, which generates hydroxide OH and turns the system into alkaline. The generated hydroxide not only quenches the CPA catalyst, but also further causes consumption of Br2 by forming BrO, which shuts down the indole oxidation. In principle, such an issue might be alleviated by adjusting the current. However, it is tedious to tune these parameters for each substrate. Thus, a more general protocol applicable to all the substrates would be highly desirable. Scheme 3. Preliminary examination of substrate generality and analysis. We envisioned that a biphasic system allowing physical separation of the indole oxidation and cathodic reduction might be a possible solution to the above issue Table 2. We then employed a mixture of DCM and H2O as solvent. NaBr was chosen as a source of bromide and electrolyte as well, since it has a good solubility in aqueous phase. Unfortunately, the results were irreproducible entry 1, suggesting partial water reduction in the cathode might be still involved to cause an unstable pH value of the system. In this context, we reasoned that the addition of an external acid should ensure an acidic medium, despite its possible interference with CPA in asymmetric induction. Thus, various Brønsted acids of different strengths were examined, including weak acid AcOH and strong inorganic acids HCl, H2SO4, and H3PO4. Among them, HCl and H2SO4 showed neither obvious improvement nor negative effect entries 23. However, AcOH was able to improve the enantioselectivity 93 ee, but with almost no increase in yield entry 4. To our delight, H3PO4 proved superior, resulting in both excellent yield and enantioselectivity entry 5. Moreover, the results were reproducible, with either one or two equivalents of loading entry 6. We believe that the ability of H3PO4, together with its conjugate bases, to serve as a potential buffer to stabilize the acidity of the reaction system might contribute to its extraordinary performance. Furthermore, to briefly test the generality, 1h and 1k were subjected to this new protocol. Both resulted in excellent efficiency and enantioselectivity entries 78, thereby illustrating improved generality of this biphasic binary acid system. It is also worth noting that, to the best of our knowledge, the combined use of CPA and H3PO4 for effective enantioselective catalysis has not been demonstrated before.2 Table 2. With the newly optimized biphasic protocol, we next examined a wide range of different indole substrates for the enantioselective electrochemical oxidative rearrangement Scheme 4. These reactions were smoothly enlarged to 0.3-mmol scale, along with a higher electric current of 9 mA. Different protecting groups on the nitrogen of the tetrahydro-β-carbolines, such as Boc, Fmoc, Cbz, Bz, and Ts, were all well-tolerated under the mild conditions 2a2e. Moreover, various substituents at different 4- to 7- positions of the indole ring, including both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing ones, all led to excellent outcomes 2f2p. It is worth noting that simple deprotection of 2h could generate the natural alkaloid horsfiline with ease.13 This electrochemical system has a number of advantages over our previously reported chemical oxidation protocol.10 Other than the use of green electricity, the new conditions showed a broader substrates scope. For example, substrates bearing a C4- or C7-substituent e.g., 2f, 2o2p were unsuccessful before, but they reacted smoothly to provide the desired products with excellent enantioselectivity and efficiency under the present electrochemical system. Moreover, tetrahydrofuranyl-sprooxindole 2q, representing another important family of substructures,14 could also be easily synthesized with high enantiopurity. In contrast, such molecules were obtained with sub-optimal enantiocontrol under the previous chemical oxidation system.10 Of note, the previous chemical oxidation system strictly required careful operation at low temperature to achieve high enantioselectivity, but the new electrochemical condition worked efficiently at ambient temperature. Finally, the monophasic system could also be applied to indoles without ring fusion in the 2,3-positions, leading to the corresponding oxindoles 2r2u bearing a non-spiro all- carbon quaternary stereocenter.15 However, a 2-aryl-substituted indole may form the 3-brominated imine product, which was unreactive toward further rearrangement see more details in the SI. Importantly, a gram-scale synthesis of 2h with a reduced catalyst loading resulted in equally high yield and enantioselectivity, illustrating the practicability of this electrochemical process. It is also worth mentioning that all these examples demonstrated exceptionally high Faradaic efficiency, mostly exceeding 80. Scheme 4. See the Terms and Conditions https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comterms-and-conditions on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License RESEARCH ARTICLE 5 Next, cyclic voltammetry of both the monophasic and biphasic systems was measured Figure 1. In the monophasic system, substrate 1a showed higher oxidation potential than nBu4NBr, suggesting the indole oxidation was performed indirectly by the in-situ generated oxidant from bromide Figure 1a. Upon mixing with 1a, the solution of nBu4NBr exhibited a catalytic current, suggesting consumption of the intermediary oxidant e.g., Br2 by reacting with 1a. For the biphasic system, we examined the effect of additives Figure 1b. The addition of H3PO4 had no influence on the cyclic voltammetry curve of NaBr. In contrast, the addition of NaOH caused an obvious change featuring a higher oxidation current, which might be due to the consumption of the generated Br2 by NaOH. Control experiments were also performed to probe the role of bromide Figure 1c. Replacing NaBr with NaNO3, an alternative electrolyte, led to no reaction. However, the addition of a catalytic amount of NaBr to this system restored the reactivity. These observations implied that NaBr not only served as an electrolyte, but also a mediator, which was consistent with our proposed mechanism involving Br2 as oxidant. Notably, increasing the NaBr concentration did not lead to further improvement see more details in the SI. Then we investigated the role of H3PO4. Two electrolysis reactions of 1a were performed in parallel, with and without H3PO4, under otherwise identical standard conditions Figure 1d. In the absence of H3PO4, the pH value of the aqueous phase increased obviously over time. In the meanwhile, the product enantioselectivity was mediocre and unstable. In contrast, with H3PO4, the same reaction showed almost constant pH value. resulting the inferior and unstable enantioselectivity. While in the presence of H3PO4, the pH value of the aqueous phase remained almost no change before reaction completion. Moreover, the product ee value was also constant and excellent. These observations undoubtedly confirmed the role of H3PO4 as a buffer to stabilize the acidity of the reaction system, which was crucial to the excellent outcome.16 Based on the above results, a possible mechanism is proposed Figure 1e. The reaction begins by anodic oxidation of the bromide in the aqueous phase. The resulting Br2 enters the organic phase to oxidize the substrate with the CPA

text: of the reaction system, which was crucial to the excellent outcome.16 Based on the above results, a possible mechanism is proposed Figure 1e. The reaction begins by anodic oxidation of the bromide in the aqueous phase. The resulting Br2 enters the organic phase to oxidize the substrate with the CPA catalyst controlling the enantioselectivity see more details in the SI for the relative distribution of bromine between phases. The rearrangement product was generated with concomitant release of HBr, which then enters the aqueous phase. Cathodic reduction of the generated HBr balances the charge and acidity. 0.0 0.4 0.8 1.2 1.6 0.00 0.04 0.08 0.12 I mA E vs SCE V blank nBu4NBr 1a nBu4NBr 1a 0.0 0.4 0.8 1.2 1.6 -0.05 0.00 0.05 0.10 0.15 0.20 I mA E vs SCE V NaBr NaBr NaOH NaBr H3PO4 Figure 1. Mechanistic studies. Conclusion In summary, we have developed the first catalytic enantioselective electrochemical oxidative rearrangement of indoles, leading to green and efficient synthesis of diverse highly enantioenriched spirooxindoles. The synergy between indole oxidation and cathode reduction proved critical to the success. The in-situ generated HBr from oxidative rearrangement proved to be detrimental to the reaction itself, but it can be perfectly consumed by cathode reduction. However, the initially developed monophasic system could not maintain this delicate balance of reaction rates, thus lacking generality. Nevertheless, careful mechanism analysis and condition optimization led to a successful improvement into a much more general biphasic 10.1002anie.202510078 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved. 15213773, ja, Downloaded from https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comdoi10.1002anie.202510078 by Tsinghua University Library, Wiley Online Library on 15062025. See the Terms and Conditions https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comterms-and-conditions on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License RESEARCH ARTICLE 6 system. This new protocol exhibited multiple advantages over the previous chemical oxidation approach, including less waste, broader scope, and milder conditions. The choice of H3PO4 as an additive not only ensured good reproducibility and robustness of this protocol but also improved the chemical efficiency and enantioselectivity. This is also the first demonstration of CPA catalysis in cooperation with H3PO4 in aqueous media. The unusual enhancement in performance by H3PO4 could be explained by the formation of a hypothetical heterodimer with CPA. Mechanistic and control experiments confirmed that NaBr served as both electrolyte and mediator. The development of other organocatalytic enantioselective electrosynthesis methods by weak interactions is ongoing in our laboratories. text: Elucidating the Activity of Electrochemical Nitrate Reduction: High- Valent Anionic Intermediates as Kinetic Gatekeepers Sheng-Jie Qian, Hao Cao, Xin-Mao Lv, Jun Li, and Yang-Gang Wang Cite This: https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c05728 Read Online ACCESS Metrics More Article Recommendations sı Supporting Information ABSTRACT: The persistent paradox in electrochemical nitrate reduction NO3 RRthe requirement of high overpotentials despite its highly exothermic natureremains a critical roadblock for efficient ammonia electrosynthesis. Here, we resolve this conundrum by identifying a high- valent anionic intermediate as kinetic gatekeepers during the nitrate reduction on a single-atom catalyst by using AIMD simulations under explicit solvation and electrode potentials. Employing our self-developed constant-potential thermodynamic integration method, we reveal a stark kinetic barrier dichotomy: while the reaction is thermodynamically favorable governed by the NO break, the protonation to oxygen at a low anionic state necessitates substantial activation energy. Mechanistic analysis uncovers that electrode polarization preactivates NO3 into a metastable high-valent NO3 2 intermediate, which serves as the key step to the following protonation process. Crucially, this intermediates stabilization requires a highly negative potential, directly linking its formation to the observed overpotential. Furthermore, molecular dynamics simulations also demonstrate that K cations play a key role in electrostatically stabilizing the adsorption of negatively charged NO3 onto the negatively polarized cathode. This work calls for the urgent reconsideration of conventional nitrate reduction mechanisms and the exigency of refined interface design principles for improved nitrate electrocatalysis. INTRODUCTION Since the 1980s, electrochemical nitrate reduction NO3 RR has traditionally been proposed for sewage treatment, facilitating the conversion of nitrate into innocuous nitrogen N2.13 Recently, there has emerged a revitalized interest in NO3 RR, motivated by the goal of producing ammonia NH3 instead.4,5 Therefore, electrochemical nitrate reduction repre- sents a sustainable pathway and a promising route for both water treatment and ammonia generation. The practical applications of NO3 RR in energy and environment, however, face a significant challenge due to its exceptionally high overpotential, despite the thermodynamically favorable path- ways with theoretical equilibrium potentials of 1.17 V vs SHE for N2 and 0.12 V vs SHE for NH3 formation. The universal initial two-electron 2e reduction of nitrate to nitrite is generally identified to be a rate-determining step.68 There are two popular contradictory hypotheses regarding the mechanism of reduction of nitrate to nitrite in the NO3 RR. One genre believes that nitrate reduction begins with a protonation process where NO3 interacts with H in solution to form adsorbed HNO3 at the electrode NO3 H HNO3, which is considered a solution-mediated proton transfer reaction and does not require electron transfer.9,10 Then, the formed HNO3 undergoes a process of protonation and dehydration to produce NO2. However, this does not conform to the common chemical knowledge that HNO3 is a strong electrolyte and would inevitably electrolyze into the proton and nitrate ion. The other representation points out that NO3 first undergoes an oxidative associative adsorption, where NO3 is adsorbed and discharged to form NO3 NO3 NO3 e.7,8,1115 Subsequent reduction and hydrogenation pro- cesses lead to the formation of NO2 or NO2 . However, the

text: inevitably electrolyze into the proton and nitrate ion. The other representation points out that NO3 first undergoes an oxidative associative adsorption, where NO3 is adsorbed and discharged to form NO3 NO3 NO3 e.7,8,1115 Subsequent reduction and hydrogenation pro- cesses lead to the formation of NO2 or NO2 . However, the oxidative adsorption is unlikely to proceed at the cathode electrode, where the electroreduction of NO3 is operated. Therefore, the mechanism of nitrate anion adsorption on the cathode remains controversial, and the origin of the high overpotential required for NO3 reduction is still poorly understood. Metalnitrogencarbon MNC, M Fe, Co, Mn, Ni, etc. single atom electrocatalysts,16,17 with a well-defined atomic structure, have emerged as a class of ideal model systems for fundamental studies to investigate the electro- catalytic mechanism. When combined with DFT calculations Received: April 4, 2025 Revised: May 26, 2025 Accepted: May 27, 2025 Article pubs.acs.orgJACS XXXX American Chemical Society A https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c05728 J. See https:pubs.acs.orgsharingguidelines for options on how to legitimately share published articles. to understand the reaction mechanism, the computational hydrogen electrode CHE model18 is still the most popular. For example, gaseous H2 and HNO3 are often chosen as reference points for calculating the binding energy of NO3 , as proposed by Calle-Vallejo et al.19 GNO d3 GNO d3 G GHNO d3g 12GH d2g Gcorrect. A large number of DFT calculations based on the CHE model have indicated that the rate-determining step of the transition of nitrate to nitrite is markedly exothermic. However, many catalysts such as Fe NC catalysts exhibit a significant overpotential exceeding 0.6 V.79,11,12,2022 Therefore, current theoretical calculations fail to explain the origin of the high overpotential, strongly suggesting that previously overlooked dynamic processes or complex interface effects may have played a key role. It is only within the past few years that an ever-increasing understanding of dynamically electrified solidliquid interfaces has started to trigger a return to this foundational pillar of electrochemistry, namely, uncovering the roles of electrode potential and solvent in electrochemical reactions under realistic electrochemical conditions,23,24 notably, in the CO2RR,25,26 ORR,27 and NRR.28 Unlike these neutrally charged small molecule reactants like CO2 and N2, NO3 ions are negatively charged in solution, which is expected to result in a significantly different mechanism. Nevertheless, it is fair to acknowledge that no study has yet provided a definitive description of the reduction behavior of NO3 at the electrodeelectrolyte interfaces. Here, we uncover the origin of the high overpotential for NO3 RR on the FeNC catalyst by employing the self- developed constant potential kinetic modeling method. Specifically, the critical roles of electrode potential and cations in the reaction mechanism were revealed. The 2ereduction pathway from nitrate to nitrite is characterized as exothermic thermodynamically, but our calculations show a notable kinetic energy barrier that must be surmounted. The electrode potential plays its role in accelerating the reaction kinetics by preactivating NO3 to high-valent NO3 2, while K at the interface

text: were revealed. The 2ereduction pathway from nitrate to nitrite is characterized as exothermic thermodynamically, but our calculations show a notable kinetic energy barrier that must be surmounted. The electrode potential plays its role in accelerating the reaction kinetics by preactivating NO3 to high-valent NO3 2, while K at the interface stabilizes the negatively charged NO3 2by electro- static interactions. Notably, the observed high overpotential is attributed to the highly negative reduction potential required for the conversion of NO3 to NO3 2. Our results highlight the pronounced electrostatic interactions at the electro- chemical interface in stabilizing charged reaction intermediates and provide new mechanism insights into the NO3 reduction process. This work explains the origin of experimentally observed high overpotentials, which cannot be accounted for by traditional models. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION The Role of K in Nitrate Adsorption. First, explicit counterion models were constructed to examine the dynamic adsorption of nitrate at the FeN4Cwater interface Figure S4. In the explicit counterions model, different numbers of K atoms were added, which spontaneously convert to hydrated K and charge the electrode surface. In the K-Inter model, K was placed on the side of the adsorbate at the interface Figure 1. Role of K. The FeO distances that vary with the number of cations a; potential-dependent charge on NO3 b; the adsorption energy of NO3 at 0.82 V vs RHE c; and the charge on NO3 during adsorption d. By contrast, the K-Back model placed the K at about 15 Å away from the interface, and the K and adsorbate were on either side of the slab due to the periodicity of the model, thereby avoiding direct interaction between the K and nitrate. These two models enable a comparison of how cations influence the electrochemical reaction at the interface under varying applied potentials. Each model ran at least 10 ps AIMD simulations to adequately equilibrate, and the density distribution of water and the distribution of K were analyzed from the trajectory at different electrode potentials Figure S5. In the K-Inter model and K-Back model, the distributions of water and K are symmetrical with respect to the electrode surface. An evident first water adsorption peak appears within 24 Å of the surfaces, reaching a maximum density of water of about 2.0 gcm3. After the first layer of water, there is a depletion of water with a minimum density of 0.5 gcm3 at about 5 Å. Further away from the surface, the wave fluctuations of water are gradually suppressed, and the density is recovered with an average value of around 1.0 gcm3. However, the K are distributed dynamically within the range of 26 Å away from the surface of the FeN4C electrode. text: However, the K are distributed dynamically within the range of 26 Å away from the surface of the FeN4C electrode. We then investigated the adsorption behavior of nitrate by collecting bond length and charge in AIMD simulations, as shown in Figure 1. NO3 is adsorbed on the FeN4C catalyst via an end-on configuration, in which one O atom of the nitrate binds with the Fe center. It can be observed in Figure 1a that the length of the FeO bond in the K-Back model remains at 2 Å until the number of K ions increase to 5, when it suddenly becomes longer longer than 5 Å. This indicates that NO3 is desorbed due to the electrostatic repulsion with the negatively polarized electrode surface as the number of K increases. By contrast, the FeO bond length in the K-Inter model fluctuates in the range of 23 Å, where the location of nitrate is perturbed by the dynamic distribution of K at the interface. These results demonstrate that the K cations play a crucial stabilizing role in the nitrate anion adsorption process. In the K-Back model, the NO3 species maintains both its monovalent character of 0.85 e and a N O bond length of 1.27 Å across the entire potential window. Notably, a potential-dependent charge accumulation phenom- enon was observed in the K-Inter model. At an electrode potential of around 0.8 V vs RHE, we observed a significant additional charge transfer of about 0.6 e to NO3 Figure 1b, converting to a high-valent NO3 2 anion. This transformation is accompanied by a distinct structural change, as evidenced by the elongation of the average NO bond length from 1.27 to 1.37 Å, indicative of nitrate activation. The stabilized adsorption of the high-valent NO3 2species can be attributed to enhanced electrostatic interactions with neighboring K cations, as confirmed by our electronic structure analysis Figure S6. These findings demonstrate a unique nitrate activation that is specifically enabled by the K-Inter model, highlighting the crucial role of electrostatic interactions in stabilizing nitrate adsorption at the electrified interfaces. Further, our recently developed Constant-Potential Ther- modynamic Integration CPTI method29,30 was employed to calculate the reaction energetics of nitrate adsorption in K- Inter and K-Back models at the electrode potential of 0.82 V. The CPTI method enables realistic modeling of the electrochemical interface, and the efficient free energy calculations are based on a robust surface charge density descriptor. At each collective variable CV chosen along with the reaction pathways, the CPTI method was applied to regulate the total number of electrons of the system to keep the electrode potential constant. By collecting the mean force of constraint at each CV Figure S7 and integrating over the mean force of constraint with respect to the CV, the free energy under fixed potential can be computed. The free energy curves in Figure 1c suggest that the adsorption energy of nitrate is only about 0.1 eV with a negligible energy barrier, which is thermally accessible. Moreover, the location of K hardly changes

text: constraint with respect to the CV, the free energy under fixed potential can be computed. The free energy curves in Figure 1c suggest that the adsorption energy of nitrate is only about 0.1 eV with a negligible energy barrier, which is thermally accessible. Moreover, the location of K hardly changes the adsorption energy of nitrate. Nevertheless, we found a difference in the charged state of the nitrate at adsorption Figure 1d. In both models, the electrode potential is maintained at the preset potential of 0.82 V during the reaction. It is worth noting that in the K-Back model, the charge of nitrate during adsorption is kept at 0.85 e, while in the K-Inter model, nitrate accepts about 0.6 additional electrons during adsorption, transforming from NO3 to NO3 2. This result can be interpreted as a shift of adsorption from physiosorbed NO3 in the K-Back model to chemisorbed and activated NO3 2in the K-Inter model. Thus, all results suggest that the nitrate is adsorbed on the surface of the electrode in the form of anions and emphasize the crucial role of electrostatic stabilization by K in the process of chemical adsorption and activation of NO3 into NO3 2on the FeN4C electrode. Recognizing the pivotal contribution of cations to the reaction mechanism, we focus on the K-Inter model to restore the dynamic behavior of K on the interface in the following discussion. The Mechanism of Nitrate Reduction. In a series of AIMD simulations at different electrode potentials, the dynamic evolution of nitrate reduction from NO3 to NO2 was captured uniquely at the electrode potential of 0.85 V. As displayed in Figure 2a, the evolution of nitrate reduction proceeds where the proton is first transferred to the adsorbed NO3 , followed by dissociation of hydroxide anions, leaving an adsorbed NO2 on the FeN4C electrode surface in a period of several hundred femtoseconds during the AIMD simulations. The change of bond length Figure 2b Figure 2. Evolutions in AIMD simulations. The change of potential energy a and distance b of nitrate reduction from NO3 to NO2 at 0.85 V vs RHE. XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX C also shows that the HO bond is formed with a bond length of 1.0 Å after proton transfer, subsequently followed by NO bond cleavage from a bond length of 1.3 Å during hydroxide dissociation. At a more positive electrode potential of 0.05 to 0.77 V, NO3 can be stably adsorbed during the simulations without obvious structure evolutions Figure S8. Inspired by this observation, we then employed the CPTI method again to calculate the reaction energetics of nitrate reduction at the representative electrode potentials of 0.55 V and 0.82 V. In order to capture the metastable intermediates, we have chosen two sets of CVs for the proton transfer step and hydroxide dissociation step, respectively, to dissect the 2e reduction reaction of nitrate to nitrite. text: and 0.82 V. In order to capture the metastable intermediates, we have chosen two sets of CVs for the proton transfer step and hydroxide dissociation step, respectively, to dissect the 2e reduction reaction of nitrate to nitrite. The free energy diagrams along the reaction pathway are shown in Figure 3, and the average force curves of CPTI simulations are collected in Figure S9. At an electrode potential of 0.55 V, nitrate reduction from NO3 to NO2 is a significantly exothermic process of about 2.63 eV, but there is a notable barrier of 0.92 eV Figure 3a. Specifically, the proton transfer for NO3 is endothermic with a free energy of 0.92 0.01 eV, while the hydroxide dissociation from NO2OHto NO2 is exothermic with a free energy of 1.59 0.02 eV. The evolution of structures along the reaction pathway in Figure 3b shows that the NO bond of NO3 is 1.29 Å, while the NO bonds are 1.27 and 1.32 Å in NO2 . There is a process of electron transfer required to charge the metastable inter- mediate for subsequent hydroxide dissociation after proton transfer. By contrast, when the electrode potential is reduced to 0.82 V, the energy barrier of the reduction reaction caused by the proton transfer step is greatly reduced to only 0.30 0.01 eV. It is worth emphasizing that prior to the proton transfer step, NO3 has first undergone reduction to NO3 2during adsorption at the electrode potential of 0.82 V, as supported in the previous sections. The protonation of preactivated NO3 2is largely easier to occur kinetically than the direct protonation of NO3 with a reduction of reaction energy of about 0.6 eV. The evolution of structures along the reaction pathway also confirmed the potential-dependent activation of NO3 with a longer NO bond of NO3 2of 1.36 Å at 0.82 V than that at 0.55 V. The results suggest that the activation of nitrate induced by electrode potential determines the further reduction kinetics to nitrite. The regulation of the electrode potential and the total number of electrons added to the system along with the reaction coordinates are displayed in Figure 4. The electrode potentials along the reaction pathways are all within the set convergence threshold centered on 0.55 V and 0.82 V in Figure 4a,c, respectively, during the CPTI simulations. The solid lines show the total number of electrons added to the system during proton transfer blue and hydroxide dissoci- ation sampled as red. It takes about 2 electrons for the reduction reaction from NO3 to NO2 and about 1 electron for the reduction reaction from NO3 2to NO2 . The change in charge on intermediates was also analyzed, which allowed one to consider the following nitrate reduction mechanism. At 0.55 V Figure 4b, during proton transfer blue line, the charge on NO3 and the total charge on NO3 and the transferring proton denoted as NO3 H were collected. NO3 initially obtains the first electron for prereduction to form high-valent NO3 2eq 1; then, NO3 2undergoes the protonation process and subsequently obtains the second electron to dissociate into NO2 and OHeq 2. Detailed charge distribution analysis suggests that the electron accumulation on a specific oxygen atom of the nitrate molecule, as complemented by background charge, drives the dissociation of the OHgroup Figure S10. The density of states DOS was also conducted to show that the arrangement of d orbitals of the Fe center is evolved as the electrode potential decreases to promote the adsorption and activation of nitrate at the active Fe center Figure S11. Thus, the d orbitals of the Fe active center act as a medium for electron transfer, bridging the electrode surface and NO3 . Our calculations indicate that a significant energy barrier must be overcome in the reduction process to nitrite, despite the reaction being thermodynamically exothermic. The crucial intermediate of NO3 2along with the determining step in the reaction pathway has been identified. The 2ereduction of NO3 to form NO2 by direct protonation is kinetically extremely challenging. Intriguingly, when NO3 is first activated to NO3 2by a reduction step, the subsequent protonation and one-electron reduction processes to form NO2 are significantly facilitated. text: NO3 to form NO2 by direct protonation is kinetically extremely challenging. Intriguingly, when NO3 is first activated to NO3 2by a reduction step, the subsequent protonation and one-electron reduction processes to form NO2 are significantly facilitated. However, the reduction potential required for the conversion of NO3 to NO3 2is highly negative, accounting for the experimentally observed high overpotential for nitrate reduction. Our calculations reveal that it is a decoupled process where electron transfer precedes proton transfer in the 2ereduction process. That is why the traditional CHE model failed in this system as the model assumes a coupled proton and electron transfer. Consequently, it is indicated that the preactivation of NO3 is the potential- determining step, while the protonation process is the rate- determining step during the 2enitrate reduction. Further- more, the essential role of electrode potential in accelerating reaction kinetics through preactivation of NO3 to NO3 2is highlighted. The Physical Picture of Electrochemical Interface Dynamics. Electrochemical reactions take place at the electrified electrodeelectrolyte interface, characterized by an Figure 4. XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX E intricate solution environment and inherent dynamics, where reaction intermediates are influenced by both the dynamic electrolyte and the varying electrode potential. We provide a schematic representation of interfacial interactions involved in nitrate reduction in Figure 5a. Within the Helmholtz plane, there are many charged species with ubiquitous electrostatic interactions and dynamic polarization phenomena. Specifically, at the negatively polarized electrode surface, hydrated alkali metal cations, which are commonly used as supporting electrolytes, are expected to partially localize in the Helmholtz plane. This behavior creates a large interfacial potential drop as pictured in Figure 5b, which dominates the occurrence of electrochemical electron transfer ET processes. As the negatively charged NO3 ions migrate into the interfacial Figure 5. Physical picture of electrochemical interface dynamics. This is evidenced by the electron localization between the negative oxygen and positive charge K centers Figure 5c. The appearance of a sharp first peak in the radial distribution function and the measured KO distance also confirms the short-range electrostatic interaction between K and NO3 Figure 5d,e. In addition to electrostatic effects, the solvation effect would also play a role in stabilizing the adsorption of charged intermediates Figure S12. text: function and the measured KO distance also confirms the short-range electrostatic interaction between K and NO3 Figure 5d,e. In addition to electrostatic effects, the solvation effect would also play a role in stabilizing the adsorption of charged intermediates Figure S12. When the electrode potential drops to the reduction potential, one electron transfers from the electrode to the nitrate at the interface, converting NO3 into high-valent NO3 2. Under this electrode potential, the electrostatic repulsion between the electrode and NO3 2is strengthened, while the corresponding electrostatic attraction between K and NO3 2is also enhanced, thereby stabilizing the adsorption of NO3 2for subsequent reactions. Once the reduction potential of NO3 to NO3 2is reached, the protonation process becomes kinetically more favorable, allowing the 2ereduction from NO3 to NO2 to proceed efficiently. We reaffirm that the high-valent NO3 2anion predicted in our theoretical study during the two-electron reduction of nitrate is metastable with a very short lifetime. It is anticipated that advanced time-resolved spectroscopic techni- ques may enable its detection in future studies. Strategies such as the cation,31 electrode potential,32 halogen electrolyte,33 and heterostructure34,35 have been proposed to improve the performance of electrocatalytic nitrate reduction. For example, Wen et al.31 found that K can regulate the electrostatic potential distribution and proton transport in the electric double layer, thus enhancing the kinetics for the conversion of NO3 . Moreover, a series of alkali metal ions Li, Na, K were compared, and it was found that due to the smallest radius of K hydrated cations, the effects were more significant in promoting charge transfer and nitrate reduction. Guo et al.32 proposed to unitize electrode potential to control the active siteintermediate interactions to enhance NO reduction reactivity on oxygen vacancy-modified TiO2. These studies support our calculations here that alkali metal cations can promote the adsorption of nitrate ions, highlighting the key regulatory role of the electrochemical interface micro- environment including electrode potential and electrolyte composition in the kinetics of electrocatalytic reduction reactions. Future studies could further discuss the effects of different species of cation. We anticipate that our work will inspire the development of refined interface design principles for improved nitrate electrocatalysis. CONCLUSIONS In this work, a full explicit model combined with constant potential modeling based on density functional theory was employed. Our work resolves a long-standing puzzle of the high overpotential in nitrate reduction by revealing the mechanism with a particular emphasis on the roles of electrode potential and cations. First, NO3 is observed to absorb on the negatively polarized electrode surface as an anionic species. Subsequently, constant potential kinetics calculations indicate that the 2ereduction pathway from nitrate to nitrite is thermodynamically exothermic, yet it encounters a significant reaction energy barrier. Further, the first electron transfer, driven by the electrode potential, activates NO3 to NO3 2 and emerges as the key of 2ereduction of nitrate to nitrite. Importantly, the electrostatic stabilization provided by K is also indispensable for the adsorption of NO3 anions. Due to the highly negative reduction potential for converting NO3 to NO3

text: transfer, driven by the electrode potential, activates NO3 to NO3 2 and emerges as the key of 2ereduction of nitrate to nitrite. Importantly, the electrostatic stabilization provided by K is also indispensable for the adsorption of NO3 anions. Due to the highly negative reduction potential for converting NO3 to NO3 2, a high overpotential is required experimentally for nitrate reduction. By considering kinetics, which is often overlooked in traditional calculations, as well as the effects of the electrode potential and cations, this work offers critical insights and timely guidance for electrochemical nitrate reduction. Our findings also call for the urgent reexamination of conventional nitrate reduction mechanisms and the exigency of refined interface design principles to advance electrocatalytic performance. COMPUTATIONAL DETAILS The dynamic properties were conducted using the Born Oppenheimer molecular dynamics BOMD simulations carried out with the CP2K package.36 The wave functions were adopted with optimized double-ζ Gaussian basis sets with a cutoff energy of 500 Ry,37 and valence electrons were modeled by scalar relativistic norm-conserving pseudopoten- tials with 16, 4, 5, 6, 1, and 9 valence electrons for Fe, C, N, O, H, and K, respectively. The canonical ensemble NVT employing NoseHoover thermostats was set to 300 K, and 2 atomic mass units were adopted for all H atoms with a time step of 1.0 fs.38,39 The CPTI method was implemented into the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package VASP code,40,41 and a Python code was programed to regulate the electrode potential.29,30 The PerdewBurkeErnzerhof PBE exchangecorrelation functional within a generalized gradient approximation GGA was employed.42 The van der Waals interactions were considered using the empirical DFT D3 method proposed by Grimme et al.43 The valence states were expanded in a plane-wave basis set with a cutoff of 400 eV. The Γ-point sampling of the Brillouin zone was used due to the large computation cost.44 The NoseHoover thermostat was employed, and the time step was set as 1.0 fs. In the CPTI method, the number of electrons in the system was manipulated to maintain a constant electrode potential; see more details in refs 29 and 30. The periodical FeN4C model was built by a supercell of N- doped graphene with a dimension of 17.04 14.76 20.00 Å3. A water film consisting of 140 H2O molecules with an average density of 1 gcm3 was given in the vacuum region, as displayed in Figure S2. text: Data-Driven Strategies for Designing Multicomponent Molten Catalysts to Accelerate the Industrialization of Methane Pyrolysis Yuanzheng Chen, Xuxuan Huang, Yangdong He, Qian Liu, Junmei Du, Wei Yang, Wenhan Wang, Di Zhang, Xue Jia, Hongyan Wang, Yongliang Tang, Qingkai Yu, Seok Ki Kim, and Hao Li Cite This: ACS Catal. 2025, 15, 1100311012 Read Online ACCESS Metrics More Article Recommendations ABSTRACT: Methane CH4 pyrolysis via molten media catalysis presents a transformative coke-free pathway for carbon-neutral hydrogen production and high-value carbon capture, yet its industrial scalability remains constrained by energy-intensive ultrahigh temperature require- ments. Recent breakthroughs in multicomponent molten systems i.e., binary, ternary, and quaternary have shown great potential for effective CH4 pyrolysis at a moderate temperature, opening up exciting possibilities for the industrialization of CH4 pyrolysis. However, the combinatorial complexity of element selection and atomic disorder in molten media, coupled with the limitations of empirical experimentation and conventional computational methods, present great hurdles for multicomponent molten catalysts design. With the development of artificial intelligence and data technology, the data-driven strategy offers a promising alternative to the traditional experimenttheory approach. From this perspective, we expound and emphasize the data- driven approach for enhancing molten media catalysts discovery and advancing the industrialization development of CH4 pyrolysis. We discuss the capacity of this approach to explore the design space along with several data-guided strategies tackling the existing challenges associated with molten catalysts design. KEYWORDS: methane pyrolysis, artificial intelligence, data-driven, molten catalysts, multicomponent 1. FRONTIER OF MOLTEN CATALYSTS CH4 PYROLYSIS Natural gas, one of the primary global fossil fuel reserves, is abundant and widely employed, playing a significant role in global energy production.1 However, while its direct combus- tion generates vast amounts of energy, this process releases CO2 as a byproduct, contributing negatively to global warming. Thus, a decarbonization of natural gas to hydrogen has always been a pursuit of researchers. As a result, decarbonizing natural gas into hydrogen has long been a focus of scientific research. As an effective pathway of hydrogen H2 production, CH4 pyrolysis can achieve carbon-free clean energy conversion specifically occurring under the temperature, pressure, and catalyst. In the absence of catalysis, full CH4 conversion or dissociation usually requires a high operating temperature or narrow pressure range. Additionally, the reaction mechanism exhibits intricate coupling steps with various branching byproducts that become progressively more complex as the reaction progresses.24 The formation of H2 and carbon is favored at a high reaction temperature e.g., 1200 C, a long residence time for CH4 in the high-temperature reaction zone, and a moderate pressure.5 Catalysts can significantly lower the temperature required for CH4 pyrolysis down to 500800 C in traditional solid catalysts application,6 but in which carbon produced from CH4 pyrolysis often quickly encapsulates solid particles and deactivates catalysts Figure 1A. Among various routes of CH4 conversion i.e., high-temperature thermal cracking,7 catalytic cracking,8 and plasma cracking,9 molten cracking has emerged as a promising solution. This technique employs molten media i.e., molten metals, molten salts, molten metals alloys, molten metals-salts as both a catalyst and a heat transfer
