text: deactivates catalysts Figure 1A. Among various routes of CH4 conversion i.e., high-temperature thermal cracking,7 catalytic cracking,8 and plasma cracking,9 molten cracking has emerged as a promising solution. This technique employs molten media i.e., molten metals, molten salts, molten metals alloys, molten metals-salts as both a catalyst and a heat transfer medium to facilitate CH4 pyrolysis. This approach has garnered more and more attention due to its superior advantages,10 including high conversion efficiency, easy separation of products, and produced possibly high-value carbon i.e., graphene11 and diamond12. One particular advantage is that molten media offer a liquid reaction environment in which accumulated solid carbon can potentially be readily transported and removed, thus preventing deactiva- Received: April 8, 2025 Revised: June 4, 2025 Accepted: June 4, 2025 Perspective pubs.acs.orgacscatalysis XXXX American Chemical Society 11003 https:doi.org10.1021acscatal.5c02415 ACS Catal. 2025, 15, 1100311012 Downloaded via TSINGHUA UNIV on June 15, 2025 at 07:47:41 UTC. See https:pubs.acs.orgsharingguidelines for options on how to legitimately share published articles. tion by coke deposition that happened in solid catalysts Figure 1B. 2. MOLTEN CATALYSTS DESIGN DILEMMA FOR CH4 PYROLYSIS Despite the demonstrated capability of molten catalysts in mitigating coke deposition and catalyst deactivation during CH4 pyrolysis, their industrial implementation remains constrained by the high operating temperatures required by the systems currently reported systems. In this context, the primary challenge for the industrialization of CH4 pyrolysis is the development of highly efficient molten catalysts at low temperatures for decreasing heat supply costs. The recent findings on the catalysis of multimetalsnonmetal elements mixing molten media Figure 1A have shown great potential for effective CH4 pyrolysis at a moderate temperature, opening up exciting possibilities for the industrialization of CH4 pyrolysis. Meanwhile, the potential for mixing multiple molten media presents a vast uncharted space beyond the corners of metal nonmetal elemental and chemical compositional diagrams Figure 1C, offering new avenues for the design of high- efficiency catalysts for CH4 cracking. Previous reports on catalyst compositions, particularly molten metal alloys, have shown that they can be highly effective catalysts and heat-transfer media for CH4 pyrolysis. For instance, in 2017, Upham et al. reported that a 27 Ni73 Bi molten alloy achieved 95 CH4 conversion at 1065 C.13 On the basis of this binary alloy, Chen et al. further proposed a high-efficiency ternary molten metal alloy 2.3 Ni 96.4 Bi1.3 Mo, reaching a hydrogen production efficiency of 4.05 mLgmin even at a low temperature of 800 C.14 Although the inclusion of additional elements offers huge opportunities to design catalysts of molten metals, it also introduces significant challenges in experiments and theory. The first one is the difficulty in exploring the effective alloy, mainly due to the large number of metal elements, the complexity of metal alloy combinations, and the diversity of alloy composition proportion. Even if considering only the most used metal elements in the periodic table, this spans a composition space of at least 1050 metal alloy variants, which cannot be managed by experiment by blind trial and error testing due to the high labor-intensiveness and

metadata.title: Chen 等 - 2025 - Data-driven strategies for designing multicomponent molten catalysts to accelerate the industrialization of methane pyrolysis.pdf

text: and the diversity of alloy composition proportion. Even if considering only the most used metal elements in the periodic table, this spans a composition space of at least 1050 metal alloy variants, which cannot be managed by experiment by blind trial and error testing due to the high labor-intensiveness and the large energy cost. When the space is expanded to other molten media systems, the challenge is even more hard. Additionally, the experimental understanding of the CH4 activation mechanism in molten catalysts is also challenging owing to the scarcity of in situ tools for molten matter. Second, under an extremely molten liquid state, the catalytic activity geometry, active site, and atomic arrangement of molten media catalysts are dynamically evolving, so that the catalytic activity and reaction mechanism in a liquid catalyst cannot be expounded by conventional catalysis theory.15 In catalysis theory, theoretical reactivity markers are routinely estimated for catalytic property and used in the design of a catalyst. While many theoretical works can be found on solid- state catalysts for various applications,1618 research on molten liquid-state media is still in its nascent stages. In a conventional first-principles simulation, although adopted ab initio molecular dynamics AIMD can obtain an amorphous molten state,19,20 this procedure exhibits a great efficiency bottleneck since it is limited by the need for extensive and costly computational validation. It requires the exploration of a thermodynamic equilibrium model under consideration of a large-atomic scale supercell. In a large spanning space of multimetalsnonmetal elements mixing molten media, the limited spatial and temporal simulation scales of first-principles methods pose challenges in the simulation of dynamic evolution and catalytic CH4 processes in molten catalysts design. Figure 1. The catalytic advantages and design dilemma of molten catalysts for CH4 pyrolysis. A A conceptual representation of solid catalysts deactivated process for CH4 pyrolysis on a single solid particle, and schematic of CH4 pyrolysis using the catalyst from solid to multielements mixing molten media as a function of time, referring to refs 1214. B The CH4 pyrolysis using molten media as the catalyst. C A vast elements space of molten media component and the potential for mixing multiple combinations. D A conceptual representation of data-driven approaches. Some identifiers in figure D reproduced with permission from ref 25. Copyright 2022, Wiley-VCH. ACS Catalysis pubs.acs.orgacscatalysis Perspective https:doi.org10.1021acscatal.5c02415 ACS Catal. 2025, 15, 1100311012 11004 3. THE ROLE OF MOLTEN MEDIA COMPOSITION FOR CH4 PYROLYSIS CH4 pyrolysis is conceptualized as a complex four-step dehydrogenation process, which is an endothermic, thermody- namically constrained, and equilibrium-limited reaction. In a liquid reaction environment, the composition of molten media affects not only the conversion efficiency of CH4 pyrolysis but also the pyrolysis byproduct type. For industrial viability, the production of high-value carbon is also an important concern, being secondary to catalyst efficiency. In a molten catalytic CH4 pyrolysis, the type of carbon byproduct significantly differs from noncatalytic pyrolysis in a gas condition.4,2124 For example, Palmer et al. reported that the gas CH4 decomposition inside gas bubbles results in amorphous carbon materials,22 while

text: is also an important concern, being secondary to catalyst efficiency. In a molten catalytic CH4 pyrolysis, the type of carbon byproduct significantly differs from noncatalytic pyrolysis in a gas condition.4,2124 For example, Palmer et al. reported that the gas CH4 decomposition inside gas bubbles results in amorphous carbon materials,22 while surface decomposition at gasmolten metal interfaces results in the formation of graphitic carbon. By adjusting the composition of molten media, CH4 pyrolysis can not only yield these common carbon forms but also facilitate the production of high-value carbon materials, such as graphene and diamond. For example, by adopting molten copper as the medium, we achieved high- quality multilayer a few layers 40 layers graphene preparation via molten Cu-assisted pyrolysis of methane.11 Recently, our group adopted the ionic complexes of the transition metal chloride and realized the efficient pyrolysis of CH4 and achieved one-pot synthesis of 0D carbon black2D graphene carbon materials.23 Ruoff et al.12 reported that diamond can grow in the subsurface of a molten medium composed of gallium, iron, nickel, and silicon at a 1 atm pressure and 1025 C. These works demonstrated that the different molten media dictated distinct carbon atom growth modes, further determining the carbon product structure. Of course, there also exist some other factors i.e., gas bubble diameter profiles, gas bubble rise velocity, reaction rates, temperature, pressure, and gas compositions that influence carbon formation and its structure. However, from the catalytic viewpoint and structureactivity relationship, the composition of molten media can be considered as a key factor in controlling carbon products, thus necessitating the careful selection for desired outcomes. 4. DATA-DRIVEN STRATEGIES OF MOLTEN CATALYSTS DESIGN FOR CH4 PYROLYSIS Along with the development of artificial intelligence AI and data technologies, the data-driven approaches offer a promising alternative to the traditional experimenttheory approach, which can achieve a much more accurate design or prediction for a large amount of component Figure 1D. In the past decade, machine learning ML and its subdomain deep learning have been explosively rising, which can establish mathematical models to analyze data and reveal the relationships and patterns within them, exhibiting great capability in the field of catalyst design26,27 and alloy predictions, especially in the field of high-entropy alloys.28,29 The success of ML mainly lies in its capability to describe complex patterns within multidimensional data sets, offering systematic optimization pathways through iterative learning processes. ML models enable swift identi- fication of the most promising candidates from thousands of potential catalysts, a feat nearly impossible with traditional methods. For molten catalyst systems, specifically, the challenge of navigating vast compositional spaces makes data-driven strategies particularly valuable. These approaches can efficiently map the complex relationships among composition, structure, and catalytic activity while accounting for the unique physics of liquid-state catalysis. By combining advanced ML techniques with domain knowledge of molten systems, researchers can now explore previously intractable design spaces, predict promising catalyst compositions, and accelerate the discovery of high- performance materials for CH4 pyrolysis. The integration of generative models further expands these capabilities, enabling the systematic

By combining advanced ML techniques with domain knowledge of molten systems, researchers can now explore previously intractable design spaces, predict promising catalyst compositions, and accelerate the discovery of high- performance materials for CH4 pyrolysis. The integration of generative models further expands these capabilities, enabling the systematic exploration of novel catalyst compositions, while Figure 2. Data-driven approaches and simulations methods. A Descriptor-guided design visualization demonstrating the challenge of sparse data points represented by colored circles in a high-dimensional descriptor space, where effective descriptor selection enables meaningful correlation with catalyst performance despite data limitations. Reproduced with permission from ref 30. Copyright 2024, Nature Publishing Group. B Schematic of AIMDDFT simulation on molten media catalyzing CH4 pyrolysis. ACS Catalysis pubs.acs.orgacscatalysis Perspective https:doi.org10.1021acscatal.5c02415 ACS Catal. 2025, 15, 1100311012 11005 incorporating physical and chemical constraints specific to molten systems. 4.1. Descriptor-Guided Design. Data-driven approaches contribute to uncovering catalyst design rules that go beyond physical and chemical intuition. At the heart of this advancement lies the descriptor-guided design methodology, which system- atically leverages structureproperty relationships to identify promising catalyst candidates. As illustrated in Figure 2A, this approach enables the rational design of high-performance systems through carefully selected descriptors that capture essential material characteristics.30 The key point of this approach applied to the molten media design for CH4 pyrolysis is to explore the compositioncatalytic relationship, which can be derived from combining experimental data and theoretical calculations. The theoretical simulations mainly based on first-principles calculations that incorporate simplified model systems can capture the critical aspects of complex realistic systems and thus guide the rational design. Currently, a rough first-principles calculation route Figure 2B can be summarized as follows: obtaining an amorphous molten surface by AIMD, adsorbing the reactants, and calculating the activation barrier using kinetics computation methods e.g., the DFT-based nudged-elastic band method.20 According to the existing molten media prototypes and element-related variations, previous experimenttheoretical simulations-based efforts to elucidate CH4 activation mecha- nisms reveal that a charge transfer at the active site influences the CH4 activation energy, showing solute atoms with less negative charge in molten metal alloy systems exhibit higher activity in CH4 decomposition.13 This chargeactivity correlation offers a suitable option for descriptor-guided design. Based on this essential charge descriptor, Kwon et al. designed Zn0.45Bi0.55 molten alloys as a promising catalyst for CH4 pyrolysis, in which the active metal Zn contributes to changing the charge states of base metal Bi, facilitating CH dissociation.31 Some similar designs were made for CuBi20 and Se-doped NiBi32 molten alloys and their change in the Bader charge of the solvent metal Bi obeys such a rule. Recently, we have explored the Bibased binary molten alloy systems to identify two novel descriptors linked to CH4 activation characteristics: i the H binding energy

text: were made for CuBi20 and Se-doped NiBi32 molten alloys and their change in the Bader charge of the solvent metal Bi obeys such a rule. Recently, we have explored the Bibased binary molten alloy systems to identify two novel descriptors linked to CH4 activation characteristics: i the H binding energy of the solute metal as an indicator of CH3H affinity; ii the solute diffusivity as a measure of active-site accessibility.33 Based on these descriptors guidance, we further designed two ternary alloys Bi68Ni27Cu5 and Bi68Ni27Mn5 that demonstrated superior performance with more catalytic activity than the binary BiNi alloy, and their superiority was corroborated by the results of experiments.33 However, current theoretical andor experimental descriptors face important limitations. They often fail to fully capture crucial dynamic phenomena such as the motion of the metal atoms and the vibration of the molecules. At high temperatures, atom or molecule vibrational modes of CH4 pyrolysis often become anharmonic, which could affect the accuracy of free energy calculations, including entropic and enthalpic components; thus, there would be need to consider such effects in the DFT calculations. Additionally, high-temperature molten catalysts may exhibit a mixed electronion conductor effect. However, these effects cannot be accurately accounted for in the static DFT modeling. For complex molten systems, the traditional AIMDDFT calculation route seems to be more difficult for obtaining the rationality of amorphous surfaces generated by AIMD with no scientifically robust structural sampling methods or evaluation criteria. Furthermore, the reaction of CH4 activation possibly occurs at various catalytic environments i.e., the mobile bubble interface; the catalytic activity could be affected by multiple interconnected properties such as surface composition, surface energy, surface tension, viscosity, and density. For instance, Scheiblehner et al. reported Ni-promoted molten metal catalysts exampled by Ni-doped NiSn alloys for methane pyrolysis, for which the reason is attributed to its low surface tension and viscosity, which facilitate the formation of smaller bubbles, thereby increasing the gas residence time within the melt.34 This multifaceted nature of molten catalysis for CH4 pyrolysis calls for the development of more comprehensive descriptors capable of capturing the full complexity of multicomponent catalyst systems. The challenge lies in the extensive computational and experimental resources required to explore the vase compositional space of molten catalysts. Traditional approaches relying solely on experimental methods or computationally intensive AIMDDFT calculations become prohibitively expensive and time-consuming when applied to the full range of potential catalyst compositions. These limitations underscore the need for more efficient strategies in descriptor identification and validation. The establishment of descriptor-guided design principles is fundamentally dependent on comprehensive composition- property data sets. ML enables systematic derivation of mathematical relationships within these data sets, facilitating the identification of latent physicochemical descriptors. This methodology begins with the construction of advanced regression or classification models that quantitatively rank catalyst candidates through statistical correlation analyses between identified descriptors and target performance metrics e.g., CH4 conversion efficiency and activation energy minimization. The analysis then progresses to a rigorous prioritization phase, where candidate materials aligned with strongly correlated descriptor-property relationships. This evaluation

text: of advanced regression or classification models that quantitatively rank catalyst candidates through statistical correlation analyses between identified descriptors and target performance metrics e.g., CH4 conversion efficiency and activation energy minimization. The analysis then progresses to a rigorous prioritization phase, where candidate materials aligned with strongly correlated descriptor-property relationships. This evaluation applies strict statistical criteria, such as maintaining the Pearson correlation coefficient above 0.7 or meeting comparable significance thresholds. To address the common challenge of data scarcity, the methodology incorporates feature engineering strategies. Through iterative multicycle learning with diversified descriptor combinations, the approach progressively distills critical structureproperty determinants. Such a multiparametric optimization framework effectively overcomes the information extraction limitations inherent to sparse experimental data, thereby enabling data-driven discovery of molten salt catalysts for CH4 pyrolysis. Symbolic regression techniques, particularly the sure independence screening and sparsifying operator SISSO methodology,3537 have emerged as powerful tools for establishing structureactivity relationships in catalysis. These data-driven approaches systematically explore nonlinear corre- lations by constructing mathematical descriptors through combinatorial operations on primary feature sets. As demon- strated in a representative study by Andersen et al.,36 SISSO successfully identified a nonlinear descriptor for single-atom catalysts that surpassed traditional scaling relations in predicting adsorption energies, achieving both improved accuracy and enhanced transferability across material systems. The core strength of symbolic regression lies in its ability to perform exhaustive searches through high-dimensional feature spaces generated by mathematical operator combinations, typically implemented via genetic programming or deterministic optimization algorithms. However, two critical challenges ACS Catalysis pubs.acs.orgacscatalysis Perspective https:doi.org10.1021acscatal.5c02415 ACS Catal. 2025, 15, 1100311012 11006 hinder the direct application of these techniques to the molten catalyst design for CH4 pyrolysis. First, the inherent complexity of molten liquid systems introduces additional degrees of freedom in feature selection, particularly regarding dynamic surface reconstruction and transient coordination environ- ments. Second, while symbolic regression excels at identifying optimal feature combinations, the resulting mathematical expressions often lack physical interpretability, a crucial requirement for guiding rational catalyst design. This interpret- ability gap becomes particularly pronounced when dealing with molten catalysts, where the liquid-phase nature introduces nontrivial thermodynamic and kinetic couplings. To address these limitations, we advise a synergistic approach combining sensitivity analysis with domain-specific feature engineering. Systematic sensitivity mapping of regression- derived descriptors can reveal dominant molten system characteristics such as ionic polarizability and metalligand bond fluctuation frequencies. This physical grounding enables the translation of mathematical descriptors into actionable design principles, such as optimizing charge transfer dynamics or tuning liquid-phase coordination symmetry, thereby establish- ing a closed-loop framework for the development of high- performance molten catalysts. 4.2. Generative Model-Guided Design. Considering some existing data sets of available molten media for CH4 pyrolysis, a realistic expectation is to directly sample new compositions with the desired properties. The generative model offered the potential to explore the unknown combination space. This model learns the intrinsic features of existing data set, acquires knowledge related to element combination, and then samples and generates new components based on the learned patterns. Currently, several techniques i.e., generative adversa- rial network GAN,38 transformers,39 variational autoen- coders,40

text: offered the potential to explore the unknown combination space. This model learns the intrinsic features of existing data set, acquires knowledge related to element combination, and then samples and generates new components based on the learned patterns. Currently, several techniques i.e., generative adversa- rial network GAN,38 transformers,39 variational autoen- coders,40 and diffusion models41 have been developed to construct generative models. These generative models have been used to instruct multiple materials design research, such as spintronic materials,42 2D materials,43 and high-entropy alloys.44 In general, the generative models require a material encoding method that is compliant with symmetry operations, in which the lattice vectors, elemental species, atomic numbers, and atomic site coordinates are mainly implemented.45,46 However, molten systems present a unique challenge due to their lack of crystalline symmetry, necessitating specialized approaches focused primarily on elemental species generation. Although the reduced complexity of modeling amorphous molten systems is compared to crystalline materials, ensuring the generated materials from a learned distribution fall inside the desired criteria becomes difficult. Thus, the generative framework must be enhanced with additional constraints and fine-tuning mechanisms, specifically tailored to molten catalyst systems. These refinements should incorporate both theoretical understanding of catalytic mech- anisms and experimental insights into structureproperty relationships, ultimately enabling more precise control over the generated catalyst compositions. To illustrate the generative model procedure for generating molten media, a GAN-based simplified flow diagram is illustrated in Figure 2C, in which the generator takes media compositions from the existing experimental and computational data sets as the input and learns their intrinsic features to generate new compositions. The next step then functions as a discriminator for obtaining reasonable compositions. A crucial intermediate step in this process involves systematic element screening through an iterative enumeration method Figure 2D. This process employs multiple physical and chemical criteria to refine the candidate pool. The selection criteria may include fundamental properties such as suitable melting point and boiling point to ensure operational stability, mutual solubility between elements to maintain homogeneous mixing, and strategic difference in electronegativity to promote effective charge transfer between atoms. These filters can reduce the component space of possible molten catalysts and support a high-efficiency learning in the following discriminator step. The primary technical challenge lies in developing a generative model with strong generalization abilities to effectively expedite the discovery of a new molten catalyst system for CH4 pyrolysis. These models must demonstrate sufficient predictive power to justify their computational overheads, ensuring that the efficiency gains from model predictions outweigh the training costs. A well-trained model should capture the training data sets important latent variables and external conditions, serving as a powerful tool for data augmentation. But the current training set cant perform reaction conditions such as temperature and pressure, hindering the generation of ideal model under reaction conditions. To address these limitations, we suggest advancing the field through external-variate training technology and adaptive strategies. By the integration of active learning and transfer learning, the framework can continuously enhance and improve its predictive capabilities. We expect the new research paradigm

text: hindering the generation of ideal model under reaction conditions. To address these limitations, we suggest advancing the field through external-variate training technology and adaptive strategies. By the integration of active learning and transfer learning, the framework can continuously enhance and improve its predictive capabilities. We expect the new research paradigm that involves training the generative model of a molten catalyst for CH4 pyrolysis and using the constructed model to generate candidates for further DFT validation. 4.3. Active Learning-Guided Design. The development of accurate composition-property predictions for CH4 pyrolysis in molten media faces significant challenges due to the limited available data and inherent biases in feature selection. Conven- tional ML approaches often struggle with these constraints, necessitating more sophisticated methodological frameworks. By synthesizing new data points and refining feature selection methods, we can enhance predictive accuracy and reliability. Advanced methodologies, such as active learning, can extract complex patterns from limited data sets, improving our understanding of catalytic methane properties in pyrolysis processes. Active learning has recently emerged as an alternative choice for materials discovery, demonstrating remarkable success across diverse applications.4749 This methodology excels at extracting complex patterns from limited data sets, offering crucial insights into catalytic behavior during pyrolysis processes. For instance, Raabe et al. constructed an active learning strategy to accelerate the design of high-entropy Invar alloys in a practically infinite compositional space based on very sparse data, characterizing 17 new alloys out of millions of possible compositions.48 Similarly, Tran and Ulissi conducted an active learning-guided theoretically automated screening in the huge search space, and proposed 54 alloys and 102 alloys as potential electrocatalysts of CO2 reduction and H2 evolution, respectively.49 These advancements in active learning highlight its potential for revolutionizing material discovery. By employ- ing such an active learning strategy, researchers could efficiently explore vast compositional spaces, identifying promising candidates with minimal prior data in catalytic CH4 pyrolysis. Active learning, constituting a subfield of ML, employs iterative sampling of the design space to enhance model predictions. This approach addresses the inherent limitations of ACS Catalysis pubs.acs.orgacscatalysis Perspective https:doi.org10.1021acscatal.5c02415 ACS Catal. 2025, 15, 1100311012 11007 initial models that inadequately characterize the entire material space while exhibiting significant potential for efficiently navigating vast and complex material systems to discover innovative candidates. A representative active learning frame- work typically integrates Bayesian optimization with surrogate modeling, wherein the model is initially trained on sparse experimental data sets. The surrogate model undergoes iterative refinement through cyclic integration of DFT calculations, thermodynamic simulations, and targeted experimental vali- dation. This creates a dynamic, closed-loop optimization process that progressively improves both prediction accuracy and the models ability to generalize to unexplored materials. Crucially, the methodology achieves an optimal balance between the exploration of uncharted regions and the exploitation of known high-performance areas within the search space. This dual-focused approach proves to be particularly valuable when addressing the critical challenge of reconciling limited experimental data with high-dimensional search domains. These distinctive advantages position active learning as a particularly promising paradigm for accelerating the discovery of molten catalysts for

text: exploitation of known high-performance areas within the search space. This dual-focused approach proves to be particularly valuable when addressing the critical challenge of reconciling limited experimental data with high-dimensional search domains. These distinctive advantages position active learning as a particularly promising paradigm for accelerating the discovery of molten catalysts for CH4 pyrolysis in ultralarge parameter spaces. As illustrated in Figure 3, adopting an active learning approach, a closed-loop strategy was given for CH4 pyrolysis molten catalyst design, which includes four interconnected steps: database construction, targeted composition generation, physics-informed screening, and experimental verification. The first step involved collecting all data of molten catalysts verified by experiment, performing a statistical data analysis on these data, and removing a portion of them corresponding to the inefficient composition, in order to obtain a preliminary database. This initial database incorporates detailed feature vectors containing both elemental properties i.e., position in the periodic table, electronegativity, valence electron concen- trations, melting and liquids temperatures, heat capacity, atomic radii and volumes, thermal conductivity and diffusivity, heat of fusion and experimental performance metrics i.e., conversion efficiency, activation energy, along with atomic molten information. The second step involves using generative modeling to explore the unknown composition design space by feature engineering of the existing database. It contains two key constituents, encoder and decoder, in which the encoder learns features from the database as the input and the decoder then functions for producing reasonable media compositions given the learned latent representations. This enables the targeted generation of promising new catalyst compositions. Following generation, a two-stage ensemble regression model further investigated the activity of the generated compositions. The initial stage concerns composition-based regression models aiming at fast and large-scale composition inference, while the second stage conducts physics-based quantitiesmetrics vali- dation such as H formation energy, solute metal diffusivity, surface exposure of active metals, surface tension, and so on through AIMDDFT calculations, ensuring theoretical sound- ness of predictions. In the last step, the most promising compositions are selected by a ranking-based policy. The top- ranked candidates underwent thorough experimental testing. Note that, at high temperatures, gas-phase decomposition of CH4 may also become dominant; thus, we suggest a dual-track experimental workflow to isolate molten media-specific catalytic effects from background CH4 gas-phase pyrolysis: i conduct- ing identical pyrolysis experiments in inert reactors without molten media and systematically mapping temperature-depend- ent methane conversion rates under identical flowpressure conditions; ii performing parallel experiments with molten media under identical conditions and identifying the true catalytic data by subtracting the thermal background. The obtained data and results feed back into the database, continuously enriching the database for subsequent iterations. As the iteration repeats and the experimental database continues Figure 3. Schematic summary of a closed-loop active learning strategy for the molten catalysts design applied in the CH4 pyrolysis. It is based on an active learning framework, which combines database, ML models, AIMD thermodynamic simulations, DFT calculations, and experimental feedback. This iterative process not only refines the compositions of molten catalysts but also enhances our understanding of their properties and behaviors. The power of this approach lies in its integration of advanced ML techniques with rigorous computational modeling and experimental validation. This synergistic combination enables the efficient exploration of vast compositional spaces while maintaining scientific rigor. The resulting active learning paradigm accelerates catalyst discovery while advancing our fundamental understanding of sustainable energy conversion processes. 5. TOWARD THE INDUSTRIALIZATION OF DATA-DRIVEN CH4 PYROLYSIS The current data-driven approach for molten catalysts in CH4 pyrolysis research primarily stems from the potential to accelerate the discovery and development of multicomponent molten alloy catalysts. This vision can be operationalized through AI-enabled tools and algorithms designed to assist researchers in identifying optimized catalyst compositions and stoichiometric ratios worthy of experimental validation. Under this way, the integrated application of descriptor-based analysis, generative model recognition, and active learning method- ologies aims to recommend high-performance component combinations that transcend chemical intuition or intelligently explore the vast compositional space within alloy systems to guide experimental investigations. It must be emphasized that the prescriptive analytics achieved through the synergy of catalytic data, machine intelligence, and expert knowledge constitute an iterative process that may not yield immediate results. In this data-driven methodology, a forward model is trained on an initial small data set, which feeds to an optimizer to generate experimental recommendations. A set of these recommendations are experimentally validated, and the data generated are used to expand the data set for model retraining, in order to enhance the predictive accuracy of target variables and enable more confident proposals for subsequent experimental iterations. By these steps and more iterations, we can be confident that the catalyst to meet the needs of methane pyrolysis industrialization will be obtained. It should be believed that the data-driven methodology will revolutionize the catalysts research paradigm of CH4 pyrolysis, accelerating the industri- alization of CH4 pyrolysis Figure 4A. Looking ahead, we anticipate that data-driven tools will be deeply integrated into the entire workflow of CH4 pyrolysis catalysis research, accelerating experimental design, empower- ing data analytics, and fostering the emergence of multi- component molten catalysts. This integration will drive data- informed rational design of molten catalysts and provide innovative solutions to address the grand scientific challenge of developing highly efficient, low-consumption catalysts tailored for the industrialization of CH4 pyrolysis. 6. SUMMARY AND OUTLOOK This perspective offers an in-depth exploration of the potential of a data-driven strategy in the development of high-perform- ance molten catalysts for CH4 pyrolysis, highlighting their pivotal role in accelerating the industrialization of this process. SUMMARY AND OUTLOOK This perspective offers an in-depth exploration of the potential of a data-driven strategy in the development of high-perform- ance molten catalysts for CH4 pyrolysis, highlighting their pivotal role in accelerating the industrialization of this process. The data-driven strategies are becoming increasingly important in the pursuit of efficient molten catalysts, offering a promising path in CH4 pyrolysis research. By leveraging data sets and ML techniques, researchers can use effective descriptors derived from the composition-property relationship, extrapolative sampling, and generating candidate materials in the latent space based on generative models. Additionally, active learning can be used to expand training sets, enabling exploration of the vast combinatorial space of potential elements and combina- tions. This approach significantly reduces both time and costs associated with traditional experimental or computational methods. This strategy enables a more systematic identification of optimal catalyst compositions that deliver high activity and catalytic efficiency for CH4 pyrolysis while minimizing energy inputs. The essence of this perspective centers on the utilization of data-driven techniques within the design of molten alloy Figure 4. The question of whether these data-driven emerging methodologies, in conjunction with current market demands, will revolutionize the landscape of CH4 pyrolysis research remains an intriguing topic awaiting further exploration. Some outlooks are given as follows: i. Developing ML-Based Molten Catalyst ModelingThis model involves constructing a high-quality training data set that includes molten media data related to possible element-component-pyrolysis methane activity. This task necessitates integrating diverse sources of data, encom- passing experimental data including reaction conditions i.e., high-temperature and high-pressure and reactor parameters, computational data, theoretical models, and domain expertise, to train models capable of capturing the intricate relationships between composition and catalytic property of molten media. The data must be collected and managed efficiently for the use in model training. The language models LLMs such as GPT,55 DeepSeek56 hold promise for playing a pivotal role in accelerating data acquisition. Their advanced natural language processing and text mining capabilities facilitate efficient navigation and extraction of relevant information from scientific literature. To ensure the reliability of data from LLMs, we can implement consensus-based verification workflows where multiple LLMs independently process the same data sources. Discrepancies between outputs will automatically trigger human expert review, creating a safety net for critical parameters. Additionally, the development of an experimental database, e.g., the recently emerging Digital Catalysis Platform DigCat,57 www.digcat.org, is expected to play an essential role in providing high-volume and

Additionally, the development of an experimental database, e.g., the recently emerging Digital Catalysis Platform DigCat,57 www.digcat.org, is expected to play an essential role in providing high-volume and high-quality data to aid in the ML-based modeling for the reactions. ii. Developing Self-Driven Platform for Data Acquisition In addition to data availability concerns, more exper- imental validation of ML tasks would help establish the utility of these approaches in a molten environment as well as provide insight into the performance of the model. This reality can be accelerated through the utility of some schemes i.e., widespread experimental researcher partic- ipation in scientific data commons initiatives, developing auto high-throughput experiments, standardization of the characterization of relevant properties data. Through an automation of experimental workflows and autonomous data-driven planning agents system, a self-data-driven platform can be enabled for catalyst design and CH4 pyrolysis testing Figure 4B, in which the extending accumulation of experimental data would facilitate the data learning optimization and comprehensively enhance the overall efficiency of data-driven CH4 pyrolysis catalysis research, significantly accelerating research progress. iii. Advancing Multiscale and ML Force Field Approaches for Molten SimulationsAnother important challenge is related to the realistic molten simulation of CH4 pyrolysis. Although the first-principles calculation method men- tioned above can roughly simulate the microscopic process of CH4 pyrolysis, the nonintrinsic risk of its obtained data needs to update current approaches and develop new route to push the boundaries of simulating down further to real reaction. At high temperatures, molecule or atom vibrational modes of CH4 pyrolysis often become anharmonic. To consider such effects in the accounted DFT simulation, a promising approach is to develop temperature-dependent effective potential to systematically capture anharmonic contributions by iteratively refining interatomic force constants from AIMD trajectories. Along this direction, further efforts are required to develop multiscale calculation methods for simulating the realistic molten catalysis data. In particular, the development and application of an ML force field MLFF, also called the ML potential, MLP would be essential in providing a long time scale and large atomistic scale simulations at a near-DFT level. The development of general-purpose interatomic potentials is one of the most promising applications of ML to research. However, though there are some typical works that report the precise development of carboncatalyst interactions,58 the applications of MLFF for molten catalysis CH4 pyrolysis remain rare. We anticipate that such MLFF will be used to simulate the realistic CH4 pyrolysis systems and, eventually, to accelerate the development of multicomponent molten catalysts design technologies. iv. Disciplinary CooperationThe research of molten catalysts CH4 pyrolysis encompasses interdisciplinary knowledge spanning physics, chemistry, and materials science, while the design of molten catalysts systems entails data-driven multiobjective performance optimiza- tion, necessitating the integration of interdisciplinary strategies and methodologies. Thus, the development of data-driven tools necessitates collaborative efforts among researchers from diverse disciplines such as physics, chemistry, and computer science. The disciplinary cooperation will foster data-informed decision-making

The disciplinary cooperation will foster data-informed decision-making in rational catalyst design and assist in addressing some of the grand challenges in CH4 pyrolysis catalysis research. In the future, the AI revolution will further spark data-driven catalyst design paradigms; there are vast opportunities to further refine data-driven technology for addressing these challenges of multicomponent molten catalysts design. The VoR will be published online in Early View as soon as possible and may be different to this Accepted Article as a result of editing. Readers should obtain the VoR from the journal website shown below when it is published to ensure accuracy of information. The authors are responsible for the content of this Accepted Article. To be cited as: Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2025, e202509423 Link to VoR: https:doi.org10.1002anie.202509423 1 Operando Spectroscopic Insights into CO2 Reduction at ElectrodePolyelectrolyte Interfaces Jieyu Wang, Bing Huang, Li Xiao, Gongwei Wang, Lin Zhuang College of Chemistry and Molecular Sciences, Hubei Key Lab of Electrochemical Power Sources, Wuhan University, Wuhan 430072, China Corresponding e-mails: gwwangwhu.edu.cn, lzhuangwhu.edu.cn 10.1002anie.202509423 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved. 15213773, ja, Downloaded from https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comdoi10.1002anie.202509423 by Tsinghua University Library, Wiley Online Library on 15062025. See the Terms and Conditions https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comterms-and-conditions on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License 2 Abstract The electrodepolyelectrolyte interface is a notable feature in modern electrochemical technologies that utilize membrane electrode assembly MEA configurations. However, its interfacial structure and catalytic behavior remain poorly understood. Here we developed an integrated operando Raman spectroscopy and mass spectrometry MS method, to directly investigate the CO2 reduction mechanism at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface within a practical MEA electrolyzer operating at high current densities. Combined with isotope labeling experiments and ab initio molecular dynamics AIMD simulations, we provide, for the first time, the direct spectroscopic evidence of CCO, a crucial intermediate for C2 product formation, which has been frequently hypothesized but rarely detected in previous studies. By contrast, the linearly adsorbed COL intermediate, typically observed in conventional liquid electrolytes, was absent. These distinct behaviors arise from the unique structure of the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface, which shifts the rate-determining step from the usual C-C coupling to the CCO hydrogenation in the conversion of CO2 to C2 products. This study not only deepens our understanding of electrodepolyelectrolyte interfacial characteristics, but also offers valuable insights for advancing the performance of CO2 MEA electrolyzers. Keywords: Electrodepolyelectrolyte interface, CO2 reduction, Operando mechanism, Raman spectroscopy, Mass spectrometry 10.1002anie.202509423 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. text: on 15062025. See the Terms and Conditions https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comterms-and-conditions on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License 3 Introduction Electrochemical technologies, such as fuel cells,1,2 water splitting,3,4 and CO2 electrolysis,5,6 offer significant promise for addressing the urgent challenges of large-scale renewable energy storage and carbon emission reduction. At the heart of these technologies is the electrodeelectrolyte interface, where electrochemical reactions occur.7 A thorough exploration of the interfacial structure and its impact on electrochemical processes is thus essential.8 This understanding is crucial for the rational design of key materials, such as efficient electrode catalysts and electrolytes, and for advancing the performance of electrochemical technologies.9 Early electrochemical studies primarily relied on electrical signals for both excitation and detection, through applying varying potentialsvoltages or currents and observing the corresponding responses to probe the electrodeelectrolyte interface.10 Since the 1970s, the introduction of various spectroscopic techniques, such as electrochemical in-situ infrared and Raman spectroscopy, has enabled the acquisition of molecular- and atomic-scale information at the electrodeelectrolyte interface during electrochemical testing,1113 significantly deepening our understanding of electrochemical interfaces and reaction mechanisms. Nevertheless, it is important to note that most electrochemical in-situ spectroscopies developed to date focus on studying the electrodeliquid electrolyte interface. In contrast, modern electrochemical technologies increasingly employ polymer electrolytes i.e., polyelectrolytes instead of liquid electrolytes e.g., HClO4, KOH solution.14 This shift enables the construction of zero-gap membrane electrode assembly MEA devices, which help reduce internal resistance and thus improve electrochemical energy conversion efficiency.15 The inherent differences between polyelectrolytes and liquid electrolytessuch as variations in ionic species organic versus inorganic and ionic mobility bound versus freeinevitably result in significant differences in the microstructure and catalytic behavior at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface compared to the conventional electrodeliquid electrolyte interface. For instance, our recent studies have shown that CO2 reduction can occur at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface with immobilized organic cations, a reaction that is challenging to achieve in liquid electrolytes containing free organic cations.16,17 Additionally, to facilitate spectroscopic detection, these widely used in-situ spectroscopies 10.1002anie.202509423 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved. 15213773, ja, Downloaded from https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comdoi10.1002anie.202509423 by Tsinghua University Library, Wiley Online Library on 15062025. See the Terms and Conditions https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comterms-and-conditions on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License 4 often require specially designed electrochemical cells.18 This often leads to a mismatch in the testing conditions between in-situ spectroscopic characterization and electrochemical performance evaluation, making it unreliable to correlate spectroscopic evidence with actual electrochemical behavior in mechanistic studies.19 This issue is especially pronounced in practical polyelectrolyte-based MEA devices, where operating conditionssuch as current density, temperature, pressure, and humiditydiffer significantly from those of conventional liquid electrolyte systems. These variations in operating conditions can even lead to markedly different catalytic behaviors.20,21 For instance, a previous study demonstrated that while the nonprecious Mn-Co catalyst shows inferior oxygen reduction reaction ORR performance compared to PtC in aqueous KOH electrolyte, this trend reverses in alkaline

metadata.source: /Users/zemao/ChemQA/data/raw_papers/Wang 等 - 2025 - Operando spectroscopic insights into CO2 reduction at electrodepolyelectrolyte interfaces.pdf
metadata.title: Wang 等 - 2025 - Operando spectroscopic insights into CO2 reduction at electrodepolyelectrolyte interfaces.pdf

text: those of conventional liquid electrolyte systems. These variations in operating conditions can even lead to markedly different catalytic behaviors.20,21 For instance, a previous study demonstrated that while the nonprecious Mn-Co catalyst shows inferior oxygen reduction reaction ORR performance compared to PtC in aqueous KOH electrolyte, this trend reverses in alkaline polyelectrolyte fuel cells APEFCs with gas diffusion electrodes GDEs operating at 60C, due to differences in water content at the catalytic interfaces.22 Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop operando spectroscopic methods that are compatible with the operating conditions of MEA devices, to more accurately reveal the structural characteristics and catalytic behavior of the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface under practical working conditions. Indeed, some progress has been made in probing the interfaces within practical MEA-type fuel cells and water electrolyzers, through the combined use of techniques such as X-ray absorption spectroscopy XAS,23 near-ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy NAP-XPS,24,25 infrared spectroscopy,26,27 and Raman spectroscopy.28,29 However, operando studies focusing on CO2 MEA electrolyzers, particularly those operating in a polyelectrolytepure water medium without any liquid electrolytes, remain rather limited. In this study, we develop an integrated operando Raman spectroscopy and mass spectrometry MS method using the MEA configuration, to investigate CO2 reduction at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface. This approach allows for the simultaneous detection of interfacially adsorbed intermediates and volatile products such as CO, CH4, C2H4, C2H5OH, and others under industrial-scale current densities, providing molecular insights into the CO2 reduction mechanism in practical MEA electrolyzers. Notably, unlike the linearly adsorbed COL intermediate commonly observed in Cu-catalyzed CO2 reduction in KOH or KHCO3 aqueous electrolytes,30 we are surprised to find that COL is absent at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface. Instead, through the combination of isotope labeling and ab 10.1002anie.202509423 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved. 15213773, ja, Downloaded from https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comdoi10.1002anie.202509423 by Tsinghua University Library, Wiley Online Library on 15062025. See the Terms and Conditions https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comterms-and-conditions on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License 5 initio molecular dynamics AIMD simulations, we successfully detected and identified the presence of CCO, a crucial intermediate for C2 product formation, which has been frequently hypothesized but rarely detected in previous studies with conventional liquid electrolytes.31 Furthermore, we reveal that the presence of CCO intermediate is attributed to the unique electrodepolyelectrolyte interfacial structure, which facilitates the Eley-Rideal type hydrogenation pathways directly using interfacial hydrogen bonding water as the proton source, while hinders the Langmuir-Hinshelwood type hydrogenation pathway involving surface- adsorbed water H2O. Results and discussion To compare the CO2 reduction behavior at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface with that at the conventional electrodeliquid electrolyte interface, we developed two types of spectroelectrochemical cells. Figure 1a is the setup for investigating the electrodeliquid electrolyte interface photograph in Figure S1, which is similar to designs reported in previous studies.32,33 The working electrode, a Cu GDE, was prepared by spray-coating Cu nanocatalysts onto a hydrophobic carbon paper substrate Figure S2. The counter and reference electrodes were immersed in the electrolyte

metadata.title: Wang 等 - 2025 - Operando spectroscopic insights into CO2 reduction at electrodepolyelectrolyte interfaces.pdf

text: setup for investigating the electrodeliquid electrolyte interface photograph in Figure S1, which is similar to designs reported in previous studies.32,33 The working electrode, a Cu GDE, was prepared by spray-coating Cu nanocatalysts onto a hydrophobic carbon paper substrate Figure S2. The counter and reference electrodes were immersed in the electrolyte solution. The excitation laser passes through a quartz window and a thin layer of the electrolyte solution, allowing the Raman scattering signals at the electrodeliquid electrolyte interface to be collected Figure S3a. Although this GDE- based setup significantly enhances CO2 mass transport and allows for electrochemical testing at current densities exceeding 100 mAcm2, the high internal resistance between the working and counter electrode, due to their large separation distance, makes operation at higher current densities challenging. Additionally, at higher current densities 300 mAcm2, vide infra, a large number of gas bubbles will form on the electrode surface, which can severely interfere with Raman signal collection. Figure 1b and Figure S4 illustrate the operando Raman-MS cell designed in this study, based on the zero-gap MEA configuration. In this setup, the cathode was fabricated using the catalyst-coated membrane CCM process, in which the Cu nanocatalyst and QAPEEK ionomer molecular structure shown in Figure 1b were ultrasonically mixed and spray-coated onto an alkaline polyelectrolyte membrane QAPPT, Figure S5 to form the cathode Details in 10.1002anie.202509423 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved. 15213773, ja, Downloaded from https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comdoi10.1002anie.202509423 by Tsinghua University Library, Wiley Online Library on 15062025. See the Terms and Conditions https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comterms-and-conditions on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License 6 Supporting Information. An IrO2-coated Ti anode was tightly pressed against the opposite side of the QAPPT membrane. A hydrophobic carbon paper with pre-drilled small holes 100 μm, Figure S6 was used as the gas diffusion layer, and a quartz optical window was installed at the cathode flow field. This design allows the excitation laser with a spot diameter of approximately 1 μm to pass through the flow field and small holes, reaching the cathode catalyst layer for Raman signal collection Figure S3b. Notably, the cathodic incidence detection can effectively eliminate the interference of fluorescence signals from alkaline polyelectrolyte membranes e.g., QAPPT in this study, which typically contain a large number of conjugated benzene-ring structures. In addition to the Raman characterization, a capillary sampling port was introduced at the cathode outlet for MS analysis. This setup enables the collection of reaction intermediate information at the cathode interface by Raman and the simultaneous analysis of corresponding volatile products by MS for the CO2 MEA electrolyzer under its normal operating conditions. The working electrode was a Cu GDE, and the electrolyte was a 1 M KHCO3 aqueous solution. b Operando Raman-MS setup for probing the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface in MEA electrolyzer. The

The cathode was a CuQAPEEK ionomer GDE, and the anode was a porous IrO2-coated Ti electrode, with pure water as the anolyte. The right illustration shows the chemical structures of the QAPEEK ionomer and the QAPPT membrane. Both setups were operated at room temperature and ambient pressure in this study. Figure 2a presents the in-situ Raman spectra for CO2 reduction at the Cu GDE1 M KHCO3 interface across varying current densities from 50 to 300 mAcm2, obtained using the setup 10.1002anie.202509423 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. Testing at higher current densities was limited due to interference from gas bubbles, as mentioned above. The obtained spectra are consistent with those reported in the literature,34,35 displaying some characteristic vibrational bands. The bands at around 280 cm1, 360 cm1, and 2060 cm1 correspond to the frustrated rotation, Cu-CO stretching, and C-O stretching of linearly adsorbed COL, respectively,3638 which is generally considered a key intermediate for CO2 deep reduction into CH4 as well as C2 products e.g., C2H4, C2H5OH.39 The band at 526 cm1 is attributed to surface Cu-OH species.40,41 The bands at 1015 cm1 and 1070 cm1 correspond to the HCO3 and CO32, respectively,42,43 with their relative intensity reflecting the local pH near the electrode surface. The band at 1386 cm1 can be assigned to the C-O vibration of COOH intermediate.44,45 Additionally, the bands at 1600 cm1 and 3000- 3600 cm1 are associated with the bending δH2O and stretching νO-H vibration of interfacial water, respectively.46,47 Figure 2b shows the operando Raman spectra for CO2 reduction at the CuQAPEEK i.e., electrodepolyelectrolyte interface across current densities ranging from 50 to 700 mAcm2, obtained using the MEA setup illustrated in Figure 1b. The peaks marked with asterisks can be assigned to the characteristic signals of QAPEEK ionomer, by referring to its Raman spectrum in Figure S7. The spectra collected differ notably from those in the liquid electrolyte Figure 2a. Figure 2c-2f highlight the regions with significant spectral differences in Raman spectra acquired at 100 mAcm2. Notably, the characteristic bands of COL at 280 cm1, 360 cm1, and 2060 cm1 were not detected at the CuQAPEEK interface Figure 2c, 2e. Instead, a band at 1830 cm1, corresponding to bridge-absorbed COB,48,49 and an unidentified band near 1945 cm1 Figure 2b, 2erarely observed for CO2 reduction on Cu electrodes in conventional liquid electrolyteswere detected. The unidentified band at 1945 cm1 shifted to lower Raman shift positions as

Instead, a band at 1830 cm1, corresponding to bridge-absorbed COB,48,49 and an unidentified band near 1945 cm1 Figure 2b, 2erarely observed for CO2 reduction on Cu electrodes in conventional liquid electrolyteswere detected. The unidentified band at 1945 cm1 shifted to lower Raman shift positions as the current density increased i.e., with increasing polarization potential, Figure 2b red dashed line, demonstrating a Stark effect and suggesting that it is associated with an adsorbed species on the electrode surface. Additionally, a broad band appeared at approximately 460 cm1 Figure 2c, whose intensity seems to correlate with changes in the 17502000 cm1 region COB and a new, yet-to-be-identified species as the current density increased Figure 2b. This band at 460 cm1 is distinct from both Cu-COL and Cu-OH species and likely consists of two different vibrations or species, as indicated by its asymmetric peak 10.1002anie.202509423 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. Moreover, both the two bands at 460 cm1 and 17502000 cm1 disappeared in Ar atmosphere Figure S8, suggesting that they are associated with CO2 reduction intermediates rather than any impurities or decomposition products of the ionomer. Comparison of the Raman spectra for CO2 reduction at the electrodeliquid electrolyte and electrodepolyelectrolyte interface. a In-situ Raman spectra for CO2 reduction at the Cu1 M KHCO3 liquid electrolyte interface under varying current densities. b Operando Raman spectra for CO2 reduction at the CuQAPEEK interface under varying current densities. c-f Comparison of Raman spectra in different regions at the electrodeliquid electrolyte interface Cu1 M KHCO3, lower blue curves and electrodepolyelectrolyte interface CuQAPEEK, upper green curves at 100 mAcm2. In addition, although the bands of HCO3 and CO32 were still present at the CuQAPEEK interface, their relative intensity was reversed compared to those in the liquid electrolyte Figure 2d. The local pH values for the two systems under different current densities were calculated using the CO32HCO3 integral area ratio and the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation Figure S9, Note 1,50 revealing a higher pH at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface. This phenomenon likely stems from the unique properties of polyelectrolytes compared to liquid electrolytes. 10.1002anie.202509423 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. text: Commons License 9 Specifically, the movement of anions e.g., OH is somewhat constrained by the alkaline polyelectrolyte-bounded cations, hindering the rapid transfer of OHgenerated from CO2 reduction and water dissociationaway from the electrode surface. Another significant observation is the complete disappearance of the νO-H band at the CuQAPEEK interface Figure 2b, 2f. This can be attributed to two factors: first, the reduced water content at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface due to the presence of the hydrophobic backbone of QAPEEK; and second, the preservation of a strong hydrogen bonding network within the water at this interface, due to the inability of the polyelectrolyte-tethered organic cations to form a compact double layer under negative potentials, as found in our previous study.17 There is a broad consensus that Raman spectroscopy is insensitive to water, but recent research suggests that the disruption of hydrogen bonding network is critical for detecting water vibrations via surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy.51 This explains why the νO-H band can be detected at the electrodeliquid electrolyte interface Cu1 M KHCO3, Figure 2a, whereas it cannot be detected at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface CuQAPEEK, Figure 2b. To identify these specific species and their formation mechanism, as well as examine their relevance to CO2 reduction at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface, various CO2 reduction volatile products, including CO, CH4, C2H4, and C2H5OH, were simultaneously monitored in real-time using the operando MS technique Figure 1b, alongside Raman measurement. The yields of these products generally exhibited an increasing trend with rising current densities Figure 3a. Figure 3b presents the average ion currents of these products at different current densities, while Figure 3c displays the integral areas of the unidentified band at 1945 cm1. Notably, as the current density increased, there was a strong correlation between the generation rate of C2 products C2H4 and C2H5OH and the peak intensity at 1945 cm1. Both showed a synchronized changing profile, which was different from the generation rates of CO and CH4. This suggests that the band at 1945 cm1 likely corresponds to a key intermediate involved in the C2 products formation. Furthermore, the correlation between the generation rates of these volatile products and the COB peak intensity is minimal Figure S10, supporting claims in the literature that COB acts as a surface inactive poisoning species and cannot undergo subsequent reduction.48 10.1002anie.202509423 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. To identify the newly detected species at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface, we conducted isotopic experiments employing 13C- and D-labelling Figure 4a-4c, Figure S11. The 12CO213CO2 exchange resulted in a noticeable redshift of the Raman bands at 1945 cm1, 1834 cm1, 460 cm1, and 353 cm1 Figure 4b, 4c. In contrast, these bands exhibited negligible shifts in the H2OD2O isotope exchange, indicating that the corresponding species contain carbon but no hydrogen. Specifically, the band shift from 1834 cm1 to 1793 cm1 aligns well with the estimated value for COB Supporting Note 2. For the unidentified band at 1945 cm1, which is associated with C2 products formation, a redshift from 1945 cm1 to 1913 cm1 was observed during the 12CO213CO2 exchange. Previous studies have suggested that the vibration bands in the 19002000 cm1 range may correspond to two adjacent adsorbed CO in the co-existence of OH,52 multi-bound CO,53 or CCO.54 However, based on the band shift value noted in the isotope experiments, we can rule out the possibility that this band corresponds to surface-adsorbed CO species Supporting Note 2. On the other hand, CCO is often regarded as an intermediate in the conversion of CO2 to C2 products. Although it has 10.1002anie.202509423 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved. 15213773, ja, Downloaded from https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comdoi10.1002anie.202509423 by Tsinghua University Library, Wiley Online Library on 15062025. See the Terms and Conditions https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comterms-and-conditions on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License 11 been referenced in numerous studies related to CO2 reduction pathways,55,56 it is rarely detected spectroscopically. Our analysis indicates that both the isotope-induced band shifts from 1945 cm1 to 1913 cm1 and from 460 cm1 to 453 cm1 are consistent well with two vibration modes of the CCO Supporting Note 2, and the changes in the integral areas of the two peaks also show a strong correlation as the current density increases Figure 2b, S12. Moreover, the band at 1945 cm1 is also quite closely matched to that of the CCO molecule in the gas phase.57,58 According to our further AIMD calculations Figure S13, the band at 1945 cm1 can be assigned to the asymmetric stretching vibration, while the band at 460 cm1 corresponds to the bending vibration of CCO. The isotope-exchange Raman spectra under various current densities are illustrated in Figure S11. Zoom-in view and peak fitting of the Raman spectra in the regions of 200650 cm1 b and 16502150 cm1 c. d Proposed pathways for CO2 reduction to C2 products: in which H2O represents the hydrogenation step where water acts as a reactant i.e., proton source, and H2O represents the dehydration step where water serves as a product. e Protonation process of CCO through minimal energy path. IS: initial state, TS: transitional state, FS: final state. 10.1002anie.202509423 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved. 15213773, ja, Downloaded from https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comdoi10.1002anie.202509423 by Tsinghua University Library, Wiley Online Library on 15062025. See the Terms and Conditions https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comterms-and-conditions on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License 12 Based on the results mentioned above and the CO2 reduction pathways hypothesized in previous studies,31 the unusual CO2 reduction reaction pathways at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface i.e., CuQAPEEK can be schematically illustrated in Figure 4d. The high local pH at this interface Figure S9, generally believed to facilitate C-C coupling,59,60 leads to the rapid consumption and conversion of active COL. This explains why COL is not observed in operando Raman spectra. Moreover, in the preceding steps for CCO generation, protonation primarily occurs at the highly electronegative oxygen Oδ site rather than at carbon Cδ, for example, as seen in the step of COOH formation. Due to the restricted mobility of polyelectrolyte-tethered organic cations, a rigid hydrogen bonding network is maintained at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface under negative potentials, with a high proportion of strongly hydrogen-bonded water sh-H2O. It is reasonable to infer that the Hδ in sh-H2O can readily interact with the Oδ in these oxygen-containing intermediates, facilitating direct protonation with interfacial water via the Eley-Rideal mechanism.61 However, for the further conversion of CCO, the protonation of α-C to form CHCO is thermodynamically more favorable.62 To elucidate the protonation process of CCO, we conducted density functional theory DFT calculations. The calculations demonstrate that the protonation of α-C atom via the Eley- Rideal mechanismwhere CCO reacts with dangling water molecules above the electrode surfaceis not feasible, restricted by the substantial spatial separation between them. Instead, due to the proximity of the α-C atom to the electrode surface, the only viable pathway for this protonation process follows the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism, where the reaction occurs with surface-adsorbed water H2O, Figure S14. Nonetheless, this pathway still needs to overcome a relatively high transition-state energy barrier of 0.89 eV Figure 4e. In addition, due to the low water content and the constraint imposed by the rigid hydrogen bonding network at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface, the transport and adsorption of water molecules onto the electrode surface are significantly limited. Consequently, the conversion rate of CCO to CHCO is relatively slow, allowing the Raman detection of the CCO intermediate. This also explains the absence of Cu-OH species 526

text: rigid hydrogen bonding network at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface, the transport and adsorption of water molecules onto the electrode surface are significantly limited. Consequently, the conversion rate of CCO to CHCO is relatively slow, allowing the Raman detection of the CCO intermediate. This also explains the absence of Cu-OH species 526 cm1 at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface CuQAPEEK, Figure 2b, 2c, in stark contrast to the electrodeliquid electrolyte interface, as observed in our study Cu1 M KHCO3, Figure 2a, 2c and supported by the general findings 10.1002anie.202509423 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved. 15213773, ja, Downloaded from https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comdoi10.1002anie.202509423 by Tsinghua University Library, Wiley Online Library on 15062025. See the Terms and Conditions https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comterms-and-conditions on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License 13 in the literature.34,63,64 This is because surface OH i.e., Cu-OH is another product from the Langmuir-Hinshelwood hydrogenation reaction with surface-adsorbed water H2O, Figure 4e upper, and thus its formation is similarly hindered. Overall, the distinct electrodepolyelectrolyte interfacial structure shifts the rate-determining step from the usual C- C coupling to the CCO hydrogenation in the conversion of CO2 to C2 products. Conclusions In summary, we have investigated the CO2 reduction mechanism at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface within a practical MEA electrolyzer by combining operando Raman and MS analyses. We successfully captured direct spectroscopic evidence of a key CCO intermediate for C2 products formation, which was further verified through 13C- and D- isotopic substitution experiments as well as AIMD calculations. Notably, the CCO intermediate has been rarely detected in previous studies on CO2 reduction in conventional liquid electrolytes. This observation is due to the distinct structural characteristics of the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface, including a relatively high local pH, lower water content, and a more rigid hydrogen bonding network in the interfacial water. These features favor the Eley-Rideal type hydrogenation and disfavor the Langmuir-Hinshelwood type hydrogenation in CO2 reduction, thus promoting the conversion of surface-active COL to CCO while limiting its further protonation. These findings can not only facilitate the design of efficient electrocatalytic interfaces in practical MEA electrolyzers for CO2 and pure water co-electrolysis, but also highlight the importance of developing operando spectroscopic methods for studying interfacial catalysis under MEA working conditions. Further efforts can be made to introduce a stable and reliable reference electrode into the MEA device, in order to probe changes in interfacial species at different electrode potentials, rather than just observing their variations relative to current densities. Although some studies have attempted this, eliminating the measurement errors resulting from non-uniform currentpotential distributions still poses a challenge.65,66 10.1002anie.202509423 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. Xie Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Bath, Bath BA2 7AY, U.K. Supporting information for this article is given via a link at the end of the document. Abstract: Electrochemical nitrate reduction reaction NO3RR is a promising approach to simultaneously realize pollutant removal and ammonia generation. However, this process involves the transfer of eight electrons and nine protons along with multiple by-products, resulting in a significant challenge for achieving high ammonia yield and selectivity. Herein, we introduced bimetallic covalent organic frameworks catalysts with Cu and Co active sites to achieve a two- step tandem reaction, avoiding excessive nitrite accumulation and enabling efficient NO3RR. For the initial two-electron process, the Cu sites in the bimetallic catalyst exhibit a strong binding affinity with nitrate, promoting their conversion to nitrite. The Co sites enhance the supply and adsorption of active hydrogen and stabilize the subsequent six-electron process, thereby improving the overall catalytic efficiency. Compared to monometallic Cu and Co catalysts, the CuCo bimetallic catalyst demonstrates superior ammonia yield and Faradaic efficiency NH3

text: affinity with nitrate, promoting their conversion to nitrite. The Co sites enhance the supply and adsorption of active hydrogen and stabilize the subsequent six-electron process, thereby improving the overall catalytic efficiency. Compared to monometallic Cu and Co catalysts, the CuCo bimetallic catalyst demonstrates superior ammonia yield and Faradaic efficiency NH3 yield rate 20.8 mgh1cm2, FE 92.16 in 0.3 M nitrate. Such coordinated two-step process advances the efficiency and applicability of NO3RR through optimizing a cascade catalytic reaction, thereby establishing an innovative path for the engineering of NO3RR electrocatalysts. Introduction Ammonia NH3 remains not only an essential precursor in chemical industries,1 but also a next-generation hydrogen storage medium and carbon-neutral energy carrier.2 However, the conventional Haber-Bosch process for industrial NH3 synthesis involves high-energy consumption and generates significant greenhouse gas emissions.3 As an attractive alternative, electrocatalytic nitrate reduction reaction NO3RR for NH3 synthesis has emerged due to its environmental friendliness and mild reaction conditions.4 Alternative to nitrogen and nitric oxide,4c, 5 NO3 benefits from its lower dissociation energy, higher solubility, and rapid reduction kinetics at the liquid-solid interface, thus being regarded as a more promising N source for NH3 production.4a, 6 Additionally, NO3 is a prevalent harmful pollutant in contaminated groundwater, industrial wastewater, and nuclear emissions, which poses risks to both the environment and human health. Consequently, converting nitrate into the value-added product NH3 is environmentally beneficial and economically advantageous. The NO3RR process NO3 8e 9H NH3 3H2O, E0 0.69 V vs. RHE involves a complicated eight-electron and nice-proton transfer process,7 and is prone to generate by- product NO2, NO, NH2OH, N2H4, etc..8 This complex process can be divided into two consecutive reactions: a 2e process from NO3 to NO2 and a 6e process from NO2 to NH3.9 Matching the reactivity of two-step reactions is crucial to achieve high ammonia yield and Faradaic efficiency FE. Early studies have shown that Cu could effectively facilitate the adsorption of NO3 due to the similarity of energy levels between the d orbitals of Cu and the LUMO of nitrate.10 Additionally, the low hydrogen accumulation on the Cu11 surface promotes NO3 reduction while suppressing hydrogen evolution reaction HER.12 However, insufficient H supply may kinetically limit the hydrogenation step in the NO3RR.13 This calls for the rational regulation of water adsorption and enhanced supply of H 14 over the surface of Cu-based catalyst.15 The inherent oxyphilic nature and electronegativity of Co could facilitate H adsorption and supply,16 creating an excellent interfacial environment for the NO3 hydrogenation process while mitigating the formation of by- products. Therefore, coupling the Cu and Co active sites has 10.1002anie.202507956 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright.
